Posts.Content: Originally Posted by LILDOG We all know that positive margins are an adverse finding on the path report after prostate surgery but do they always result in BCR ? Your thoughts and literature if available to back up your answer please ! Let me comment/speculate as a layperson: 1. As Dr. Walsh said in his book, the act of cutting away might kill off cancer cells that were left behind from the positive surgical margins. So BCR is not a given. 2. Most surgeons recommend not start radiation right away when positive margins are < a few mm as they may not cause BCR. 3. I watched a number of Da Vinci prostatectomy videos and noticed differences in surgical techniques of different surgeons. Most surgeons used a combination of Thermal Dissection and Athermal Dissection. In addition, after cutting out the prostate, often, some surgeons "cleaned up" the area around the void and removing "debris" before attaching the urethra to the bladder. If the positive surgical margin is small my speculation is that in using Thermal Dissection, and in cleaning up, the remaining cancer cells might perish or be removed. This is pure speculation on my part and have no medical basis. Best wishes.
Posts.Signature: PCa Dx 2010 at 65. PSA increased from 2.5 in 2000 to 10.7 in 2010. Four biopsies in 6 years. Final biopsy in 2010: 1 of 12 cores 5% cancer, G6 CT, bone scans & MRI all negative Da Vinci 8/10; nerve sparing, catheter out in 7 days; no incontinence, no ED Post Op Pathology pT2N0Mx: organ confined; negative margins; lymph nodes & seminal vesicle not involved but PNI present; cancer extensive within prostate, multifocal G 3+3 and tertiary G 4 Infected lymphocele diagnosed and treated in 2014, 4 yrs after RALP PSA <.1 for the past 6 years.
Posts.Title: When are positive margins insignificant or significant ?

Posts.Content: Yes, Old Bridge, we all do that: Prepare for the worst and hope for the best. .06 is still a very small number and could very well be a measurement error. It is also not unusual you have some tiny amount of benign cells left behind as one of the early posts on this forum discussed some time back. But, it is prudent to keep an eye on it regularly. In the mean time arm yourself with some knowledge of what options you have in case it keeps going up. This is a life time watch for us all. Watching our PSA on a regularly basis is something we all do for the rest of our life.

Posts.Title: 15 month Update - PSA moved from .02 to .06. Concerned...

Posts.Content: robrauy, First of all welcome, second, you should not worry too much, especially about all the diagnostics they are going to perform on you. They are all quite easy to handle and really not too painful (the biopsy) at all. As for the symptoms, they could mean BPH, inflammation or cancer, with cancer the least likely outcome for someone your age. Your doctor should be able to use the DRE (or later using ultrasound during biopsy), to "gauge" the size of your prostate and from that gets an estimate of whether your PSA is "normal". You see, there is a general rule of thumb sometimes used by doctors: Prostate Volume x .066 = approximately the PSA #. There are a lot of variabilities but could give you a sense of whether your PSA is "excessive". Working backward, a PSA of 2.6 means your prostate size is around 4 cm in diameter, which for your age is as your doctor described, "biggish". By the way, a normal size prostate for someone your age is ~2.5cm. Good luck and hope you won't join us.
Posts.Title: Worried - Enlarged Prostate

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mom2two first of all his PSA was undetectable, which is great! Let's hope it stays that way. As for the pathology report: -surgical margins all are negative for malignancy (apical, bladder neck and peripheral) -perineural invasion is present (not so good) -extraprostatic soft tissue-tumor shows established extra-porstatic extension, left posterior aspect (pT3a) (this is where I really start to worry) -bladder neck final margin, query median lobe: prostate tissue that is negative for malignancy histologic type: adenocarcinoma (acinar) -extraprostatic extension : present nonfocal (established extensicve) -margins: margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma perineural invasion: present Primary tumor: pT3a: extraprostatic extension or microscopic invaskon of bladder neck Regional lymp nodes (pN): pN0 (number of regional lymph nodes examined-1) GROSS DESCRIPTION: tumor grossly identified: white irregular, left apex to mid posterior prostate perihpehral; approximate size: 1.1cm x0.8cm x 0.6cm; gross extent of local invasion: confiend to the prostate; no tissue is stored frozen Overall I suppose I feel good, but the ECE worries me as does the fact that from the biopsy there was no perineural invasion present and while waiting all this time for sugery it was now prsesent...I am happy the Gleason went from 8 to 7, though most of it was still a 4 rather than a 3. Welcome back! I highlighted those areas of your concerns. Let me give you my non professional opinion: 1. Don't worry too much about PNI, many studies concluded that those found by post op pathology report that are within the prostate did not increase the chances of recurrence. 2. The finding on EPE, and surgical margins etc. seemed conflicting but that is very good news. Apparently, there were EPE of soft tissues involvements, but his surgeon made a wide cut and took out all of the cancer tissues and that was why all the final inked margins were deemed negative. 3. There were no lymph nodes, seminal vesicles or other areas where cancer invaded. 4. That is why first PSA was undetectable, the surgeon did a good job. Overall a very good pathology report. Let's hope he will continue to have undetectable PSA. If you are not comfortable, get a second opinion from an oncologist about whether it still makes sense to do any adjuvant treatments. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Finally post-op pathology results...input welcome!

Posts.Content: ILance, Your pathology report looks very good but sorry you keep having penis pain. Not knowing any details and not a healthcare professional mean I can only speculate and give you perhaps some suggestions. First is to see if you can get a copy of the surgeon's surgical notes. Many surgeons have written reports after surgery to record what they did. If it is available, you might be able to see what challenges the surgeon faced during surgery and if he encountered any challenges with nerve sparing, etc. especially since you had extraprostatic extension, as pain could be nerve damage related. Second, pains in certain areas after surgery are very common, after all, this is a major surgery, one of the most complex surgeries in medicine. We all had some pains here and there. I had some penis discomforts/aches and swelling scrotum but they went away after a few weeks. 4 months is a little long but probably not out of the normal range of surgical after effects. Third, you did not say what type of aches are you encountering? dull aches, dull discomforts, sharp pains, continuous vs occasional, are they there during certain activities and conditions. Usually, a sharp pain needs attention right away and dull aches can wait. You need to let your doctor know exactly what you are having. The fact that when you drank a lot of beer and the pain went away is a good sign. Perhaps that means it might go away eventually. Give yourself time, drink a lot of fluid to stay hydrated and take things easy for a while. Fourth, in addition to UTI, there is one potential post surgery problem that might also cause some pains in that part of the body: a lymphocele that accumulates fluid and thus presses on some of the nerves/blood vessels. These are speculations by an untrained layperson and most likely completely off base. I am doing it to provide some talking points for you to talk to your doctor. Please consult your doctor. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Penis Pain

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind The study linked below made big waves when it was first published. I think it's just as valid now as it was 1.5 years ago .. http://www.prostatecancertreatmentce...tudyGroup.aspx Fairwind, I have no doubt the results are valid but we have to be a little careful about the conclusions. There are usually some study biases in any study no matter how careful the researchers scoped and framed the study. For example, the results are valid for the surgeons they selected for the study just as valid as the brachy practitioners they selected. Dr. Grimm is one of the best, if not the best brachy physicians in the world and his associates are up there too. If I selected brachy, he would be my first choice. If Dr. Walsh compared his and Johns Hopkins' results to the typical brachy oncologist, they are probably better or at least comparable. I compared the 2011 published Johns Hopkins 30 years survival results to your study and the Johns Hopkins' surgery outcome were better than the one you quoted and their survival results spanned 30 years. My own opinion is that in the hands of a good practitioner, all three treatment methods perform about equally well. Perhaps, brachy should produce the least side effects just because of the physics of the method. I almost went for brachy after I read Andy Grove's account of his research for his prostate cancer but my prostate was too large and I wanted to see the final pathology. Peace and cheers.

Posts.Title: Which Treatment Is Best?

Posts.Content: RTS, Sorry you are joining us but welcome. My suggestion is instead of worrying about your diet, first order is to understand your cancer stage and condition; formulate with your doctor a treatment approach, then worry about what diet to follow. If you already have cancer, it is not likely that diet will cure your cancer. I have not found any scientific evidences to substantiate those claims of cures. That said, I agree with the others, if a diet "do no harm" go ahead if you like to do it but do not risk your life on a diet cure. Just my personal opinion. By the way, your cancer seemed to be early stage (G6) and if the clinical staging indicated it is organ confined, you have a high probability of cure if you choose a good treatment plan. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 AN ITALIAN STUDY?? With all of the high tech medical resources in this country, we're going to fall back on a 4-year-old ITALIAN study? LOL Jim, go easy on me and don't beat up on our Italian friends. I extracted the articles from my own archive. Remember, my surgery was in 2010 and at the time, this research was the most up to date. There were other more dated American studies with similar conclusion. By the way, it was published in a respected journal, peer reviewed and often cited. It would be interesting to find out if there are more recent studies. Peace and best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rooster0330 Thank you everyone here are a few specifics he is 69 years old gleason was a 7 (4+3) his PSA was a 7.1 Initial pathology came back all clear... today the doctor said a couple of cells escaped...so they wanted to do radiation. But the initial report said they got it all.... The doctor did not say if it was in lymphnodes etc...does this mean it spread? All bone/cat scans came back fine. Thanks for any insight! rooster, Your post does not make sense to us. If pathology came back all clear, how did the doctor concluded that "a couple of cells escaped"? Was it because of post Op PSA reading not "zero"? If PSA post Op is not zero, it certainly is not "a couple of cells escaped". You and your Dad need to get hold of the pathology report and read it. Or, it you like post it here and perhaps the others can look at it and comment.

Posts.Title: Which Treatment Is Best?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Yes, it was basically a good report. The only thing I would say is that they'll probably keep a close check on his PSA due to the perineural invasion. It is possible to have a recurrence, when perineural invasion is identified, even with clear margins. This is because with PI, cancer cells group themselves in the space around the tiny nerves inside the prostate near the surface. Highlander, Not trying to argue your point but since I also had PNI, I did some research to find out the implication of PNI at the time of surgery. PNI found in biopsy seemed to have some increase risk of adverse outcome post treatment but PNI found in post op pathology did not have adverse effect on outcome. For example, an Italian study published in 2010 looked at post op PNI found by post op pathology and recurrence. Here is a link to the report: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20516669 And here is the statement they made: The actuarial biochemical progression-free survival rate for all patients was 96.9 and 93.5% at 60 and 84 months, respectively, and the stratification based on the presence or absence of PNI did not allow us to identify different prognostic groups. Here is a summary by The "NEW" Prostate Cancer Infolink: http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...me-of-surgery/ who stated: This study appears to suggest that the prognostic impact of PNI on risk for progressive prostate cancer is actually much lower than has been assumed in the past. So, I believe mom2two should not worry too much about the PNI finding in the pathology report. Peace.

Was it because of post Op PSA reading not "zero"? If PSA post Op is not zero, it certainly is not "a couple of cells escaped". You and your Dad need to get hold of the pathology report and read it. Or, it you like post it here and perhaps the others can look at it and comment.

Posts.Title: radiation after prostate removal

Posts.Content: Fairwind is correct about lymphocele. The risk is real. For the majority of folks, it stays asymptomatic and eventually goes away. For some, it could be life threatening. I had asymptomatic lymphocele for three years but this last July, the abscess was infected and turned sepsis. It almost killed me. I was hospitalized in intensive care with a drain tube in my stomach, 24/7 iv antibiotics and anti-fungal drugs. Home iv antibiotics until infection cleared up. I will need to get periodic CT scan to make sure it does not recur. It is one of the risks most surgeons do not mention. The IR radiologists who did the drainage told me it was more common than a lot of surgeons admitted. That said, if I were to do it over again, I would still want the lymph nodes out - I believe in the points njs said, it is still worth the risks. Best of luck to you
Posts.Signature: PCa Dx 2010 at 65. PSA increased from 2.5 in 2000 to 10.7 in 2010. Four biopsies in 6 years. Final biopsy in 2010: 1 of 12 cores 5% cancer, G6 CT, bone scans & MRI all negative Da Vinci 8/10; nerve sparing, catheter out in 7 days; no incontinence, no ED Post Op Pathology pT2N0Mx: organ confined; negative margins; lymph nodes & seminal vesicle not involved but PNI present; cancer extensive within prostate, multifocal G 3+3 and tertiary G 4 Infected lymphocele diagnosed and treated in 2014, 4 yrs after RALP PSA <.1 for the past 6 years.
Posts.Title: L nodes ?

Posts.Content: I am impressed you actually looked at and reviewed your biopsy slides! You must have some training in cell biology! Finding of PNI is actually quite common and it may or may not be significant depends on who you talk to. I won't worry too much about it at this stage. Good luck on your surgery.

FeatherBoy, On the other hand, I had read studies that said combining ADT and radiation provided the best long term cancer specific survival as compared to radiation therapy alone. Interestingly, combining ADT and surgery did not increase survival. Somehow ADT helped radiation killed off cancer cells. Anyway, best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Cvmiller My question is which is the better of the types of surgery, robotic or open prostectomy. Welcome. To specifically answer your question, go robotic. There is a reason other than hype that 80+% of prostatectomy are now robotic. In my non professional opinion, robotic allows for more precision because the mechanical arms have more degrees of freedom, smaller steadier movements, and color 3D, 10X magnification view which more than compensate for lack of feel of the surgeon's hands. An analogy would be machine soldering vs hand soldering of electronic boards. That said, the surgeon operates the machine so make sure you find the best operator to work on you. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Harding, I don't think you should worry as long as the PSA continues to drop. What is killing your cancer cells is the radiation and for most folks it takes a while for the effects to fully deploy. You are at less than three months and that is early. It is not uncommon to take 1 to 2 years. Also, since you are really not on ADT but is naturally low on T, intuitively I think the effects are not the same as there should be no drastic drop from suddenly starting ADT, as is typical of people on combined radiation and ADT. I think your RO is correct. I think your treatment is successful and you just have to be patient. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by catchmeifucan Isramed quoted $5795.00/month for Zytiga. This is not modest sum for me or my father. It is a shame medications are costing so much. I really feel for you and your Dad. However, lancepeace made a good point. There maybe other medications he can try before resorting to Zytiga, Jevtana, Xtandi... Looks like your father's cancer is under control, so, before spending large sum of money for new drugs, perhaps his doctor should keep trying combinations of existing medications. The top oncologists in the US like Myers, Scholz, Lee et al, are able to use combinations, sometimes inexpensive drugs to keep cancer under control, some for years. Perhaps you should discuss with his doctor about a consult with those oncologists. Hope this buys you time so that in a couple of years generics should be available in India and should be reasonably priced. Good luck.

If it worked as hope, this type of tests should cut down on unnecessary treatment and at the same time provide early detection for those that really need it. In terms of whether our cancer was aggressive and required treatment, we were essentially flying blind. For most of us the gamble that it was indolent even with high probability was not an option we wanted to take, thus most chose treatment and some suffered from unwanted side effects unnecessarily.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mom2two first of all his PSA was undetectable, which is great! Let's hope it stays that way. As for the pathology report: -surgical margins all are negative for malignancy (apical, bladder neck and peripheral) -perineural invasion is present (not so good) -extraprostatic soft tissue-tumor shows established extra-porstatic extension, left posterior aspect (pT3a) (this is where I really start to worry) -bladder neck final margin, query median lobe: prostate tissue that is negative for malignancy histologic type: adenocarcinoma (acinar) -extraprostatic extension : present nonfocal (established extensicve) -margins: margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma perineural invasion: present Primary tumor: pT3a: extraprostatic extension or microscopic invaskon of bladder neck Regional lymp nodes (pN): pN0 (number of regional lymph nodes examined-1) GROSS DESCRIPTION: tumor grossly identified: white irregular, left apex to mid posterior prostate perihpehral; approximate size: 1.1cm x0.8cm x 0.6cm; gross extent of local invasion: confiend to the prostate; no tissue is stored frozen Overall I suppose I feel good, but the ECE worries me as does the fact that from the biopsy there was no perineural invasion present and while waiting all this time for sugery it was now prsesent...I am happy the Gleason went from 8 to 7, though most of it was still a 4 rather than a 3. Welcome back! I highlighted those areas of your concerns. Let me give you my non professional opinion: 1. Don't worry too much about PNI, many studies concluded that those found by post op pathology report that are within the prostate did not increase the chances of recurrence. 2. The finding on EPE, and surgical margins etc. seemed conflicting but that is very good news. Apparently, there were EPE of soft tissues involvements, but his surgeon made a wide cut and took out all of the cancer tissues and that was why all the final inked margins were deemed negative. 3. There were no lymph nodes, seminal vesicles or other areas where cancer invaded. 4. That is why first PSA was undetectable, the surgeon did a good job. Overall a very good pathology report. Let's hope he will continue to have undetectable PSA. If you are not comfortable, get a second opinion from an oncologist about whether it still makes sense to do any adjuvant treatments. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by living with Pca 2009 initial psa at age 54 was 322 since that Luperon, Casodex, Radiation, Provenge, Zytiga, Oxfigo, Xgeva, Xtandi. Right now on Luperon, Xtandi and Xgeva. Psa now 97.7 Sooo looks like he will do the chemo because there is nothing else offered. I want chemo to give more time but not sure if we want sick time. No surgery turmor was to large. Gleason score 9. Spread to lymph nodes in 2009 and to bones in March 2014. We are still talking, thinking and praying on what to do. Carol My heart goes out to you and your husband. If you folks are near the U of Michigan and have not done so, you may want to consult with the oncologists there to see if his cancer can be controlled better: Dr. Maha Hussian or Dr. Ken Pienta came to my mind, both are at the U of Michigan, both published extensively on prostate cancer research and may be able to provide some out of the box thinking. Every prostate cancer case is different so treatment needs to tailor to each individual. A good oncologist is very important in managing the outcome. I believe the endgame is still far far away so don't give up and keep on fighting. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: gjune, I am glad you are looking at getting him to MDA. It is certainly one of the best if not the best cancer center in the US. I hope they can find a combination medications that could work for him. My understanding is with so many different treatment options, it is not clear what combination or sequence will work best for your Dad. For example, one review article (http://www.jnccn.org/content/12/5S/773.short) stated: During the past 4 years, a host of new agents have been approved for the treatment of patients with advanced prostate cancer. As a result, selecting the right agent for the right patient at the right time is a clinical challenge. At the NCCN 19th Annual Conference, Dr. Celestia Higano explored the rationale behind such therapeutic decisions and the supporting clinical trial data. She reviewed the different classes of therapeutic agents, from immunotherapy and hormonal therapies to chemotherapy and radioisotopes, and offered suggestions for the clinical scenarios in which they may be used most successfully. Therefore someone with experience like MDA could be most helpful. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gjune My Father was diagnosed 7 years ago now - Gleason 9, PSA 5, Stage IV - he's had bone mets for 1.5 years and is mCRPC. He has never shown any signs of having cancer and now has extremely aggressive liver mets. Based on his genotesting, the new PD-1 drug could work for my Father, but he needs to get into a clinical trial. It is his only option. Has anyone had the drug or know of any available trials. Thank you in advance! IMHO, you did not provide us enough information to comment on whether joining the PD-1 clinical trial is right for him. The obvious question is has he exhausted all available options including all of the modern drugs, immunotherapy, chemo, etc.? Sometimes, trying different sequencing, different combinations (e.g. combined chemo and hormone) work well for some patients. Getting advice from a medical oncologist specializing in treating prostate cancer is perhaps the next step. He/she can also help sign him up for the PD-1 clinical trial. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Yes, it was basically a good report. The only thing I would say is that they'll probably keep a close check on his PSA due to the perineural invasion. It is possible to have a recurrence, when perineural invasion is identified, even with clear margins. This is because with PI, cancer cells group themselves in the space around the tiny nerves inside the prostate near the surface. Highlander, Not trying to argue your point but since I also had PNI, I did some research to find out the implication of PNI at the time of surgery. PNI found in biopsy seemed to have some increase risk of adverse outcome post treatment but PNI found in post op pathology did not have adverse effect on outcome. For example, an Italian study published in 2010 looked at post op PNI found by post op pathology and recurrence. Here is a link to the report: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20516669 And here is the statement they made: The actuarial biochemical progression-free survival rate for all patients was 96.9 and 93.5% at 60 and 84 months, respectively, and the stratification based on the presence or absence of PNI did not allow us to identify different prognostic groups. Here is a summary by The "NEW" Prostate Cancer Infolink: http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...me-of-surgery/ who stated: This study appears to suggest that the prognostic impact of PNI on risk for progressive prostate cancer is actually much lower than has been assumed in the past. So, I believe mom2two should not worry too much about the PNI finding in the pathology report. Peace.

Posts.Title: Finally post-op pathology results...input welcome!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by LILDOG We all know that positive margins are an adverse finding on the path report after prostate surgery but do they always result in BCR ? Your thoughts and literature if available to back up your answer please ! Let me comment/speculate as a layperson: 1. As Dr. Walsh said in his book, the act of cutting away might kill off cancer cells that were left behind from the positive surgical margins. So BCR is not a given. 2. Most surgeons recommend not start radiation right away when positive margins are < a few mm as they may not cause BCR. 3. I watched a number of Da Vinci prostatectomy videos and noticed differences in surgical techniques of different surgeons. Most surgeons used a combination of Thermal Dissection and Athermal Dissection. In addition, after cutting out the prostate, often, some surgeons "cleaned up" the area around the void and removing "debris" before attaching the urethra to the bladder. If the positive surgical margin is small my speculation is that in using Thermal Dissection, and in cleaning up, the remaining cancer cells might perish or be removed. This is pure speculation on my part and have no medical basis. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: When are positive margins insignificant or significant ?

Posts.Content: ILance, Your pathology report looks very good but sorry you keep having penis pain. Not knowing any details and not a healthcare professional mean I can only speculate and give you perhaps some suggestions. First is to see if you can get a copy of the surgeon's surgical notes. Many surgeons have written reports after surgery to record what they did. If it is available, you might be able to see what challenges the surgeon faced during surgery and if he encountered any challenges with nerve sparing, etc. especially since you had extraprostatic extension, as pain could be nerve damage related. Second, pains in certain areas after surgery are very common, after all, this is a major surgery, one of the most complex surgeries in medicine. We all had some pains here and there. I had some penis discomforts/aches and swelling scrotum but they went away after a few weeks. 4 months is a little long but probably not out of the normal range of surgical after effects. Third, you did not say what type of aches are you encountering? dull aches, dull discomforts, sharp pains, continuous vs occasional, are they there during certain activities and conditions. Usually, a sharp pain needs attention right away and dull aches can wait. You need to let your doctor know exactly what you are having. The fact that when you drank a lot of beer and the pain went away is a good sign. Perhaps that means it might go away eventually. Give yourself time, drink a lot of fluid to stay hydrated and take things easy for a while. Fourth, in addition to UTI, there is one potential post surgery problem that might also cause some pains in that part of the body: a lymphocele that accumulates fluid and thus presses on some of the nerves/blood vessels. These are speculations by an untrained layperson and most likely completely off base. I am doing it to provide some talking points for you to talk to your doctor. Please consult your doctor. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Penis Pain

Posts.Content: robrauy, First of all welcome, second, you should not worry too much, especially about all the diagnostics they are going to perform on you. They are all quite easy to handle and really not too painful (the biopsy) at all. As for the symptoms, they could mean BPH, inflammation or cancer, with cancer the least likely outcome for someone your age. Your doctor should be able to use the DRE (or later using ultrasound during biopsy), to "gauge" the size of your prostate and from that gets an estimate of whether your PSA is "normal". You see, there is a general rule of thumb sometimes used by doctors: Prostate Volume x .066 = approximately the PSA #. There are a lot of variabilities but could give you a sense of whether your PSA is "excessive". Working backward, a PSA of 2.6 means your prostate size is around 4 cm in diameter, which for your age is as your doctor described, "biggish". By the way, a normal size prostate for someone your age is ~2.5cm. Good luck and hope you won't join us.

Posts.Title: Finally post-op pathology results...input welcome!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mom2two first of all his PSA was undetectable, which is great! Let's hope it stays that way. As for the pathology report: -surgical margins all are negative for malignancy (apical, bladder neck and peripheral) -perineural invasion is present (not so good) -extraprostatic soft tissue-tumor shows established extra-porstatic extension, left posterior aspect (pT3a) (this is where I really start to worry) -bladder neck final margin, query median lobe: prostate tissue that is negative for malignancy histologic type: adenocarcinoma (acinar) -extraprostatic extension : present nonfocal (established extensicve) -margins: margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma perineural invasion: present Primary tumor: pT3a: extraprostatic extension or microscopic invaskon of bladder neck Regional lymp nodes (pN): pN0 (number of regional lymph nodes examined-1) GROSS DESCRIPTION: tumor grossly identified: white irregular, left apex to mid posterior prostate perihpehral; approximate size: 1.1cm x0.8cm x 0.6cm; gross extent of local invasion: confiend to the prostate; no tissue is stored frozen Overall I suppose I feel good, but the ECE worries me as does the fact that from the biopsy there was no perineural invasion present and while waiting all this time for sugery it was now prsesent...I am happy the Gleason went from 8 to 7, though most of it was still a 4 rather than a 3. Welcome back! I highlighted those areas of your concerns. Let me give you my non professional opinion: 1. Don't worry too much about PNI, many studies concluded that those found by post op pathology report that are within the prostate did not increase the chances of recurrence. 2. The finding on EPE, and surgical margins etc. seemed conflicting but that is very good news. Apparently, there were EPE of soft tissues involvements, but his surgeon made a wide cut and took out all of the cancer tissues and that was why all the final inked margins were deemed negative. 3. There were no lymph nodes, seminal vesicles or other areas where cancer invaded. 4. That is why first PSA was undetectable, the surgeon did a good job. Overall a very good pathology report. Let's hope he will continue to have undetectable PSA. If you are not comfortable, get a second opinion from an oncologist about whether it still makes sense to do any adjuvant treatments. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by living with Pca 2009 initial psa at age 54 was 322 since that Luperon, Casodex, Radiation, Provenge, Zytiga, Oxfigo, Xgeva, Xtandi. Right now on Luperon, Xtandi and Xgeva. Psa now 97.7 Sooo looks like he will do the chemo because there is nothing else offered. I want chemo to give more time but not sure if we want sick time. No surgery turmor was to large. Gleason score 9. Spread to lymph nodes in 2009 and to bones in March 2014. We are still talking, thinking and praying on what to do. Carol My heart goes out to you and your husband. If you folks are near the U of Michigan and have not done so, you may want to consult with the oncologists there to see if his cancer can be controlled better: Dr. Maha Hussian or Dr. Ken Pienta came to my mind, both are at the U of Michigan, both published extensively on prostate cancer research and may be able to provide some out of the box thinking. Every prostate cancer case is different so treatment needs to tailor to each individual. A good oncologist is very important in managing the outcome. I believe the endgame is still far far away so don't give up and keep on fighting. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Hope Changes

Posts.Content: I think a PSA reduction of over 50% in less than two months is a good response. Good luck.
Posts.Title: ON Casodex (bicalutamide) for 8 weeks now...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gsteve im considering brachy.. is andys research here? Andy Grove, the former Chairman and CEO of Intel had prostate cancer back in the mid 1990s and after extensive research selected brachy as his first line treatment. Fortune published an article in 1996 on his journey and his rationales for selecting brachy. I went through very similar reasonings, read the Fortune article but ended up selecting surgery. Truly, there are more than one way to skin a cat. If you selected brachy, you won't go wrong. Just make sure you pick an experienced radiation oncologist. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Which Treatment Is Best?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 AN ITALIAN STUDY?? With all of the high tech medical resources in this country, we're going to fall back on a 4-year-old ITALIAN study? LOL Jim, go easy on me and don't beat up on our Italian friends. I extracted the articles from my own archive. Remember, my surgery was in 2010 and at the time, this research was the most up to date. There were other more dated American studies with similar conclusion. By the way, it was published in a respected journal, peer reviewed and often cited. It would be interesting to find out if there are more recent studies. Peace and best wishes.

AgeInfo.Phrase: to fall back on a 4 year old ITALIAN study <Z>

Posts.Title: Finally post-op pathology results...input welcome!

Posts.Content: RTS, Sorry you are joining us but welcome. My suggestion is instead of worrying about your diet, first order is to understand your cancer stage and condition; formulate with your doctor a treatment approach, then worry about what diet to follow. If you already have cancer, it is not likely that diet will cure your cancer. I have not found any scientific evidences to substantiate those claims of cures. That said, I agree with the others, if a diet "do no harm" go ahead if you like to do it but do not risk your life on a diet cure. Just my personal opinion. By the way, your cancer seemed to be early stage (G6) and if the clinical staging indicated it is organ confined, you have a high probability of cure if you choose a good treatment plan. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Which Treatment Is Best?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind The study linked below made big waves when it was first published. I think it's just as valid now as it was 1.5 years ago .. http://www.prostatecancertreatmentce...tudyGroup.aspx Fairwind, I have no doubt the results are valid but we have to be a little careful about the conclusions. There are usually some study biases in any study no matter how careful the researchers scoped and framed the study. For example, the results are valid for the surgeons they selected for the study just as valid as the brachy practitioners they selected. Dr. Grimm is one of the best, if not the best brachy physicians in the world and his associates are up there too. If I selected brachy, he would be my first choice. If Dr. Walsh compared his and Johns Hopkins' results to the typical brachy oncologist, they are probably better or at least comparable. I compared the 2011 published Johns Hopkins 30 years survival results to your study and the Johns Hopkins' surgery outcome were better than the one you quoted and their survival results spanned 30 years. My own opinion is that in the hands of a good practitioner, all three treatment methods perform about equally well. Perhaps, brachy should produce the least side effects just because of the physics of the method. I almost went for brachy after I read Andy Grove's account of his research for his prostate cancer but my prostate was too large and I wanted to see the final pathology. Peace and cheers.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Yes, it was basically a good report. The only thing I would say is that they'll probably keep a close check on his PSA due to the perineural invasion. It is possible to have a recurrence, when perineural invasion is identified, even with clear margins. This is because with PI, cancer cells group themselves in the space around the tiny nerves inside the prostate near the surface. Highlander, Not trying to argue your point but since I also had PNI, I did some research to find out the implication of PNI at the time of surgery. PNI found in biopsy seemed to have some increase risk of adverse outcome post treatment but PNI found in post op pathology did not have adverse effect on outcome. For example, an Italian study published in 2010 looked at post op PNI found by post op pathology and recurrence. Here is a link to the report: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20516669 And here is the statement they made: The actuarial biochemical progression-free survival rate for all patients was 96.9 and 93.5% at 60 and 84 months, respectively, and the stratification based on the presence or absence of PNI did not allow us to identify different prognostic groups. Here is a summary by The "NEW" Prostate Cancer Infolink: http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...me-of-surgery/ who stated: This study appears to suggest that the prognostic impact of PNI on risk for progressive prostate cancer is actually much lower than has been assumed in the past. So, I believe mom2two should not worry too much about the PNI finding in the pathology report. Peace.

Posts.Content: lancepeace, Thanks for the post. If it worked as hope, this type of tests should cut down on unnecessary treatment and at the same time provide early detection for those that really need it. In terms of whether our cancer was aggressive and required treatment, we were essentially flying blind. For most of us the gamble that it was indolent even with high probability was not an option we wanted to take, thus most chose treatment and some suffered from unwanted side effects unnecessarily.

Posts.Title: Genetic tests to gauge prostate cancer aggressiveness

Posts.Content: gjune, I am glad you are looking at getting him to MDA. It is certainly one of the best if not the best cancer center in the US. I hope they can find a combination medications that could work for him. My understanding is with so many different treatment options, it is not clear what combination or sequence will work best for your Dad. For example, one review article (http://www.jnccn.org/content/12/5S/773.short) stated: During the past 4 years, a host of new agents have been approved for the treatment of patients with advanced prostate cancer. As a result, selecting the right agent for the right patient at the right time is a clinical challenge. At the NCCN 19th Annual Conference, Dr. Celestia Higano explored the rationale behind such therapeutic decisions and the supporting clinical trial data. She reviewed the different classes of therapeutic agents, from immunotherapy and hormonal therapies to chemotherapy and radioisotopes, and offered suggestions for the clinical scenarios in which they may be used most successfully. Therefore someone with experience like MDA could be most helpful. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: I am impressed you actually looked at and reviewed your biopsy slides! You must have some training in cell biology! Finding of PNI is actually quite common and it may or may not be significant depends on who you talk to. I won't worry too much about it at this stage. Good luck on your surgery.
Posts.Title: Results of second opinion of biopsy

Posts.Content: Yes, Old Bridge, we all do that: Prepare for the worst and hope for the best. .06 is still a very small number and could very well be a measurement error. It is also not unusual you have some tiny amount of benign cells left behind as one of the early posts on this forum discussed some time back. But, it is prudent to keep an eye on it regularly. In the mean time arm yourself with some knowledge of what options you have in case it keeps going up. This is a life time watch for us all. Watching our PSA on a regularly basis is something we all do for the rest of our life.

Posts.Title: 15 month Update - PSA moved from .02 to .06. Concerned...

Posts.Content: Fairwind is correct about lymphocele. The risk is real. For the majority of folks, it stays asymptomatic and eventually goes away. For some, it could be life threatening. I had asymptomatic lymphocele for three years but this last July, the abscess was infected and turned sepsis. It almost killed me. I was hospitalized in intensive care with a drain tube in my stomach, 24/7 iv antibiotics and anti-fungal drugs. Home iv antibiotics until infection cleared up. I will need to get periodic CT scan to make sure it does not recur. It is one of the risks most surgeons do not mention. The IR radiologists who did the drainage told me it was more common than a lot of surgeons admitted. That said, if I were to do it over again, I would still want the lymph nodes out - I believe in the points njs said, it is still worth the risks. Best of luck to you

Posts.Content: Harding, I don't think you should worry as long as the PSA continues to drop. What is killing your cancer cells is the radiation and for most folks it takes a while for the effects to fully deploy. You are at less than three months and that is early. It is not uncommon to take 1 to 2 years. Also, since you are really not on ADT but is naturally low on T, intuitively I think the effects are not the same as there should be no drastic drop from suddenly starting ADT, as is typical of people on combined radiation and ADT. I think your RO is correct. I think your treatment is successful and you just have to be patient. Good luck and best wishes.

Perhaps, brachy should produce the least side effects just because of the physics of the method. I almost went for brachy after I read Andy Grove's account of his research for his prostate cancer but my prostate was too large and I wanted to see the final pathology. Peace and cheers.

Posts.Title: Which Treatment Is Best?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gjune My Father was diagnosed 7 years ago now - Gleason 9, PSA 5, Stage IV - he's had bone mets for 1.5 years and is mCRPC. He has never shown any signs of having cancer and now has extremely aggressive liver mets. Based on his genotesting, the new PD-1 drug could work for my Father, but he needs to get into a clinical trial. It is his only option. Has anyone had the drug or know of any available trials. Thank you in advance! IMHO, you did not provide us enough information to comment on whether joining the PD-1 clinical trial is right for him. The obvious question is has he exhausted all available options including all of the modern drugs, immunotherapy, chemo, etc.? Sometimes, trying different sequencing, different combinations (e.g. combined chemo and hormone) work well for some patients. Getting advice from a medical oncologist specializing in treating prostate cancer is perhaps the next step. He/she can also help sign him up for the PD-1 clinical trial. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Prostate cancer with liver mets, need a PD-1 trial...

Posts.Content: I think a PSA reduction of over 50% in less than two months is a good response. Good luck.
Posts.Title: ON Casodex (bicalutamide) for 8 weeks now...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by catchmeifucan Isramed quoted $5795.00/month for Zytiga. This is not modest sum for me or my father. It is a shame medications are costing so much. I really feel for you and your Dad. However, lancepeace made a good point. There maybe other medications he can try before resorting to Zytiga, Jevtana, Xtandi... Looks like your father's cancer is under control, so, before spending large sum of money for new drugs, perhaps his doctor should keep trying combinations of existing medications. The top oncologists in the US like Myers, Scholz, Lee et al, are able to use combinations, sometimes inexpensive drugs to keep cancer under control, some for years. Perhaps you should discuss with his doctor about a consult with those oncologists. Hope this buys you time so that in a couple of years generics should be available in India and should be reasonably priced. Good luck.
Posts.Title: How can I get Zytiga and MDV3100 at low cost in non US countries? say India

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Cvmiller My question is which is the better of the types of surgery, robotic or open prostectomy. Welcome. To specifically answer your question, go robotic. There is a reason other than hype that 80+% of prostatectomy are now robotic. In my non professional opinion, robotic allows for more precision because the mechanical arms have more degrees of freedom, smaller steadier movements, and color 3D, 10X magnification view which more than compensate for lack of feel of the surgeon's hands. An analogy would be machine soldering vs hand soldering of electronic boards. That said, the surgeon operates the machine so make sure you find the best operator to work on you. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F TY for the confounding info newporter! The author, Stephen Feller, makes the statement: "Although studies have suggested PSA tests give false positives too often and can miss tumors, the tests have been used to detect or predict prostate cancer since the early 1990s." Either he is highly misinformed or I've accidentally clicked onto the wrong Forum! A far better summary appeared in Uro-Today: "Results of a number of studies demonstrate that the serum prostate-specific antigen (PSA) in and of itself is an inadequate screening test. Today, one of the most pressing questions in prostate cancer medicine is how can screening be honed to identify those who have life-threatening disease and need aggressive treatment." As we are witnessing the field of genomic testing advance at a rapid rate, medical science is getting us all closer to answering: The BIG PCa Question = "How to discriminate between lethal and non lethal PC?" I greatly look forward to the answer. MF The study was hot off the press so represented the latest and the author was MA Preston: Preston MA et al. Baseline Prostate-Specific Antigen Levels in Midlife Predict Lethal Prostate Cancer, Journal of Clinical Oncology DOI: 10.1200/JCO.2016.66.7527 I did not read the original paper but according to Harvard School of Public Health, here is the summary: The researchers found that this single, baseline PSA level measured at midlife could accurately predict future risk of prostate cancer: Of the lethal prostate cancer events, 82 percent, 71 percent and 86 percent occurred in men with a baseline PSA above the median at ages 40-49, 50-54 and 55-59, respectively.

Posts.Content: George, Sorry you have to be here but welcome. Yes, a G10 post op pathology report indicated a very aggressive cancer and your Dad should prepare for plan B if necessary. If your parents let you, you should accompany them to the follow up appointment and help ask questions to prepare for follow up actions if necessary. Here are some of the questions to ask: 1. Ask the urologist for a copy of the full pathology report (if you only have the summary report) and explain the findings, e.g., if the surgical margins were positive/negative (negative is good); if there were spreads outside the prostate (EPE), seminal vesicles, lymph nodes, etc. and the staging T2, T3, etc. 2. If he had a PET scan (not pre op CT & bone scans) post surgery, ask for the finding of and explain the scan results. 3. Ask for what sort of follow up actions are required and treatment options, what ifs. 4. Ask to refer to a medical oncologist and a radiation oncologist for second and third opinions. To educate yourself, go read the book by Dr. Pat Walsh on Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Content: I noticed no one responded to your post, so please allow me make a few comments: The few articles I read all indicated those with a lower PSA nadir after Primary Hormone treatment had better survival. You might want to look through Pubmed and get some newer publications. Two articles regarding Primary Hormone treatment, one published in 2006 another 2012: 1. BJU Int. 2006 Sep;98(3):573-9 Efficacy of primary hormone therapy for localized or locally advanced prostate cancer: results of a 10-year follow-up. Akaza H1, Homma Y, Usami M, Hirao Y, Tsushima T, Okada K, Yokoyama M, Ohashi Y, Aso Y; Prostate Cancer Study Group. Author information Department of Urology, Institute of Clinical Medicine, University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, Japan. [email protected] 2. Acta Med Indones. 2012 Jan;44(1):10-5 Primary hormonal treatment in localized and locally advanced prostate cancer: effectiveness and survival predictive factors. Utomo NB1, Mochtar CA, Umbas R. Department of Urology, University of Indonesia-dr. Cipto Mangunkusumo Hospital, Indonesia. [email protected] From what I read, in general folks using combined hormone and radiation got better survival outcome than Primary Hormone, e.g.: 3. Lancet 2009;373:301-08 Widmark A, Klepp O, Solberg A, et al. Endocrine treatment, with or without radiotherapy, in locally advanced prostate cancer (SPCG-7/SFUO-3): an open randomized phase III trial. Your doctors at UCSF are more knowledgeable so should be able to give you better guidance. Best wishes.

The outcome seemed too good to me: Out of 347, treatment side had 63 fatalities and out of 348 on the AS side, had 99 fatalities. It is like every 9 you treated early, you saved 1 extra live. Much better outcome than the USPSTF's position that every 1000 you save 1. So, something does not add up. Let me read the journal article before I make any further comments. Regards,

Posts.Content: I have no opinion but in the drug label for AndroGel, FDA required the manufacturer to include the following warning for prescription: 5 WARNINGS AND PRECAUTIONS 5.1 Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia and Potential Risk of Prostate Cancer  Patients with BPH treated with androgens are at an increased risk for worsening of signs and symptoms of BPH.  Patients treated with androgens may be at increased risk for prostate cancer. Evaluation of the patient for prostate cancer prior to initiating and during treatment with androgens is appropriate.  Increases in serum PSA from baseline values were seen in approximately 18% of individuals in an open label study of 162 hypogonadal men treated with AndroGel for up to 42 months. Most of these increases were seen within the first year of therapy [see Contraindications (4), Warnings and Precautions (5.9), Adverse Reactions (6.1), and Nonclinical Toxicolog(13.1)]. Also: 17 PATIENT COUNSELING INFORMATION See FDA-Approved Medication Guide (17.5) 17.1 Men with known or suspected prostate or breast cancer should not use AndroGel Did your physician advice you on either and requested PSA testing when he/she prescribed your T treatment?
Posts.Title: On testosterone therapy for 1 year prior to finding i had PC

Posts.Content: Researchers from Cambridge University in UK published an article in the British Journal of Cancer in January 2014, claimed that the current tools of PSA, biopsy etc. did not accurately select the right candidates for AS. The link: http://www.nature.com/bjc/journal/va...c2014192a.html Here is a summary of their finding: Results: Of 848 patients, 415 had Gleason 3+3 disease on biopsy. Of these, 32.0% had extra-prostatic extension and 50.2% were upgraded. One had positive lymph nodes. Two hundred and six (24% of cohort) were DAmico low risk. Of these, 143 had more than two biopsy cores involved. None of the tools evaluated has adequate discriminative power in predicting insignificant tumour burden. Accuracy is low in PSA-screened and -unscreened populations. Their conclusion: We need better tools in order to select the right candidates to practice AS. The authors were not against AS, they just concluded that the diagnostic tools we currently have are not too accurate in predicting staging and severity of cancer and therefore may not get the right patients to practice AS.

Posts.Title: New Finding Regarding PSA Testing

Posts.Content: ronjem, How high was your PSA? When I was researching treatment options, my urologist told me the primary consideration for brachy was prostate size and that mine was too enlarged for brachy and neither my PSA of >10 nor my Gleason were factors. As JohnT said, I now know that I could have brachy if I took hormone to shrink the prostate prior to seeding. However, like surgery, seeding success depends greatly on the skill of the radiation oncologist. I think this is one of the confusion on the success rate of seeds. For example, if you research the success rate of great radiation oncologists in Seatle, Southern and Northern Cal... you find excellent outcomes that were better than surgery but general published results were a little different. By the way, this is the same with surgery if you compare Dr. Walsh's results vs generally published results. In your case, perhaps a combination of hormone+brachy+IMRT, like what JohyT had is the best option for you. Make sure you consult a radiation oncologist and an oncologist. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Interstital Radiation Therapy (Seeds)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ruby42 My husband was recently diagnosed with PC and after meetings with doctors and looking at options he has decided on robotic surgery. We are considering either Dr. Tewari or Dr. Samadi in NYC and I was curious about any experiences users have had with either doctor and factors you looked at in making the decision. One question that has seem to come up on prior posts was whether either of the doctors run multiple rooms or have residents perform some of the surgery. Would appreciate providing of first hand experience on any of these questions. Thanks for any advice. Both were on my short list when I was selecting a surgeon to perform my prostatectomy. Tewari has a stellar academic reputation. He is one of the pioneers and one of the few surgeons that actually published his surgical outcome, which were very impressive. Samadi also publicizes his results which were equally impressive. But I cannot recall if they were peer reviewed publications. He liked to advertise and conducted quite a few TV interviews. Both surgeons' results based on some posters here and elsewhere were impressive, so in my non professional opinion, you cannot go wrong with either. As to the surgical process, I believe both perform the critical part of the surgery themselves and often, if you feel strongly that you want them to handle the surgery from beginning to end you can request it. In a teaching hospital, it is unavoidable that the residents, (more likely the fellows) will be assisting and it is not harmful to the outcome. If you tour any hospital's Da Vinci machine, you will find that there are usually two consoles both can see the surgical site and move the instruments so usually the chief would be running it while the fellow watches and assists. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Latest PSA 9 months after Brachytherapy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ruby42 My husband was recently diagnosed with PC and after meetings with doctors and looking at options he has decided on robotic surgery. We are considering either Dr. Tewari or Dr. Samadi in NYC and I was curious about any experiences users have had with either doctor and factors you looked at in making the decision. One question that has seem to come up on prior posts was whether either of the doctors run multiple rooms or have residents perform some of the surgery. Would appreciate providing of first hand experience on any of these questions. Thanks for any advice. Both were on my short list when I was selecting a surgeon to perform my prostatectomy. Tewari has a stellar academic reputation. He is one of the pioneers and one of the few surgeons that actually published his surgical outcome, which were very impressive. Samadi also publicizes his results which were equally impressive. But I cannot recall if they were peer reviewed publications. He liked to advertise and conducted quite a few TV interviews. Both surgeons' results based on some posters here and elsewhere were impressive, so in my non professional opinion, you cannot go wrong with either. As to the surgical process, I believe both perform the critical part of the surgery themselves and often, if you feel strongly that you want them to handle the surgery from beginning to end you can request it. In a teaching hospital, it is unavoidable that the residents, (more likely the fellows) will be assisting and it is not harmful to the outcome. If you tour any hospital's Da Vinci machine, you will find that there are usually two consoles both can see the surgical site and move the instruments so usually the chief would be running it while the fellow watches and assists. Good luck.
Posts.Signature: PCa Dx 2010 at 65. PSA increased from 2.5 in 2000 to 10.7 in 2010. Four biopsies in 6 years. Final biopsy in 2010: 1 of 12 cores 5% cancer, G6 CT, bone scans & MRI all negative Da Vinci 8/10; nerve sparing, catheter out in 7 days; no incontinence, no ED Post Op Pathology pT2N0Mx: organ confined; negative margins; lymph nodes & seminal vesicle not involved but PNI present; cancer extensive within prostate, multifocal G 3+3 and tertiary G 4 Infected lymphocele diagnosed and treated in 2014, 4 yrs after RALP PSA <.1 for the past 6 years.
Posts.Title: Choosing Surgeon in NYC

Posts.Content: There were a lot of discussions on this topic in a number of threads lately. However, I think most on both sides just hand waved and didn't back up their claims one way or another. Let me try to present some numbers from a number of recent studies in medical journals. I don't claim the studies were unbiased and let the readers decide for themselves. There is a June 2010 publication I collected (right at the time my urologist told me I had prostate cancer so it was timely for me) from the journal Therapeutic Advances in Urology:2(3)119-125. It was a review paper, namely it reviewed a bunch of studies and summarized their outcome in the paper and drew some conclusions and those that are technically inclined will spot some inconsistencies in the studies and conclusions: 1. The incidences of secondary primary cancer after radiation therapy was 1/70 (1.4%). The most common sites were bladder and rectum. 2. The latency period between radiation therapy and malignancies were between 5 and 15 years. 3. One study in 2006 cited National Cancer Institute's SEER data and concluded the incidences were 9.9% after treatment (I think the results were from the early 1970s to 2002). It said the risks were greatest for EBRT and least for brachy and in between for brachy+EBRT. Another study indicated brachy did not significantly increase the risk. 4. Epidemiological studies indicated the risk of bladder cancer is 5% to 6% vs 3.7% for surgery patients. 5. The authors' conclusions were that the risk is real but modest however they question the use of radiation therapy for low risk prostate cancer patients with minimal risk of dying from prostate cancer because of the adversed effects. I took a look at the SEER database on bladder and colorectal cancer and found some inconsistent statistics: The lifetime risks of bladder cancer was 2.4% and colorectal cancer was 4.8%. But if you sum the incidences by age, the total incidence was only about 2% for colorectal cancer and 1% for bladder cancer. If you double the numbers, for radiation patients, 2% incidence for bladder cancer and 4% for colorectal cancer for a total of 6% for bladder and colorectal cancer combined. A side note, the often quoted risks of dying from prostate cancer surgery was 1-2%, also not insignificant. I welcome others to show statistics that are different.

AgeInfo.Phrase: after radiation therapy was 1 70  1 4% <Z> <Z> <Z>

In the Walsh book you carry, there is also a Partin table, look at it to find out the odds. However, don't rely on them too much or you are going to lose too much sleep. Posts.Title: Husband recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: I have no opinion but in the drug label for AndroGel, FDA required the manufacturer to include the following warning for prescription: 5 WARNINGS AND PRECAUTIONS 5.1 Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia and Potential Risk of Prostate Cancer  Patients with BPH treated with androgens are at an increased risk for worsening of signs and symptoms of BPH.  Patients treated with androgens may be at increased risk for prostate cancer. Evaluation of the patient for prostate cancer prior to initiating and during treatment with androgens is appropriate.  Increases in serum PSA from baseline values were seen in approximately 18% of individuals in an open label study of 162 hypogonadal men treated with AndroGel for up to 42 months. Most of these increases were seen within the first year of therapy [see Contraindications (4), Warnings and Precautions (5.9), Adverse Reactions (6.1), and Nonclinical Toxicolog(13.1)]. Also: 17 PATIENT COUNSELING INFORMATION See FDA-Approved Medication Guide (17.5) 17.1 Men with known or suspected prostate or breast cancer should not use AndroGel Did your physician advice you on either and requested PSA testing when he/she prescribed your T treatment?

Posts.Title: Current Tools To Identify AS Candidates Not Accurate

Posts.Content: Researchers from Cambridge University in UK published an article in the British Journal of Cancer in January 2014, claimed that the current tools of PSA, biopsy etc. did not accurately select the right candidates for AS. The link: http://www.nature.com/bjc/journal/va...c2014192a.html Here is a summary of their finding: Results: Of 848 patients, 415 had Gleason 3+3 disease on biopsy. Of these, 32.0% had extra-prostatic extension and 50.2% were upgraded. One had positive lymph nodes. Two hundred and six (24% of cohort) were DAmico low risk. Of these, 143 had more than two biopsy cores involved. None of the tools evaluated has adequate discriminative power in predicting insignificant tumour burden. Accuracy is low in PSA-screened and -unscreened populations. Their conclusion: We need better tools in order to select the right candidates to practice AS. The authors were not against AS, they just concluded that the diagnostic tools we currently have are not too accurate in predicting staging and severity of cancer and therefore may not get the right patients to practice AS.

Posts.Content: I think you won't find too many surgeon's peer reviewed surgical outcome studies nowadays. In the early days of robotic surgery (prior to 2010) pioneering surgeons did published a lot of their statistics but now most don't. Many surgeons (mine for one) keep their own unaudited statistics and are willing to share with prospective patients. I ended up not using any of the surgeons that published but a local guy willing to share statistics and patients references. Some interesting recently published global statistics are that robotics are actually better than open and that high volume surgeons performed better than low volume ones. Also, we are all obsessed with PSM (I was) but it turned out PSM was not a strong predictor of overall survival but cancer characteristics was. First of all, volume is a strong predictor of PSM, i.e., # performed per year is an important determinant of outcome. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21771246 High volume surgeons have less peri-operative and postoperative complications and better surgical and disease-free outcomes than low volume surgeons. In the UK, raising the current minimum Improving Outcomes Guidance threshold from five RP cases per surgeon per annum to no less than 20 (and ideally to 35 or more cases per annum) could potentially improve overall outcomes. Second, it takes a long time and a large number of operations for surgeon to be proficient, and they are not talking about a hundred but a thousand! Also, their conclusion was the same as the UK study that tumor characteristics determined PSM. http://www.medpagetoday.com/MeetingC...e/ASCOGU/24908 The principal outcomes of interest were the rate of positive surgical margins and operative time. Surgical performance was evaluated after every 50 RALP procedures. For all cases, positive-margin rate started at about 20% and then gradually declined to less than 10% after 1,600 total cases. At the end of the six-year review period, rate remained in a downward trajectory, suggesting continuation of the learning curve, said Sooriakumaran. For the subgroup of patients with extracapsular disease (pT3), the positive-margin rate began at about 40% and remained stable throughout the study period. Third, here is an interesting statistics about positive surgical margin and overall survival: http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2490/14/86 This is their Conclusions: More aggressive tumor characteristics were strong determinants for positive margins. Furthermore, surgical margin status per se was not an independent prognostic factor for prostate cancer-specific survival after adjusting by the gravity of the disease in the multivariate analysis. Ten-year PCSS (prostate cancer specific survival) was 96.6% [95% CI: 94.3-98.] for the negative surgical group, and 92.0% (95% CI: 88.5-95.4) for the PSM group [log rank p = 0.008]. What they were saying was that PSM was more associated with patients' tumor staging than anything else. What you need is to find a high volume surgeon. If I use this to predict your outcome, most likely with a high volume surgeon your chance of PSM is very small (<10%) and even if you have PSM, your overall 10 year survival will not be very different from those of us with NPSM. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Husband recently diagnosed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo This is not helpful for those who already went through seeds or radiation.... ddayglo, It is actually helpful. The two numbers you need to focus on are: For radiation treatment, the secondary cancer rate was 1.4% For surgery, the mortality rate was ~1-2% All the other studies, claims are somewhat contradictory. In other words, the "bad things" that can happen are about equal. So, for the uninformed, it makes no difference. The reason I chose surgery was not secondary cancer but that I could control the 1-2% mortality rate by being fit, no prior abdominal operations, no heart problems, no obesity and find a good surgeon, etc. whereas I was not sure I could control the secondary cancer rate. Hope this answers your concerns.

Posts.Title: Secondary Primary Cancers After Radiation Therapy

Posts.Content: blank, I just do not think "1600 number of robotic surgery be done before someone is proficient" is credible. Imagine, Da Vinci in the US started in 2003, a surgeon would have to perform 200 per year before he is proficient by 2013? That means 4 per week, every week and every year since 2003! In my search, I only found two and maybe three in Southern Cal who had done as many. If that were true most patients who chose robotic surgery were doomed to BCR failure but I just don't see the statistics indicating such. In fact, the statistics for BCR had not change much since surgery was transition from open to robotic. The 250 number of surgery before proficient had a lot of research behind it, especially for open surgery. In 2007 Vickers et al published a study in the Journal of National Cancer Institute showing the results of a large study: • N=7765 (number of cases) • 72 surgeons at 4 US centres (MSK, Baylor, Wayne State, Cleveland) • Experience – >999 – 250-999 – 100-249 – 50-99 – <50 • Outcome: BCR is defined as PSA >/= 0.4 ng/ml and rising • Rate of BCR dependent on surgical experience • Inflection point at 250 Meaning after a surgeon had 250 cases, the surgical outcome did not improve. There are a number of published reports on robotic surgery by surgeons with similar results. I agree those were not large population studies but by specific surgeons reporting their own results since starting robotic surgery. But to think using a robot required 6 1/2 times more practice is indeed "absurd". I have no dog in this fight but the article you quoted could be doing us a diservice and could scare away folks who are contemplating Da Vinci. Cheers.

Posts.Title: Doctors Need 1,600 Robot-Aided Prostate Surgeries for Skills, Study Finds

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by blank If the article is flawed then we should point out its flaws. If it isn't men should know. I read the article. It is a sample of three surgeons. I don't think 3 is a sufficient sample size for a statistical analysis and draw general conclusions. Also, one might confuse improvement with proficiency. One notable surgeon, Dr. Walsh, constantly tried to improve his technique. He mentioned in his book that he video taped his surgery and watched them to see how he could keep improving the outcome and that he constantly improved his outcome. His last surgery statistics were phenomenal, better than his prior results. I would consider someone proficient once his outcome reaches an inflection point, namely at that point no further improvements are achieved while using the same technique and that the outcome equalled standard outcome. I consider improvement when he figured out a way to achieve better outcome than the general standard. One example is surgeons figured out how to use "cold" scissors instead of the normal "hot" cut and thus improved the ED rate by reducing nerve damage.... And this, a few years after they used Da Vinci so according to this article they were still learning and not proficient. I am happy surgeons can constantly improve their techniques so that those come after us reap the benefits, just like radiation oncologists constantly improve on theirs. Thanks for your post. It is good to present different data to share with us so we all can learn something new.

Posts.Title: 2 Days after RRP with Di Vinci

Posts.Content: Welcome to our club. We know how you feel - been there, done that - your feeling is normal. With a G7, and all right cores positive, you need treatment soon. Usually surgeons won't perform prostatectomy until 8 weeks after biopsy since right now the prostate is like a pin cushion and it takes time to heal so the surgeon won't miss anything when he/she opens you up. I used your numbers and ran the MSK nomogram, you have less than 10% probability the cancer spread to other organs including the seminal vesicles and lymph nodes and that is excellent odds in my book. So, the good news is you caught it early. If you select surgery, 15 year cancer specific survival (your chance of not dying from prostate cancer) is 99%. radiation should give you similar odds. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Feedback about my potential surgeon

Posts.Content: With a pre-op PSA of 5.3, using a half life of 3 days, at 6 weeks (42 days) you should get 14 half life reductions of PSA or a PSA value of .0003. With most instruments, your PSA should be undetectable at 6 weeks. If not it could be due to cancer cells left behind, benign tissues left behind or systemic. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Initial PSA 6 wks post op

Posts.Content: General guideline by my health insurance at the time of my diagnosis: If PSA >10, G scores >6, an MRI was called for. Otherwise, prior authorization was needed. 3T gives resolution better than CT, 1.5T will not, so, if you want to do MRI, get a 3T MRI.

Posts.Title: 3T MRI Question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Brett Trommler I was diagnosed with prostate cancer back in February. Fortunately it was a very early detection; only 10% on one of the twelve cores of the biopsy. I was blessed to be able to receive cyberknife treatment in April and when I was tested in August, my PSA was down to 2.8 which is almost normal for me. Well, I was tested again a couple weeks ago and now my PSA is up to 4.6 which is higher than it's ever been. My oncologist is hopeful that it is only an infection and I have just completed a round of strong antibiotics and will be retested in a couple weeks. My question is... will sexual activity affect the PSA? I did ask the doctor if my wife could be intimate during this whole process and she said that was no problem. But I am wondering if that may be what's causing the high PSA reading. Because quite honestly, things have never felt quite... normal, during sex or otherwise, since the cyberknife treatment. Brett, Welcome. There is something called PSA bounce after radiation treatment, i.e., the PSA will go up and down, sometimes a few times but the general trend after the first bounce is down. I don't know if the first bounce can get higher than the PSA prior to treatment but am not surprise if it does. Your current PSA about 6-12 months after radiation treatment could be a case of PSA bounce. The next couple of PSA tests will indicate if you have a bounce or if it is something else. Your cancer seemed to be early stage. We don't know your biopsy history (e.g. Gleason score, staging etc.) so don't know how aggressive is your cancer. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: PSA higher than it's ever been

Posts.Content: Unfortunately there is no guarantee in this business as Webheadfred said, undetectable PSA does not mean you are free of cancer, only that they cannot be detected by the instrument. Most likely you will have to track your PSA at least annually for as long as you live and hopefully they will continue to be undetectable. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: When I get post PSA test done

Posts.Content: I think you won't find too many surgeon's peer reviewed surgical outcome studies nowadays. In the early days of robotic surgery (prior to 2010) pioneering surgeons did published a lot of their statistics but now most don't. Many surgeons (mine for one) keep their own unaudited statistics and are willing to share with prospective patients. I ended up not using any of the surgeons that published but a local guy willing to share statistics and patients references. Some interesting recently published global statistics are that robotics are actually better than open and that high volume surgeons performed better than low volume ones. Also, we are all obsessed with PSM (I was) but it turned out PSM was not a strong predictor of overall survival but cancer characteristics was. First of all, volume is a strong predictor of PSM, i.e., # performed per year is an important determinant of outcome. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/21771246 High volume surgeons have less peri-operative and postoperative complications and better surgical and disease-free outcomes than low volume surgeons. In the UK, raising the current minimum Improving Outcomes Guidance threshold from five RP cases per surgeon per annum to no less than 20 (and ideally to 35 or more cases per annum) could potentially improve overall outcomes. Second, it takes a long time and a large number of operations for surgeon to be proficient, and they are not talking about a hundred but a thousand! Also, their conclusion was the same as the UK study that tumor characteristics determined PSM. http://www.medpagetoday.com/MeetingC...e/ASCOGU/24908 The principal outcomes of interest were the rate of positive surgical margins and operative time. Surgical performance was evaluated after every 50 RALP procedures. For all cases, positive-margin rate started at about 20% and then gradually declined to less than 10% after 1,600 total cases. At the end of the six-year review period, rate remained in a downward trajectory, suggesting continuation of the learning curve, said Sooriakumaran. For the subgroup of patients with extracapsular disease (pT3), the positive-margin rate began at about 40% and remained stable throughout the study period. Third, here is an interesting statistics about positive surgical margin and overall survival: http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2490/14/86 This is their Conclusions: More aggressive tumor characteristics were strong determinants for positive margins. Furthermore, surgical margin status per se was not an independent prognostic factor for prostate cancer-specific survival after adjusting by the gravity of the disease in the multivariate analysis. Ten-year PCSS (prostate cancer specific survival) was 96.6% [95% CI: 94.3-98.] for the negative surgical group, and 92.0% (95% CI: 88.5-95.4) for the PSM group [log rank p = 0.008]. What they were saying was that PSM was more associated with patients' tumor staging than anything else. What you need is to find a high volume surgeon. If I use this to predict your outcome, most likely with a high volume surgeon your chance of PSM is very small (<10%) and even if you have PSM, your overall 10 year survival will not be very different from those of us with NPSM. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Researching A Surgeon's Surgical Margin Rates

Posts.Content: When it comes to PSA testing after surgery, it can be confusing because different testing lab uses different machine with different sensitivity (resolution), some has sensitivity of .1, others .01, etc. What you should look for is the < sign in front of the PSA number, for example, if the machine sensitivity is .1, anything less than .1 is considered undetectable, < .1, = 0. Your tests were done with an ultra sensitive machine and there were no < sign in front of the PSA numbers meaning your PSA were not 0. Does it means your cancer is back? Not necessarily. Sometimes, some benign tissues were left behind and so the PSA was not 0. There were a few posters on this site had this happened to them. However, in those cases, PSA stabilized to a small number and stayed there. That is also why the medical community considers recurrence only after three successive number of > .1 and PSA reaches .2 or greater. My advice is to watch your PSA carefully and start to prepare for plan B just in case, i.e., prepare for the worst but hope for the best. Plan B should include consultation with an oncologist and a radiation oncologist as Fairwind stated. Good luck.
