Posts.Title: PSA creeping up after Da Vinci surgery

Posts.Content: Your husband's pathology report did state that the one lymph node positive is microscopic, so, like all the other posters said, if I were you folks, I would still shoot for a cure: adjuvant radiation to the prostate bed and lymph nodes areas and ADT. There are a number of studies indicating adjuvant radiation and ADT after a failed surgery increased the chances of cure and survival. Also, as JNF said, some oncologists believed and practiced spot radiation to a few affected spots and claimed to have good outcome. Agree with Fairwind that you folks need to consult with an oncologist, one that specializes in prostate caner. Good luck and hope everything works out for you folks.

Posts.Title: Need Guidance

Posts.Content: I noticed your cancer was G(4+4) and staged T3b meaning your cancer was aggressive and had spread to the seminal vesicles. So you are considered a high risk case. However, not all high risk cases resulted in recurrence and even if recur can be cured with radiation and hormone therapy. There are quite a few posters in similar situation as you and I hope they can chime in and help out. Take care.
Posts.Title: PSA creeping up after Da Vinci surgery

Posts.Content: With a pre-op PSA of 5.3, using a half life of 3 days, at 6 weeks (42 days) you should get 14 half life reductions of PSA or a PSA value of .0003. With most instruments, your PSA should be undetectable at 6 weeks. If not it could be due to cancer cells left behind, benign tissues left behind or systemic. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Initial PSA 6 wks post op

Posts.Content: Welcome to our club. We know how you feel - been there, done that - your feeling is normal. With a G7, and all right cores positive, you need treatment soon. Usually surgeons won't perform prostatectomy until 8 weeks after biopsy since right now the prostate is like a pin cushion and it takes time to heal so the surgeon won't miss anything when he/she opens you up. I used your numbers and ran the MSK nomogram, you have less than 10% probability the cancer spread to other organs including the seminal vesicles and lymph nodes and that is excellent odds in my book. So, the good news is you caught it early. If you select surgery, 15 year cancer specific survival (your chance of not dying from prostate cancer) is 99%. radiation should give you similar odds. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by maplessr I'm 15 months post surgery and doing great, with one exception. Beginning immediately after the surgery I noticed a significant change in my urine -it is cloudy and smells horrible. I have talked to my doctors and am being told that the only thing that could cause this is dietary changes, of which there haven't been any. Has anyone else experienced anything like this? maplessr, First thing to try: drink a lot of water to see if that can flush things out. If persist, get a second opinion. cloudy and smelly urine could indicate infection. So, perhaps ask for a urine analysis. There could be other causes and a blood test might also be appropriate. In any case we are non professionals so you should seek professional advice. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Xtandi is working

Posts.Content: Sorry about your Dad and Mum. You did not say how old is he and his treatment history so it is difficult to comment. However, I suggest he seeks out an oncologist specializing in prostate cancer to take over the management of his disease. Prostate cancer treatment, after cancer metastasized is tricky and more an art than a science as the variations in drugs, drugs combinations, etc. are long and extensive and often time an experience oncologist might be able to get the right combination to extend his life a long time. Best wishes and best of luck.

Posts.Title: Rising PSA levels

Posts.Content: poppygirl, Sorry you have to be here but welcome. A PSA of 5.3 by itself coupled with an enlarged prostate could be normal and not necessarily prostate cancer. As for a "positive" DRE, you have two conflicting results: First consultant stated prostate was enlarged but smooth indicating normal. The second felt one side "rigid" but he really did not feel a "nodule" and that could be due to inflammation from the first DRE disturbing the prostate too much and the subsequent high (5.3) PSA could be due to that also. That said, a biopsy is probably a smart thing to do to rule out cancer. Biopsy is uncomfortable but not painful and many of us had multiple biopsies over the years. Even if he has cancer and has to join our club, it is not a death sentence. We survived and thrived after diagnosis. So, look at the bright side and wait for the biopsy result. In the unfortunate case that he tested positive, come back and many of us would be happy to be helpful, share our experiences and opinions. I am not a healthcare professional and my opinions are just opinions and not professional advices. Good luck.

Posts.Title: so worried for my partner :(

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by nrhk Thanks Michael F and Highlander for your responses and your support. We did his next chemo today. He does have nail discoloring, but thankfully no other bad symptoms. The team of oncologists decided that since his PSA is going up, it could be one of two things - a flare from the catheterization, or perhaps the chemo isnt working to control the cancer. They have advised we should do a repeat bone scan, chest XRay and a CECT abdomen in two weeks, and another PSA before the next chemo to figure out what is going on. I really hope and pray that the cancer hasnt spread to the organs, that would really suck. There is another possibility, sometimes at this stage immediate PSA is not a good indicator of whether the treatment is working. The fact that your dad's pain is gone and he seemed responding well is a good sign to me and may be they should finish the chemo before doing anything else. Also, after first line hormone e.g. Lupron, fails, new classes of hormone still work, e.g. Zytiga and Xtandi because they act on different sites on the cancer cells. I am wondering if it makes sense to add them to the treatment protocol at this stage? I am a layperson so all these are just pure speculations on my part. Best wishes.

This has been an ongoing battle between radiologists and urologists for years. JohnT, It is interesting that radiologists perform most biopsies, like breast, liver, kidney...except prostate. My personal belief is that radiologists are trained in diagnostics and should be more competent in performing biopsies. In fact my final biopsy that detected cancer was done by a radiologist. Posts.Content: Originally Posted by LL Fauntleroy Any recommendations for getting prepared for the staple gun in the ass procedure? They do provide 10mg valium and one percocet First and foremost, follow the instructions to make sure your bowel is clean otherwise you increase the chance of infection. Second, take the antibiotics as instructed. If I were you, I would request them to numb the site before the actual biopsy so there will be minimal pain and discomfort. Old urologists claimed there were no nerves there and so not painful. They were wrong. Now, numbing the site should be a normal procedure. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Suspect Alternative to Biopsy from first time confused poster

Posts.Content: No one answer your post so let me try. From my reading the labels of the hormone drugs, memory loss, tired/weak and potential osteoporosis are some of the potential side effects. Consult your physician. He may prescribe some medications to counter the side effects.
Posts.Title: memory

Posts.Content: Let me add my comments to what Michael and highlander said: 1. It is always advisable to get a second opinion both for a re-read of the biopsy slides and the treatment options. It may change the approaches to treatment. 2. With a PSA of 30 and a diagnosis of t3, it is likely the cancer may have grown outside the prostate and it that case the radiation + hormone is as food if not superior to surgery since there is a high probability that radiation is needed after surgery to clean up the cancer outside. 3. Radiation two months after the start of hormone is a standard protocol. It serves two purposes: Sensitizes the cancer cells to radiations for easier kill; shrink the prostate so radiations can be more effective. many studies confirmed the advantages. 4. You need to ask what mode of radiations is the doctor talking about as there are many different protocols. Seeds, IMRT, EBRT are the most common and sometimes they combine seeds + IMRT. For large prostates, IMRT or EBRT are more appropriate. By the way seeds are not appropriate for large prostate. 5. Sounded to me his doctor is very up to date on the subject and the approach is appropriate so don't worry too much. The one thing I would worry if he agrees to go the radiation route is the equipment is critical. Older generations of radiation equipment are just not as good and precise and the side effects/damages to surrounding tissues are worse. So make sure he gets the latest and best equipment. I am just a layperson so my opinions are not advices. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Gleason 3+4 / 3+3, stage T3NxM0 questions

Posts.Content: Frankly I would not worry about the 3.1 to 4.3 unless you have another couple of tests showing consistently higher numbers. PSA can easily change by a point if: You had sex prior to test, irritated your prostate (e.g. perform a DRE) prior to test, infection or inflammation... By the way, I did a doubling calculation for you. From April 2013 to Oct 2014, PSA doubled every 2.6 years, if I go back to 2012, the doubling time was 2.1 years. So, your PSA "increase" actually is slowing down, which is another good sign. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Done

Posts.Content: I think the nurse quoted you the size in cm. A 2 cm ball (the prostate is approximately a sphere) would have a volume of about 32cc. So, your prostate did not shrink. Good luck on your biopsy.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Delawarean I am newly diagnosed and getting a second look at S-K. The doc at S-K wants me to have bone and CAT scans before my appointment. My local doc said no. Are these scans appropriate? Gleason of 7, PSA of 7, 60 years old. Is it normal to get these scans? Any reason not to? With your stats, the scans will most likely not show any metastasized cancer. However, many physicians like you to get the scans mostly as a baseline in case your treatment fails and you develop metastasized cancer to the bones or other organs. Often time, if you have old injuries or arthritis, they will light up the scan so the baseline scan will provide a reference that future scans can be compared to. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Done

Posts.Content: The cost of a biopsy is not cheap, ~ a couple of thousands, maybe more if you do not have insurance as hospitals charge more if you do not have insurance. As your doctor would have told you, there are three possibilities for a high PSA: enlarged prostate, infection/inflammation and cancer. Your DRE should tell you if you have enlarged prostate and gave you a size estimate which could be used to estimate PSA due to a large prostate. In addition, chronic inflammation also causes high PSA, sometimes abnormal DRE and is difficult to get rid of even with Cipro (mine was never cured by Cipro). A PSA of 8.5 may not indicate cancer but is certainly a concern. For sure if the next PSA increases another 1 or 2 points, you should get a biopsy. Good luck.

Posts.Content: A lot of physical activities can cause the PSA to go up and down. Infection can also change your PSA up or down. Cancer produced PSA will not go down. Most likely you had other things that caused your PSA to move up and down. As the other posters said, for your age, your PSA is well within the normal range. If I were you I won't do biopsy.

Posts.Title: Suspect Alternative to Biopsy from first time confused poster

Posts.Content: SeaCock, There were a number of very old threads on this site discussing this issue and I recalled a gentleman discussed using T replacement after prostate cancer treatment and without ill effect. Here are my logics for and against: 1. Hormone therapy starves cancer cells that feed off testosterone and is able to shrink the tumor as a result. So, if there are still cancer cells in your body after surgery, don't feed the cancer with T replacement. 2. On the other hand, if after surgery, your PSA is undetectable for a prolong period of time, it means there are no more cancer cells or prostate cells. In that case T replacement should not be an issue. As for the finer points of pros and cons, here are articles discussing this very subject in case you are interested: http://www.harvardprostateknowledge....rostate-cancer http://www.europeanurology.com/artic...l-implications Regards,
Posts.Title: Testosterone Therapy

First time I have read about a negative finding on seminal vesicles but positive on vas deferens. Did the surgeon take out any lymph nodes for examination? Posts.Title: Nerve sparing and psa after rp !!!!!!

Posts.Content: gurley43, Welcome. First of all, with a G8, you need to get off active watch and seek treatment. Both radiation and surgery can provide a cure for you. You should not worry too much as your cancer, though a G8, is mostly likely still confined within the prostate. I did a nomogram for your stats and it came back as 74% probability of organ confined and less than 4% probability of lymph node involvement which are very good odds (better odds than mine prior to treatment). Look at the bright side, you did gain two years of "normal life" and it is not too late to take action. Good luck and cheers.

Posts.Title: vas deferens invasion

Posts.Content: The cost of a biopsy is not cheap, ~ a couple of thousands, maybe more if you do not have insurance as hospitals charge more if you do not have insurance. As your doctor would have told you, there are three possibilities for a high PSA: enlarged prostate, infection/inflammation and cancer. Your DRE should tell you if you have enlarged prostate and gave you a size estimate which could be used to estimate PSA due to a large prostate. In addition, chronic inflammation also causes high PSA, sometimes abnormal DRE and is difficult to get rid of even with Cipro (mine was never cured by Cipro). A PSA of 8.5 may not indicate cancer but is certainly a concern. For sure if the next PSA increases another 1 or 2 points, you should get a biopsy. Good luck.

Posts.Title: active watch for 2 years and now gleason 8...what now

Posts.Content: SeaCock, There were a number of very old threads on this site discussing this issue and I recalled a gentleman discussed using T replacement after prostate cancer treatment and without ill effect. Here are my logics for and against: 1. Hormone therapy starves cancer cells that feed off testosterone and is able to shrink the tumor as a result. So, if there are still cancer cells in your body after surgery, don't feed the cancer with T replacement. 2. On the other hand, if after surgery, your PSA is undetectable for a prolong period of time, it means there are no more cancer cells or prostate cells. In that case T replacement should not be an issue. As for the finer points of pros and cons, here are articles discussing this very subject in case you are interested: http://www.harvardprostateknowledge....rostate-cancer http://www.europeanurology.com/artic...l-implications Regards,

Since it has been 17 months, and the PSA is stable at ~ .03 to .04, if I were you, I would wait to see how it plays out as statistics is in your favor. Best wishes

Posts.Title: What caused decrease in psa ?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JustBrandon Hello once again everyone, one topic in prostate cancer I find of particular intrigue, and that is perineural invasion, both in biopsy and surgical pathology. Some articles have mentioned PNI as a negative factor in prognosis, especially if found on biopsy. Other articles have said it is of little significance. What is your take on this? Ill throw it out there that my dad had PNI in both the biopsyand surgical pathology. It was present in the left lobe, but not in the right. JustBrandon, Sorry you are here but welcome. I have not participated in prostate cancer forum for a while and just happened to see your post. Since I had PNI so I was naturally worried after surgery. Like Highlander's post, my surgeon also said it was nothing to worry about. Still, I was worried and so did my own research. There were indeed a number of clinical studies on this subject and indications were PNI was not a predictor of surgery outcome. And, after three and a half years, I am still in remission. If you really want to be technical, here is a summary of one study I kept in my file that indicated such: The prognostic implications of perineural invasion at the time of surgery (Posted on June 23, 2010 @ prostatecancerinfolink.net) A recently published Italian study has reported on whether perineural invasion (PNI) has prognostic value in patients undergoing radical prostatectomy for organ-confined prostate cancer, and on its possible correlation with other recognized prognostic factors. Between January 2000 and December 2007, Masieri et al. carried out a careful prospectively designed study and collected data from 251 consecutive patients who had pathologically localized (organ-confined) prostate cancer after radical prostatectomy. Data from 239 of these patients was usable for analysis. The authors defined PNI as adenocarcinoma observed within the perineural space adjacent to a nerve. The results of their study showed that: Intraprostatic PNI occurred in a total of 157/239 patients (65.7 percent). PNI was more commonly observed in men with pathologic stage T2b/c (149/204 patients or 73 percent)) than in men with pathologic stage T2a (8/35 patients or 26 percent). PNI was also more common in men with a Gleason score of 7 to 10 (73/93 patients or 78.5 percent) than in men with a Gleason score of 2 to 6 (84/146 patients or 57 percent). Average (mean) follow-up was 65.4 months (range, 24 to 118 months). 11/239 patients (4.6 percent) had biochemical recurrence after surgery and 7 of these 11 patients (63.6 percent) showed PNI. 228/239 patients (95.4 percent) were free from biochemical progression after surgery and 150 of these 228 patients (65.7 percent) had PNI. The actuarial biochemical progression-free survival rate for all patients was 96.9 percent at 60 months and 93.5 percent at 84 months, respectively. Stratification based on the presence or absence of PNI did not allow for identification of different prognostic groups. The authors conclude that, at least in their series of patients, men with pathological stage T2 disease and PNI were found to present with a higher pT2 stage and Gleason score than men without PNI, but that the biochemical progression-free outcomes among these patients were similar to the outcomes of patients without PNI at a follow up of between 2 and 12 years. This study appears to suggest that the prognostic impact of PNI on risk for progressive prostate cancer is actually much lower than has been assumed in the past. It may well be that as men have increasingly been diagnosed earlier in the progression of their disease, that perineural invasion is a less significant prognostic factor for men with truly localized disease than it has been thought to be for men known to have extraprostatic extension of their disease. In other words, PNI in men with pathological T3/4 disease may have greater prognostic significance than it does in men with pathological T2 disease. Good luck

Posts.Title: Presence of perineural invasion, and its impact on outcome

Posts.Content: Not just for diabetics, for everyone else good physical health is critical to minimize complications and side effects. Most of us exercised and controlled our diet before surgery or radiation. I know for me it helped a lot in speeding up recovery. You should try to exercise, eat a balanced diet and take your diabetic medication to prepare for the radiotherapy. You have 2 to 3 months to get in shape. By the way, exercise will also help reduce the side effects of Zoladex. Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: diabetic

Posts.Content: I don't understand his urologist/surgeon. With his clinical stage most would refer him to an oncologist and a radiation oncologist. I am with JohnT, after prostatectomy, there is no normal prostate cell, measuring free/bound PSA, PCA3 and PAP are not meaningful. The most sensitive test after surgery is PSA. As for MRI, some doctors believe it could better detect cancer spread to soft tissues. Bone scan is to detect bone met.
Posts.Title: Questions about 'post surgery'- recurrence, etc.

Posts.Content: markperky, Hope things work out for you and you stay in remission. However, Frenchy made a good point, when your cancer is aggressive, here in the US, many doctors want to get a jump in case the cancer has not spread and there is time to catch it. One way is get a post op PSA done at 4 to 6 weeks instead of 3 months because in your case time may be important. The second way they try to beat the cancer is to do adjuvant treatment, usually start hormone right away and after a short period of a few months do adjuvant radiation. Of course none of us are healthcare professionals so it is best you discuss all of these with your doctors. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Update on my cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JD1969 Well last week I had my 1 month follow up. PSA came back at .22 and then a retest a few days later (different lab) showed .24, so it looks like radiation treatment is in my future. For those that have gone through it, what can I expect? Is one month too soon to be looking at PSA numbers? JD1969. Sorry about your PSA results. Looks like your PSA is not undetectable. There are two possibilities: cancer has escaped or some benign prostate tissues may be left behind. Looking at your pathology report summary, looks like you had positive margin on one side with EPE and seminal vesicle involvement so it is possible the cancer has escaped causing the PSA. If all cancer cells and benign cells are out, a one month PSA test should be undetectable. PSA half life in your body is between 2 to 3 days which means with an initial PSA of 10, within 30 days, it should be down to .01 or less. I suggest you consult an oncologist and a radiation oncologist to plan you next attack and hopefully the cancer is still local, in the prostate bed and can be eradicated. No lymph node involvement is a good sign. Again, I am not a healthcare provider so it is just a layperson speculation and could be wrong. Best wishes and good luck.

Posts.Title: 1 month post op PSA check.

Posts.Content: Unfortunately PSA testing is not very definitive as a diagnostic tool and everyone says we need something better but so far none has come to replace it yet. Most likely your husband's cancer has been there for a while. The PSA rule of 4 is usually for older folks. For those younger and at risk the cut off is lower. My question is what is the size of his prostate and has he been taking medications like Proscar that masked his PSA #. If his prostate is normal size (~25cc) his PSA should be less than 2 so anything higher is caused by something else, could be infection, inflammation or cancer, indolent or aggressive. In any case from now going forward, focus on treating and managing his cancer to ensure a long remission. Take care.

Posts.Title: Very confused about PSA- can anyone help me with this?

Posts.Content: Like Fairwind said, no one knows the answer. What got oncologists excited was the clinical trial outcome of combining chemo and hormone early. For individual cases, most likely the outcome will be a lot better than the statistics cited in the trials. A logical thinking is the combination reduces the chance that cancer cells can mutate into something deathly, cancer cells that is not killed by hormone will be killed by chemo, perhaps similar to the HIV treatment using combination drugs. So, we don't know but he should do a lot better than hormone mono therapy and let's hope for a complete remission, or to a point that allows for other adjuvant therapy. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Progressive Cancer after Chemo....

Posts.Content: With treatment, whether surgery or radiation, the best possible outcome for sexual function is returning to where you were prior to treatment. If you had ED prior, you will have ED after. Your Stanford physician was being honest with you. Both Stanford and UCSF have some of the best physicians for prostate cancer so you won't go wrong with either. Good luck.

Posts.Title: prostate cancer feedback from patient after treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by chrisz I've been through this PCa scare-thing for 8 years. My PSA keeps going up and down. Up to 15 then next PSA down to 3.0. PSA now 12. Free and Total PSA look bad. Udoc wants another Biopsy. My 3rd Biopsy (one was a saturation biopsy), with my third different Udoc. Lately I have loss my desire for sex, and before that I had the desire, but hard to get an erection. I've tried 3 different ED meds, none help even a little bit. Mdoc and Udoc both did not seem to know why. I am 61 years old. Wife doesn't seem to care that I don't want sex.... In fact, she seems happy. So, do you think PCa can cause this ? I do have BPH, may it could cause it ? ED is one of the symptoms of prostate cancer. However, all prostate cancer symptoms can be caused by other problems like BPH, infection.... To rule out you have cancer at places that the needles cannot get at (and perhaps why the negative biopsy), you need different tests, i.e., PCA3, color doppler, C11 PET scan... To understand what I said, you can look at the human anatomy and see that the transrectal probe and needles can easily access some areas and hard to get at some other areas (frontal, apex and transition zones for example) within the prostate. The other poster's suggestion of getting a second opinion is a good one. It took a radiologist, instead of an urologist, performing the biopsy to find my cancer.

Posts.Title: Can PCa cause loss of Libido and ED.

Posts.Content: In the three years after surgery, I had a few bouts of minor UTI. Each time it increased urgency and frequency and caused some dripping after urination. So, UTI is something to watch out for. Then there is the possibility of bladder spasm which in minor cases sometimes has the same effects. Finally, if your stitches are not healing properly or have small scar tissues, they might also cause similar problem. Ask your surgeon if there are additional things you can do (back to Kegel?) or medications you can take. You are only a few weeks out so time will heal most short term problems. Let your body heal. Best to you.
Posts.Title: Strong Stream/ Low Volume

Posts.Content: Lence, It will get better. It's been a while but my recollection is that I started with frequent urinations (but with strong stream). Perhaps got up once per night to empty. After a few months, the bladder seemed to learn to get back to its old self and I never had to get up at night anymore. Daytime frequency is now 4-6 hours in between. Looking at your pathology report, your prostate is not that big (mine was twice your size) so should not cause any bladder wall thickening issue. Most likely what you experienced was just effects after surgery and should not be permanent. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: JustBrandon made a very good point. Don't be discouraged by clinical trial survival numbers as they typically enrolled the sickest patients so once the protocol is picked up by the general patient population, the results should be amazing.
Posts.Title: Should I start chemo?

Posts.Content: I don't know how you could call prostate cancer a hoax when it is the second leading cancer death among men and in 2014 29480 men will die of it. I for one am thankful there was a PSA test that alerted me to a potential fetal disease and cured me of it. Before PSA tests came along, back in 1975-77, the 5 year survival rate of all prostate cancer patients were ~65% about the same as many other types of cancer like lymphoma, etc. and today it is >98%. I believe the main reason is due to PSA testing and early detection from that. Even today, if you do not take a PSA test and find out about your cancer due to having symptoms, i.e., cancer metastasizes to distant organs, the five year survival rate is <30%. If I were you, I won't ignore my PSA number and if it is high, go do a biopsy which is quite painless and then if positive, decide if you want treatment or not. Peace and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Current reading: Redefining Prostate Cancer. Overdiagnosed. The Great Prostate Hoax.

Posts.Content: Evilene, Sorry to see you here but welcome. I agree with Otago, from what I read, Prostate cancer before it escapes the capsule rarely has PSA goes up that rapidly - doubling every 4 months all of a sudden from a stable base. It could very well be infection or inflammation. However, I am not a healthcare provider and my opinion is based mainly on research and studies so could be incorrect. Do what Fairwind suggested, get a copy of Dr. Walsh's book and arm yourself with knowledge so you won't worry unnecessarily. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: First Post M- CRPC What now?

Posts.Content: markperky, Hope things work out for you and you stay in remission. However, Frenchy made a good point, when your cancer is aggressive, here in the US, many doctors want to get a jump in case the cancer has not spread and there is time to catch it. One way is get a post op PSA done at 4 to 6 weeks instead of 3 months because in your case time may be important. The second way they try to beat the cancer is to do adjuvant treatment, usually start hormone right away and after a short period of a few months do adjuvant radiation. Of course none of us are healthcare professionals so it is best you discuss all of these with your doctors. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Update on my cancer

Posts.Content: In a way picking physicians is like picking restaurants. I often judge how good a restaurant is by looking at how long the waiting queue is outside. Since there is no universal registry that rates physicians, one of the criteria I look at is how busy the surgeon is. Unfortunately, if he/she is extremely busy, he/she has very little time to answer "unimportant" questions (to them, a negative biopsy is not important). My surgeon was very nice when I met with him face to face but it is extremely difficult to get him to return my calls for general discussions/questions. Most of the time it was his PA that returned my calls. If he is very busy, very competent and you trust him, stay with him if not find someone else.
Posts.Title: Quality of service/care at major centers

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by StarsFan33 Also, he is having major swelling in his thigh/leg/feet on one side and we believe it is lymphedema. Shortly after the surgery they discovered an abseced pocket of lymph fluid in his gut that they had to drain for almost a week. now, that appears to be normal but his leg is swelling. It is almost twice the size of his other leg. In other news, while I keep reading that the hormone therapy doesn't offer a cure, according to dad's oncologist, post surgery and after adding the casodex with the shot, dads PET and PSA has come back clean and his PSA in 0. The oncologist says he is currently cancer free, but that they must monitor it because it will most likely return in the future. thoughts, comments, suggestions??? Thank you, Steve Lymphocele/lymphedema is quite rare but do happen - in about 3% of cases. I had the same thing happened to me - lymohocele/lymphedema after surgery because the surgeon took out some lymph nodes and the fluid had no place to go and accumulated inside. The swelling of the leg is related so should go away. You are right hormone is not a cure but it can keep things under control for a long time sometimes decades. Good luck.

Posts.Title: enzalutamide formerly MDV3100 approved USA as Xtandi

Posts.Content: In my non professional opinion, C-11 Choline scan should be very beneficial to determine your best treatment options. Yes, most C-11 Choline scans are used for recurrence because it is more sensitive to detecting metastasis than CT or MRI. In your case, there is still a chance for a cure if scan can identify all of the metastasis sites and if it is oligometastatic, either surgically removing them (lymph nodes or soft tissues) or spot radiating (bones). In a number of cases, that together with treating the prostate achieved lasting remission. Between 2011 and present, as part of the usual AS protocol, did your physician order at least annual biopsies to see why PSA went up so much? Perhaps the decision to treat should have been made earlier. In my opinion, you should get a second opinion/third opinion on treatment options. Good luck.

Posts.Content: nysupraman, Welcome and thanks for posting. It is normal to be heartbroken and worried. We have all been there and done that. His clinical stage is aggressive (one G4+4) but the amount of involvement is quite small. In other words, he is fortunately he caught his cancer quite early and it is very likely organ confined. Either surgery or radiation should provide an excellent chance of a "cure" or remission as some others would prefer we said. There are actually a number of excellent clinics in NY, for example Sloan Kettering is probably the best cancer center in the US if not the world. Cleveland Clinic is also one of the very best and you cannot go wrong with going there either. Don't wait to seek treatment as in his case time is of the essence. Good luck and peace be with you.

Posts.Title: Father newly diagnosed ....

Posts.Content: Do you have any family history of prostate cancer? Symptoms (higher PSA and frequent urination at night and even some positive DRE) could very well be just a case of infection. Your doctor should prescribe a course of antibiotics to rule that out. The higher PSA could also be due to other things like having sex the night before, riding a bike, and doctor performing a DRE plus a few other activities prior to taking a PSA test. By the way, a PSA of 1.5 is still on the normal side if you are over 50 years old. I would not be too concern until all other causes are ruled out. Good luck.

Posts.Title: First Time User - Seeking Advice

Posts.Content: Marathon Man, Welcome back. I am following your footstep, 3 1/2 years out with undetectable PSA and keeping my fingers crossed. Using your non < PSA numbers from Sept 2011 to Jan 2014, your doubling time is about 16 months. So, it is slow rising and if continues, will be years before you need treatment. For such slow doubling, Johns Hopkins's 30 year survival statistics were very good. Also, in your case, supplements like pomegranate juice, etc., and a healthy diets may slow PSA doubling even further and worth a try. It is also possible that your surgeon left behind a microscopic amount of benign prostate tissues and they are slowly growing larger. I had read cases where PSA slowly rising and plateau at a low level. Some oncologists sometimes try finasteride and if the PSA # went down by half and stays there, then it might be benign tissues. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Welcome and like Highlander, I thank you for your service to our country. Since the USPSTF (US Preventive Service Task Force, a penal appointed by the US Department of Health and Human Service) recommended no PSA testing in 2012, it has been the policy of Government Health Care Units to not do routine PSA test. So, you should not blame the VA, blame the US government for the VA not measuring your PSA on a routine basis. On the other hand, it sounded like your surgeon was quite bad for cutting a hole in both your bladder and rectum and was unable to extract the whole prostate! In any case a post surgery PSA of 2.33 indicated cancer is still within you so you need to continue treatment. As for a pre op PSA of 9.47, it is high but actually not too high (my pre op PSA was 10.7), indicating you cancer was probably still local. If I were you I would get a second opinion from a radiation oncologist and a prostate cancer oncologist to see if radiation is still an option now that both holes are "patched". If radiation is possible, you can still shoot for a cure instead of just controlling the cancer with Eligard. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Week 2 Update

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RILEYO Is it possible to accurately calculate PSA doubling time with an ultrasensitive assay at very low PSA levels? For example, my PSA level was at 0.028 in April 2013 and went to 0.055 in October 2014 with tests given every 2-3 months apart. PLEASE HELP ! Mathematically we can calculate the doubling time even for values less than .1 by doing so call "least square fit". However, to be accurate, more than two numbers over a period of time are needed. In your case if you only have two reading, the calculation will not be accurate and the PSADT will most likely be very misleading. If you list all of the PSA numbers and dates they were tested, I can calculate your best guess doubling time for you. Whether they are meaningful only your physician can tell you we can only offer our non professional opinions. Regards,

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gsteve Ok sorry i was in a rush. Im 52 and have low risk pc. my gleason is 6 , psa 8.4 , tc2 . biopsy showed hits in 8 of 12 . Prostate is 39cc. Im leaning towards brachy. What effect will having my prostate pretty much killed off on muscle quality , retention , strength etc? Is that the info needed? thanks sj Testosterone is not produced by the prostate so treatments, either brachy or surgery, should not affect your T level. Hormone therapy on the other hand would reduce testosterone level. Testosterone is fuel for prostate cancer so it is not advisable to take T unless you are sure the cancer is completely eliminated. With surgery, if you have undetectable PSA for a few years, some doctors would prescribe T. For brachy, sometimes PSA does not reduce to undetectable due to benign cells remaining in there. When that happens taking T is not smart. That said, with a 39cc prostate and 8 core G6, you are a good candidate for brachy. Good luck.

My Oncologist stated that Colo-rectal Cancer is possible after Rad Treatments. Posts.Title: Radiation side-effects

Posts.Content: dupres, If you don't mind can you share your biopsy results here? Most important is the extend of your positive cores. A pre treatment PSA of 29 is quite high and the extend could indicate if the cancer was localized Michael F made a good point. After primary radiation treatment PSA usually does not go to zero but remains at a low but stable level (nadir). Sometimes there is a bounce but after 5 years, it should remain at a low level. You can see how stable by looking at PSADT. If I use all the PSA numbers you posted, your doubling time is 8.4 years meaning within the measurement errors, most likely it is very stable and there is nothing to worry about (at that doubling time you will die of something else in your old age). I did a couple of additional regression analyses. Perhaps the early years did not count because of hormone, so I used the last two years' data, from 5/29/2013 to the most recent #: PSADT is now 8.9 years! I begun to see a trend only if I used the 5 most recent PSA numbers. PSADT is now 1.9 years however because the data has significant spread, I think the statistical error is too large to be meaningful. The next PSA measurement will be important to see if the trend is real. Another scenario is the base value of 1.2 indicated benign prostate tissues and the highs are caused by infection/inflammations. Do you have any symptoms of urinary infections? Anyway, the following link indicated a PSA nadir of ~1 or less produced good outcome in terms of recurrence: http://www.cancernetwork.com/article...ostic-variable I am just a layperson so discuss all of these with your RO. Best wishes.

The other point I remembered is JH's AS protocol requires one side positive and not both sides. Anyway AS is a good way to go if you fit the criteria. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo Has a state-of-the-art MRI been discussed? It would image the entire prostate and are non-evasive. Issues are: 1. State of the art 3 Tesla MRI has a resolution of ~.5cm. Even endorectal MRI is only slightly better, so, if your cancer is multi-focal or focal << .5 cm, most likely MRI won't show. There are multispectral MRI but there is no consensus if that gives a better reading. However, my knowledge of MRI is about 2 years old, so there maybe better machines and procedures out there that I am not aware of. 2. In the end, you still need a biopsy to be a definitive diagnosis. 3. We are not physicians, so, if the physician concludes, after seeing the patient, that a biopsy is needed, who are we to tell the patient that he does not need a biopsy. In my view, the best we can advice is to seek a second professional opinion. Peace.

AgeInfo.Phrase: knowledge of MRI is about 2 years old  so there maybe

If I find the online publication, I will let you know. Actually the positive of the article is that by tracking the changes, in the future, physicians could target our specific types of prostate cancers with effective target drugs and if that works, we can also track indolent vs aggressive cancer and truly able to practice AS. Posts.Content: Chiguy, Welcome. If you are serious about AS, I suggest you consult JH or UCSF as they have strict protocols on AS with great results, namely if you fit their criteria for AS, even if you later need treatment, your chance of cancer not spread is very good. My two cents: If the 9.51 PSA is real and not due to infection, with a normal size prostate it is high for a 2 core positive G6. So cancer could be more extensive. The other point I remembered is JH's AS protocol requires one side positive and not both sides. Anyway AS is a good way to go if you fit the criteria. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by shazada My father has prostate cancer and liver metastasis, wat to do? Can Anyone help me? shazada, Sorry you are here but welcome. It is unusual for prostate cancer to metastasize to the liver first unless it is an unusual kind, for example small cells or neuroendrocrine. po18guy and Highlander gave you excellent advices to seek help from a cancer center because finding out what kind is key to find the right treatments. If you can, go to Johns Hopkins or MSK which are reasonably closest to you. Perhaps, they can perform a liver biopsy to see the type of prostate cancer so a good treatment plan can be formulated. Of course I am a non healthcare professional and it is only my opinion. Good luck.

Posts.Title: New to this, Recently diagnosed with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gsteve Ok sorry i was in a rush. Im 52 and have low risk pc. my gleason is 6 , psa 8.4 , tc2 . biopsy showed hits in 8 of 12 . Prostate is 39cc. Im leaning towards brachy. What effect will having my prostate pretty much killed off on muscle quality , retention , strength etc? Is that the info needed? thanks sj Testosterone is not produced by the prostate so treatments, either brachy or surgery, should not affect your T level. Hormone therapy on the other hand would reduce testosterone level. Testosterone is fuel for prostate cancer so it is not advisable to take T unless you are sure the cancer is completely eliminated. With surgery, if you have undetectable PSA for a few years, some doctors would prescribe T. For brachy, sometimes PSA does not reduce to undetectable due to benign cells remaining in there. When that happens taking T is not smart. That said, with a 39cc prostate and 8 core G6, you are a good candidate for brachy. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Welcome. With prostate cancer, you have a lot more options. As the other posters said, you can do salvage radiation, if than fails, you can do hormone therapy and there are a lot of them available, you can also do chemo or even immunotherapy... so, you need not worry too much at this stage. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Having problems, now 11 weeks after Davinci....any suggestions welcome

Posts.Content: I searched past posts on this site and here is one from neutrondbob back in May 2011 on Zytiga that may be useful. Also, all else fail, if he had not tried Ketoconazole, a very similar drug targeting the same CYP17 enzyme and might be effective.Talk to his doctor if he has not try Keto yet. If you buy Keto from Canada, the cost is very reasonable (costs ~$100 per month?). Good luck. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- From neotrondbob: Abiraterone/Zytiga discussion fwd- J & J has financial assistance program now too Here is the good, the bad and the ugly on this from another forum where I brought up my questions, and pointed out it looks like re-engineered Ketoconazole with a huge price tag added, sure likely is better and more potent, you would think so at this price. Words below are from a leading PCa advocate on another forum whom is experienced in helping patients for many years now.--- I understand from what Robert says that there is a lot of frustration among men with advanced prostate cancer concerning cost of the newer drugs like (one cited to me today) Zytiga. I sympathize with this frustration. Zytiga doesn't impress me much. They tweaked keto. Lately a lot of tweaking of androgen blockades and chemos. Tweaking makes a difference and it also resets the price with a new patent. The new versions of old therapies will help more than a few men. Incremental improvements are important for handing advanced prostate cancer as a "chronic disease," which has been the oncologists' and pharma companies' best aim for the past decade. But these are not major game changers. Specifically regarding Zytiga - for anyone who can't afford it: Johnson and Johnson (the pharma company that bought the Zytiga patent from its start up company, Cougar) has a financial assistance program for men who qualify. They make it sound like a trip to Vegas. Here's what I know so far: ZytigaOne Instant Savings Program Flashcard. Eligible patients may qualify for instant savings on their private insurance co-pay, deductible, and co-insurance medication costs for ZYTIGA (abiraterone acetate) through ZytigaOne Instant Savings Program. If a patient qualifies and activates the ZytigaOne Instant Savings Card, the patient will pay no more than $20 per month for ZYTIGA. The program is subject to a $6,000 annual program benefit, 12 months after activation or 12 doses, whichever comes first. To activate your instant savings card or to enroll in the Instant Savings Program, click here. To learn more about the program, including eligibility and restrictions, click here. http://www.centocoraccessone.com/pag...sist/intro.jsp For men who do NOT have any private insurance, this is worth a try (same link): access2wellness. If a patient does not have coverage for ZYTIGA, access2wellness may be the gateway to assistance for eligible patients that meet specific medical and financial criteria. You can reach an access2wellness specialist at 866-317-2775, Monday through Friday, 9:00 AM to 5:00 PM ET. More information is also available at access2wellness.com. ================================================== (My words on costs: $5,000 a month for 4 pills a day vs. Keto as low as $129 for 100 ct. of 200mg thru Canadian Rx in USA dollars at www.northdrugstore.com ) Perhaps exposing such things, will bring the price down...or they may send a hit man out to find me for pointing such things out...which wouldn't surprize me in this culture today.)

Posts.Title: life after p cancer?

Posts.Content: jeepguy, Chuck is right, according to Dr. "Google": Blood in semen, also called haematospermia, can happen to men at any age after puberty. It is most common in men aged 30 to 40 years and in men over 50 years of age with benign prostate enlargement (BPH). The majority of cases go away in time without treatment. To answer your question specifically, prostate biopsy is an easy procedure and the pain/discomfort is quite minimal so if your physician orders one, don't be too concern about taking it. Our only advice is to follow the instructions carefully to avoid post biopsy infection which is more trouble than the biopsy itself. Many of us had multiple biopsies without any problem. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Biopsy or no biopsy.

Posts.Content: A recent UCLA study indicated that: Prostate cancer stem cells evolve into different cells as the disease progresses and this becomes a moving target for treatment, U.S. researchers say. Drs. Andrew Goldstein, Owen Witte and Tanya Stoyanova and colleagues at the University of California, Los Angeles' Eli and Edythe Broad Center of Regenerative Medicine and Stem Cell Research, said scientists must be prepared for the continual evolution of the stem cell as tumors adapt and become resistant to new and more potent therapies. The study, published online ahead of print in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, found prostate cancer can develop in one type of stem cell, then evolve to be maintained by a stem cell that looks very different, creating a moving target for treatments. (Adult stem cells are regenerative cells that replace diseased or damaged cells in organs. The researchers previously reported that prostate cancer can originate in basal type stem cells. The new study, based on that research, showed that tumors can start in basal stem cells that evolve to luminal cells that result in aggressive spread of the cancer and that these luminal cells can change in their characteristics over time; thus, making them resistant to treatment.) Read more: http://www.upi.com/Health_News/2013/...#ixzz2lpAoMbYT Does that mean cancer that is initially non aggressive can evolve into more aggressive cancers? Does that mean that our view that G6 will never evolve into more aggressive cancer may not be correct?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Friendly Is a little pain in the groin on the left side common with prostate radiation treatments? I have had four Radiation Treatments of the 45 ordered. Tonight I have a little pinch or pain in my groin on the left side, is this to be expected or going to get worse? I am not a health care professional so I am just speculating: I believe radiation can cause irritations to the nerve bundles that surround the prostate. Those nerve bundles control erection and sensations around the groin area so perhaps the slight groin pain is a side effect of nerve irritations. If that is the cause, it should go away after a while. You should discuss it with your radiation oncologist to make sure it is a common side effect of his treatment protocol. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Is a little pain in the groin common with prostate radiation treatments?

Posts.Content: Riding a bike for 35 miles less than 8 weeks out from surgery is a bit much in my opinion. You probably stressed or injured your sphincter muscles? Give them some rest and hopefully you will return to normal again. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Incontinence is back!

Posts.Content: Welcome. His oncologist is most up to date on the recent best practices. The most important thing is to make sure your dad is healthy enough to withstand the rigor of chemo. For some, chemo is well tolerated whereas others may not be. The thing I would do if I were you is to send his biopsy slides to Johns Hopkins or Bostwick for a second read. I would be most interested in finding out his cancer type, i.e., the most common form or the rarer forms. The treatment protocols may be different depending on that. After the second read by a US lab, you can then do a second opinion consult with a US oncologist (i.e., JH, Mayo or MDA, etc.). That can be done by telephone. Even with the cancer spreading, with the right treatment, he will be around for years, so the family should not look at it as a death sentence and make sure he knows that too. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Newbie.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bravehardon TDubb, I probably should know this but what were the staples used for? I had seen another poster on a diff site who had a nightmare experience with staples as his surgeon left several inside him, and over time they moved and caused some severe bladder damage. Brave Bravehardon, What you referred to are not staples but surgical clips used during surgery e.g. to seal blood vessels to prevent bleedings, etc. Both open and robotic surgeries use them. They are left behind after surgery. Sometimes they can migrate and cause problem. Most common is bladder neck contracture and causes urination problem. the incidences are rare and happened in less than 1% of cases. As for staples, many surgeons do not use them but use "superglue" (mine) or other means instead. Take care.

Posts.Content: Agree with JustBrandon your DH has an excellent post op pathology report, as good as they come. +PNI has no bearing on future prognosis according to some studies. I would not be too concern about not taking out lymph nodes on the left side. Most likely they are very small and unremarkable so that is why the surgeon missed them (or choose not to look for them). You need to know that many surgeons do not routinely take out lymph nodes unless the patients specifically asked them. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wam737 Thank you for the reply. He did have bone and CT scans and they all came back negative three years ago when he was initially diagnosed. Michele Miclele, your Dad's cancer is most likely systemic. He needs to consult a prostate cancer oncologist ASAP to plot his net course of action. He also needs to get bone and CT scans again to see where the cancers are now. The radiation oncologist should no longer be the one treating him now. If given proper treatments, he could still have many years ahead of him so don't delay and get treatments as soon as possible. Best of luck to him.

Posts.Title: Worried About My Dad - PSA Level 100

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Nibbs His last PSA test was this week and in the last 3 months it has risen to 90. I'm so scared the cancer is back. Obviously all the tests are being scheduled. Bone scan, CT scan, biopsy. They have started him on pills (hormone maybe?) and he will be getting the hormone shot this week. Is there anything more to do? I'm scared. I want it to be an infection....is there a high chance of that at all? Any stories here about PSA rising after treatment and such? Sorry you are here and sorry about your Dad's situation. He had radiation and hormone, PSA went to zero for a while and came back so I am afraid he has what we call a BCR (biochemical recurrence) meaning cancer is back. It is not likely the PSA rise is due to infection. You need to find him an oncologist that specializes in prostate cancer and get the best treatments possible. There are many new medications that can control the growth of prostate cancer and he can still live a very long and productive life under treatment. Good luck.

Posts.Title: My Dad, in remission 1 year, now PSA rise...so worried

Posts.Content: Fatherbuild, If you search many of the posts here you will find testicular swelling is very normal and it should subside. As for pain in the bottom of his feet, that is more unusual but many posters had pain in a lot of other areas after surgery. The good news is eventually they all reported the pains went away or reduced significantly after allowing sufficient time to heal. We all heal differently so some will take longer. I am not a healthcare provider so it is just layperson opinion: His surgeon decided to "go aggressive" with the surgery. Very likely he/she disturbed or damaged some nerves. The nerves that are around the prostate touch many of the lower half of our body including our legs. It is entirely possible those are affected and if so, they will heal and go away in time. Tell your Dad not to worry too much and concentrate on healing. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Brand New

Posts.Content: Pratoman, I know you are the worrying type so want to make sure everything is exactly correct. Sometimes the surgeon's support staffs did not know the exact situation and might have embellished. If indeed this is the case, it said your surgeon had done an excellent job of looking out for you and it is indeed a negative margin case so you have nothing to worry about. Many times, the surgeon will cut widely just to make sure he got it all. Under the 10X magnifications of a Da Vinci camera, he could see a lot more clearly but yours did it even better by taking it to the pathologist before he closed you up. I read a detail surgery report of my relative's surgery two years ago: The surgeon did not like the look at the bladder neck and cut out a chunk more. After taking out the prostate, she took out a lot of the surrounding fatty tissues and lymph nodes because she wanted to make sure. Turned out cancer invaded the bladder neck and some fatty tissues. So far, his PSA is undetectable. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: New to this, Recently diagnosed with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: As a surgery guy: I was back to my normal routines after the catheter came out in 7 days. However, I was not allowed to lift anything over 5 (or 10?) lb or to perform normal physical activities (playing sports) for four weeks. I took an overseas trip (16 hrs flight) two months after surgery without any problem. If you select radiation, you should have it even easier as most posters said. You have a fairly aggressive case, so do not delay. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Do You Keep Working ?

Posts.Content: Welcome back. We are thrilled and happy that your outcome is so successful. Your Kaiser surgeon is one of the best in SoCal so your outcome is not a surprise. Whether someone with your stats should seek treatment is a controversial subject with no easy answers. The choice is personal no one else but you, with recommendation from your physician, can decide. Hope you have many many years of undetectable PSA. Best wishes.
Posts.Signature: PCa Dx 2010 at 65. PSA increased from 2.5 in 2000 to 10.7 in 2010. Four biopsies in 6 years. Final biopsy in 2010: 1 of 12 cores 5% cancer, G6 CT, bone scans & MRI all negative Da Vinci 8/10; nerve sparing, catheter out in 7 days; no incontinence, no ED Post Op Pathology pT2N0Mx: organ confined; negative margins; lymph nodes & seminal vesicle not involved but PNI present; cancer extensive within prostate, multifocal G 3+3 and tertiary G 4 Infected lymphocele diagnosed and treated in 2014, 4 yrs after RALP PSA <.1 for the past 6 years.
Posts.Title: Living and Loving Life

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo Has a state-of-the-art MRI been discussed? It would image the entire prostate and are non-evasive. Issues are: 1. State of the art 3 Tesla MRI has a resolution of ~.5cm. Even endorectal MRI is only slightly better, so, if your cancer is multi-focal or focal << .5 cm, most likely MRI won't show. There are multispectral MRI but there is no consensus if that gives a better reading. However, my knowledge of MRI is about 2 years old, so there maybe better machines and procedures out there that I am not aware of. 2. In the end, you still need a biopsy to be a definitive diagnosis. 3. We are not physicians, so, if the physician concludes, after seeing the patient, that a biopsy is needed, who are we to tell the patient that he does not need a biopsy. In my view, the best we can advice is to seek a second professional opinion. Peace.

AgeInfo.Phrase: knowledge of MRI is about 2 years old  so there maybe

Posts.Title: Biopsy or no biopsy.

Posts.Content: jeepguy, Chuck is right, according to Dr. "Google": Blood in semen, also called haematospermia, can happen to men at any age after puberty. It is most common in men aged 30 to 40 years and in men over 50 years of age with benign prostate enlargement (BPH). The majority of cases go away in time without treatment. To answer your question specifically, prostate biopsy is an easy procedure and the pain/discomfort is quite minimal so if your physician orders one, don't be too concern about taking it. Our only advice is to follow the instructions carefully to avoid post biopsy infection which is more trouble than the biopsy itself. Many of us had multiple biopsies without any problem. Good luck.

When it came back positive, the Surgeon cut more, and sent it for Frozen Section and it came back Negative. So they stopped cutting. They didn't take any of my nerve bundles (near the Apex, I believe). Are you sure this is what happened? Did you speak with your surgeon about this? If not, you should talk to him directly.

Posts.Title: Cancer at the Apex

Posts.Content: Pratoman, I know you are the worrying type so want to make sure everything is exactly correct. Sometimes the surgeon's support staffs did not know the exact situation and might have embellished. If indeed this is the case, it said your surgeon had done an excellent job of looking out for you and it is indeed a negative margin case so you have nothing to worry about. Many times, the surgeon will cut widely just to make sure he got it all. Under the 10X magnifications of a Da Vinci camera, he could see a lot more clearly but yours did it even better by taking it to the pathologist before he closed you up. I read a detail surgery report of my relative's surgery two years ago: The surgeon did not like the look at the bladder neck and cut out a chunk more. After taking out the prostate, she took out a lot of the surrounding fatty tissues and lymph nodes because she wanted to make sure. Turned out cancer invaded the bladder neck and some fatty tissues. So far, his PSA is undetectable. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: External Radiation options

Posts.Content: No blood vessel or lymphatic tutor invasion found No extraprostatic tumor extension present No seminal vesicle involvement by tumor present No perineural tumor invasion found No tumor invasion of prostate capsule present Adenofibromatous Prostatic Hyperplasia of non-neoplastic prostate tissue These are excellent outcome and I am glad you chose not to wait as your cancer is 75% Grade 4. Also, the pathologist did note that there were no blood vessel and lymphatic tumor found so most likely lymph nodes if taken out would have been negative. Congratulations for an excellent outcome!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FeatherBoy Well Guys, Looks like I will be leaving the '<0.1 Club'. You maybe experiencing PSA bounce after radiation treatment. It is not uncommon to have 1 to 2 bounces after treatment, so don't throw in the towel yet. Your nadir is undetectable which is also a very good sign. According to Johns Hopkins, those with nadir <.1 had excellent long term survival records and you will see your grand daughter grow up. Good luck.

Posts.Title: It's Been Fun.

Posts.Content: Fatherbuild, If you search many of the posts here you will find testicular swelling is very normal and it should subside. As for pain in the bottom of his feet, that is more unusual but many posters had pain in a lot of other areas after surgery. The good news is eventually they all reported the pains went away or reduced significantly after allowing sufficient time to heal. We all heal differently so some will take longer. I am not a healthcare provider so it is just layperson opinion: His surgeon decided to "go aggressive" with the surgery. Very likely he/she disturbed or damaged some nerves. The nerves that are around the prostate touch many of the lower half of our body including our legs. It is entirely possible those are affected and if so, they will heal and go away in time. Tell your Dad not to worry too much and concentrate on healing. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Post radical laparoscopic prostatectomy concerns

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Badger199 Just about everything has gone wrong - keyhole surgery was abandoned and after 2 hours in theatre the surgeon had to resort to full open surgery, wound opened up after 12 days, urinary infection and now an extra week with catheter. Is anything going to be straightforward for me I wonder! Think of the positives. There was a reason they had to abandon keyhole, could be scar tissues, adhesions or too much fatty tissues, etc. You are actually fortunate your surgeon (or someone) was able to revert to open and finished it. Imagine the alternative if they could not find someone experienced enough to do open at the time? Also, with urinary infection and the risks of stricture, blockage, etc., it is best to leave the catheter in a little longer. If they took out the catheter too soon and there was blockage, you could end up in the emergency room. I don't recall reading any report that tied incontinence to how long the catheter is in. I think it mostly depends on how much of the sphincter muscles the surgeon can spare. Give yourself time to heal and this shall pass. In a few months, all these will be distant memories. I wish you a great recovery.
Posts.Title: can't get rid of this catheter

Posts.Content: FeatherBoy, Welcome to the other side. Your post op pathology report is very good except for the positive surgical margins. On the other hand, according to Dr. Walsh's book, positive margins do not means the surgery failed and based on your stats, there is a good chance your treatment is curative. Concentrate on your recovery and hope everything works out for you.
Posts.Title: Yet ANOTHER Newbie Looking For Good Company In "The Club".

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FeatherBoy Adjuvant or salvage. With adjuvant, I start radiation now even with a zero PSA based on the positive margins. With salvage, We wait and see what happens down the line. My MAIN concern is if I opt for salvage, if and when it becomes necessary, am I increasing my risk for distant mets? I'm not as concerned about treatment side effects as I am in eradicating the cancer! I'm sort of asking, what would you guys choose if this was your case? Thanks for any input! Welcome back! You asked a question that no one has an answer, not even the best urologist or oncologist. With your stat my guess is most doctors would recommend wait and see. There were some studies indicated for advanced and aggressive cancer, adjuvant had a survival advantage but for early stage like yours, I had not come across any studies favoring adjuvant treatment. Dr. Walsh mentioned in his book that positive margins did not automatically meant some cancer cells were left behind. For me personally, I tend to be aggressive and if I had an advanced case, I would go for broke and throw everything at it. However, if I had your case, I would wait. Just a personal opinion and not a medical advice.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Nibbs His last PSA test was this week and in the last 3 months it has risen to 90. I'm so scared the cancer is back. Obviously all the tests are being scheduled. Bone scan, CT scan, biopsy. They have started him on pills (hormone maybe?) and he will be getting the hormone shot this week. Is there anything more to do? I'm scared. I want it to be an infection....is there a high chance of that at all? Any stories here about PSA rising after treatment and such? Sorry you are here and sorry about your Dad's situation. He had radiation and hormone, PSA went to zero for a while and came back so I am afraid he has what we call a BCR (biochemical recurrence) meaning cancer is back. It is not likely the PSA rise is due to infection. You need to find him an oncologist that specializes in prostate cancer and get the best treatments possible. There are many new medications that can control the growth of prostate cancer and he can still live a very long and productive life under treatment. Good luck.

Posts.Content: The jury is still out on this issue. Many physicians believe G6 will not evolve into G7,8,9 and there are many studies that supported this. However, there are also researchers that believed G6 could evolve. Here are two research articles that supported this view: The first indicated there are genetic evidence that G6 can evolve into more aggressive forms. And this seems logical since cancer is believed to evolve due to mutations and if so G6 can mutate as easily as a normal cells, in fact logic would conclude that cells that already mutated perhaps can mutate faster vs normal cells? http://cancerres.aacrjournals.org/co...73/3/1050.full The second indicated that clinical G6 could still die from metastasized cancer http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/1...28102/abstract Bottom line: Keep checking your PSA and don't take things for granted. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Does a G6 PCa grow to G7, G8, G9 PCa

Posts.Content: CPO2CWO, In spite of my prior post, I believe it is safe to say that most G6 will not morph into G7,8,9 and it is a very low risk cancer as numerous studies confirmed that cancer death from G6 is very low (but not zero - from a Johns Hopkins study). Another point, Gleason grades and scores are not objective grades but subjective based on the opinions of the trained pathologists, so if they said you were a G6, were you really a G6?. My post was not intended to contradict conventional wisdom but to point out there are always exceptions and variations and as laypersons we should seek expert advices when in doubt. Your post op outcome and pathology report are as good as they come and your long term prognosis should be excellent. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Congratulation on a wonderful outcome. The leakage should heal after a few months. I recommend you read Dr. Walsh's book especially the section on side effects after surgery and radiation. He said it could take up to 18-24 months for side effects (incontinence and ED) to heal. In the mean time, like the others said, do your Kegel but do not overdo. Also avoid some beverages like beer, coffee etc. Someone said some types of beverages may cause leakage in the first few months after surgery as they might affect the sphincter muscles' function . I don't know if that is true but no harm trying. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OTCHU on the 13 samples, 3 are bad .... here the numbers, if somebody can explain me ... I dont understand : Core(cm) Gleason %PCA 1.5 3+3 5% 1.0 3+3 <5% 1.1 3+4 5% so the doctor told me that I will have to choose my options: - remove with a robot the prostate - freeze the prostate - radiation Please guys, I need some advices .... I am so young for that Sorry you are joining our club but welcome. Relax, most likely you can be cured if you choose a good treatment plan that fits your situation. The side effects of surgery and radiation are real but most were able to lead a normal life without incontinence. ED is a tougher challenge but again even if you have ED, with medication it can be managed. With a PSA of 2.86 and Gleason score of 3+3, 3+3 and 3+4, your cancer is early stage and the Gleason 3+4 indicated a small sample of the cancer cells are intermediate aggressive (the second # is the minority sample, 4 indicated more aggressive cancer cells). Here is what your biopsy basically said: They took out 13 cores (samples) and 3 of the samples are positive for cancer. The cores they took out ranged from 1 cm to 1.5 cm long and only 5% of the cores that are positive showed cancer and of those, most are low grade (Gleason 3+3). So, it is actually not a bad situation for you. It means very early stage and you have a good chance for a cure if you choose the appropriate treatment. What should you do? First of all ask the urologist (doctor) to send the slides to a different pathologist for a second opinion. It is important to confirm the Gleason scores (3+3, 3+3 and 3+4) because the scores will tell you what path to take. Second, read up on the subject, perhaps buy and read Dr. Walsh's book on Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. You will find that you have lots of treatment options and you have to select the plan that is most comfortable to you. Surgery and radiation offers equal outcome in terms of cancer cure but slightly different outcome in side effects. There is no right or wrong choice, whatever you choose will be the right one for you. Third, find the best surgeon or best radiation oncologist you can find and have him/her performed the treatment you selected. The outcome depends more on the doctor's skill that the treatment options. Good luck

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OTCHU on the 13 samples, 3 are bad .... here the numbers, if somebody can explain me ... I dont understand : Core(cm) Gleason %PCA 1.5 3+3 5% 1.0 3+3 <5% 1.1 3+4 5% so the doctor told me that I will have to choose my options: - remove with a robot the prostate - freeze the prostate - radiation Please guys, I need some advices .... I am so young for that Sorry you are joining our club but welcome. Relax, most likely you can be cured if you choose a good treatment plan that fits your situation. The side effects of surgery and radiation are real but most were able to lead a normal life without incontinence. ED is a tougher challenge but again even if you have ED, with medication it can be managed. With a PSA of 2.86 and Gleason score of 3+3, 3+3 and 3+4, your cancer is early stage and the Gleason 3+4 indicated a small sample of the cancer cells are intermediate aggressive (the second # is the minority sample, 4 indicated more aggressive cancer cells). Here is what your biopsy basically said: They took out 13 cores (samples) and 3 of the samples are positive for cancer. The cores they took out ranged from 1 cm to 1.5 cm long and only 5% of the cores that are positive showed cancer and of those, most are low grade (Gleason 3+3). So, it is actually not a bad situation for you. It means very early stage and you have a good chance for a cure if you choose the appropriate treatment. What should you do? First of all ask the urologist (doctor) to send the slides to a different pathologist for a second opinion. It is important to confirm the Gleason scores (3+3, 3+3 and 3+4) because the scores will tell you what path to take. Second, read up on the subject, perhaps buy and read Dr. Walsh's book on Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. You will find that you have lots of treatment options and you have to select the plan that is most comfortable to you. Surgery and radiation offers equal outcome in terms of cancer cure but slightly different outcome in side effects. There is no right or wrong choice, whatever you choose will be the right one for you. Third, find the best surgeon or best radiation oncologist you can find and have him/her performed the treatment you selected. The outcome depends more on the doctor's skill that the treatment options. Good luck

Posts.Title: biopsy result yesterday ... I have prostate cancer at 40 years old. Need advices

Posts.Content: Radiologists are trained to "read everything". So, a well trained one will point out anything that is suspected or abnormal or unusual. Heterogenous signal could mean a lot of different things like inflammation, BPH, cancer.... and without a biopsy, one cannot rule out anything. However, the fact that you had two separate MRI and both indicated the same and no changes, and that your PSA is normal means probably you just have to keep watching things and not have to do anything at this stage. Of course I am not a healthcare professional, so please get advice from a real physician. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by J. Geerlings Do i have time to decide? Please help!!!!!!!!!!!!! Don't panic, you have time to decide. In fact do not rush into any treatment until you are totally comfortable with your choice. You have one shot to do it right, so choose carefully. By the way, in your case, both surgery and radiation are good options, it is more a personal preference than which is a better outcome. That said, you are young and physically very fit, so, surgery is a good option. I exercised for two months prior to surgery and that helped with recovery. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Wheelar

Posts.Content: hope, I am very sorry to hear about your husband's advanced prostate cancer. If your husband is still been cared for by his urologist, the best advice the others gave you is you and him should consult an oncologist specializing in prostate cancer to get the best treatment protocol for his special situation. Manipulating and cycling through different drugs seems to be an art and some oncologist are better at it then others. There are quite a few new prostate cancer drugs/chemos and treatments approved by the FDA recently that can be relied upon after primary hormone treatments failure. So, he has a lot of options. Best of luck to both of you.

Posts.Title: Did you get anesthesia during your biopsy?

Posts.Content: The standard definition of a failed radiation treatment is a PSA of nadir+2. You reached nadir in May 2011, if PSA bounces around 1.2 to 1.4, I would not worry. My friend's PSA after SRT went from undetectable to about 1 within a year but then stayed at 1 for many years since. That said, the last # of 1.7 is worrisome, hopefully just a random fluctuation. Your urologist is correct to want to see your PSA in three months. Using your last 6 PSA #, your doubling time is about 1.7 years. It would be about 2 years without the last PSA #. So, yes, long term it is slowly going up. With that doubling time, most likely you will die of something else and not prostate cancer. Also, you should have plenty of time to consider if you want treatment or not. Good luck with the next PSA test.
Posts.Title: post radiation PSA results at 18 months after treatment completed

Posts.Content: the pathologist looked for primary (>50%), secondary (<50%) cancer types (grades), so in your case, >50% were grade 3, <50% were grade 4. Then, he saw small samples of more aggressive cells, he called them out as tertiary with a grade of 5. It indicated some cancer cells started to mutate into more aggressive type. With all negative margins, consider yourself fortunate that you caught yours early before the grade 5 spread and tertiary becomes secondary or even primary. Best wishes and good luck.

Posts.Title: I don't like this club!!

Posts.Content: Even the most famous prostate cancer surgeon Dr. Walsh agreed that modern radiation treatment is as effective and in certain cases more so than surgery. You are about to embark on a very lonely journey in trying to decide on the treatment path. No one can decide for you, not even your doctor. So, read, research, discuss, consult and select your path, then relax and be at peace with your choice. The good news is that you catch yours early and with your stats, you can shoot for a "cure" either with surgery or with radiation. Being a young 54 year old, you should have many years of good life ahead of you. Welcome to the club and best wishes.
