Posts.Title: Deciding on course of therapy - Surgery vs Brachytherapy

Posts.Content: cy7, I admire your courage and attitude and hope your medical team can find a way to keep your cancer at bay for a long time. Reading your signature, I noticed you have the aggressive form of ductal adenocarcinoma and your medical team is providing you with the best treatment protocol so there is nothing we can add. On the other hand, you might want to discuss testing for genetic markers (e.g., BRCA1/BRCA2, etc.) with your doctors and see if that might help design a more specific treatment protocol. In breast cancer, those that carry specific genetic markers can be treated more effectively with specific chemo drugs and I am wondering if similar effectiveness can happen with prostate cancer, or at the very least you maybe able to sign up for a clinical trial. Of course I am not a healthcare professional so it is pure speculations on mine part and not clinical advices. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Xtandi and Zytiga

Posts.Content: You should discuss with your doctor the risks of taking Proscar. Here is the FDA's safety announcement in 2011 regarding this class of medications use to treat BPH: FDA Safety Announcement [6-9-2011] The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is informing healthcare professionals that the Warnings and Precautions section of the labels for the 5-alpha reductase inhibitor (5-ARI) class of drugs has been revised to include new safety information about the increased risk of being diagnosed with a more serious form of prostate cancer (high-grade prostate cancer). This risk appears to be low, but healthcare professionals should be aware of this safety information, and weigh the known benefits against the potential risks when deciding to start or continue treatment with 5-ARIs in men. Facts about 5-ARIs Drugs in this class are finasteride (marketed as Proscar [finasteride 5 mg] and Propecia [finasteride 1 mg]) and dutasteride (marketed as Avodart). Dutasteride is also available in combination with tamsulosin, under the brand-name Jalyn. Proscar, Avodart, and Jalyn are approved to improve symptoms of an enlarged prostate gland (benign prostatic hyperplasia or BPH). Proscar and Avodart are also approved to reduce the risk of urinary retention or surgery related to an enlarged prostate. Propecia is approved to treat male pattern hair loss. Approximately 5 million male patients received a prescription for a 5-ARI between years 2002 to 2009. Of these, nearly 3 million patients were between the ages of 50 to 79 years.1 The new safety information is based on FDAs review of two large, randomized controlled trialsthe Prostate Cancer Prevention Trial (PCPT) and the Reduction by Dutasteride of Prostate Cancer Events (REDUCE) trialwhich evaluated daily use of finasteride 5 mg versus placebo for 7 years and daily use of dutasteride 0.5 mg versus placebo for 4 years, respectively, for the reduction in the risk of prostate cancer in men at least 50 years of age. The trials demonstrated an overall reduction in prostate cancer diagnoses with finasteride 5 mg and dutasteride treatment (see Data Summary below). This overall reduction was due to a decreased incidence of lower risk forms of prostate cancer. However, both trials showed an increased incidence of high-grade prostate cancer with finasteride and dutasteride treatment. For more information about this safety issue, also refer to the Questions and Answers. Many doctors disagree with the FDA and continue to prescribe them but some doctors are more cautious. I read the results of the clinical trials and according to my non professional view, the results of increased risk of higher grade cancers were statistically significant, and cannot be easily explained away, that is why the FDA warning. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Decisions

Posts.Content: ashie85, Very sorry you are here but welcome. Fairwind gave you an excellent response to your questions. Your Dad definitely has a very aggressive prostate cancer and for stage 4 a cure is currently not possible. However, there are a number of hormone and chemo drugs available to slow down the cancer. Typically, each will work for a period of time, maybe months maybe years. When they stop working, the doctor will try another and another... For some, it went on for years (one of my former colleagues has been on hormone for 15 years!) while for others, it stopped working after a couple of years. Get a good oncologist to take over and manage his disease. Treating metastasized prostate cancer requires someone specializes in prostate cancer to get optimum outcome. Best of luck to you and don't give up hope.

Posts.Title: My dad has stage 4 prostate cancer :(

Posts.Content: Kazzie61, In addition to what HighlandCFH said, another important point is to ask him about going forward plans. With aggressive cases, one should prepare for the worst but hope for the best. Hopefully everything will work out for him but ask his urologist about his views on adjuvant vs salvage radiation and if he recommend going ahead with adjuvant, would he also recommend adding hormone therapy prior/during/after adjuvant radiation. There were studies that indicated for very high risk cases, adjuvant radiation plus hormone offers better odds of getting rid of the cancer. Also ask him for a referral to a radiation oncologist and/or an oncologist for a second opinion consult. Best of luck to you and your husband.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobertG Kind of confused by what I'm reading here - is surgery generally preferred if you are younger? I'm guessing with the Gleason 7 on the left side the best I could hope for is single nerve sparing, correct? I am pro surgery because I wanted to find out the extent of my cancer and only surgery allowed me to see the pathology of the prostate. And I always tried to avoid radiation as much as I could. But I admit the cancer control outcome for guys with your stats should be about the same and in more advanced cases radiation is actually better. Therefore in your case it is a matter of personal preference and your physical conditions. The only advice is whichever you choose, find a skill practitioner, one that has many many treatments under his/her belt. Quote comments: No so. G7 on one side has nothing to do with nerve sparing or not. Nerve sparing depends on the skill of your surgeon and how close the cancers are to the nerves. Good luck and take care.

Posts.Content: Tom C, Sorry you are here but welcome. Urologist can usually guesstimate what your "normal" psa should be by using your prostate size and made some assumptions. If your prostate is small and the cancer is minute, a low psa is usually good news. However, as Fairwind said, some prostate cancer cells do not produce psa and those are usually very aggressive. Your biopsy clinical report should identify the type of cancer cells they found. If they are the garden variety adenocarcinoma, you are probably very early stage and perhaps could do AS for many years without problem. You should get a second opinion from an expert pathologist, e.g. Johns Hopkins, to make sure the cancer is the garden variety type. If you want additional input from others, you might want to post your stats here. For example, JohnT, a regular poster here, uses (.066 x prostate volume) to calculate what your "normal" psa should be. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dmm1987 I am trying to find information about the death rate is while on the table for this surgery and I am struggling finding information. Very rare, far fewer than the oft quoted number of 1 in 100 or 1 in 200 you read in forums. In one Swedish study of 3700 surgeries, only 4 died within the first 30 days after surgery. My surgeon performed over 1500 Da Vinci and had no fatality. So, you and your father can relax and get ready for the surgery. A good suggestion is to prepare by exercising and keeping in good physical shape prior to surgery, not for death but faster recovery.

After subsequent research, I mentioned that the score could be affected and he should mention it to his doctor. In Asia, men at the golden age, often are reluctant to mention they have sexual needs and activities. They would often be judged as inappropriate individuals, especially by the younger generation, like one's children. Often men would not want to mention their medical conditions to their family, as they fear it would cause worries and fears. So I will try to find a way to get the info without being too investigative. Will get back soon. Many thanks Chuck. The info is fantastic! Best, A Welcome. Sounds like he had a biopsy. This is what he should ask his doctor about the biopsy results: 1. How many samples were taken and how many showed cancer? 2. What are the Gleason scores. They range from6 to 10, 6 being the least aggressive and 10 the most aggressive. 3. What was the pathologist's staging? Tx, where x is between 1 and 4. 1 and 2 usually mean cancer is confined within the prostate and 3 or 4 mean it has spread outside the prostate. Don't be bashful, ask because it affects what treatment he will have to take and his chance of survival. Based on his age and PSA reading, my guess is his is not the aggressive type and will be OK, so don't worry too much. Best wishes and good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by glock19 All of my 6 incisions have finally healed over and quit leaking. The last 2 nights I was able to sleep a bit on my side instead of my back...what a relief! I'm still having some sharp pains if I sit any length of time, bend the wrong way, or make any sudden moves. I suppose it's normal after everything was moved and poked during the surgery. How long does this last? A couple of Tylenol in the AM and PM seem to help. Where is the pain? If it is near the incision sites it should go away soon? If not near the incision sites and you also have other symptoms like a fever you need to consult your surgeon. One thing few surgeons talk about post op is the possibility of lymphedema and lymphocele. Do you have leg swelling post surgery and is the pain near the lower abdomen? Lymphocele is a collection of lymphatic fluid in the lower abdominal cavity. Usually it is asymptomatic and goes away after a short period but if it gets infected it can cause pain in that area. You had a successful surgery and lets hope it is just a case of simple recovery. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Fairwind, I have been thinking about your case a lot lately. I am not a physician or in the healthcare field so my comments are purely speculative: 1. Most physicians in the US practice evidence based medicine namely unless a treatment showed demonstrable results from a clinical trial, they won't prescribe it. It is all good and it is what made modern medicine so effective. However, in some situations when there is a predictable eventual bad outcome like CRPC, that maybe too conservative. Cases like what I mentioned will probably not be in a lot of physician's treatment repertoire even if the patient will eventually becomes CRPC. 2. What do hormone therapies do to prostate cancer cells and the non scientific answer is they "kill" them or at least "starve" and make them dormant. So, since some small percentages do not respond to the first line treatment, eventually as the treatable ones are "killed off" the non-treatable ones will take over. The obvious answer to me is if one can find some combination that works for all, and typically medication works when the cancers are not overwhelming, it may be a winning strategy to the patient. A patient of one and not statistics. 3. That to me explained perhaps why the combination of Xtandi and Provenge worked in that particular case. To get general acceptance, it will take an expensive clinical trial and a few more years whereas guys might not have a few more years. 4. The case parallels HIV and AIDS in that what eventually worked was a "cocktail" of medicines. In breast cancer, the physicians are more aggressive and combination/adjuvant treatments are now a norm for aggressive cases (my wife's situation and it worked so far after 10 years). 5. So, current way of sequencing drugs will eventually fail as the remaining cancer cells will prevail or mutate into drug resistant kind. 6. The challenge is all hormone/cancer treatments have bad side effects and a combination of a few may cause the side effects to be worst than the "cure". However, there must be some physicians who are willing to try, perhaps a reduced doses of the drugs but in combination to give the same "side effect strength" but kill off all cancer types. 7. I had decided if I were ever in your situation, I would be aggressively pursuing a combination of all the new medications and will try to find a physician who is willing to work with me and there are a few on my short list. Again, this is not advice and is just pure speculation. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Fairwind & Old Sailor, My heart goes out to both of you. Those of us who are not facing CRPC just cannot imagine how you feel. I know it is easy for me to say not to give up but I think the data for prolonged survivals and success stories are real and not hype, especially for those that are at the beginning like in your cases. Here is one case published in Feb 2013 where combining Xtandi and Provenge provided complete response: Complete biochemical (prostate-specific antigen) response to sipuleucel-T with enzalutamide in castration-resistant prostate cancer: a case report with implications for future research. Graff JN, Drake CG, Beer TM. Portland Veterans Affairs Medical Center, Portland, OR 97239, USA. [email protected] Abstract OBJECTIVE: To describe the case of a patient with castration-resistant, metastatic prostate cancer who achieved a complete and durable biochemical response after treatment with sipuleucel-T while continuing with enzalutamide and to explore the immunologic basis for such a response. MATERIALS AND METHODS: We obtained serial prostate-specific antigen (PSA) measurements and bone scans to assess the patient's response to enzalutamide followed by the addition of sipuleucel-T. Using preclinical and clinical data, we describe his response through known immunobiologic mechanisms. RESULTS: This patient's PSA level became undetectable during treatment with enzalutamide and began to increase again after 14 months. He opted for treatment with sipuleucel-T, while continuing with the enzalutamide. This resulted in another complete PSA response 6 months after exposure to sipuleucel-T. CONCLUSION: Sipuleucel-T typically does not produce significant PSA reductions, and, to the best of our knowledge, only 1 previous report of a durable complete PSA response in a patient with metastatic disease has been published. The timing of this response supports an immune mechanism. The biologic rationale for the combination, coupled with the clinical result observed in our patient, provides a basis for studies of the combination of sipuleucel-T and enzalutamide. Published by Elsevier Inc. PMID: 23374810 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE] Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Content: Fairwind, I have been thinking about your case a lot lately. I am not a physician or in the healthcare field so my comments are purely speculative: 1. Most physicians in the US practice evidence based medicine namely unless a treatment showed demonstrable results from a clinical trial, they won't prescribe it. It is all good and it is what made modern medicine so effective. However, in some situations when there is a predictable eventual bad outcome like CRPC, that maybe too conservative. Cases like what I mentioned will probably not be in a lot of physician's treatment repertoire even if the patient will eventually becomes CRPC. 2. What do hormone therapies do to prostate cancer cells and the non scientific answer is they "kill" them or at least "starve" and make them dormant. So, since some small percentages do not respond to the first line treatment, eventually as the treatable ones are "killed off" the non-treatable ones will take over. The obvious answer to me is if one can find some combination that works for all, and typically medication works when the cancers are not overwhelming, it may be a winning strategy to the patient. A patient of one and not statistics. 3. That to me explained perhaps why the combination of Xtandi and Provenge worked in that particular case. To get general acceptance, it will take an expensive clinical trial and a few more years whereas guys might not have a few more years. 4. The case parallels HIV and AIDS in that what eventually worked was a "cocktail" of medicines. In breast cancer, the physicians are more aggressive and combination/adjuvant treatments are now a norm for aggressive cases (my wife's situation and it worked so far after 10 years). 5. So, current way of sequencing drugs will eventually fail as the remaining cancer cells will prevail or mutate into drug resistant kind. 6. The challenge is all hormone/cancer treatments have bad side effects and a combination of a few may cause the side effects to be worst than the "cure". However, there must be some physicians who are willing to try, perhaps a reduced doses of the drugs but in combination to give the same "side effect strength" but kill off all cancer types. 7. I had decided if I were ever in your situation, I would be aggressively pursuing a combination of all the new medications and will try to find a physician who is willing to work with me and there are a few on my short list. Again, this is not advice and is just pure speculation. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: I am sorry your husband has ductal adenocarcinoma. You are correct, it is quite rare and usually more aggressive than acinar adenocarcinoma. You probably will not find too many of us having direct personal experiences. However, from what I understand, the normal treatment protocols work for this type of prostate cancer (as opposed to small cell prostate cancer, for example). Since it is quite rare, it is better to get treatments from a national cancer center like MD Anderson, Mayo Clinics, Memorial Sloan-Kettering or UCSF, etc. I have seen articles published by MD Anderson physicians (and others) on metastasized ductal adenocarcinoma and indicated standard treatment protocols worked well with 5 year survival in the seventy percentiles range with many patients surviving much longer than 5 years. So, do not give up hope and seek treatment as soon as possible. Good luck to you and your husband.

Posts.Content: I am sorry your husband is joining our rank but we welcome him with open arms and hope he can beat this disease. I agree with the above posts. You and your husband need a second opinion regarding treatment options other than surgery. A Gleason 9 is aggressive, especially with all cores positive and a PSA of >80. In his case, radiation and hormone treatment maybe a better approach and could be curative. However, we are not healthcare professionals so it is just our layperson's opinion. But, we have read many many cases on this site from people with different background and diagnoses and your husband's case fits more with the profiles of folks who chose radiation + hormone treatment. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Content: I am sorry your husband is joining our rank but we welcome him with open arms and hope he can beat this disease. I agree with the above posts. You and your husband need a second opinion regarding treatment options other than surgery. A Gleason 9 is aggressive, especially with all cores positive and a PSA of >80. In his case, radiation and hormone treatment maybe a better approach and could be curative. However, we are not healthcare professionals so it is just our layperson's opinion. But, we have read many many cases on this site from people with different background and diagnoses and your husband's case fits more with the profiles of folks who chose radiation + hormone treatment. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Xtandi, Zytiga, Radium-223, Provenge Success Stories?

Posts.Content: Fairwind & Old Sailor, My heart goes out to both of you. Those of us who are not facing CRPC just cannot imagine how you feel. I know it is easy for me to say not to give up but I think the data for prolonged survivals and success stories are real and not hype, especially for those that are at the beginning like in your cases. Here is one case published in Feb 2013 where combining Xtandi and Provenge provided complete response: Complete biochemical (prostate-specific antigen) response to sipuleucel-T with enzalutamide in castration-resistant prostate cancer: a case report with implications for future research. Graff JN, Drake CG, Beer TM. Portland Veterans Affairs Medical Center, Portland, OR 97239, USA. [email protected] Abstract OBJECTIVE: To describe the case of a patient with castration-resistant, metastatic prostate cancer who achieved a complete and durable biochemical response after treatment with sipuleucel-T while continuing with enzalutamide and to explore the immunologic basis for such a response. MATERIALS AND METHODS: We obtained serial prostate-specific antigen (PSA) measurements and bone scans to assess the patient's response to enzalutamide followed by the addition of sipuleucel-T. Using preclinical and clinical data, we describe his response through known immunobiologic mechanisms. RESULTS: This patient's PSA level became undetectable during treatment with enzalutamide and began to increase again after 14 months. He opted for treatment with sipuleucel-T, while continuing with the enzalutamide. This resulted in another complete PSA response 6 months after exposure to sipuleucel-T. CONCLUSION: Sipuleucel-T typically does not produce significant PSA reductions, and, to the best of our knowledge, only 1 previous report of a durable complete PSA response in a patient with metastatic disease has been published. The timing of this response supports an immune mechanism. The biologic rationale for the combination, coupled with the clinical result observed in our patient, provides a basis for studies of the combination of sipuleucel-T and enzalutamide. Published by Elsevier Inc. PMID: 23374810 [PubMed - indexed for MEDLINE] Good luck and best wishes.

AgeInfo.Phrase: best of our knowledge  only 1 previous report of a durable

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kazzie61 Hi, My husband had a RP 3 weeks ago and has already been told he'll need radiotherapy. On his post op appt on June 14th which will be 4.5 weeks after the op we'll find out what radiotherapy they will suggest. If it is aduvant therapy my research on the internet(!) says aduvant therapy would start 'immediately'. This might sound stupid but what is immediately when the post op appt is already 4.5 weeks after the op. Don't you have to recover more fully from the surgery before radiotherapy starts? Most likely they found his pathology had some problems and that's why they wanted adjuvant radiation. If he has no incontinence or his leakage is minimal, his radiation oncologist could start him as soon as can be scheduled. And Fairwind is right, studies found hormone in addition help reduced recurrance.

Posts.Content: Justthe2ofus33, Short answer is everything is normal: colon/bowel, bladder, pelvic area, lymph nodes, prostate and seminal vesicle. Prostate situation is consistent with the results of the prior biopsy. For the radiologist's CYA, he/she said there are uncertainties in the peripheral zone but no nodule seen so probably OK. I can give you the long answer but you don't need it. Good news overall so relax and the added benefit is you do not need to check your bladder (systoscope) or colon (colonoscopy) or intestines (diverticulosis) for the radiologist examined all of your interior and gave you a clean bill of health. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Welcome back Kathy. Sounds like his oncologist is on top of thing and is giving him the best treatment protocol, combination hormone and radiation. Fairwind gave a very good suggestion and that is to radiate that positive lymph node and its surrounding. I am quite sure his radiation oncologist is going to do that but no harm discussing with him on that aspect of his treatment. If radiating the positive lymph node did not result in a cure, most likely at this stage his doctors will be talking about managing his disease like a chronic condition instead of a cure. His chance of living a normal life for a long time is still good as there are lots of options left. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Update. Lymph node positive

Posts.Content: Tom C, Sorry you are here but welcome. Urologist can usually guesstimate what your "normal" psa should be by using your prostate size and made some assumptions. If your prostate is small and the cancer is minute, a low psa is usually good news. However, as Fairwind said, some prostate cancer cells do not produce psa and those are usually very aggressive. Your biopsy clinical report should identify the type of cancer cells they found. If they are the garden variety adenocarcinoma, you are probably very early stage and perhaps could do AS for many years without problem. You should get a second opinion from an expert pathologist, e.g. Johns Hopkins, to make sure the cancer is the garden variety type. If you want additional input from others, you might want to post your stats here. For example, JohnT, a regular poster here, uses (.066 x prostate volume) to calculate what your "normal" psa should be. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Low psa but yes, I have prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Sorry you had a positive diagnosis. Glad you made your decision on treatment as your G3+5 means you really should get treatment without delay. I know a lot of folks probably feel you are rushing into surgery a little too soon, without the benefit of second opinions on alternatives like seeds or radiation. My opinion is just the opposite. If I were you, I know I need treatment and I won't want to give my G8 cancer any more time to grow or heaven forbid, leave the prostate. My suggestion is "parallel processing", i.e., schedule your surgery at the same time consult with radiation oncologists and oncologists since popular surgeons have long wait lists. This way, you won't lose time if the end result is still surgery. In fact that was exactly what I did as my surgeon's wait time was two to three months at a minimum. By doing so, I was able to schedule surgery two months after diagnosis. The two surgeons you considered are two of the best in the US so you won't go wrong. Good luck.

Posts.Title: updated for david x

Posts.Content: Your flu like symptom & fever could be inflammation or infection (of the prostate). I also agree with both replies, waiting till January 2012 should be OK. However, if you have fever and it persists for more than a few days, you should see a doctor asap. The symptom you described may or may not be cancer, the only definitive test is a prostate biopsy, which should follow PSA/DRE if the doctor finds something suspicious. And by the way, a biopsy is not a big deal as I had four of them. I suffered from exactly the same BPH, prostatitis for many years with negative biopsies. One side benefit of cancer & prostatectomy (as if there is such a thing) was all the symptoms of nocturia, slow stream, dripping, lower back and groin pains were all gone after surgery. In any case, cheer up, we understand your feeling, I had the same anxiety for many years. Good luck & cheers.

Posts.Title: Surgery Monday

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Nic till I have read so much Negative stuff. What are the chances that his biopsy results are not accurate. Also are the surgery side effects really that bad for young men with no prior issues. If we do not treat it now, what are chances it will not spread and not cause issues in the future. Please help, I am losing my mind thinking of him having to wear pads for the next 20 yrs... Thanks for any advice you have. Sorry you have to be here but welcome. It is normal to be scared but do not worry too much as the situation is not as bad as you think. We all were very scared when first diagnosed but for most things turned out OK. The others gave excellent advices so here I just want to give some positive news: 1. For early stage prostate cancer, the current 10 year cancer specific survival (according to the National Cancer Institute's statistics) is almost 100% and 20 years cancer specific survival after treatment is equally impressive. So, you will no doubt see your husband around for a long long time. 2. As for surgery side effects, most actually recovered their continence after a recovery period, and a majority avoided ED. For those that had ED, medications will help most men. 3. Being young is actually an advantage regarding avoiding surgery side effects. If you have not already done so, you and your husband should take the time to look into other treatment options. However, being only 39, I do not think not treating is a good idea as his cancer has many years to grow and mutate. The key to long term survival is early detection and he is very lucky that he caught his cancer at an early stage, so you folks should actually be thankful for the job physical that could save his life! Best of luck to both of you.

Posts.Title: Surgery scheduled Scared to death - help

Posts.Content: I am very sorry to hear of his post operation complications. It is the first time I have heard of such a post op complication and I have spoken to and met at least 30 to 40 patients among my friends and within my cancer support group. It is also the first time I have heard of a surgeon abandoned robotic surgery and had to revert to open. As for his healing problem, it could be he has some problem with slow healing, e.g., those with diabetes tend to have slow healing, etc. However, given time he should recover fully. You and him just have to be careful with infection and make sure he does not exert too much to stress the stitches and wounds. We have all been given a set of post op instructions like: Make sure bowel movements are smooth (by taking Colace and drinking prune juice for example), do not lift anything over 5 lbs, etc. If he has not been given such, ask his surgeon/GP to provide a set of do's and don't's. I think it is a good sign that he may not have ED. The urge to urinate is common and will subside gradually. Hopefully by "very wet" his surgeon doesn't mean he will have difficulty with incontinence. Again, prior to surgery, our physicians advised us to do Kegel exercise and after catheter out also continued to do Kegel to strengthen the muscles that control the urination. Things will get better. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Post prostatectomy problems

Posts.Content: If you do robotic, hospital stay is usually 2 days, you will leave the hospital with a catheter attached to your penis for 7 to 10 days. After that, many of us can do desk work. You are still not allow to do heavy physical work for probably another couple of months. Of cause for someone your age, recovery may be quicker. I had my surgery in August and 6 weeks later took a long overseas flight (16 hrs) and spent a months overseas. Some surgeons claimed incontinence rate of less than 5% so the odds are in your favor if you find someone who has done tons of surgeries to operate on you. Finally, exposure to some chemicals are know risk factors to prostate cancer. Agent Orange is one I read about. You may be able to claim disability with the VA if you were exposed to known carcinogens. So, you may want to consult an attorney. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer at 27 years old

Posts.Content: I have never encountered or read anything about someone as young as you had prostate cancer. The youngest I read or met was in his late 30. The problem with AS for someone your age is you have too many years for the cancer to grow and escape. Once out of the capsule, it is incurable. Also, reading your biopsy report, I saw you had 4 cores positive so you do not fit the definition/recommendation for AS. In addition, you had three other cores with atypical cells which usually will lead to cancer. You also had one core High Grade PIN which could also lead to cancer. So, all in all my opinion is don't wait, get rid of your prostate before the cancer escape the capsule. Remember, your life expectancy is over 78, so you have another 50 years' life left if you can get rid of the cancer. Go find a surgeon who has done hundreds of procedures. You then have a better chance of not having any side effects. Good luck.
Posts.Signature: PCa Dx 2010 at 65. PSA increased from 2.5 in 2000 to 10.7 in 2010. Four biopsies in 6 years. Final biopsy in 2010: 1 of 12 cores 5% cancer, G6 CT, bone scans & MRI all negative Da Vinci 8/10; nerve sparing, catheter out in 7 days; no incontinence, no ED Post Op Pathology pT2N0Mx: organ confined; negative margins; lymph nodes & seminal vesicle not involved but PNI present; cancer extensive within prostate, multifocal G 3+3 and tertiary G 4 Infected lymphocele diagnosed and treated in 2014, 4 yrs after RALP PSA <.1 for the past 6 years.
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer at 27 years old

Posts.Content: If you do robotic, hospital stay is usually 2 days, you will leave the hospital with a catheter attached to your penis for 7 to 10 days. After that, many of us can do desk work. You are still not allow to do heavy physical work for probably another couple of months. Of cause for someone your age, recovery may be quicker. I had my surgery in August and 6 weeks later took a long overseas flight (16 hrs) and spent a months overseas. Some surgeons claimed incontinence rate of less than 5% so the odds are in your favor if you find someone who has done tons of surgeries to operate on you. Finally, exposure to some chemicals are know risk factors to prostate cancer. Agent Orange is one I read about. You may be able to claim disability with the VA if you were exposed to known carcinogens. So, you may want to consult an attorney. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer at 27 years old

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by NavyProud Good day to everyone, I just received my first PSA test results since my surgery two months ago. The PSA level is shown as <0.13 in the test report. Jim Congratulations! The < sign is more important than the number. It meant PSA was undetectable based on the accuracy of the machine. The PSA half life in our body is 2 to 3 days, so, typically by 4 weeks, for most of us it should be undetectable if the surgeon "got it all out".
Posts.Title: My First PSA Test After Da Vinci Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: DMD, You said: "In addition to the classic symptoms, I've also been experiencing chronic flu-like symptoms (fatigue, lower abdominal pain, feverish) for several months." I am not a doctor, but let me emphasize again, if you have persistent fever that won't go away, it could mean serious infections, so you should see a doctor quickly for that. PSA, DRE etc. can wait. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Feeling Terrible

Posts.Content: Good luck to you. You should write down all your symptoms and go over them one by one with your doctor tomorrow. Otherwise, you may forget to mention some of them during consultation and then regret it later. Also, not a bad idea to make up a list of questions to ask about prostate cancer, BPH and prostatitis.
Posts.Title: Feeling Terrible

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by fivecents First PSA 5 weeks out = 0.02 I am confused about this PSA level and won't see my surgeon until next week. I'm not sure if I should be happy or not. Congratulations for a successful surgery. Looks like you have early stage and organ confined prostate cancer and should be on your way to a cure. If there is a < sign infront of the .02, that means undetectable, lower than the ability of the instrument to detect it. If not, it is still a very small number and should be consider undetectable. Noticed my readings were all <.1

Posts.Title: newbie five weeks out

Posts.Content: First of all, ask for a copy of your pathology report and ask the doctor to explain the report to you and discuss any risk areas and what you need to do if there are risk areas. If you have a copy of the report we can help answer any questions you have. Next, if you are not fully recovered, i.e., still leak and still have ED, ask him to prescribe medications for you to help you along, especially for ED rehab. Does he or his staff has any exercise plan, diet plan, etc. You should also ask him about his prognosis of the situation though most doctors will be very optimistic at this juncture. You can also ask him when you can exercise, lift heavy weighs, go back to work.... Good luck.

Posts.Title: Questions for the Doctor

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Friendly We just got home from seeing my tests results; the cancer has not spread to my Bones and most likely not to my organs. There is a small spot on the liver, however he is sending me for a second opinion and feels we must go after the Prostate Cancer. Treatment will be with Hormone Therapy and Radiation after the second opinion and as soon as it is possible. The spot on the liver did not show up on both tests and is so small he does not want to wait any longer then getting the second opinion and starting my treatment. I am going to record my voice on the answering machine this week just encase some one were to think it is Nancy answering the phone after the Hormone treatments begin. Friendly Very encouraging and good results. I don't think the small spot in your liver means anything. I had some questionable stuffs in my liver and kidney too but the radiatologist said they were most likely nothing serious. You make the right choice going with hormone and radiation. And, you are correct, don't wait any longer and get it over with. See you on the other side with good results. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: We just got home from seeing my tests results;

Posts.Content: It is important to know what is the resolution of the machine that measured your PSA. Some could measure to .1, some .01, etc. So, usually you will see something like: PSA <.1 or PSA < .01 which usually is interpreted as 0.0 or undetectable by the machine, whether it is .1 or .01. It looks like your machine had a higher resolution that .06 or .07, since I don't see the < sign in front of the number. It is important to check your PSA a couple of times to see if it stays at ~.06, ~.07 or is creeping up. If it were me, I won't take action if the PSA stays stable even if it is not undetectable since it could be due to benign tissues left behind. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: A new member of the club no one wants to join

Posts.Content: Sorry you had a positive diagnosis. Glad you made your decision on treatment as your G3+5 means you really should get treatment without delay. I know a lot of folks probably feel you are rushing into surgery a little too soon, without the benefit of second opinions on alternatives like seeds or radiation. My opinion is just the opposite. If I were you, I know I need treatment and I won't want to give my G8 cancer any more time to grow or heaven forbid, leave the prostate. My suggestion is "parallel processing", i.e., schedule your surgery at the same time consult with radiation oncologists and oncologists since popular surgeons have long wait lists. This way, you won't lose time if the end result is still surgery. In fact that was exactly what I did as my surgeon's wait time was two to three months at a minimum. By doing so, I was able to schedule surgery two months after diagnosis. The two surgeons you considered are two of the best in the US so you won't go wrong. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Feeling Terrible

Posts.Content: We had a number of discussions on this board with many posters stated that the upper sphincter muscle was always removed during operations and indeed Dr. Walsh's book stated the same thing for open surgery. Recently I had my three year check up with my surgeon and I posted the question to him and this was his reply: I always preserved both sphincter muscles and both nerves unless the cancers were too closed to the bladder neck or the nerves. If both muscles were preserved incontinence usually should not be a problem, and recovery should be easier. For those considering Da Vinci, perhaps it is worthwhile to enquire if your surgeon preserves both sphincter muscles.

Posts.Title: Preserving Both Sphincter Muscles in Robotic Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by glock19 I received a very welcome call from my surgeon this morning. The path report bumped my previous scores to several G7's and a few G8's. A couple of the G8's had 5's. But, all margins were clear, all lymph nodes were clear, he spared both nerve bundles, and told me he had a rather long bladder neck for connection. He told me that the later would aid incontinence issues much quicker. I don't recall coming across this anywhere else. Has anyone else heard this? No one commented so let me try. First of all, congrats for an excellent surgical outcome with all negative margins and cancer confined to your prostate. As far as I know, some surgeons do practice the technique you described, and mine was one of them. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Path report today?

Posts.Content: I understand your anxiety but don't think you need to worry until you have a couple of additional PSA tests under your belt and they run way above .02. I know someone whose PSA bounced around .01, .02 for quite a while and stayed there. Since you have combo hormone + SRT, I don't think you know if you fail SRT until the treatment runs its course. At .01 and .02 it is still within the variability of the measurement, or could be post SRT PSA bounce. There is a reason the oncology community does not recommend taking action until PSA rises to >0.2. Good luck
Posts.Title: Anxiety and psa both doubling

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MartyAtx I'm beginning to feel the anxiety that is normal before surgery. Very nervous! I truly appreciate everyone's help while going thru this. Thank you All!! Marty Marty, Your feeling prior to surgery is entirely normal. We have all been there done that. Good luck and see you on the other side.

Posts.Title: Surgery Monday

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by LL Fauntleroy Down to two options, local RO or Dattoli clinic Local RO had my prostate measured by their own in-house tech, standard b&w ultra sound at 39cc, doctor not present, but tech with 20+ years experience. At my 2nd opinion consult with Dr Dattoli, with him participating, color doppler ultra sound, prostate measured at 65.1cc? Someone made a mistake. The difference is about 40%. If I have to guess, the correct size is the one measured at Dr. Dattoli's place. It is important as the radiation dosage and coverage depend on the determination of the prostate size. The markers determine the locations only. In my opinion, the real time method of location adjustment together with accurate measurement of the prostate size should be a better approach. I suggest you get to the bottom of this before starting treatment. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer at 27 years old

Posts.Content: I think the jury is still out regarding intermittent vs continuous ADT. Another journal article published in the same journal (New England Journal of Medicine) in Sept 2012 indicated there were no difference in survival between the two. This was a large population (~1400) study whose lead organizations was the Canadian NCIC but also included the Southwest Oncology Group, the Radiation therapy Oncology Group, the Cancer Trial Support Unit and the UK Institute of Cancer Research Clinical Trial & Statistics Unit. Their basic conclusion was there were no survival difference between the two treatment method. The lead author of the study was JM Crook, MD. You can google his name and read the article. I looked at their statistics. at the 8 year mark, the two were identical. At 10 years, the continuous group had a slight advantage but I don't think it was statistically significant. For some of you facing ADT, discuss both options with your doctor.
Posts.Title: Intermittent Androgen Deprivation Not Equivalent To Continuous Treatment For Prostate

Posts.Content: Sorry you are here but welcome. I feel for you and hope you will find the best treatment to keep your cancer under control. 1. Your quick rise definitely does not mean the end is near. I have been here long enough to know that your situation is not atypical and a lot of folks are facing the same challenge. Some folks (including some of my personal friends) have been fighting this for many many years some for over a decade. It is not hopeless as there are lots of drugs/treatments available that are able to keep the cancer under control for a long time. 2. You need to find an oncologist specializing in prostate cancer to be your doctor. Urologists are surgeons typically not cancer oncologists and your case needs an oncologist. Good luck and do not give up.
Posts.Title: Scared after prostate surgery and radiation failure, please adivise

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gearloose I try to exercise but its a catch 22 feel to tired to start and feel more burnt when I stop. No matter how much I sleep, still feel wasted. Any other suggestions? Thanks Some oncologists prescribe vigorous exercise under the care of a personal trainer precisely to overcome situations like what you are experiencing. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Zoladex and Lupron. Fatigue

Posts.Content: A PSA of 570 is very high and cannot be caused by an enlarged prostate, so there are only two possibilities: infection/inflammation or cancer. The prostate biopsy should clear it up for you. The good news is CT scan did not detect anything unusual so even if it is cancer, it could be localized and treatable. Hoag has one of the best prostate robotic surgeons in SoCal and their radiation facility is also first rate. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Very high PSA, but no cancer found yet. What's going on ?

I have read a lot of pros and cons of this treatment. Any info you could give me would be very appreciated. Here are my results: Gleason 9 (4+5). EPI (+) (+) PNI SVI (+) Portion of prostate involved by tumor 95%. PT3b. Seminal vesicle invasion present. extraprostatic extension present. perineural invasion present, extensive. No one knows for sure, not even your doctor, but you are still young and healthy so should be able to withstand the rigor of radiation well. If I were you I would go for it: Prepare for the worst but hope for the best. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Need advice on radiation therapy pros and cons

Posts.Content: I am glad you found an explanation for his high PSA. However, with a PSA of over one hundred and 8 of 12 cores positive with a G7, if it were me, I would not wait till January, especially with a tumor at the top (near the bladder neck so could easily metastasize to the bladder). I also think a PSA history, as HighlanderCFH stated could shed some lights on whether you can delay treatment. If PSA is doubling fast, don't wait. I did not want to wait when I had a PSA of 10.7 at diagnosed and the final pathology report was much worst than biopsy indicated. In any case, we are not healthcare professionals and are just speculating. His doctor must know more so if he says OK to wait, perhaps he is right. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: NJ116, Sorry you have to be here. Yes, your surgeon most likely realized the surgery might be a failure and was preparing you for the worst case scenario. Let's hope for the best as there is an outside chance that your PSA will stabilize at a low number and not increase any further. The detectable PSA after surgery could be due to some cancer cells or some benign prostate cells left behind locally so a salvage treatment will work for you. Best wishes.

As Fairwind said in the sticky, read Dr. Walsh's book. Good luck and hope we can deny your membership application.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Guarnera Does this mean people with PC that has spread to the bone actually live 10 years and up? The Oncologist I saw was kind of slippery with the answers. I know it was the first visit, and she hadn't reviewed the disk with the bone scans yet, But I couldn't get a percentage rate of how many make it 5 years and beyond. All she would say is it depends on if you respond to the treatment. But this sounds encouraging. Yes, some lived way beyond 10 years. Of course every case is different and it is difficult to predict which camp one would belong to. However, one oncologist told me treating metastatic prostate cancer is still an art than a science and sometimes a good practitioner can rotate through different medications to keep cancer at bay for a long time. It is advisable to find an oncologist specializes in prostate cancer for treatment if you have metastasized cancer. Good luck.

Posts.Title: PSA Test

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by p_shah Hello All, Dad (is in India) was diagnosed with prostate cancer with bone mets last June. His Gleason score then was 9 and his PSA was 12. The cancer had spread to his spine, pelvic and some other bones. He had no symptoms other than weight loss. After biopsy, bone scan and other tests at that time the best approach was determined to go with Orchiectomy to reduce his testosterone levels. His PSA dropped to 0.6 and stayed there till last month. The PSA not has risen back to 2.6 in the test a month ago and 5.2 in the recent tests. He has been taking Zoledronic acid (Zometa) injections every month to 6 weeks on the onco's recommendation for his bone strength. So far no other meds and he has some minor pain, but no major symptoms. His age is 78 years old. We have talked to a couple of oncologists and oncosurgeons and are getting two schools of thoughts: 1. Get him on chemo (and maybe additional Hormone) and that will help both his pain but also might lengthen his lifespan 2. Given his age - don't treat the PSA - but treat his symptoms. If he is not in pain, wait till the pain comes and then manage pain through Hormone first and then evaluate Chemo. The thought here is Chemo at his age will really have a lot of side effects and will impact his quality of life quite a bit without really lengthening the lifespan dramatically. The opinion really was neither will cure the cancer completely. We might use localized radiation to manage pain at some point in time as well. So the goal is to manage the pain / quality of his life as well as use the optimum treatment to lengthen the lifespan as much as possible. Given the background, I had a couple of questions - any experiences or recommendations will help us determine the course of action: a. The general presumption is that Chemo has tons of side effects at that age - I presume it has gotten better over years, but we are not sure if we should go to chemo immediately or wait. b. I have read up on immunotherapy and it sounds promising, but at this advanced stage - there didn't seem like an option. Any trials that are worth considering? c. Any experiences on what is the standard approach in US in this stage. I am in US, while my dad (and siblings) are in India. At this point we are a confused about the next step and whether we go aggressive or manage to his quality of life. Probably no silver bullet, but the path forward seems blurry. Thanks in advance for your help. Also I am new to the forum so if I can provide any other info - please let me know. thx Look into the following scientific study and review papers and draw your own conclusions: http://www.thelancet.com/journals/la...012-1/abstract http://journals.lww.com/oncology-tim...astatic.3.aspx The second article was by Dr. Maha Hussian MD, Prof of Medicine, U of Michigan, one of the foremost prostate cancer oncology experts in the US. In my view, if I were him and I am healthy, I would go for chemo. There is a > 40% longer survival. Chemo side effects can be managed for many folks and you can always stop if things get out of hand. This is a layperson opinion as I am not a healthcare professional, just a fellow patient. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Need advice on radiation therapy pros and cons

Posts.Content: LogicBoy, Seems like you are very logical, so, here is one way to look at your situation logically: 1. Your urologist should gather the following information in addition to the biopsy in order to logically decide the treatment approach: DRE result, estimate of the size of your prostate, any symptoms, CT, bone scan and MRI-3 Tesla and trans-rectal coil if possible. These tests will hopeful shed some light on if the cancer has escaped the capsule. This should then give you a clinical staging of your cancer and perhaps the optimum treatment plan. 2. A PSA of 11 is not too high if you have a very large prostate, however, even then, you do have aggressive prostate cancer (G9), so as Fairwind said, aggressive treatment is probably needed. However, if I were you, I would not eliminate any options until I have a complete assessment and second, third opinions. You have one chance to do it right and there is no do-over in this business. 3. Go to Walsh's book, look at the Partin Table, that will give you some assessment of the probability of cancer escapes the capsule. 4. At 66 years of age, my opinion is radiation is a very good choice, so if you are comfortable with radiation, go for it, but I would add adjuvant hormone therapy if I were you. 5. Get a third opinion from a radiation oncologist in addition to an oncologist, and a second opinion on your biopsy slides. Good luck and hope to see you around.

Posts.Title: It Seems Aggressive...

Posts.Content: I am posting this link as a public service for those newly diagnosed with G6 prostate cancer. Normally G6 are low risk cases and many argued that they are indolent and should not be treated and are excellent candidates for AS. So, even if it changes, there is time enough to take action. More cancer centers are advising patients to take this route some here would even say that G6 would never metastasize outside of the prostate. I was always puzzled by the logic and statistics since I saw a 30 year Johns Hopkins study indicating clearly some G6 metastasized. The argument was always it was wrongly read by the pathologist as a pure G6 or there must be some microscopic G7,8 or 9 hiding in there, specifically Dr. Epstein of JH was a strong proponent of AS for G6. In a recent article in The "New" Prostate Cancer Infolink, Dr. Epstein provided an answer to my puzzled: It is not just the cancer staging and Gleason scores that determined metastasis, it is some classifications that though identified by biopsy as G6 were more aggressive, e.g., intra-ductal prostate cancer. http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...leason-scores/ Based on this study, Khani and Epstein conclude that  most men with IDC-P on biopsy/TURP have aggressive tumors, even when the invasive tumor on biopsy is Gleason score 6. As a minority of men may only have Gleason 6 invasive cancer at RP and a favorable prognosis, we recommend that IDC-P on biopsy/TURP be reported separately and not assigned a Gleason score. i.e., intra-ductal G6 can be successfully treated by surgery if done soon enough but could spread if waited too long. I am now in the camp that G6 can successfully do AS without additional risk provided one is a true G6. The challenge for us patients is when confronted with a biopsy report of G6 and no other differentiations as to the type of cancer, how do we know if there is a chance we have "more aggressive variants lurking around"? I think at a minimum, if you are a G6 and are considering AS, send your biopsy to at least one other place like JH for a second read to make sure you are a pure G6.

Posts.Title: G6 Prostate Cancer and AS

Posts.Content: I am very sorry you have to join us but welcome. I am not a healthcare professional so my knowledge of prostate cancer came mainly from my own research as a patient while trying to determine what treatment approach I should take and trying to prepare for my "what if". They are from medical journals, studies, reports, discussions with doctors... According to my notes, prostatic adenocarcinoma with neuroendocrine differentiation (positive with neuroendocrine markers) typically means small cell carcinoma of the prostate. They tend not to metastasize to bones but to other soft organs. Also, hormone tends not to be effective and I think that is why abireterone did not work for you. But chemo that are effective against small cell carcinoma of other organs (lung, for example) are effective against this type of prostate cancer, e.g. docetaxel, cisplatin, etoposide..... I may be all wrong so please consult your doctor. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by okadam PSA 7. Adenocarcinoma, highest Gleason score 7 of 10 (3+4) involving both sides of prostate. Tumore involves 8 of 14 cores. Greatest linear dimension of tumor 0.7 cm. We welcome you with open arms. Your stats indicated a moderately aggressive cancer (G7) and fairly extensive (8 of 14 cores positive) so treatment is most likely needed. The other folks gave you excellent suggestions and I will add additional comments: 1. Take your time to understand this disease by reading and doing some research, you do not have to act immediately. You have one shot to do it right and it is important to find the treatment you are comfortable and only you can make the final choice. What is the right treatment for me may not be right for you. 2. As many before us said, the first priority is to cure your cancer, then the second priority is to minimize complications and side effects. 3. If preservation of sexual function is important to you, perhaps you should look at radiation treatment more seriously. Many on this site that chose radiation reported less ED problem than us surgery guys. Modern radiation treatment produces similar long term results in terms of cancer outcome and sometimes less side effects. 4. Even if you have ED after treatment, do not despair, there are medications and treatments that can fix it, so, don't be too worry. 5. Talk it over with your surgeon but ask to seek a second opinion from a radiation oncologist and then decide. Hang in there and best of luck to you.

Posts.Title: Hopefully this thread will help others

Posts.Content: The argument against testing was cost effectiveness, bad side effects and no life saving benefit: The number I remembered that USPSTF cited was like out of 1,000 tested you saved 1 life and created a large number with side effects. However, statistics can be manipulated to suit one's answer. For example, one European long term study indicated testing saved life and provided much better survival. For me the telling answer came from the long term US Cancer Institute SEER statistics. It indicated much better survival today than in the 1970s (prior to PSA testing). These are total statistics and cannot be manipulated. 10 year cancer specific survival in 1975 was < 55% whereas 2000 and beyond (after PSA testing was implemented) cancer specific survival was >98%. These are for all cases diagnosed in a specific year. It indicated to me that most of the better survival was due to early detection by using PSA testing. For even today, 5 year survival was 100% for organ confined and localized cases whereas for metastasized cases was 28%. Modern medical treatment advancement really did not offer any better survival once the cancer metastasized. On a personal level, two of my friends never tested until symptoms showed up. One was dead within two years (passed away last year), one is in hospice after two years. Of the 7 of us that found our cancer through testing within the past 10 years, all are still living. 2 had BCR and is being treated with hormone (survived 10 years), 1 is on AS for a few years now, 4 are cancer free after treatment. To me the most important thing is to test early perhaps at 45 or 50 to establish a baseline. Then look at our own case individually and make our decision after looking at our own risk factors and consult with our physician. Maybe we do not test for another 5-10 yrs or maybe we test more often after that. We are talking about <$100 to do a blood test and the cost is even less if it is included in an annual blood test.

AgeInfo.Phrase: early perhaps at 45 or 50 to establish a baseline <Z>

Posts.Title: To test or not to

Posts.Content: Drinking alcohol can cause elevated ALT/AST. Also, taking statins or some other medications can cause elevated ALT/AST. I stopped taking statins because this turned out to be one of the side effects. In any case, you should consult your physician as it may indicate more serious ailments.
Posts.Title: Causes of liver enzymes elevated (ALT/AST) ?

Posts.Content: Jacakay, Sorry your husband may have metastatic prostate cancer. If unfortunately it is confirmed, then he needs to seek treatment. With treatment, he will have many years of productive life ahead of him. Here are some of the questions to asked his urologist: 1. Ask him to explain the biopsy pathology report to you. Take note as you will forget what he says if you do not take note. Also, ask for a copy so you can take it to another physician for review if necessary. 2. You like to have in addition to the bone scan, a CT scan and a MRI scan to look at the soft tissue involvement, especially the lymph nodes, the bladder neck area, the Seminal Vesicles, any extra-prostatic extension. Ask him to order those tests. They are important diagnostic tools to assess the situation and develop a treatment protocol. 3. Is a cure still possible? Even with metastatic cancer, there may be hope for a "cure" if the spread is limited to only a few spots (<5 for example). Some oncologists like Dr. Myers advocate spot treating the metastatic spots with radiation in addition to hormone therapy. They reported some complete remissions from that treatment protocol. 4. Ask for recommendation to see a radiation oncologist and an oncologist. If the cancer escapes the prostate, the urologist is not the best physician to provide treatment, you need an oncologist, preferably one that specializes in treating prostate cancer. 5. Ask him to recommend some books for you to get familiarize with this disease. Good luck.

Normally G6 are low risk cases and many argued that they are indolent and should not be treated and are excellent candidates for AS. So, even if it changes, there is time enough to take action. More cancer centers are advising patients to take this route some here would even say that G6 would never metastasize outside of the prostate. I was always puzzled by the logic and statistics since I saw a 30 year Johns Hopkins study indicating clearly some G6 metastasized. The argument was always it was wrongly read by the pathologist as a pure G6 or there must be some microscopic G7,8 or 9 hiding in there, specifically Dr. Epstein of JH was a strong proponent of AS for G6. In a recent article in The "New" Prostate Cancer Infolink, Dr. Epstein provided an answer to my puzzled: It is not just the cancer staging and Gleason scores that determined metastasis, it is some classifications that though identified by biopsy as G6 were more aggressive, e.g., intra-ductal prostate cancer. http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...leason-scores/ Based on this study, Khani and Epstein conclude that  most men with IDC-P on biopsy/TURP have aggressive tumors, even when the invasive tumor on biopsy is Gleason score 6. As a minority of men may only have Gleason 6 invasive cancer at RP and a favorable prognosis, we recommend that IDC-P on biopsy/TURP be reported separately and not assigned a Gleason score. i.e., intra-ductal G6 can be successfully treated by surgery if done soon enough but could spread if waited too long. I am now in the camp that G6 can successfully do AS without additional risk provided one is a true G6. The challenge for us patients is when confronted with a biopsy report of G6 and no other differentiations as to the type of cancer, how do we know if there is a chance we have "more aggressive variants lurking around"? I think at a minimum, if you are a G6 and are considering AS, send your biopsy to at least one other place like JH for a second read to make sure you are a pure G6.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rmotacek1 I had my prostate removed via davinci robotic 4 weeks ago. My doctor is now pushing for radiation therapy as soon as I heal. I have read a lot of pros and cons of this treatment. Any info you could give me would be very appreciated. Here are my results: Gleason 9 (4+5). EPI (+) (+) PNI SVI (+) Portion of prostate involved by tumor 95%. PT3b. Seminal vesicle invasion present. extraprostatic extension present. perineural invasion present, extensive. No regional lymph node metastasis. Is it worth it to try radiation or too late? I have heard radiation can cause many more problems. I am very confused. BTW I am 52 yrs old and otherwise very healthy. Thanks. Your only chance of a cure is to do radiation (or in combination with hormone). Is is too late? No one knows for sure, not even your doctor, but you are still young and healthy so should be able to withstand the rigor of radiation well. If I were you I would go for it: Prepare for the worst but hope for the best. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Need advice on radiation therapy pros and cons

Posts.Content: dirkv, Sorry to see you here but welcome. I have not had hormone or radiation but did a lot of research on them "just in case". I also have plenty of friends and folks at my support group gone through surgery, salvage radiation and hormone. If you refused radiation the first time, very likely your cancer is systemic by now (three years later) and it may be too late to try radiation. But I am not a doctor, so, you are smart to consult a radiation oncologist. As for Casodex, my understanding is many patients after taking Casodex and Lupron for a long time and see their PSA increasing can see a reduction in PSA by stopping Casodex. So, oncologist will try this first before going to plan B. However, this response is temporary and eventually the PSA will start to rise again. If this fails, don't give up, there are other hormones, immunologic treatment and chemo that can keep your cancer at bay. Good luck.
Posts.Title: new member

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by catsforkids Hi dad! Glad to see you on the forum! Newporter, how do you find a support group? And those in your support group that has salvage radiation, was it effective for a while? Thanks! catsforkids, Welcome. Most hospitals have prostate cancer support groups. So, the first place to look is to contact the hospital where your Dad did his surgery. At my hospital, there are two groups, one for general support and education. Every month, we invited practitioners/experts to give talks on various topics. In my three and a half years with this group we had cycled through all the topics of detection, treatment options, BCR, clinical trials, ED, incontinence..... We also tried to help one another by sharing experiences. The other support group is for prostate cancer patients with metastasis. Some patients participated in both. I do not know the success rate of salvage radiation in my group as we did not keep record. As usual, most folks that were successfully treated with radiation tended to move on and we did not see them again. Definitely there were failures as we met some of them. One that I remembered well was the Chief of Pathology of one of the local hospitals. But after failed radiation, he managed to control his with Lupron and came back to talk about it. Good luck and best wishes.
Posts.Title: new member

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by okadam PSA 7. Adenocarcinoma, highest Gleason score 7 of 10 (3+4) involving both sides of prostate. Tumore involves 8 of 14 cores. Greatest linear dimension of tumor 0.7 cm. We welcome you with open arms. Your stats indicated a moderately aggressive cancer (G7) and fairly extensive (8 of 14 cores positive) so treatment is most likely needed. The other folks gave you excellent suggestions and I will add additional comments: 1. Take your time to understand this disease by reading and doing some research, you do not have to act immediately. You have one shot to do it right and it is important to find the treatment you are comfortable and only you can make the final choice. What is the right treatment for me may not be right for you. 2. As many before us said, the first priority is to cure your cancer, then the second priority is to minimize complications and side effects. 3. If preservation of sexual function is important to you, perhaps you should look at radiation treatment more seriously. Many on this site that chose radiation reported less ED problem than us surgery guys. Modern radiation treatment produces similar long term results in terms of cancer outcome and sometimes less side effects. 4. Even if you have ED after treatment, do not despair, there are medications and treatments that can fix it, so, don't be too worry. 5. Talk it over with your surgeon but ask to seek a second opinion from a radiation oncologist and then decide. Hang in there and best of luck to you.

According to the Sloan-Kettering nomogram, someone with your case should have a 15 year cancer specific survival rate of 99% if you seek treatment. According to JohnT, if you choose AS, the chance of survival will be the same. Either way it is not bad. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Feeling Cured

Posts.Content: Work out, lose weight and keep in shape are excellent steps to take prior to treatment. I did that and believed they helped my recovery. I am still biased against AS, especially for someone in their 50s. Your cancer has 30-40 years to grow and turn nasty and I am not sure you can be 100% sure when is the right time to take action, or that your cancer is indolent or will stay indolent... Is is worth it to take the gamble? Will G6 ever turns into G7, G8? Of course they might, otherwise why would my non cancer prostate first turned into PIN, then atypia then cancer? Looking at my post op pathology, mine was quite extensive by the time of surgery and seemed to rapidly turning into tertiary G8 from G6. Who knows, if I waited another year cancer might escape the prostate. It is not even a question of cost: Take a biopsy every year for 20-30 years, take PSA every 3-6 months and see your urologist every 3-6 months for 20-30 years, the cost is at best about a wash compare with surgery (two years after surgery, my urologist released me back to my PCP) or brachy. If you ended up having to take action, it will be more costly. As for side effects, folks here reported very few radiation side effects and mine surgery side effects were minimal with QOL actually better than before surgery (hematuria, slow stream, unable to empty, nocturia, frequent urgencies, lower back pain, groin pain all gone). But, it is a personal opinion and not medical advice. Also, I greatly admire folks who have the courage to do AS and deal with the uncertainties over long periods. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Wish I knew then..

Posts.Content: oshguy, Welcome to our side of the world. Looks like you got your cancer out just in the nick of time before it spread and your chance of a complete cure is very high. Overall I think the news for you is very good with minor negatives of microscopic bladder neck invasion and a positive margin. It is great news that lymph nodes are all negative, seminal vesicle negative (another big deal) and fat, fibrovascular tissue negative (meaning no evidence of microscopic spread). You had a very good surgeon. He removed a lot of lymph nodes and surrounding fat tissues, saw the extend of the cancer and cut wide including the bladder neck where the microscopic invasion was. He is correct that very likely the cut (using a heated knife) killed off any cancer cells at the margin or near the bladder neck. The reason I know he cut wide is your current incontinence, with a wide cut into the bladder neck, he probably affected some of the smooth muscles that control the opening of the bladder so your continence recovery will be slower than most. And I bet he spared both your nerves. He is also proactive and wanted a PSA test in 6 weeks instead of 3 months to make sure you get an early start if something more needs to be done. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Fairwind is correct. Not too many surgeons took the time and effort to compile and publish their success/failure rate. It is a no win situation for the surgeon and it takes time, money and manpower to keep and compare records. Only a few high volume surgeons or surgeons at academic centers of excellence bothered to published peer review studies. Those that published indicated it took a surgeon 250-400 procedures to be very good at it. ThatBiopsyHurt is also correct, The Cleveland Clinic is one such center of excellence and surgeons at the center who has done more than 250-400 should be quite good. You also need to interview them to pick someone you are comfortable with. Good luck.

Posts.Title: new member

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Deb 27 The following are his results: Margins involved by invasive carcinoma, unifocal. Perineural invasion was present. Additionally, it said it was high grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia. PT2c. So, the positive margins have me a little concerned as well as the perineural invasion!!! Deb 27, It is an excellent pathology report except for the two things that worried you. I like to add my response to the two items quoted above to support the other posters' responses. First of all, the positive margin is unifocal, meaning they only found it at one place. Also, I interpret from your post op pathology summary that it barely showed at that margin. If that is the case, very likely the act of surgery killed any cancer cells at the margin (per Dr. P Walsh's book). If you are still not sure, get hold of the pathology report and see what they actually said about cancer at the margin (usually expresses as _ mm at the margin). Some pathologist also examined the cancer cells at the margin to see if it is grade 3 or grade 4. If it is grade 3, they normally don't live long outside the prostate even if surgery did not kill them, so you can relax. Second, perineural invasion (PNI) in post op pathology findings has no bearing on the risks of BCR (biochemical recurrence). There were several medical studies on that topic and that was their conclusions. In his case, it is even better as they stated the PNI was not cancer but high grade PIN (did I read it correctly?), which is pre-cancerous cells. Overall, you should be happy with the outcome and we wish him the best of luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Rolian Hello, hope everyone is doing well here. My dad received surgical castration early June and has been taking Flutamide. PSA dropped to 4.08 first month after. Another blood test couple of days ago, and his PSA bounced back to 50!! So worried, what could be wrong? Does it mean it's castration resistant already? Doctor did not give much info yet as what the next step will be, we gonna talk to him later. Does anyone have similar experience, or know anything about what the problem could be, and next step? Thank you Rolian, Sorry to hear you Dad's PSA bounced back. From a nadir of 4 to 50 in 6 months is a very rapid increase and most likely indicated his cancer is aggressive and not responding to castration or first line hormone treatment. I don't know how the medical system works in China but in the US/Canada he usually is been treated at this stage by a medical oncologist specializing in prostate cancer and in cases like his probably will move him to second line treatments like chemo, new generations of hormone, immunology therapy.... By cycling through the new treatments, they will be able to keep his cancer at bay for a long time. Best wishes and best of luck to your Dad.

Posts.Title: Are you not supposed to have sex before a post-op PSA test?

Posts.Content: The argument against testing was cost effectiveness, bad side effects and no life saving benefit: The number I remembered that USPSTF cited was like out of 1,000 tested you saved 1 life and created a large number with side effects. However, statistics can be manipulated to suit one's answer. For example, one European long term study indicated testing saved life and provided much better survival. For me the telling answer came from the long term US Cancer Institute SEER statistics. It indicated much better survival today than in the 1970s (prior to PSA testing). These are total statistics and cannot be manipulated. 10 year cancer specific survival in 1975 was < 55% whereas 2000 and beyond (after PSA testing was implemented) cancer specific survival was >98%. These are for all cases diagnosed in a specific year. It indicated to me that most of the better survival was due to early detection by using PSA testing. For even today, 5 year survival was 100% for organ confined and localized cases whereas for metastasized cases was 28%. Modern medical treatment advancement really did not offer any better survival once the cancer metastasized. On a personal level, two of my friends never tested until symptoms showed up. One was dead within two years (passed away last year), one is in hospice after two years. Of the 7 of us that found our cancer through testing within the past 10 years, all are still living. 2 had BCR and is being treated with hormone (survived 10 years), 1 is on AS for a few years now, 4 are cancer free after treatment. To me the most important thing is to test early perhaps at 45 or 50 to establish a baseline. Then look at our own case individually and make our decision after looking at our own risk factors and consult with our physician. Maybe we do not test for another 5-10 yrs or maybe we test more often after that. We are talking about <$100 to do a blood test and the cost is even less if it is included in an annual blood test.

I rest my case.

Posts.Content: Read the books recommended and choose a course of action you are comfortable with. The outcome will all be good. According to the Sloan-Kettering nomogram, someone with your case should have a 15 year cancer specific survival rate of 99% if you seek treatment. According to JohnT, if you choose AS, the chance of survival will be the same. Either way it is not bad. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Introduction

Posts.Content: SoMd, Welcome. We are very sorry your husband is diagnosed with aggressive prostate cancer. Do not give up hope. I absolutely agree with lancepeace that the metastasis could be misdiagnosed since it coincided with the location of an old injury. My old shoulder and spinal injuries showed up as bright spots on my ct scan. Get a second opinion. Even with bone met, if there are only a few spots, spot radiation might get rid of them completely and if it were me, since there is a chance that after surgery, I may still need hormone and salvage radiation, I would skip surgery and go for a combination of hormone and radiation. Remember also you have a lot of other weapons against prostate cancer at your disposal. I am a lay person so this is non professional opinions and speculations. Take care and we expect to see you and your husband around for a long time.
