Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Green tara Tuesday will bring the full diagnosis. Sounds like he is set on hormone therapy, do the bone mets and lymph node involvement change prognosis dramatically? Thanks. Sorry you are here. The short answer is yes since bone met and lymph node involvement mean cancer is systemic. But the most important factor is his Gleason score from the biopsy results. A low Gleason score like a 6 or 7 would indicate he should respond to treatment very well and very likely will be around for years. Also, recent studies indicated in cases similar to his, a combo chemo and hormone can increase survival by over 40%. I am just a layperson, so perhaps he should ask his physicians if such a treatment protocol is right for him. good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: new diagnosis, questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jbdubose I was diagnosed with prostate cancer and had prostatectomy in Dec. 09'. I had a high cancer score (8+). The follow-up PSA test a few weeks after showed my level at 2.9. The doctor was astounded saying the margins were clear from my surgery. So he did another PSA a week later and it was 3.2. Evidently he did not get it all and it was climbing up fast. So, in Mar. 10' I got sent to radiation for 40+ treatments and as an added "bonus" I got started on Lupron. Yes, I have now read all the bad stuff on the drug and completely agree with many assessments. It did a number on me as well. I was on the drug for 1.5 years getting zeros all the while and talked my doc into getting off of it (Nov. 11'). He said it would take the same amount of time for the drug to wear off before my PSA tests would be truly accurate and for my hormone levels to bounce back. But he did mention that I was not a candidate for HRT since I was stage 3 at one point (Radiation, etc). Since Nov. 11' I have continued to get zeros on my PSA but my pituitary gland never kicked back and my hormone levels ranged 68 until recently. Now they are dropping (50) again. Now, the doc has ordered some pituitary blood tests to see if a tumor is present. He has also relented and has put me on HRT (via gel). Options? Is there any medicine, natural or otherwise, out there that can "jumpstart" my pituitary? Although there may be a risk in doing HRT again, I have done extensive research and have found that prognosis unstable. So I am 50/50 on HRT. Has anyone in this forum experienced this or have heard of this happening? Any advice? Please help...I am pretty frustrated! Thanks in advance, Jim I am not in healthcare so I am posting as a layperson giving non professional opinions. I gather by HRT you are referring to Testosterone replacement therapy. After off Lupron, your T level should return to normal or near normal after it wears off in about 6 months. Obviously yours are still low (I understand normal is over 200). Since T is associated with energy and well being in male, low T often leads to not feeling well. First, all T gels have warning labels that it is counter indicated for prostate cancer, so most doctors won't prescribe for us. However, there are some limited studies that indicated it is OK for those whose cancer is in remission and PSA is undetectable for a period. We had a thread here sometime ago, going back and forth about the appropriateness of T replacement for us prostate cancer sufferers and if my memory is correct there were fellows on it then. I am personally against it for the cancer risk but since I don't suffer from low T, I am not in a position to argue for or against it. Who knows, with the supervision of your physician, it may be worth a try if you are suffering from depression, low energy.... If you and your doctor decide to go ahead, perhaps you can share the results so future sufferers can benefit? Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: I need help!

Posts.Content: Work out, lose weight and keep in shape are excellent steps to take prior to treatment. I did that and believed they helped my recovery. I am still biased against AS, especially for someone in their 50s. Your cancer has 30-40 years to grow and turn nasty and I am not sure you can be 100% sure when is the right time to take action, or that your cancer is indolent or will stay indolent... Is is worth it to take the gamble? Will G6 ever turns into G7, G8? Of course they might, otherwise why would my non cancer prostate first turned into PIN, then atypia then cancer? Looking at my post op pathology, mine was quite extensive by the time of surgery and seemed to rapidly turning into tertiary G8 from G6. Who knows, if I waited another year cancer might escape the prostate. It is not even a question of cost: Take a biopsy every year for 20-30 years, take PSA every 3-6 months and see your urologist every 3-6 months for 20-30 years, the cost is at best about a wash compare with surgery (two years after surgery, my urologist released me back to my PCP) or brachy. If you ended up having to take action, it will be more costly. As for side effects, folks here reported very few radiation side effects and mine surgery side effects were minimal with QOL actually better than before surgery (hematuria, slow stream, unable to empty, nocturia, frequent urgencies, lower back pain, groin pain all gone). But, it is a personal opinion and not medical advice. Also, I greatly admire folks who have the courage to do AS and deal with the uncertainties over long periods. Good luck.

Posts.Title: new diagnosis, questions

Posts.Content: No one responded so let me give it a try and I assumed you had a negative DRE. There are three possibilities: Enlarged prostate (BPH), infection/inflammation and cancer. Enlarged prostate does not give yo-yo PSA numbers, usually the PSA increases gradually over a period of time as the prostate grows larger. Cancer also normally does not give yo-yo PSA number and usually PSA increases rather rapidly if the cancer is aggressive. That leaves infection/inflammation. PSA can go up and down based on the infection flair up, etc. So, a yo-yo PSA could signal infection. However, you also have a rather high baseline - >4 (you didi not mention your age, I am just guessing you are young) so it could be a combination of all three that caused the symptoms. Another thing to remember is that a TRUS biopsy does not sample all areas of the prostate, even if the doctor do a saturation biopsy. There are some areas that are difficult for a TRUS biopsy to access so if there is cancer there biopsy could be all negative. You and your doctor might want to try other means, maybe MRI, color doppler ultrasound etc. by an experienced radiologist.... Another note, in 2011, the FDA asked the drug manufacturers of finesteride to put a warning label that indicated a possibility of increase detection of more aggressive prostate cancer. There are currently two schools of thoughts on this, one group of doctors believe finesteride makes detecting aggressive cancer easier whereas another group believe finesteride promotes the growth of more aggressive prostate cancer. You might want to get a second opinion about taking this medication. Good luck

Posts.Title: Yo-yo PSA readings!!!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Lowlightsolutions thanks very much for responding, PSA actually closer to 7 now. Yes biopsy does not sound pleasant. I may post another question as I'm thinking of changing doctors and there are minor complications. For someone who is 53, a PSA of 3.5 is considered on the high side. 7 is certainly very high. There are three possibilities: BPH (enlarged prostate), infection and cancer. Most urologist will try to eliminate the first two before doing biopsy to detect cancer. Your urologist should be able to tell if your prostate is enlarged by doing DRE, and he should have given you a course of antibiotics to see if the high PSA is caused by infection. Also, he should tell you that a few days prior to PSA test, do not engage in sex or doing anything to upset the prostate (like riding a bike for a long time, or a DRE, etc.) to eliminate tasks that stimulate the production of PSA from your prostate. If after all of the above, your PSA is still 7, I would not be afraid to go for a biopsy as it is really the only sure way to detect cancer if found positive and it is not that painful. On the other hand, a negative biopsy does not mean no cancer because it could miss the cancer. If you are not comfortable with your urologist, you should change doctor. It is very likely that you need a lot of care and advice from your urologist and you absolutely have to trust him and like him. Best of luck and hope you won't join our club.

Posts.Title: Another newcomer - some perspective required

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Katyana08 Now he has been diagnosed with aggressive stage 4 cancer and they recommended radiation therapy and hormone replacement therapy. He is refusing both, as his father and uncle died of this disease and he refuses to deal with the side effects of the treatment. I am wondering how much time he might have left. I want him to see me get married, and for him to travel and see family and friends, but I have no idea if this is something likely to kill him in a few months or years. Any information would be helpful. Thank you! Every individual is different so it is difficult to answer you question as to how much time he has. I am not a healthcare professional so the following is from researching cancer statistics compiled by the National Cancer Institute and I could be miss interpreting the outcomes so please check with his physicians: For those whose cancer is organ confined or regional (metastasized to the adjacent organs like bladder, rectum, etc.) the 5 year relative median survival is almost 100%. On the other hand, if it metastasizes to the bones, the 5 year relative median survival is only about 30%. Still, in that case, it means 30% still live more than 5 years after the staging. He is a stage 4, which include metastasizes to either regional lymph nodes, organs or bones so it is important to find out which is which. Also another thing is that there are some very significant advances in prostate cancer treatments recently and the outcome will definitely be much better than during his father and uncle's time. A combination of chemo and hormone dramatically lengthen the survival time compare to conventional treatment by over 40%. As for side effects, there are a few medications that can minimize them. I sure wish he would not give up and continue to fight. I have an associate who as a stage 4, survives over a decade after failed surgery with various treatments. He is still living and I visit him regularly; he is by no means cured as he has to keep taking medications but he live a very meaningful and happy life. Best of luck to both of you and I pray that he still has time to see you get married.

Depression prior and post surgery are common so your post surgery feeling maybe related to depression or healing especially prior to the catheter removal but if it continues you should seek some help. Posts.Title: Hopefully this thread will help others

Posts.Content: August 20th was my six year anniversary post surgery. Normally, folks that had successful surgery seldom hung around support sites like this, mostly they moved on and return to a normal, routine life. I decided to hang around because I continued to read up on the latest research on prostate cancer and wanted to share them with you. Also, I wanted to make many of the newcomers aware that there were successes and not all gloom and doom. Well, after six years of <.1, and surgery only a very faint memory, it is hard for me to "share" my experience and advice others anymore. So it is time to move on, "ride off into the sunset" and let others who are more qualified to hold your hands and give you comfort. My post is to say good bye and to thank you all for keeping me sane after my diagnosis, supported me emotionally and provided me with lots of advices post surgery to help my recovery. Regards, Newporter

Posts.Title: After much thought, Brachytherapy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jessjokin I've purchased a book on nutrition for prostate cancer, so now I'm drinking 2 soy protein shakes a day "about 90 gm" with vitamins, lycopene, longevinex and peterapure "resveratrol", vitamine E 400, n-acetyl cystene, and tomato juice daily, anyone having any advice or thoughts on nutrition would be greatly appreciated. thanks With a PSA of 24 to 30 and a Gleason score of 8, you need the best in conventional medicine to fight your cancer. Adding diets and supplements are smart moves but do it in moderation and as an adjunct. IMHO, it is OK to use diet to help fight your cancer as you will find that most of us (me included) eat a lot healthier (and added supplements) after cancer diagnosis. However, using proven, evidence based medical treatment is critical to help you get rid of your cancer. If you search published peer review scientific studies, you will not find any of the supplements in your list proven to cure cancer. In fact, a clinical trial on vitamin E was stopped when the result indicated it actually increased the risk of prostate cancer. It is just like financial investment: When it is too good to be true, it is not true. That said, to support what Fairwind said, as far as I know, the only clinical trial (2 phase II trials in fact, one from UCLA and the other from Johns Hopkins) that I found demonstrated a slow down in PSA increase (after conventional treatments failed) are on pomegranate juice and extract (pills). Even then, the results were not definitive (they were only phase II trials). I apologize if I sounded impolite, but please take it as I care about you getting well. Good luck and peace be with you.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed with questions about nutrition

Posts.Content: There are a lot of hypes about proton but studies did not indicate any survival or side effect advantages over brachy or IMRT, just very expensive. Also, long term outcome studies are lacking. Based on what I have read, if you choose radiation, brachy+IMRT offers the best outcome and least side effects. Also, some studies point to even better outcome if you combine that with adjuvant hormone therapy. Good luck.

However, most likely they have many good radiation oncologists that he trained and they should be very acceptable too. Good luck.

Posts.Title: High PSA and enlarged Prostate!!

Posts.Content: I think most studies said minimum is 250 operations. 300 is adequate if he is really good. Ask him the following: 1. How many operations had he done every week in the past year? You want someone who has done at least 2 to 4 a week every week. Practice makes perfect and frequency is important. 2. What are his statistics regarding positive margins, incontinence and ED? The best surgeons, e.g., Dr. Walsh, kept statistics, video tape their operations and published their statistics and you can go online to find out. 3. Can you talk to some of his recent patients? If he is good, he should be very willing to share his statistics with you, if not find someone else. You have one shot and there is no "do over" in this business so you want and should demand the very best. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Another new member

Posts.Content: Oncologists generally follow two different approaches, one practice is sequencing through medications and the other is more in using multiple drugs regimen to hit the recurrence hard to prevent recurrence. Recent evidences suggest the multiple drug approach could be better at prolonging remission. None of us are doctors, we get our knowledge through our own experiences or by reading/researching. Since every case is different and we don't know your case, you should discuss this with your oncologist. Casodex and Lupron act on different mechanisms (anti-androgen - blocking the production of testosterone vs LHRH argonist - blocking the enzyme that starts testosterone production), if Casodex stops working Lupron could still work because neither is 100% effective, of course if the cancer cells that remain do not need testosterone to grow then Lupron will be of no use. But I am just a lay person, so please ask your doctor. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Constipation is a common problem after surgery, especially if you are still taking pain medications like Dilaudid whose common side effect is constipation. The anesthesia during surgery caused your intestine to be dormant and it takes a while to get things going again. Some takes longer than others. I took Colace and drank a lot of prune juice and did not take food with lots of fiber for a while to keep the stool soft until I recovered. Consult with your doctor if things are not getting better.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RedBull151 I've had a lot of abdominal pain pain level over 5, the last couple of days, just wondering if anyone went through this, the pain seems to be subsiding, Been taking the pills, I also have these dry coughing spells I use a pillow on my stomach to put a little pressure there, just wondering if anyone has had this dry coughing, Getting use to the catheter bags aren't they so much fun, should be getting it out this Friday the 13, cant wait, Thanks Again everyone, Welcome to our side and wish you a full recovery. Your abdominal pains should go away soon. They might be due to irritation of the wounds (internal or external) from coughing. Dry cough is normal due to breathing tube irritations. Pressing a pillow on your abdomen while coughing is smart, that should minimize potential damages to your wounds and surgical stitches. Getting rid of the catheter ranked as one of the best moments of my life. Good luck.

Posts.Content: If your DRE is negative (not palpable) and cancer is found in a biopsy the staging is T1. If cancer is detected only in one lobe, it is T1a which is what you have. I wouldn't say you had 100 core and only one is positive because they were taken at different years, but I would say if you have a saturation biopsy of 30+ and they only found 1 core 5% G6, it is very early stage. I think the MD Anderson recommendation is a good one. Even if your cancer progresses you still have time to treat. I also read somewhere that transition zone cancers tend to be less aggressive, less prong to spread? Don't risk treatment with all the potential side effects, as neither surgery nor radiation are a walk in the park. Perhaps, change your diet, take some supplements and wait it out for a couple of years with AS is your best option. Good luck.

Posts.Title: prostate cancer - two doctors, two evaluations

Posts.Content: You could very well have what they called chronic inflammation of the prostate which cannot be easily cleared by a short course of antibiotics. The best strategy is to retest your PSA again to confirm the high number and if persists, get a biopsy done. If you need a biopsy, your urologist should know how to deal with you health issues prior to the biopsy. You just have to strictly adhere to his instructions. My PSA history was similar. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Howdy Folks, New to the site with a few questions.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Uncle Bill Date PSA age 7/15 4.9 49 1/15 3.0 49 5/14 3.6 48 9/13 3.6 47 3/12 3.2 46 free PSA 14% 4/11 3.4 45 7/11 biopsy 44 5/10 3.1 44 9/9 3.2 43 2/9 2.3 43 5/8 2.1 42 1/8 2.4 42 Uncle Bill, I agree with Otago, you need no worry too much as the last PSA # could be an anomaly, due to a number of factors like infection or you could be "exercising" your prostate too much prior to the last test. Wait a few months and retest, make sure this time, a few days prior to test, you do not have sex, ride a bike for too long, etc. I used the PSA history you provided and with all the data your PSA doubling time is about 10 years! If I removed the latest PSA, your doubling time is > 12 years. And, if I removed the early years using data from 2009 onward, your PSA doubling time is now 18 years. With this level of doubling time, you will be 90 years old with a PSA of 10-20, and you will die of something else and not prostate cancer. In your situation my opinion is unless your future PSA increases rapidly and is monotonic, you need not worry too much. Good luck.

AgeInfo.Phrase: doubling time  you will be 90 years old with a PSA

Posts.Title: PSA increasing

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by D&K FYI: my husband's PSA was 6 3 yrs ago; 2 yrs ago was 7. no one seemed worried. Last year it somehow got missed. This year was 73; EVERYONE jumped on the bandwagon, doing MRI & CT scan. He has metastasized, & immediately got into treatment. IF IT MAKES YOU FEEL BETTER, JUST DO IT! Sorry about your husband's situation. Why his physician was not worry about a PSA of 6 and 7 is quite a surprise to me as that indicated a PSA doubling time of 4.5 years, and not doing yearly monitoring or discussing his options? In my opinion his PCP is not doing his/her job. We need to be educated and understand what our test indicators mean in our situation. I hope going forward you and your husband read up on what his doctor's treatment protocol means because in prostate cancer there are multiple options and often time patient needs to participate in selecting the best option to fit his situation. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: PSA increasing

Posts.Content: It should not take 6 months from a first PSA of 61 until a biopsy is performed! If I were you, I would be more proactive from now on. "Normal" PSA for a 62 year old should be in the low single digit, so something is going on there and your doctors should be eager to find out for you ASAP. Good luck and hope we can deny your membership application.

Posts.Title: Base Level PSA

Posts.Content: Like lancepeace said, HT could keep his cancer under control for years. In my cancer support group, many are on HT for many years. I have a colleague on intermittent HT for over a decade and another on HT for some time after BCR and failed surgery/SRT and currently with PSA undetectable. He will be on HT vacation soon. The question is, your dad enjoyed undetectable PSA for a few years, but once PSA started rising why not took action and why waited until it went up to 49? From his stats of G7 and initial undetectable PSA, he is someone who could enjoy long survival with HT. It is not too late to act. Consult his oncologist for recommendation as there are many options even with a heart condition. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Micro Metastatic Prostate Cancer/My Father

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jessjokin I've purchased a book on nutrition for prostate cancer, so now I'm drinking 2 soy protein shakes a day "about 90 gm" with vitamins, lycopene, longevinex and peterapure "resveratrol", vitamine E 400, n-acetyl cystene, and tomato juice daily, anyone having any advice or thoughts on nutrition would be greatly appreciated. thanks With a PSA of 24 to 30 and a Gleason score of 8, you need the best in conventional medicine to fight your cancer. Adding diets and supplements are smart moves but do it in moderation and as an adjunct. IMHO, it is OK to use diet to help fight your cancer as you will find that most of us (me included) eat a lot healthier (and added supplements) after cancer diagnosis. However, using proven, evidence based medical treatment is critical to help you get rid of your cancer. If you search published peer review scientific studies, you will not find any of the supplements in your list proven to cure cancer. In fact, a clinical trial on vitamin E was stopped when the result indicated it actually increased the risk of prostate cancer. It is just like financial investment: When it is too good to be true, it is not true. That said, to support what Fairwind said, as far as I know, the only clinical trial (2 phase II trials in fact, one from UCLA and the other from Johns Hopkins) that I found demonstrated a slow down in PSA increase (after conventional treatments failed) are on pomegranate juice and extract (pills). Even then, the results were not definitive (they were only phase II trials). I apologize if I sounded impolite, but please take it as I care about you getting well. Good luck and peace be with you.

If you had a PSA test a few years ago, it is very helpful to your doctor if you can find out what that number was because it could give some insight on how rapidly your PSA is rising. Hopefully, you have BPH + inflammation which could also cause the symptoms you mentioned. Best of luck.

Posts.Content: It is called SBRT - Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy, some called it Cyberknife. Another technical term is hypofractionation: Total radiation is given in less number of large doses so instead of 40 sessions, they are combined into 4 to 5 sessions of larger doses.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Race A friend of mine had RALP last month, and I went over to cut his grass for him. He seemed to have a little rougher recovery time than I had. He said he had a drain in for about 10 days. Then he also said the doctor told him not to eat anything with red dye in it for awhile. I had never heard of this. So, I'm wondering, what's up with that? It sounds more like a colonoscopy kind of thing. Don't know about the red dye part but I think the reason he was having a rougher time was because his surgeon took out some lymph nodes which sometimes caused additional discomfort. That was also the reason for the JP drain for 10 days.
Posts.Title: RALP recovery - don't eat red dye?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DDBNY I believe (could be reversed as he didn't want someone with him at consulation) that his PSA is 6 and his Gleason is 4.2. However his DR. did say 2 tumors, one is larger and "aggressive" He is 59 and in good health/shape. He begins radiology on monday which is scary because from what Ive read here, most effected usually have more time to wait. Any thoughts/info appreciated. DDBNY, Welcome. Based on the stats you mentioned, your Dad's cancer is early stage and non aggressive. PSA of 4.2, G6 and 2 cores positive, mostly likely the cancer is organ confined - stays in the prostate capsule, and the chance of cure is very high. Radiation treatment is an excellent option, sometimes does produce side effects but often they go away after treatment so don't worry unnecessarily. Go get Dr. Walsh's book and read the section on radiation treatment to understand the treatment protocol and possible side effects and treatment of side effects. Good luck.

AgeInfo.Phrase: larger and  aggressive  He is 59 and in good health shape

Posts.Title: Dad is joining the club

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Wheelar Sleeping is also better, but I’m still getting up every 3 hours to pee. It’s like having BPH all over again….. My bladder has seemingly shrunk, because even during the day I have no “holding capacity”. Usually, because of BPH, your bladder wall became "harden", i.e., the bladder wall muscles thicken and were not as flexible so you could not hold a lot of urine. After surgery, it takes some time for the bladder wall to get back to its original condition. For some folks, things might not get back to normal but that is not usual. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Gleason 7 - Other Factors "minimal"

Posts.Content: Yes, I like to join Highlander and lancepeace to welcome you as fellow sufferers and accept you as a new club member. Your PSA of 40 to 60 are very high numbers indicating a risk of EPE (extra-prostatic-extension), i.e., cancer may have grown beyond the prostate. In addition a Gleason (4+3) is moderately aggressive. So you should not waste any time and seek treatment asap. However, that said, with the right treatment, you should be around for a long time. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Content: If your DRE is negative (not palpable) and cancer is found in a biopsy the staging is T1. If cancer is detected only in one lobe, it is T1a which is what you have. I wouldn't say you had 100 core and only one is positive because they were taken at different years, but I would say if you have a saturation biopsy of 30+ and they only found 1 core 5% G6, it is very early stage. I think the MD Anderson recommendation is a good one. Even if your cancer progresses you still have time to treat. I also read somewhere that transition zone cancers tend to be less aggressive, less prong to spread? Don't risk treatment with all the potential side effects, as neither surgery nor radiation are a walk in the park. Perhaps, change your diet, take some supplements and wait it out for a couple of years with AS is your best option. Good luck.

Posts.Title: prostate cancer - two doctors, two evaluations

Posts.Content: Agree with the others, it seems premature to take aggressive action unless there are indications of cancer escaping the capsule, after all, .04 is <.1 or consider undetectable in standard PSA tests. First order of business for you is to get hold of the post op pathology report to see what the pathologist said about the specimen: Any EPE (extraprostatic extension, cancer outside the capsule), any positive margins (cancer outside/on the edge of the specimen), any seminal vesicles involvement, any bladder neck involvement, any urethra involvement, any lymph nodes involvement..... If there are none of the above, there are two possibilities for non zero PSA post op other than cancer cells left behind: some benign tissues left behind or the PSA was taken too early as the PSA half life in the blood is about 2 to 3 days so it takes several weeks for the remaining PSA to clear the blood plasma. Anyway, most of us do the following: Prepare for the worst and hope for the best. Good luck and hope for the best for you.

Posts.Title: Treatment options - prostate cancer back after Radical Prostatectomy + colon cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Uncle Bill Date PSA age 7/15 4.9 49 1/15 3.0 49 5/14 3.6 48 9/13 3.6 47 3/12 3.2 46 free PSA 14% 4/11 3.4 45 7/11 biopsy 44 5/10 3.1 44 9/9 3.2 43 2/9 2.3 43 5/8 2.1 42 1/8 2.4 42 Uncle Bill, I agree with Otago, you need no worry too much as the last PSA # could be an anomaly, due to a number of factors like infection or you could be "exercising" your prostate too much prior to the last test. Wait a few months and retest, make sure this time, a few days prior to test, you do not have sex, ride a bike for too long, etc. I used the PSA history you provided and with all the data your PSA doubling time is about 10 years! If I removed the latest PSA, your doubling time is > 12 years. And, if I removed the early years using data from 2009 onward, your PSA doubling time is now 18 years. With this level of doubling time, you will be 90 years old with a PSA of 10-20, and you will die of something else and not prostate cancer. In your situation my opinion is unless your future PSA increases rapidly and is monotonic, you need not worry too much. Good luck.

AgeInfo.Phrase: doubling time  you will be 90 years old with a PSA

Posts.Content: Sorry to be the bearer of bad news. Your post operation pathology is worrisome: G9, positive margin, with one positive lymph node and positive bladder neck. In my non professional opinion, your cancer is probably still there, so if I were you I would go immediately into plan B, with perhaps adjuvant RT and hormone start right away to hopefully catch the cancer before it goes systemic. Get a second opinion from a prostate oncologist ASAP if I were you. Good luck.

Posts.Content: donelson, First thing first as from your posts it does not seem you have a prostate biopsy yet. Without a positive biopsy, you may or may not have prostate cancer. High PSA and MRI showed mass are not definitive diagnosis. MRI could showed a mass due to other causes. It is good to get prepare just in case but do not jump the gun. If you already have a positive biopsy, it is important to know the clinical pathology results before deciding on a treatment plan. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Down graded from G9 to G7 is a big deal. Seminal Vesicle involvement is still classified as localized and the survival statistics are not that different from organ confined. You should be OK with your treatment protocol. Best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: update; biopsy downgraded from 5+4 to 4+3 (hurray), but spread to seminal vesicles

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by GeorgeS While it is doubtful that by itself common practice will budge much this article is still interesting. http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...ostate-cancer/ IMHO: it appears that the evidence that multiple combined treatments in many cases are more effective than single treatments alone is growing. I was a bit surprised at the ~12% new patients being diagnosed as node positive. g. George, Good points. I am a layperson but I agree with you 100%. Reading many of the advances in cancer and HIV treatments, a lot of breakthroughs came from combination therapy. It has been standard for breast cancer for at least 10 yrs; HIV became a chronic disease instead of a death sentence after combination of drugs given concurrently.... I just don't understand why this is not done for prostate cancer that has spread. The recent clinical trial combining chemo and hormone early showed significant survival advantage is just a first step. Intuitively, I would think a combination would cut down cancer cell mutation, drug resistance and have a higher chance of kill. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: ADT-and-radiation-for-first-line-treatment-of-node-positive-n1-prostate-cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by D&K FYI: my husband's PSA was 6 3 yrs ago; 2 yrs ago was 7. no one seemed worried. Last year it somehow got missed. This year was 73; EVERYONE jumped on the bandwagon, doing MRI & CT scan. He has metastasized, & immediately got into treatment. IF IT MAKES YOU FEEL BETTER, JUST DO IT! Sorry about your husband's situation. Why his physician was not worry about a PSA of 6 and 7 is quite a surprise to me as that indicated a PSA doubling time of 4.5 years, and not doing yearly monitoring or discussing his options? In my opinion his PCP is not doing his/her job. We need to be educated and understand what our test indicators mean in our situation. I hope going forward you and your husband read up on what his doctor's treatment protocol means because in prostate cancer there are multiple options and often time patient needs to participate in selecting the best option to fit his situation. Best wishes.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> This year was 73  EVERYONE jumped on the bandwagon

Posts.Title: PSA increasing

Posts.Content: Welcome sosad. You may not believe me but don't worry too much as most likely even if he has prostate cancer there is time to treat and recover. It is good that he tracks his PSA regularly so that if in the unfortunate case he has to join us, his cancer is early stage and curable. With a PSA under 10 in most case even if cancer is detected it is organ confined and curable. It is true that if ct and bone scan are positive, the cancer is systemic (out of the prostate) but even then it can be controlled for years and years with medications. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Worried sick for my husband

Posts.Content: All excellent suggestions. The first two days, I slept on a reclining chair. When I slept, I hung my large bag inside a large cleaning bucket sitting on the floor beside my chair or bed. Also, I asked the hospital discharge nurse to give me my hospital gown and wore it at home. I only walked inside my house and only ventured out on the day of the catheter removal. That was also the only time I used the leg bag. It is very easy to irritate the tip where the catheter comes out. To avoid infection, clean the tip with clean cold water (distilled water if available) frequently and apply Neosporin once a day. Do not wash it with alcohol or other disinfectants for they may cause more irritations.
Posts.Title: Sore but relieved

Posts.Content: Quite common most likely due to scar tissues build-up at the surgical stitches site between the urethra and the bladder. You need to get back to your urologist to get it examined with a cystoscope. Otherwise, if the blockage is total you will end up in ER.

Posts.Title: MRI shows lump 1/5th size of prostate, PSA was 33, now 25, bone scan and biopsy soon

Posts.Content: I am very sorry about your husband's situation. I don't have any personal experience to help answer your questions and you really need to get it from his physicians. However, please give the treatment time to work. Ductal is a very rare form and there are not a whole lot of information available. There were conflicting reports as to whether it was more or less aggressive than the usual kind. Recent findings did indicate it to be more aggressive. If it is organ confined, the cure rate and survival rate are quite good. One recent study (2010) quoted ~80% at 10 years. However, once it escapes it is more aggressive and tend to metastasize to soft organs like lung and liver. Researchers seemed to indicate it should be treated aggressively in order to minimize spread and prolong survival. There is a case presented indicating a treatment of surgery and radiation kept it at bay for a long time and when it came back, it was treated with a 4-round chemo. The patient had a 10 year clinical history since first diagnosed. Hopefully your husband will have as much time if not more. The question you need to ask his physicians is what are their plan (surgery+radiation+?) and what is plan B (there has to be a plan B). If you an afford it, travel to a major cancer center for treatment for they are more likely to have more experience in treating this rare form. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Chemo working?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by trinity3 I went to Johns Hopkins yesterday. My 4+4 has turned into a 4+5..which of course is very concerning. This is a big change from my 3 core Gleason 6 last November. I am scheduled at this point for Robotic on December 3 - unless there is something really whacky with the other test results. Hopkins mentioned a PSMA Pet-CT Scan. I think they have a trial going which I may have an opportunity to be part of - not sure if any of our members here have heard of this or participated. I did not get the feeling this is being done in very many hospitals. Steve Wow, a big change within a year, from 3+3 to 4+5! This is a case where AS is not doing you a favor. Either the first time they missed something or your is turning into something very aggressive, so why wait till Dec 3rd to do surgery? You may want to ask what the PSMA Pet will do for you in your situation and will it delay your treatment plan? Good luck.

Posts.Title: PSMA PET-CT Scan

Posts.Content: If his PSA went up by a factor of 3 in three months, it is serious and he needs to get treatment. If he is seeing his urologist, my suggestion is ask his urologist to refer him to an oncologist who specializes in treating prostate cancer. Very likely they will do a batteries of tests and scans to determine if they can find the source of the PSA/cancer and go from there. Though at this stage there are probably no curative treatments for him, there are many treatment protocols and drugs that are very effective in slowing down and controlling the spread of prostate cancer, often for years. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Content: The answer depends on other factors like your family history, your age, your PSA and PSA history, DRE and other symptoms. Your urologist must have all the information in order to recommend AS. If you are not sure, you should: 1) send the slides out for a second read, 2) consult a different urologist for a second opinion. And finally, only you can decide. Some of us are just not good for AS due to personality. Sometimes, the actual cancer is much worst (just look at my signature) but hopefully a second or third biopsy will flush that out. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Hello-Worst day of my life

Posts.Content: Sorry you are here but welcome. You are young and in good physical shape, so, recovery from surgery should be fast and easy and side effects could be minimum provided you choose a good surgeon, one that has, hopefully, done 1,000 prostatectomies or more. Another point, with a PSA of 19.9, your urologist needs to make sure the cancer is still contain within the prostate by running additional tests, including an MRI and a color Doppler ultrasound if possible (in addition to the bone scan and CT you are going to do). If there is any indication of cancer escaping the capsule, surgery may not be the right treatment. As Fairwind said, very few die from a G6 prostate cancer, so good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ajuar2 Hello Guys, I used to be in the <0.1 club until yesterday. I had my prostate removed 4/11. What i remember is my PSA was 4.06 and that test was to confirm my first PSA test of 4.03, all in my first time testing. My gleason score was 6, margins clear and no spreading to the seminal vesicals. The level of knowledge in this forum is over my head but comforting when I read "Been there ,done that" regarding living in fear. At Kaiser my email for past PSA test results would show only <.01. Now the latest one shows .11 and all the bad thoughts came back. Is a result, that high, a reason for SRT even if a re-test shows <.1 again? I am 53 years old. My Doctor told me the biopsy showed 1 bad sample which i was told pre-op that it was 5% cancerous. I am currently looking forward to an appointment with my Doctor who put me at ease before and was very positive in the past. Thanks Ajuar2, Never based a treatment decision on one PSA #. Get a retest. Good luck

Posts.Title: PSMA PET-CT Scan

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Booo G) Prostate Tissue with small focus of Atypical Glands , Suspicious for Carcinoma. (Although these findings are atypical and suspicious for adenocarcinoma, , there is insufficient cytologic and/or architectural atypia to establish a definite diagnosis. Repeat biopsy is recommended with relative increased sampling of the initial atypical site's. Stains for high molecular weight cytokeratin andP63 are positive in a patchy fashion in some of the glands. I-K) HPIN Looks like hubby needs another biopsy. First path report had G at a Gleason 6 and H atypia The majority cases of atypia lead to a cancer diagnosis in subsequent biopsy. Often HGPIN also leads to a cancer diagnosis in subsequent biopsy (I know because those were the results of my third biopsy). So the two pathologists are not contradicting each other, just a slight different interpretations of the same thing. At this stage he is a good candidate for AS and careful monitoring. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Got 2nd opinion from John Hopkins

Posts.Content: I was recently hospitalized for an episode of infected lymphocele near the pelvic area, after 3 symptoms free years. Symptoms were high fever and abdominal pain. iv antibiotics plus a drain to clear out the infected fluid did the trick as I will be discharged from the hospital tomorrow. What is not known is if the problem will recur so, there will be a discussion among my physicians as to what are the going forward plans. This is certainly one of the risks that many surgeons down played and rightly so since the chance of an infected lymphocele is <1% overall but non zero none the less. This put into focus many of the discussions about risks of radiation, risks of surgery as neither are risks free so each of us has to assess our risk tolerance level and to decide for ourselves. The good news for me is after 3 years my PSA is undetectable, I have no incontinence and no ED so I do have a few things to celebrate in spite of the hospitalization.

Posts.Title: PSMA PET-CT Scan

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Brenden The reason for my post is that Im looking for an honest rundown on what I can expect my life to be like during my final few months. Can any of you regular posters point me to a previous post that might help me look ahead to where Im headed? Brenden, My heart goes out to you and sincerely hope you will be around a lot longer. Also, as the other posters said, you have not exhausted all the available treatments yet so I hope you will continue your treatment. As to your question, to me, one member that stood out was sequoiaranger who posted until the very end just before he passed away and never gave up. His courage, kindness and helpfulness were what stood out and had my utmost respect. He inspired me to want to continue and share my experiences with others. During his final days his challenge was constant pain, even with pain medication so I would say if you are suffering from pain, getting pain management right is your first priority. There is also a website www.yananow.com that published many personal stories of those suffering from prostate cancer, in their own words, with some writing until the very end. You can gain some insights there. Often time, the reason many seek additional treatment is not to prolong life but to reduce pain. For example, the new radiation drug Xofigo was found to prolong life and reduce bone pain. My Dad died from cancer (prostate? spread to other organs) and in his last few months he was given lots of pain medications to make him comfortable and pain free. He passed away peacefully. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: PSMA PET-CT Scan

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by edwardo I've just had a 16-month post RALP checkup and things have been going well otherwise. All previous PSA tests have been 0.01, but this time it is 0.03. Should I be concerned with this increase? I haven't talked to the surgeon yet; don't want to bother if its no big deal. Thanks Two questions: 1. Were they done by the same lab on the same machine. If not, there could be machine differences. 2. Were there < signs before any of the numbers? If there are no < before the .03 and the machine's resolution is .01, yes you need to worry and prepare for just in case. My suggestion is to retest in a month or two and see if the PSA settles down or continue to increase. Good luck.
Posts.Title: 16 months post RALP

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PDV I'm wearing a pad during the day and have tiny squirts when I stand up suddenly or cough.(I'm not sure anything even comes out but it feels like it does.) I'm dry at night but wake up a dozen times feeling like I need to urinate. When I get up hardly anything comes out. Hi PDV, Looks like you are one of the success stories of no incontinence right after removal of the catheter. Your surgeon did a great job. As Pratoman said, getting up frequently at night after catheter is out is quite normal, should get less frequent as time passes and eventually will go away. As a non professional, I read that sometimes, scar tissues formed, sometimes sites of the stitches got a little inflamed and the passage is semi-blocked. Another aspect for those of us with BPH is the enlarged prostate constantly pressing on the bladder causing bladder wall thickening and needs time to get back to normal. One side benefit of surgery is once back to normal, you will urinate like when you were 18 years old. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Urge to pee waking me up

Posts.Content: The fact that he has been able to keep his metastatic cancer at bay for 5 years with Lupron and bicalutamide is encouraging. Normally with aggressive prostate cancer, its effective period is shorter. That means if he moves to the second lines of hormones like Zytiga and/or combination with chemo he can continue to control his cancer. And if that starts to lose its effectiveness, there are others that his oncologist can put him on later (Xtandi for example). Some oncologist would also ask to spot radiate the bone metastatic sites if there are only a few spots and that prolongs the effectiveness of hormone even further. Don't give up hope, there are lots of options left.
Posts.Title: Metastatic Prostate Cancer Stage 4 detected 5 years ago...Need feedback

Posts.Content: Mary, Welcome and good luck to you on your Non Hodgkin's Lymphoma treatments. As for your husband, like Highlander said, he had already survived 15 years so very likely his cancer is not too aggressive and he will most likely not die of prostate cancer. From your post it looked like he had surgery and salvage radiation but did not have hormone or other types of treatments. If so he could start hormone and slow down his cancer growth. We don't have any information on him so cannot give you any of our opinions. However, in general, his doctor can observe his PSA doubling time (how fast is his PSA rising, or doubling), can do some scans to see if there are bone mets or other organ involvements and decide if any treatment is warranted. For example if his current PSA is single digit and his doubling time is greater than 12 months, he could go another 4 - 5 years and be 90-91 years old before treatment becomes necessary. Give us more details and we can be more specific. Hormone will buy him time but comes with side effects and risks especially cardiovascular and stroke risks so his doctors will be careful and check him out before getting him on hormone. I am a layperson so this is just a non professional opinion. Best of luck to the two of you.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by robthirty Hello all I am new to site but my uncle was recently diagnosed with prostate cancer and was under going chemo therapy but apparently it is not helping him and he is now going for radiation treatment as the cancer has spread. Any suggestions? We are not healthcare professionals so cannot offer medical advices. However, we have a lot of experiences to share. The folks on this site have a range of experiences from those with early stage to those with late stage like your uncle. Many with late stage prostate cancer are able to survive for many years with treatments that ranged from radiation to hormone to chemo. You should also know that just within the past few years, there are a number of new treatments (Zytiga, Xtandi, Provange...) approved by the FDA and a few new ones are in clinical trails and likely to be approved soon. So, your uncle should have a lot of options to keep him around for many years. Good luck to you and your uncle.

Posts.Title: Wish me luck today

Posts.Content: Fairwind, You are quite correct. Lymphocele is not uncommon if the surgeon took out some lymph nodes since the lymphatic fluids need to go someplace and if they cannot find a path, form a pocket call lymphocele. For most patients, they go away after a while or stay harmless if not infected. For me this one stayed dormant for three years until it was infected recently by staph infection. Fortunately, I also have the "garden variety" staph. I had both abdominal ultrasound and ct and the radiologist said lymphocele was the most likely cause but he had never seen one came on three years after surgery. After discharge, I will have to go through the same drill you went through. I posted this to share with fellow surgery members that this could be another minor bump on the road to recovery. Best to all.

Posts.Title: Lympocele

Posts.Content: Ronald007, Welcome again. There are a number of posts here discussing treatment options, surgery vs radiation. Instead of repeating, let me just say that in my opinion you should consult a radiation oncologist and consider radiation as a treatment option. You being a "big guy", have what is considered aggressive prostate cancer (Gleason 4+4) and your cancer is quite extensive, radiation could be a better choice. In these cases, from what I read, radiation gives you better odds. And, go find the best practitioner, whether it is surgery or radiation. You have one shot to do it right so you do not want to be someone's training patient. Prostatectomy is a very complicated surgery, do you want to add complexity by doing tummy tuck in addition? In my opinion, if he finds it difficult to perform, he should not do it and risk your life by adding tummy tuck. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Update with pathology report

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lancepeace http://health.usnews.com/health-news...te-cancer-risk A long study finds decrease in incidence and no increase in mortality for men who take Proscar / finasteride . If you are an optimist, you say wow, the incidence of cancer decreased and even though the incidence of aggressive cancer increased, there were no increases in mortality, so this is great. If you are a pessimist, you say, wow, the medication did not reduce the incidence of cancer mortality, so why are we taking it? In my view, perhaps, by reducing incidence of cancer, it potentially reduce over treatments.
Posts.Title: Proscar study finds no increase in mortality

Posts.Content: Jim215 is right on. First order of business is get a second opinion from another pathologist (on his biopsy slides), radiologist (on his bone and ct scans) and oncologist on staging. If he indeed has met with a PSA under 10, he might have some rare types that do not give out PSA that is why you want a good pathologist, i.e., some one from Johns Hopkins to read. I just thought of something, does he have BPH and/or is he taking anything like Proscar or even using Rogaine that could mask his PSA? In any case, if I were him I would be very aggressive in my treatment, throwing everything including the kitchen sink at the cancer, and I would seek treatment at a major cancer center. Let's hope lancepeace and the others are right, it is just an old wound instead of met. Good luck.

His courage, kindness and helpfulness were what stood out and had my utmost respect. He inspired me to want to continue and share my experiences with others. During his final days his challenge was constant pain, even with pain medication so I would say if you are suffering from pain, getting pain management right is your first priority. There is also a website www.yananow.com that published many personal stories of those suffering from prostate cancer, in their own words, with some writing until the very end. You can gain some insights there. Often time, the reason many seek additional treatment is not to prolong life but to reduce pain. For example, the new radiation drug Xofigo was found to prolong life and reduce bone pain. My Dad died from cancer (prostate? spread to other organs) and in his last few months he was given lots of pain medications to make him comfortable and pain free. He passed away peacefully. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Jim215 is right on. First order of business is get a second opinion from another pathologist (on his biopsy slides), radiologist (on his bone and ct scans) and oncologist on staging. If he indeed has met with a PSA under 10, he might have some rare types that do not give out PSA that is why you want a good pathologist, i.e., some one from Johns Hopkins to read. I just thought of something, does he have BPH and/or is he taking anything like Proscar or even using Rogaine that could mask his PSA? In any case, if I were him I would be very aggressive in my treatment, throwing everything including the kitchen sink at the cancer, and I would seek treatment at a major cancer center. Let's hope lancepeace and the others are right, it is just an old wound instead of met. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Booo G) Prostate Tissue with small focus of Atypical Glands , Suspicious for Carcinoma. (Although these findings are atypical and suspicious for adenocarcinoma, , there is insufficient cytologic and/or architectural atypia to establish a definite diagnosis. Repeat biopsy is recommended with relative increased sampling of the initial atypical site's. Stains for high molecular weight cytokeratin andP63 are positive in a patchy fashion in some of the glands. I-K) HPIN Looks like hubby needs another biopsy. First path report had G at a Gleason 6 and H atypia The majority cases of atypia lead to a cancer diagnosis in subsequent biopsy. Often HGPIN also leads to a cancer diagnosis in subsequent biopsy (I know because those were the results of my third biopsy). So the two pathologists are not contradicting each other, just a slight different interpretations of the same thing. At this stage he is a good candidate for AS and careful monitoring. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Good news

Posts.Content: I hope you do not get offended. I used your psa history from 2009 to today and calculated your doubling time to be 10 months. It is fast enough that in my opinion needs to be treated asap. I am surprised your urologist did not recommend any treatment especially after Oct 09. After all, you did have positive surgical margins indicating some cancer cells could be left behind and indeed with BCR after Oct 09, some cancer cells were left behind. For someone with positive surgical margins, salvage radiation actually has a high success rate of curing BCR (Dr. Walsh's book). Perhaps salvage radiation is still an option if you do not like ADT and I would ask for a second opinion from a radiation oncologist. I am just a layperson and it is just my opinion. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PDV I'm wearing a pad during the day and have tiny squirts when I stand up suddenly or cough.(I'm not sure anything even comes out but it feels like it does.) I'm dry at night but wake up a dozen times feeling like I need to urinate. When I get up hardly anything comes out. Hi PDV, Looks like you are one of the success stories of no incontinence right after removal of the catheter. Your surgeon did a great job. As Pratoman said, getting up frequently at night after catheter is out is quite normal, should get less frequent as time passes and eventually will go away. As a non professional, I read that sometimes, scar tissues formed, sometimes sites of the stitches got a little inflamed and the passage is semi-blocked. Another aspect for those of us with BPH is the enlarged prostate constantly pressing on the bladder causing bladder wall thickening and needs time to get back to normal. One side benefit of surgery is once back to normal, you will urinate like when you were 18 years old. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Ronald007, Welcome again. There are a number of posts here discussing treatment options, surgery vs radiation. Instead of repeating, let me just say that in my opinion you should consult a radiation oncologist and consider radiation as a treatment option. You being a "big guy", have what is considered aggressive prostate cancer (Gleason 4+4) and your cancer is quite extensive, radiation could be a better choice. In these cases, from what I read, radiation gives you better odds. And, go find the best practitioner, whether it is surgery or radiation. You have one shot to do it right so you do not want to be someone's training patient. Prostatectomy is a very complicated surgery, do you want to add complexity by doing tummy tuck in addition? In my opinion, if he finds it difficult to perform, he should not do it and risk your life by adding tummy tuck. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Update with pathology report

Posts.Content: Sorry you are here but welcome. You are young and in good physical shape, so, recovery from surgery should be fast and easy and side effects could be minimum provided you choose a good surgeon, one that has, hopefully, done 1,000 prostatectomies or more. Another point, with a PSA of 19.9, your urologist needs to make sure the cancer is still contain within the prostate by running additional tests, including an MRI and a color Doppler ultrasound if possible (in addition to the bone scan and CT you are going to do). If there is any indication of cancer escaping the capsule, surgery may not be the right treatment. As Fairwind said, very few die from a G6 prostate cancer, so good luck to you.

Posts.Content: Shouldn't be a problem while the catheter is in but after it is out, they usually tell you to avoid it for continence control as coffee is a diuretic and may affect leakage/control during initial recovery. Which stool softener is he taking? Also is he still on pain medication which may cause constipation. One suggestion is to also take probiotics to help gut bacteria recover and thus help bowel movement. Best to you.

Posts.Content: langcole, Welcome. I am not an expert on MRI, so my interpretation could be wrong: 1. First the good news: The MRI indicated the cancer is organ confined, no seminal vesicle and lymph nodes involvements and no EPE. 2. Looks like you had a torso coil 3.0 T MRI and not a transrectal MRI (endorectal coil), so the resolution of the images are around 5mm. Transrectal MRI can provide somewhat higher resolution. 3. The lesions 1 & 3 could be from the same tumor since they were from adjacent images: image 14 and 15 of series 7. My understanding is MRI takes images in slices, so I assumed image 14 and image 15 of series 7 are from adjacent locations. If so, they were from the same tumor. I would like to link this to the second positive core of your biopsy (20% positive as each biopsy sample is about 10 to 15 mm in length so a 20% could be 2 to 4 mm). It would be interesting to compare locations of the positive core of the biopsy with the location of lesion 1 & 3 location - peripheral midgland. So, you might ask your urologist about the location of the two positive cores to see if they confirmed the MRI. I would not be too concern at this time unless another biopsy indicates a Gleason upgrade (from 6 to 7 for example). Good luck.

Posts.Title: My pathology report

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by LL Fauntleroy Had a 2nd pathology report showing "perineural invasion"(nice terminology) I guess that means I am less of a candidate for surgery now then even before, this is really sinking in, feeling scared of how serious this really is, I fully expected the biopsy report to be negative..any positive comments will be appreciated, nor feeling too good a the moment Perineural invasion does not mean cancer has escaped. It means the pathologist detected cancer cells near where the nerves are. Since most nerves are near the surface of the prostate, it could mean the cancers are close to or have penetrated the surface. I had perineural invasion too but so far no BCR after two years and no side effects either. That said, your clinical pathology indicated cancer is intermediate risk but quite extensive so perhaps radiation(IMRT and/or brachy)+hormone could be your best bet as suggested by JohnT. But, please consult with your doctor as we are not health care providers, just fellow sufferers like you.

Posts.Title: Diagnosed/ Need Help With findings

Posts.Content: This was how the doctor explained Perineural Invasion to me: There are nerves running within the prostate, they tend to have empty spaces that cancer cells sometimes like to move into and in that case the pathologist would call out Perineural Invasion. Most likely it has no significance. However, there are cases that the cancer cells follow the nerves and move outside the prostate. During surgery, we will be careful to see if the cancer affects the nerve bundles and if so, we may not be able to save the bundles. Your Second Opinion Summary: 6 of the positive biopsy are G(3+3), 2 are G(3+4) and they are not that extensive, ranging from 5 to 40% of the tissues. I would say intermediate risk (due to the 2 G7) and moderately extensive cancer (8 of 12 cores ranged from 5% to 40%), so, there is a good chance your cancer is still organ confined. I use the Memorial Sloan-Kettering nomogram to calculate your odds using PSA of 5.6 from your first post on this thread: Extent of Disease Probability Indolent Cancer N/A Organ Confined Disease 69% Extracapsular Extension 33% Seminal Vesicle Invasion 3% Lymph Node Involvement 2.4% Primary Treatment Outcome Progression Free Probability after Radical Prostatectomy 5 Year 90% 10 Year 86% Probability of Cancer-Specific Survival 10 Year 99% 15 Year 99% Your odds of organ confined are actually better than mine. Your survival odds are also excellent. Of course this is just a fellow sufferer's non professional opinion. Best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed/ Need Help With findings

Posts.Content: Jim215, Thank you for your comments. Looks like Ganesh answered yours and my questions regarding chemo. And you are correct, once metastasized, cancer can only be controlled and not cured. However, often it can be controlled for a very long time, sometimes for over a decade. At this stage, the cancer is castrate resistant with PSA doubling time of about 4 months, so unless some other medications can slow it down, it will progress rapidly. Regards,
Posts.Title: Sudden increase in PSA by 150%during 3 month- orchiectomy done (3 Yrs ago)

Posts.Content: If you have a normal prostate and have no infection or chronic inflammation of the prostate (which your biopsy sometimes will detect) a PSA of 9 is worrisome. Things of concern would be PSA density (certain size prostate should produce certain range of PSA), PSA velocity (e.g., doubling time) and ratio of free PSA to total PSA. Before you launch off into other imaging technique or another biopsy, at least your urologist should discuss those with you. As some other posters said, if the cancer is in some other zones in your prostate (e.g.,the anterior, the apex, or close to the bladder neck, for example), a normal biopsy could easily miss the cancer. It took a radiologist to find my cancer after three negative biopsies by my urologist. The good news is, at a PSA of 9, even if you have cancer most likely it is organ confined. Of course we are not physicians and our opinions are just opinions. Good luck.

Things of concern would be PSA density (certain size prostate should produce certain range of PSA), PSA velocity (e.g., doubling time) and ratio of free PSA to total PSA. Before you launch off into other imaging technique or another biopsy, at least your urologist should discuss those with you. As some other posters said, if the cancer is in some other zones in your prostate (e.g.,the anterior, the apex, or close to the bladder neck, for example), a normal biopsy could easily miss the cancer. It took a radiologist to find my cancer after three negative biopsies by my urologist. The good news is, at a PSA of 9, even if you have cancer most likely it is organ confined. Of course we are not physicians and our opinions are just opinions. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Biopsy clear despite high PSA?

Posts.Content: I think your urologist's suggestion of waiting six months and then test is a reasonable approach. When my PSA reached 8.4 within a couple of years from 5+, I had a negative biopsy but showed some atypical cells. The urologist wanted to do an immediate repeat biopsy but I opted to wait a year. My rationale was that an immediate biopsy most likely would show the same outcome whereas if I truly had cancer, waited a year would allow the cancer to grow a little and became easier to detect. Cancers were detected in the biopsy a year later @ 1 core 5%.

Posts.Title: Diagnosed/ Need Help With findings

Posts.Content: Any time post op PSA became detectable (without the < sign before the number) is a concern, even after 6 1/2 years but the good news is yours goes up slowly. Based on two data point your PSA doubling time is 18 months. A number of studies indicated PSADT is a good predictor of cancer specific survival. Folks with PSADT > 12 months usually had a good chance of surviving prostate cancer recurrence. Here is a review paper on this subject: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3624708/ Some highlights of the article: 2040% of patients undergoing RP and 3050% of patients undergoing RT will experience biochemical recurrence within 10 years. So, recurrence is not uncommon. One of the strongest predictors of metastasis and death is the PSA doubling time (PSADT), a mathematical determination of the length of time (in months) needed for the PSA level to double in a given patient. BCR patients with a PSADT greater than 9 months, for example, have a high probability of long-term, metastasis-free survival and overall survival. In addition, among patients with a slow PSADT, radiographic evidence of metastatic disease is likely to be discovered before patients experience clinical symptoms from their metastatic disease. Your doubling time based on two data points is 18 months, good news. But you really need at least another PSA test to confirm the PSADT number. Significant reduction in all-cause mortality was associated with salvage radiation in both patients with a PSADT less than 6 months (HR, 0.35; P=.042) and a PSADT greater than 6 months (HR, 0.60; P=.04), but the reduction in all-cause mortality was nearly 60% greater in the patients with PSADT less than 6 months Meaning for folks with PSADT >6 months, SRT improved survival by 40% (HR=0.6). You should be concern but I won't lose any sleep over it at this time. The old saying: "preparing for the worst but hope for the best" applies here. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Content: In addition to what lancepeace said, here is what I would ask: When I visited a radiation oncologist for a second opinion, here were the questions I wanted his view on: 1. Radiation vs surgery vs AS. Since you already had surgery, there is no need to ask this question. 2. His view and recommendation regarding adjuvant radiation treatment vs salvage radiation treatment in your case, since you have fairly aggressive cancer: Clinical G7 and G9 post Op. 3. Should you do combination hormone + radiation in case you need to do radiation. 4. Radiation to prostate bed vs pelvic area + Lymph nodes.... 5. What about combining radiation vs hormone vs chemo.... 6. What type of machine is he using? Fairwind had a good recommendation of what type of machine is state of the art (Varian RapidArc?) and perhaps best. Good luck

Posts.Title: What questions should I ask on my first visit to my medical oncologist?

Posts.Content: lencepeace is correct. When the physician ordered a lower body ct scan, it covered the lower part of the body - all of the abdominal area. The radiologist who read the scan looked for all abnormalities and not just the area that the physician wanted to look. It is a very good practice as the radiologist will let you know if everything is OK or may find something else allowing in many cases early detection of other problems. Cysts in liver, kidney and pancreas are quite normal so there may no be any issues but checking them out for peace of mind is good. Good luck.

Posts.Title: It has been some months since my 45 Radiation Treatments, I am still getting

Posts.Content: Assuming you only had surgery and not have any hormone treatment, using all of your post op PSA and assuming they are "detectable", your PSA doubling time is over 5 years. You will die of something else if this pattern continues. Using the more recent numbers, from 18 months to now, doubling time is still long, ~ 3.5 years. It will be 15 years before your PSA reaches 1.0. So, if I were you, I would not be too worry. Just continue to monitor and enjoy life. Cheers.

Posts.Title: Biopsy clear despite high PSA?

Posts.Content: This was how the doctor explained Perineural Invasion to me: There are nerves running within the prostate, they tend to have empty spaces that cancer cells sometimes like to move into and in that case the pathologist would call out Perineural Invasion. Most likely it has no significance. However, there are cases that the cancer cells follow the nerves and move outside the prostate. During surgery, we will be careful to see if the cancer affects the nerve bundles and if so, we may not be able to save the bundles. Your Second Opinion Summary: 6 of the positive biopsy are G(3+3), 2 are G(3+4) and they are not that extensive, ranging from 5 to 40% of the tissues. I would say intermediate risk (due to the 2 G7) and moderately extensive cancer (8 of 12 cores ranged from 5% to 40%), so, there is a good chance your cancer is still organ confined. I use the Memorial Sloan-Kettering nomogram to calculate your odds using PSA of 5.6 from your first post on this thread: Extent of Disease Probability Indolent Cancer N/A Organ Confined Disease 69% Extracapsular Extension 33% Seminal Vesicle Invasion 3% Lymph Node Involvement 2.4% Primary Treatment Outcome Progression Free Probability after Radical Prostatectomy 5 Year 90% 10 Year 86% Probability of Cancer-Specific Survival 10 Year 99% 15 Year 99% Your odds of organ confined are actually better than mine. Your survival odds are also excellent. Of course this is just a fellow sufferer's non professional opinion. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Title: Dying Process with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: George, I agree with you but I think many doctors' are practicing the "first, do no harm" philosophy since ART/SRT present their own problems for many patients some as Fairwind mentioned, so it is really up to the patients to decide how aggressive they want to be. With my biopsy history, I was mentally preparing for the worst and was preparing to go aggressive as I wanted to gain the advantage of time against cancer spreading. I had surgery less than two months after the positive biopsy. If my PSA turned out to be detectable six weeks after surgery, or my pathology report was really bad, I probably would go ART/SRT a lot sooner than most. Good luck to you and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Delaying RT after surgery may of worse outcomes then doing it ASAP

Posts.Content: The odds of a 33 year old having prostate cancer is very very small, even if you have a family history. What you need to do is monitor your PSA regularly, perhaps yearly. Early detection is the key to long term survival. Preemptively taking out your prostate is not a good solution as the risks of side effects are not worth it. Also, after prostate surgery, you will not be able to have kids again.

Posts.Title: Spasms after catheter removal

Posts.Content: If for some reasons the newer classes of drugs like Zytiga, Xtandi and Provence are not available, ask his oncologist about older medications like estrogen, ketoconazole, flutamide, nilutamide...which can be used if his cancer is castrate resistant. Also, some doctors prescribe metformin and statins together as an off label adjuvant treatment. Don't give up, there are still a lot that can be done.
Posts.Title: Sudden increase in PSA by 150%during 3 month- orchiectomy done (3 Yrs ago)

Posts.Content: Jim215, Thank you for your comments. Looks like Ganesh answered yours and my questions regarding chemo. And you are correct, once metastasized, cancer can only be controlled and not cured. However, often it can be controlled for a very long time, sometimes for over a decade. At this stage, the cancer is castrate resistant with PSA doubling time of about 4 months, so unless some other medications can slow it down, it will progress rapidly. Regards,
Posts.Title: Sudden increase in PSA by 150%during 3 month- orchiectomy done (3 Yrs ago)

Posts.Content: I noticed other than the moderator, no one comments so let me offer my non professional opinion: 1. Ask his doctor why he ruled out chemo (ill health?) The most recent clinical trial in the US indicated doing combined chemo and hormone early extended survival by about 40%. Also, with bone metastasis and lymph nodes positive, why radiation? With cancer already spread outside the prostate, radiation to kill the cancer within the prostate is kind of futile? 2. Going forward, find out how many bone met spots he has, if < 5, maybe they can spot radiate to kill off the cancer. Some oncologists here (Dr. Myers, e.g.) believe one can sometimes get durable remissions from spot rad if <5 spots (the term is oligometastasis). Same with lymph nodes, if only one or two and if they are outside the prior radiation field. 3. He has what is called castrate resistant prostate cancer, meaning his cancer is now immuned to testosterone and bicalutamide. If he does not do chemo, he can try Lupton with bicalutamide or move to second line hormones like Zytiga and/or Xtandi, or try immunotherapy like Provenge. However these are expensive treatments (here in the U.S. anyway). 4. He needs to do something or things can turn bad fast. With appropriate treatment hopefully cancer can be controlled and he can lead a normal life a long time. If it were me I would do chemotherapy but that is an opinion from a layperson. So please consult his oncologist. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Gleason 9 - First PSA post-surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Davis 928 Tumor focally present (<200nm) right posterior apex margin. All other margins free of tumor. No extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicles free of tumor, 11/11 lymph nodes negative. No lymph or vascular invasion. Perineural invasion present. Margin involved by invasive carcinoma, focal right apex (Gleason 4), without extraprostatic extension (inked margin within prostate tissue) There is no EPE meaning the cancer was all contained within the prostate but the pathologist found a positive margin at the apex. My layperson's interpretation is your surgeon cut too close at the apex and missed cutting everything out. However, I would not worry too much and all is not lost: The positive margin is indeed very tiny, only <200 nm (<.2mm) and you need a microscope to see it!! Since in Da Vinci, the surgeon use a "heat knife" most likely the act of surgery killed the remaining cancer cells so you should have undetectable PSA going forward, and even if PSA comes back some time later, salvage radiation should take care of it since you know where the source of PSA comes from in your case. Good luck and take care.

Posts.Title: Path Report, and nagging question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by LILDOG I have questions about the meaning of these positive margins in particular . 1. APEX: Positive , focal , right side. What does focal mean with this margin ? 2. PERIPHERAL: Positive , right lateral toward apex in area of capsular incision. What does capsular incision mean with this margin ? Could this positive margin be an artifact ? First, let's try to decipher the languages: 1. As HighlanderCFH said, focal means a single spot and according to a number of posters here, PM at the apex is more common. I don't know why. 2. PM on the right side, again near the apex. So, could be from the same general prostate cancers in or around the apex location. What were missing were descriptions of the sizes of the positive margins (pathologist uses mm to describe PM) and what Gleason grades and were there benign prostate tissues left behind. It is important because if there were benign tissues left behind no harm no foul. Also, if the PM is minor/small, the act of cutting could kill off the cancer cells (Read Dr. Walsh's book) and you can still be cancer free. So, ask your doctors to give you more details and ask for the full pathology report. It is yours and you have the rights to it. Your first PSA test will give an indication of the above. If the PMs are minor, PSA should be undetectable and perhaps will stay undetectable for a long time like some of us. If the post Op PSA is not undetectable, then you need to prepare for plan B unless they were caused by benign tissues. I won't worry about it for the time being, you should enjoy and focus on your recovery. Good luck.
