Posts.Title: Are these positive margins significant ? Possibly artifact ?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by traveler Thank you all for your feedback. I didn't get Medicare part B cause I've been living in Hong Kong the last 30 years. Hong Kong does have relatively free medical but long waiting lists and I'm not sure of their proficiency. I've heard mixed info - some good some bad. I've just spent the last year and a half in the States mostly visiting my two daughters - one in New York one in Missouri. Our funds are low but my PT daughter in NY helps out occasionally. So I've got options as to how to proceed. I'll keep you all posted and thanks again for all your great comments. I'm back in Hong Kong right now. If you qualify for Medicare part A and if you have low income, part B could be free or you could qualify for Medicaid which should be free to you. However, Medicare and Medicaid would not pay for your bill if you seek treatment outside of the US. My suggestion is to come back to Missouri or New York, apply for part B or Medicaid. The costs with US Government subsidy should be lower than out of pocket payment in HK. And you will get better quality care here in the US. With a PSA of 65, and symptoms of cancer (ED, frequent urination, etc.) if I were you, I would not ignore it. If you come back now, the enrollment time is before year end and you have time to seek treatment starting 1-1-2015. For prostate cancer that time frame is not unreasonable. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Post Biopsy Symptoms

Posts.Content: Jebstart, You had 2 excellent post op PSA and there is no reason to believe it won't stay that way. Looking at your post op pathology, everything is clean and excellent including negative margins, except a very minor issue: Periprostatic Fat Invasion: Present (a microscopic focus of adenocarcinoma is seen to extend beyond the prostate capsule into periprostatic connective tissues-Block 4 However, based on your excellent PSA results post op, your surgeon probably got all of the fat invasion out so no more cancer. A good surgeon will take as much of the fat around the prostate out just in case and looks like yours did. Good luck.

Here, I would like to ask one more question that, Is PSA below 4.0 ng/ml to be considered as normal?? Also whether this increases in multiplication (e.g. 2 to 4, then 8,16,32,64,128 etc.) or any other base & with what kind of time gap? Thanks alot dear friends. Ganesh, Thank you for answering my question regarding chemo. PSA below 4 is consider normal for folks without treatment. In your Dad's case, based on the PSA you provided, I calculated his PSA doubling time to be about 4 months (latest reading was .99 and in 4 months will be about 2). Please consult his physician to see what else can be done. Regards,
Posts.Title: Sudden increase in PSA by 150%during 3 month- orchiectomy done (3 Yrs ago)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Derkie54 Thanks for the reply Brad the dre showed a very hard left side with the right feeling normal. Non of the images showed evidence of spread and up till now I have only had IMRT. When I was first diagnosed, I researched both options and even at that time all indications were the cure rates were about the same for localized cancer. For cancers that were more advanced (high risks - high Gleason, high psa...) radiation was actually better. It came down to personal choice and biases. More recently, I came across a number of studies that indicated hormone + radiation produced fewer BCR and longer survival. Another study, indicated for radiation, low psa nadir predicted much better outcome in terms of BCR and survival. So, your particular stats are actually very encouraging, G7, low nadir, etc. If I were you, I would discuss with my oncologist about combination therapy to see if that is an option for me or should I just wait it out. Good luck.
Posts.Title: What Are The Chances Of PC Returning After Radiation Treatment

Posts.Content: If for some reasons the newer classes of drugs like Zytiga, Xtandi and Provence are not available, ask his oncologist about older medications like estrogen, ketoconazole, flutamide, nilutamide...which can be used if his cancer is castrate resistant. Also, some doctors prescribe metformin and statins together as an off label adjuvant treatment. Don't give up, there are still a lot that can be done.
Posts.Title: Sudden increase in PSA by 150%during 3 month- orchiectomy done (3 Yrs ago)

Posts.Content: Some surgeons kept statistics like: How many done, % of positive margins, % continence, % without ED, etc. Some don't. Ask him to give you specifics. However, it is important to feel comfortable with whoever you choose. I could go anywhere and interviewed a few but ended up picking a local surgeon who had done hundreds by the time he operated on me. He was willing to share some of his statistics and provided names of his patients so I could check references. It helped my decision when I found out the hospital's Chief of Radiation Physics and the Chief of Pathology of another hospital selected him to operate on their prostate cancers. Good luck.

Posts.Title: DaVinci 6/25/2013

Posts.Content: If the recommendation is surgery + radiation, then you should forego surgery and do radiation (brachy + IMRT) + hormone. For high risk cases with high PSA and a potential of extraprostatic extension, radiation + hormone is the new gold standard. I had found studies that said for initiating treatment, neoadjuvant hormone + radiation gave significant survival advantage vs radiation alone. However, neoadjuvant hormone + surgery conferred no advantage vs surgery alone. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Staging Results And A Few More Questions

Posts.Content: Like a lot of folks diagnosed with prostate cancer, I hit the research trails to find if diet and exercise could "cure" my cancer. I have been unable to find any credible evidence that diet and exercise alone can cure prostate cancer. There are a lot of unsubstantiated claims, testimonials... What is sad is a lot of folks try to profit from the misery of us cancer sufferers by selling false hopes that have no benefits. What is needed is a randomized double blind clinical trial. For example, claims of vitamin E, saw palmetto were not substantiated by randomized, double blind clinical trials as the trials showed no benefit at all. As for your negative biopsy, it does not mean your cancer is now gone, it could simply mean the biopsy missed the cancer this time. Remember, a biopsy samples ~1/1000 of your prostate each time.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Biopsy Negative

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KenHayes First time on forum, just wanted to meet up with others in the same boat, share my initial outcome from surgery and see what you folks think. Diagnosed June, 2015, 2 of 12 cores showed cancer, 5% and 10%, Gleason 9 (4+5), had surgery in August, Seminal vesicles impacted, and one lymph node of 24 had a VERY small number of TINY, TINY (doc's words) micro cells. Initial PSA was 10.9. Got my first PSA today post-surgery, came back at <.019 - which to me (as a Gleason 9) makes me very encouraged, and tells me it was caught early. I know I'll be monitored closely for the rest of my life, but am I on track with that thinking? Thanks, Ken Welcome Ken. I think you got lucky and caught yours just in time. By taking out the lymph node that had a "tiny" cancer your surgeon probably got them all. People with your statistics with initial undetectable PSA had 5 & 10 year survival rates not too different from those with similar statistics that were organ confined. Since you are a G9, to enhance your chances you may want to discuss additional adjuvant treatments with an oncologist to see if you can be more proactive. You may also want to consider taking pomegranate juice as that seemed to have some beneficial effects on slowing PSA rise if your PSA is detectable after surgery though a new study casted doubt on that claim. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Easing the prostatectomy experience for husband

Posts.Content: rooster, Welcome back. Looks like he has excellent outcome even with the positive margins (two undetectable PSA post-op). Quite often, positive margins do not mean some cancer cells are left behind. Quite a few people had positive margins but were cancer free for years. In Dr. Walsh's book, he explained the reasons for that in some details. First a couple of questions: 1. Did his surgeon put him on hormone therapy right after surgery? If not, the two undetectable PSA's after surgery were very good news as they indicated good surgical outcome and that the fear of metastasized cancer in your prior posts was unfounded. 2. Even with positive margins, for his age and stats, often time if post-op PSA's are undetectable, physicians tend to wait before taking adjuvant treatments. Why did his physician put him on hormone and wanted to start radiation? There must be a reason and you need to ask the doctor, or better seek a second opinion from an oncologist. So, something does not add up here. In any case, from your post, his surgery appeared to be successful, scans were clear and there was no upgrade of aggressiveness from the post op pathology report, so, he and you should not worry too much. Enjoy your holiday.

Posts.Title: Gleason 9 - First PSA post-surgery

Posts.Content: Since no one responded so let me give it a try. However, I am a lay person and not a radiologist so my interpretation may be all wrong. First of all, MRI is like X-ray, you get images of your organs and only an experience radiologist can interpret the results based on looking at many many images of cancer and normal tissues. And in MRI, there are several types of images for the radiologist to look at. You mentioned "with and without contrast agent", so one discriminant is to look at the differences between an area with and without contrasting agent. This is call DCEI. Another is to look at the shades and is call DWI. A third is call T2WI which uses a different signal. Even then, the outcome is not certainty but probability. So, in all cases, imaging is for a preliminary diagnosis and biopsy is for a definitive diagnosis. The diagnosis is actually very encouraging: The bad - You do have one spot that looked suspicious. The radiologist believed there was a 50% probability of cancer based on the image characteristics (one out of three parametric criteria, probably DWI or diffusion weighted imaging, was positive). The good - There is no evidence of tumor getting out of the prostate, the seminal vesicles are clear, the lymph nodes look fine, there are no bone met and bladder invasion. Overall, even if it were positive for cancer, it looked very localized and early stage. Please consult your doctor. Good luck.
Posts.Title: MRI need help on results

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MN Mike I think I'm going to have to get more assertive, so far these dr.s cut me off when I try to describe what I'm experiancing. Side effects are so bad some days I can't hardly drag myself off the couch, it's usually after a nite of having to hit the bathroom 7-8 times besides the flushing and I swear some days I ache in every joint in my body. Add to that the feeling of being lower than whale poo. I feel for you but you may want to think twice about doing orchiectomy. From what I read, all the issues and side effects you are having with hormone shots will be there with orchiectomy. And it is not reversible so if the side effects are unbearable with hormone shot you at least have the ability to stop if you really want to but with orchiectomy you are lock-in forever. There maybe medications, activities (exercise for example) you can take to reduce the side effects. Your doctors can advise you on that. Find a different physician if yours are not responsive to your sufferings. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Advance Sling 8 week post op visit with Surgeon/Urologist

Posts.Content: I just updated my database and this is a more recent article and their conclusion: http://europepmc.org/articles/pmc4215584 PCa remains a challenging disease to treat primarily in the advanced setting. Once metastasized, PCa is treated with systemic therapy with little focus on the primary tumor based on the assumption that the metastases are the driving force of the cancer. However, some intriguing evidence shows a potential benefit in treating the primary tumor as in other malignancies. It has also been shown that locally advanced cancer can be operated on with comparable outcomes lending further support for local control. Taken together, and despite the plethora of weak evidence, there seems to be a foundation on which to build upon in future carefully performed clinical trials regarding the role of cytoreductive prostatectomy in mPCa. So it seems promising and currently there is a phase II clinical trial (NCT01751438 ) that is accruing patients at MD Anderson Cancer Center and will randomize patients with hormone-sensitive, M1 prostate cancer to best-systemic therapy or best-systemic therapy plus radiation or surgery with the primary end-point being progression-free survival.
Posts.Title: Why not remove the prostate in the case of Stage 4 PCA

Posts.Content: Other than Radiologists, physicians are generally not trained to read MRI images, so I am not surprised your urologist won't answer your questions except in general terms he obtained from the Radiologist report.
Posts.Title: MRI need help on results

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by heal1949 -Current advise by MDs is to get off hormonal therapy. He is now trying to get off all grains, all proteins and carbs. heal1949, I wasn't going to respond to your post because I just don't see any benefits of the so call Budwig protocol. I was unable to find any clinical evidences (clinical trials, studies in medical journals...) that it has any benefits. But since you posted your father's case history, I thought it maybe helpful for me to give you my layperson's opinions. First of all I am very surprised that with a post op PSA of .46 his MD, instead of adding additional medications wanted him to get off hormone and do what? If the answer is Budwig, he needs to run and find another MD to help him with his cancer recurrence. There are lot's of options including salvage radiation, combining hormone with chemo, etc., if he is willing to go that route. Second, as for diet supplements, there may be others but the only supplements/diets I am aware of that had gone through clinical trials and showed some promises were pomegranate juice and a supplement combining pomegranate, broccoli, green tea and turmeric extracts. But even there, the evidences were not strong. A recent clinical trial of pomegranate extract vs placebo showed no evidence that pomegranate extract did anything different than the placebo pills. So, my advice is go get a second opinion from another oncologist who specializes in treating prostate cancer, eat a healthy diet and exercise to keep him fit so he can take on the rigor of treatment protocols. He is in a fight and needs to be healthy to keep cancer at bay. Good luck and best wishes to your dad.

Posts.Title: Anyone used or heard of the Budwig protocol

Posts.Content: You asked an excellent question and there is really no good answers. From discussions with my surgeon and reading studies, it seemed debulking the cancer did offer benefits to some patients regarding increased survival but it depends on how extensive the cancer and the health and age of the patients. Here are a couple of of the studies I read: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22313515 http://www.researchgate.net/publicat...rostate_cancer If your Dad is in his forties, healthy and fit perhaps surgery to get the prostate and all the lymph nodes out may provide benefits but at his age I suspect focusing on managing the cancer is a better way to go. However, I am not in healthcare so please discuss it with his oncologist. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Why not remove the prostate in the case of Stage 4 PCA

Posts.Content: I just updated my database and this is a more recent article and their conclusion: http://europepmc.org/articles/pmc4215584 PCa remains a challenging disease to treat primarily in the advanced setting. Once metastasized, PCa is treated with systemic therapy with little focus on the primary tumor based on the assumption that the metastases are the driving force of the cancer. However, some intriguing evidence shows a potential benefit in treating the primary tumor as in other malignancies. It has also been shown that locally advanced cancer can be operated on with comparable outcomes lending further support for local control. Taken together, and despite the plethora of weak evidence, there seems to be a foundation on which to build upon in future carefully performed clinical trials regarding the role of cytoreductive prostatectomy in mPCa. So it seems promising and currently there is a phase II clinical trial (NCT01751438 ) that is accruing patients at MD Anderson Cancer Center and will randomize patients with hormone-sensitive, M1 prostate cancer to best-systemic therapy or best-systemic therapy plus radiation or surgery with the primary end-point being progression-free survival.
Posts.Title: Why not remove the prostate in the case of Stage 4 PCA

Posts.Content: You asked an excellent question and there is really no good answers. From discussions with my surgeon and reading studies, it seemed debulking the cancer did offer benefits to some patients regarding increased survival but it depends on how extensive the cancer and the health and age of the patients. Here are a couple of of the studies I read: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22313515 http://www.researchgate.net/publicat...rostate_cancer If your Dad is in his forties, healthy and fit perhaps surgery to get the prostate and all the lymph nodes out may provide benefits but at his age I suspect focusing on managing the cancer is a better way to go. However, I am not in healthcare so please discuss it with his oncologist. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Why not remove the prostate in the case of Stage 4 PCA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Notpretty PSA 18.7 and 14.9 over a two week period. Notpretty, First of all, PSA increases due to BPH do not go up as rapidly as yours indicated. Also, the normal relation between PSA and prostate size indicated if all the PSA is due to BPH, you would have a huge prostate of over 300 cc, and certainly your doctor should be able to feel it with a DRE and told you so. Second, a year ago PSA was 2.1 and a year later 18.7. It had a doubling time of less than 4 months and the only logical explanation are either an infection or cancer. The good news is two weeks later it was 14.9, if it is cancer, it is unlikely to drop by almost 4 points. Your doctor should: 1. perform a DREto see if he/she can detect any abnormality, 2. prescribe a course of antibiotics to see if he/she can drive the PSA down, before sending you to a urologist. Anyway, good luck and let's hope it is infection and we can reject your membership application.

Posts.Title: cancer vs inflamed/infected prostate

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Notpretty One question. BPH...I don't have trouble peeing or typical symptoms of BPH so I doubt its that, but can a person have an infection in the prostate that survives 10 days of cipro and not have a fever or other symptoms of infection? Looks like I either have an infection or a seriously fast growing cancer...if the latter, it means a PSA doubling each 4 months....so how urgent is treatment. HighlanderCFH gave you some very good answers. Here let me just add a couple of comments to his response: 1. Sometimes infections and especially chronic inflammation of the prostate are difficult to get rid of even with antibiotics. Some infections are resistant to Cipro too. So it is always possible a 10 day course of Cipro will not get rid of it. 2. The good news with prostate cancer, if there is such a thing as good news, is that even with the so call aggressive type, it is not that fast growing so you should have time to deal with it. The important thing after biopsy is, if positive, understand the extend and Gleason scores. If aggressive G7+, don't wait too long and deal with it as soon as practical. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: cancer vs inflamed/infected prostate

Posts.Content: You have a good RO. He is right to want to review your case thoroughly. A post op PSA of 8.2 could mean cancer is outside the prostate bed. Did your surgeon take out lymph nodes, and what was your pre op PSA? You might want to discuss with your oncologist about starting chemo early to get a jump, as a mopping action, on catching any cancer cells that are not killed by the hormone, in place of or in addition to radiation. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Salvage Radiation Questions, and should I see a Urologist or Oncologist after surgery

Posts.Content: Short answer is yes. If you are organ confined or localized, 10 year cancer specific survival today is almost 100% due to better understanding of treatment combinations, improved surgery techniques and especially great advances in radiation technology. New hormone treatments, immunotherapy and chemo all helped with survival. If you are already metastasized at detection, the outcome improvement is better but not as significant. That is why many of us advocate PSA testing to give us as much of a fighting chance as possible through early detection. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman I got my PCa3 results today and it came back at a 26. The nurse told me, as a different nurse did 2 years ago, that the cutoff is 25, so i am on the cusp. Two years ago, it was 13. She also told me its not necessarily an indication of cancer, its a test that shows whether i have inherited the PC gene, much like the gene for Breast Cancer . I thought it was a test for presence of a genetic material given off by cancer cells, WHEN THEY ARE PRESENT. So i am confused. Because 1. i was pretty sure that i was right regarding what it showed, but the nurse seems pretty knowledgeable 2. from what i've read online, and what i got from a member of another forum, the normal cutoff is 35 not 25, but two nurses told me it was 25. Anybody know the right answers? If this is high, combined with a jump in my PSA from 3.1 to 4.3 over 6 months and a %fPSA of 12, i think i am screwed. Biopsy is tomorrow. I already have it in my mind to get appointments with Samadi and Tewari. UGH NYC GMAN and you are smarter than your nurse. Is this the same nurse that told you your prostate volume was 22cc? LOL. I believe the accepted cut off is 35, i.e., most doctors worry if the number is above 35. At 25 it is 50/50.

Posts.Title: PCA3 question

Posts.Content: Welcome and best of luck to you. Modern Da Vinci surgery is very safe but I agree with Highlander that it is very important to have a surgeon who is very experience with the Da Vinci method, with perhaps hundreds of procedures done under his/her belt. This is a very complex surgery (I was in OR for 5 hours), a one shot deal and there is no do over. Studies after studies indicated a good surgeon not only had better cancer outcome but could also minimize having side effects. Your PSA history and stats indicated you have caught your cancer early and should have a very good outcome. Take care.

Posts.Title: scared but hopeful

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by erickpaul I became castrate resistant and was taken off casadex (in combination with Lupron) and replaced with Zytiga. After 3 weeks they told me to stop taking the Zytiga because my blood work was indicating the loss of kidney and liver functions. I know my pain will be coming back but I don't know what options are going to out there for me. Anyone know where this goes? Thank you. Sorry to hear about your problems with Zytiga. Liver functions problem is indeed one of them. If serious, your physician will take you off Zytiga. There are however quite a few other options your physician will try, including Xtandi, Provenge and Jevtana just to name a few. So, chin up and don't give up. Best wishes and good luck to you.
Posts.Title: Taken off of Zytiga due to Kidneys and Liver

Posts.Content: Since there is no swelling, perhaps it is not epididymitis but just some nerve damages due to surgery. If so, it should subside eventually. But as FeatherBoy said: Consult your physician to make sure there is no infection. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: 2 months post-op (new member) w/testicle pain

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by VW Tuner Questions: - I get this "Charlie Horse" feeling, so painful, when I urinate. Is this related to my prostate? I have had this pain, for about a decade, but never asked anyone. - I smell ammonia/chemicals, most of the day. The smell is in my nose. Anyone heard of this, or better yet, does this tie into the prostate at all? - PSA of 10.1, at 26 years old, do I need to be mentally preparing myself for some really bad news? Thanks! Sorry you are here but I don't think you will join our rank anytime soon. Your symptoms could be another bad case of prostatitis again. Or some other problem, like bladder or kidney.... I have been reading up on prostate cancer for several years and have not come across anyone having it at the young age of 26. There are three things that can cause a high PSA: enlarged prostate (due to old age), infection and cancer. Oh, also, if you had sex, a DRE, irritated the prostate in any way like riding a bike for a long time prior to PSA test, your PSA would go up. Anyway, your urologist should be able to sort it out for you. Good luck and do not worry too much.

Posts.Title: PSA .7 DRE showed Mass

Posts.Content: 52 Year old Pre Surgery PSA - 4.1 Pre Surgery Biopsy - 8 of 12 cores positive - Gleason 7 Da Vinci Robotic Surgery - June 3, 2015 Prostate Capsule Penetration - one nerve bundle, Seminal Vesicle and 11 Lymph nodes removed Post Op PSA - July 3rd - 0.05 Post Op Biopsy - Gleason 9 Hormone treatments (six month interval) - First Lupron injection July 3rd Radiation Treatments - 38 - treatments began September 22, 2015 - Last treatment was November 12, 2015 Second Lupron injection December 31st - PSA non-detectable: 0.04 Oncologist visit February 22, 2016 Told there is an 80% chance the cancer will return (no cure, moved to containment mode) Your post op Gleason 9 is aggressive and the two lung nodules are worrisome. However, let's hope the two lung nodules are not cancer and if so, it is highly likely your cancer is still local and treatable. I am glad you and your medical team took an aggressive approach for at a young age of 52 you have many more years to go. If I were in your situation I would do exactly the same. A couple of thoughts: Have your team contemplated doing a genetic test to see if for example you carry the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes and have your pathologist identified the types of prostate cancer you carried. A more specific treatment strategy can sometimes be formulated to treat specific situations. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rooster0330 Does this mean it metastasized? His first post op PSA came back less than 0.01. His doctor is not all the concerned , he will start radiation as soon as he gains control of his bladder, he has started hormone therapy though. My question is about whether it has metastasized or not and if that PSA post op means anything Rooster0330, Welcome. The good news is based on his post op pathology (though a little skimpy from your post) and PSA, most likely he has localized, organ confined prostate cancer. The only negative is his surgeon left a little behind hence the "positive margins". Quite often, the act of surgery will kill those cancer cells that were left behind (according to Dr. Walsh's book). As lancepeace said, his doctor wanted to start adjuvant radiation and hormone to ensure that nothing is left to chances. However, not all oncologists agree that adjuvant radiation/hormone is the way to go in this case when the post op PSA is undetectable. It is worthwhile for your dad to seek a second opinion. If you like, you can post a more detail write up of his pathology report as there maybe some other factors that caused his doctor to want to start adjuvant treatments, also so that some others can make additional comments and share their experiences. Good luck.

Warren Buffett, Governor Jerry Brown were two recent examples, both pronounced their prostate cancers were early stage, very low risks yet they both chose to treat their "early, low risk' cases with radiation. Posts.Title: Does that Cancer really need to be removed ?

Posts.Content: I do have a couple of comments: 1. Come to think of it, after surgery I had no incontinence but my urinary frequency was quite high, about once every 1 to 2 hours but the stream was very strong. That gradually lengthened to where it is now easily 5 to 6 hrs and I can sleep through the night without getting up. This compared with prior to surgery where I had to get up several times at night and urinate every hrs during the day and each time took several minutes with very weak stream. So, your physician is correct, your bladder will get more "elastic" after removing years of constraints from the prostate, and things will improve. 2. Don't know if bowel habits would change due to surgery but it can certainly change due to antibiotics killing off your gut bacterias and new types taking root inside. If I were you, I would buy some probiotics to repopulate your gut with "good' bacterias. I did after surgery and noticed better bowel habits since. Good luck.

Posts.Content: indypaul, I am very sorry to hear about your situation. Please get a second opinion and perhaps get a biopsy of the lung done to find out if it is primary or second from your prostate. Prostate cancers do metastasize to lung and liver. If it is prostate cancer, there are a lot of weapons left for you to use. If lung/liver, the new chemo drugs are more effective so there may still be hope. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: bummer

Posts.Content: Being an athlete and in good shape should help you recover from surgery faster than most. However, it is better to err on the caution side when it come to vigorous exercise after surgery. The surgeon will rearrange your plumbing and internal organs and it takes time to heal. Hernia and stitches coming apart could be messy. My doc told me not to lift anything over 5-10 lb for 4 weeks, not to do any vigorous exercise for 6-8 weeks and to avoid fly (risk of deep vein thrombosis) long distance for 2-3 months.

Posts.Content: I took your #, compared the MSK nomogram with the Johns Hopkins "Patin" Table and the Johns Hopkins probability of organ confined is not as good as the MSK probability. So, my opinion is that your radiation oncologist's plan is a good one for your case, but I would add hormone to the mix as studies indicated that if you want to take the route of radiation, adding hormone to the mix improves survival and reduces BCR (biochemical recurrence). That said, I agree with Highlander that you might as well complete your appointment with the robotic surgeon before you finally decide. By the way, Dr. Grimm, D.O., has published many articles on brachy therapy and is a well respected radiation oncologist. His results were peer reviewed and are credible. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Hi Julie, Welcome. You asked some very excellent questions. Let me give you my thoughts. First of all, for advanced aggressive cancer, hormone is an accepted treatment option and often in the hands of an experienced oncologist, can keep the cancer under control for a long time. Second, as you may have already realized, it is not curative but palliative. Finally, I think radiotherapy (and/or surgery) on the other hand can be curative for local, locally advanced or even some that spread to local adjacent organs. It is unusual for physicians not to prescribe radiation therapy if the patient requests it. Usually it is because of age, physical limitations, health issues or they think radiotherapy would not help. And, normally for G8 and PSA of 9, radiation + hormone should be a very viable option and studies showed to be superior compared to just radiotherapy alone. I am sure that is why you are asking all these questions. Your father needs to raise the issue with his physician and also seeks a second opinion from an experienced radiation oncologist. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy with enlarged prostate

Posts.Content: Tazz, Welcome. Sorry you are here but we are fellow sufferers and can share our experiences with you to make your journey easier. Here are three main points: 1. First of all, you need to get an accurate clinical staging of your cancer. The two clinical reports of your biopsy samples are too different. The reading and staging (Gleason scores) are very subjective and if a pathologist had not seen too many prostate cancer slides, he might not be calling them correctly. Usually pathologists at academic institutions are better so you may want to send the samples/slides to U Penn, U Pittsburg or Johns Hopkins for a third read. 2. Once you know if you are a G6 or a G7, you can then start to look at treatment options. If G6, you might wait and do AS otherwise, radiation or surgery. If you are technically inclined, you can start drawing up a decision tree and eventually arrive at the path you are most comfortable with. In the US, you are the decision maker, not your urologist. 3. As for good surgeons or good radiation oncologists, you won't find any published rating system so mostly it is through word of mouth, look at how many surgeries the surgeon or the rad onco had done (should be >300-500 in both cases), talk to their patients.... I attended a few sessions of my local cancer support groups to listen in on their issues and find out who their doctors were. Some seeked out surgeons that published their results in academic journals as many of them reported outstanding results. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by joeflorida Id sincerely appreciate any guidance anyone here may provide with the probability of prostate cancer based upon the information provided. My PSA history is as follows- ( all DRE's negative ) 04/14 second biopsy ( results pending ) 02/14 10.5 06/13 8.9 01/13 7.2 05/12 6.5 and first negative biopsy 08/11 5.9 Additionally, my grandfather, father and uncle had PC in their later years in life. My concern with my high PSA levels is that I am both overweight and taking medication that normally lowers ones PSA readings. joeflorida, Welcome and here are my input to your requests: 1. Your PSA history is actually very similar to mine. Your family history of prostate cancer is also very similar to mine. So, your chance of getting prostate cancer could be similar. However, no two cases are alike, so, I may be all wrong. 2. But, like Mikla, I calculated your PSA doubling time to be ~3 years, meaning if the trend continues, your PSA will be ~20 in another three years, so even if you have cancer you have time to catch it and treat it. 3. Even with a large prostate, ~95cc, your PSA attributable to normal prostate cells is ~ 6, so there are ~ 4 units due to something else. That could be infection/inflammation, or cancer. But just like in mine case, a persistent increase could be cancer whereas infection/inflammation sometimes showed erratic behaviors tends to go up and down. Mind you, these are just my lay person's view. 4. As another poster stated, with such a large prostate, a 12 core could miss a lot of real estates so perhaps if your biopsy comes back negative again, next year you should go for a saturation biopsy to get a better picture of what your situation is. 5. And, perhaps take a course of antibiotics to see if your PSA would go down and attribute your excess PSA to infection/inflammation. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Date for Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by johnT I have always had an issue using the term "gold standard" to describe any prostate cancer treatment, especially surgery as it is very misleading to patients. How can we identify something as a "gold standard" that has less than a 70% chance of curing the intermediate and higher grade cancers that are the ones most likely to harm us, while causing permanant side effects in about 50% of patients. If this is a "gold standard" then the bar is being set really low. Until we can get cure rates into the 90% and eliminate side effects due to treatment there is no "gold standard" JohnT JohnT, I agree with most of your post except this. What I have found is that published results can support both camps and in the end it is the practitioners that determine the outcome. I can Quote Dr. Grimm's excellent results and I can also quote Dr. Walsh's excellent results in the same sentence because both are top physicians in their own field and both get you the best possible outcome with their treatment methodology. Many practitioners probably would not have done as well. I collected and studied numerous medical publications on prostate cancer treatments and can cite publications after publications to support both positions. Until a randomized double blind clinical trial can be done to determine whether surgery is still the gold standard, or barachy is the "new" gold standard, us layperson can only take the studies with a grain of salt. In terms of side effects, Dr. Walsh was able to achieve ~85% potency (for men that were potent prior to surgery) and 98% continence. As for cancer outcome, Johns Hopkins' Han Tables (again peer reviewed publications) indicated someone with intermediate G(3+4), PSA between 4-10 has a 84% to 91% (T2 a and b biopsy) probability of undetectable PSA after 10 years. MSK gave about the same odds. John, these are the ~90% cure rate that you are looking for. Prostate cancer is a complicated disease and until definitive tests can be done to precisely determine what we have cancer wise, choosing treatment is still a gamble. The good news for Fauntleroy is that his cancer is most likely still localized and that both options presented him with good odds of coming out OK, provided he pick a good practitioner! Highlander, you have given the poster some very good advices, keep them coming. Peace and best wishes to all, especially Fauntleroy.

Posts.Content: anitaaraujo, Welcome. First of all, if I were him I won't spend any money on the Naturopath's supplements, especially not for $600 per month. At this stage it is a waste of money, rather I would listen to my oncologist who should know how to keep the cancer at bay for as long as possible. I would encourage him to go ahead and do chemo especially since he is very healthy and can withstand the rigor of chemo. Numerous recent studies found the combination of early chemo and hormone prolonged survivals by over 40%, so it will significantly increase the control of his cancer. At this stage his cancer cannot be eradicated but can still be managed for a long time with the right sequencing and combination of drugs. Good luck and best wishes.

If I were your DH, I would just follow his surgeon's protocol. Good luck.

Posts.Content: dsnyfans, Welcome. I am sorry to hear about your husband's situation. Renal cell cancer is highly curable if caught early, so hopefully he is in full remission there. Same thing with prostate cancer, if caught early, it is also highly curable. Gleason 4+4 is fairly agressive and should be treated as soon as possible. Only 2 cores positive, so hopefully it is organ confined and he caught it early. Both surgery and radiation are equal in treatment outcome. However, since he just had a nephrectomy, perhaps radiation (brachy + IMRT) is a better choice? Please consult a radiation oncologist and a surgeon for their recommendation. Good luck to you and your husband.

However, it is better to err on the caution side when it come to vigorous exercise after surgery. The surgeon will rearrange your plumbing and internal organs and it takes time to heal. Hernia and stitches coming apart could be messy. My doc told me not to lift anything over 5-10 lb for 4 weeks, not to do any vigorous exercise for 6-8 weeks and to avoid fly (risk of deep vein thrombosis) long distance for 2-3 months.

Posts.Title: What is running like after radical prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: You are right, Propecia, like Proscar will reduce your PSA by about half, so your prior PSA of around 1.0 translated into about 2.0 when you got off Propecia. For a normal size prostate, for a 40-50 year old, at around 25-30 cc, your "normal" PSA should roughly be around 2, so your slightly enlarged prostate giving off PSA of around 2.5 is not too alarming according to my non professional opinion and calculation. If your PSA stays around 2.5 and not increasing monotonically I don't think you should be too worry, as long as DRE is normal and there are no other symptoms. Best to you.

Posts.Title: Spike in PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rhome I am currently on triple blockade vacation. My psa at the time in May was .005. What is the chance they find bone mets in the scan. A PSA of .005 after triple blockade is very good news. It indicates your PSA nadir is extremely low and most if not all of your cancer cells are sensitive to hormone. Someone with your case should enjoy many years of good results. Furthermore, if your PSA was .005 in May of this year, not likely that a bone scan will detect bone mets. Usually unless PSA is over 5-10 bone scan should be clear, even if mets does exist, they will be too small to show up. Good luck, be happy and enjoy life.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by sapporo before 0,080 it was 0,064 sapporo, Sorry you have to be here but welcome. Like us most likely he tested his PSA every three months for the first year so he should have at least 4 to 5 PSA readings. Do you have his PSA history? If you do you can calculate his doubling time using EXCEL curve fit software. The MSK nomogram would not estimate doubling time for any number less than .1 since it is known that small PSA numbers (<.1) tend to bounce around a lot and are not reliable predictors. However, to play devil's advocate, using just the two number you provided, and assumed a linear increase, the doubling time is >12 month which, even if the cancer is coming back, is very good news as doubling time of >12 months predicts very good outcome. Of course I am not a physician and my opinion is just a layperson's opinion. Good luck.

Posts.Content: TL, Since your husband works overseas and probably cannot afford a long absence, you may want to consult with a radiation oncologist who practices SBRT (a relatively new radiation approach). The advantage of SBRT is the number of treatments are down to 4 or 5 instead of the 40 to 50 sessions of IMRT and Proton. According to a recent study, it has finally accumulated enough data to indicate equal/better(?) outcome when used as a first line treatment. There seemed to be less side effects too. Good luck.

"Not identified" is a standard term used by pathologist to indicate negative finding. It is like saying they could not find or identify any cancer in the sample. Posts.Title: Final Pathology Report (silly question)

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jebstart I have 2 questions for Highlander(since he mentioned the study) or Anyone else 1) You mentioned a John Hopkins study that no Gleason 6 patients had ever had metastasis. Do you have that information that I could read. I have a 6 and, as you can see by my history, although a negative margin, a microscopic amt got into the periprostatic fat. The following is the pathology result: Gleason Score 6(3+3) Tumor Quantitation 5-7% Extent of Invasion pT3a Regional Lymph Nodes Cannot be assessed Distant Metastasis Cannot be assessed Periprostatic Fat Invasion: Present (a microscopic focus of adenocarcinoma is seen to extend beyond the prostate capsule into periprostatic connective tissues-Block 4 There are medical studies stated that G6 never metastasized. For example: http://www.aua2013.org/abstracts/pri...cts.cfm?id=339 Well, Never is a very strong word. If you read the article carefully, you will find the picture not as clearcut. They stated that they examined 857 G6 men underwent prostatectomy and only 23 had BCR (biochemical recurrence). They then argued that with the exception of two, all were "cured" by SRT. Only two failed SRT and those two they reexamined the specimen and they upgraded them to G7. Therefore, some "G6", a very small percentages, did escape the capsule. We will never know if they would metastasized to distant organ since they were cured by SRT. Some then said those that metastasized were not "true G6". If that is true, the challenge is: How do we know we are "true G6" vs the "not true G6" if even post op pathology could not differentiate them? If you are technically inclined, there are scientific articles that supported both sides of the arguments: G6 can metastasized by mutating to G7, G8, G9... And those that stated G6, G7, G8... had different genetic makeup so they evolved differently. The bottom line IMHO is the jury is still out on this subject. Your case is one that showed G6 can spread to adjacent tissues and you are been classified as a T3a even though you are a G6 from a pathological point of view. The good news for G6 is that no matter whether G6 can metastasize, the long term survival of G6 is excellent. Both sides found that 10, 15 and even 20 year cancer specific survival of G6 who underwent prostatectomy were excellent. A 30 years Johns Hopkins study found ~95% cancer specific survival for those G6 that underwent prostatectomy at Johns Hopkins. What is interesting is this 30 years study indicated some G6 in their database did metastasize but we don't know if they are "true G6". For you, the statistics that matter is the high 30 year survival, whether G6 can spread or not is not as important. Take care and best wishes.

AgeInfo.Phrase: men underwent prostatectomy and only 23 had BCR  biochemical recurrence <Z>

Had a cystoscopy and a biopsy that indicated bladder was OK but prostate had cancer and the rest was history. For me, the cystoscopy is actually more uncomfortable than the biopsy. The good news for me is that not only did the surgery clear the prostate cancer but all of the symptoms are now history. So, there is hope. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Content: sapporo, With the three numbers you provided, assuming they were taken every three months, the doubling time is about 7.2 months, which is not too bad. However, they certainly indicated he probably has BCR (biochemical recurrence) and so you folks might want to start talking to a medical oncologist specializing in prostate cancer. I really don't know if starting hormone early is better or not, perhaps he can discuss it with the oncologist. Earlier studies indicated no difference (e.g. Dr. Walsh's book). However, I have read some recent articles that indicated better survival if hormone and salvage radiation were started early. Again, I am not making any recommendations, just a layperson's observations.

Posts.Title: 6 Months After DaVinci

Posts.Content: markinphoenix, I have no ED problem except it is dry. Full function returned about 1 month after surgery. Surgeon said his experience indicated taking 5 mg Cialis helped and he prescribed 90 days supply. I actually only took them for a week. Finally, yes, luck played a role too. Some patients in my cancer support group reported it took some time but things improved over time. I also think a lot depends on individual situations, cancer stage, skill of the surgeon and luck. In my case the cancer was organ confined but was actually extensive, worst than the biopsy report. My surgery took longer than normal but both bundles were saved. Timothy, I don't think keeping sexual function after robotic surgery is that rare. Many of the patients in my support group recovered. joedublin, I do not know about cryosurgery. In fact I was always curious as how the doctor preserved the nerve bundles during cryosurgery. I was able to find information on how they could saved the urethra by worming it but no one mentioned how to warm the nerves or did anything to protect them during cryosurgery.

Posts.Title: Home recovering

Posts.Content: From what I read, the side effects you described are common and should go away in time. How long they persist depend on individuals but for most will go away. The passing of seeds on the other hand is not usual as the seeds contain the radioactive elements that kill the cancer cells. I would consult with your radiation oncologist to make sure nothing is amiss. JohnT has seeds and has a lot of knowledge regarding brachytherapy. Perhaps he can comment or you might want to PM him.
Posts.Title: Problems after Brachytheraphy....help please.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SkipO Hello Am a newbie here but maybe I can help Had 60 seeds impanted 10/11/12 and still having problems urinating especially at nite. Doc put me on Flomax and have a few side effects, none of which are good. Dont even know if its helped as I dribble at nite but have a weak stream during the day. Dont want to increase Flomax as Im on 2 drugs for high bp. Have not passed any seeds, but feel like Im sitting on a deflated tennis ball when I sit anywhere anyone else having these same symtoms? Maybe I should have had the darn thing removed instead. Hope this is helpful. Best of luck in the future! SkipO, Welcome. Don't second guess yourself, you are only one month from having your procedure and it is still early. I hope and believe things will get better for you too. For us surgery guys, it was not a walk in the park either. The thing to remember is that whatever we chose, it was a major procedure and would take time for the body to heal. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gyndavid Just want to thank all of you for responding. I will keep you updated, but at present I do have appts to see a radiation oncologist and Dr Patel. I really appreciate all the input given here. The outcome will be about equal and it depends on which treatment you feel comfortable with. What is more important is to choose the best surgeon or radiation oncologist once you decide on the treatment. For surgery, in the hand of an outstanding surgeon like Dr. Patel, the side effects can be minimized. For radiation treatment (for example brachy), in the hand of an outstanding radiation oncologist like Dr. Grimm, the side effects can also be minimized. If you looked at their published outcome on side effects, both were excellent. Of course, every case is different and your situation often dictates the outcome.

Posts.Title: Radiation vs robotic prostatectomy, what should I do?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by LenM Greetings - I'm the guy who recently posted with the 2 PSA tests that were in the 570 range (five hundred seventy). Subsequent CT scans showed nothing. Bone scan showed nothing. I just got home from the biopsy where he collected samples everywhere from the prostate. Ultrasound did show a localized mass on the right side. He still cannot understand the crazy PSA number and the fact that things are not much worse. He did say I could have a raging infection, but I would have symptoms. I do not have any. He has never seen or heard of anything like my case. By the way, I'm supposed to have blood in my urine today from the biopsy. Well, I've gone twice and there's no blood. What the heck is going on with me? There are some areas of the prostate that are difficult for the biopsy needle to reach and can be missed. I remember one poster had many negative biopsies even after PSA went up to over 40. Turned out the cancer was hiding in areas difficult for the biopsy needle to reach. One person I know had all negative biopsies but cancer was found in the transition zone and was discovered when he did a TURP The other possibility is like all others said, a massive infection or chronic inflammation. But over 500 and no cancer would be the first I have read. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by steviez The worst thing at the min is thinking about the opt, I have never had one before. And as for the cancer I try not to dwell on it, and as for the Gleason score I don't know what the numbers mean hopefully you can tell me in laymens terms. Steviez Welcome. What you will find is most of us were actually in situation very similar to yours: I had never ever been in a hospital in my life until my operation. You will be antsy especially the few days before your operation and the day of your operation. Rest assure, you will go in, before you know it, you will go to sleep and wake up in the recovery room. You won't remember or feel a thing. The recovery is usually speedy, most of us were discharged after a two days stay. As for Gleason score, it usually starts at 6 and can go up to 10, 6 being the least aggressive. Your 3+4=7 means your cancer is not too aggressive and a cure is quite likely. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Content: Your article is perhaps out of date. Actually, the FDA in 2011 added a warning label on those drugs: 5-alpha reductase inhibitors (5-ARIs): Label Change - Increased Risk of Prostate Cancer Drugs in the 5-ARI class include finasteride and dutasteride. These drugs are marketed under the brand-names Proscar, Propecia, Avodart, and Jalyn [Posted 06/09/2011] AUDIENCE: Urology, Family Medicine, Internal Medicine ISSUE: FDA notified healthcare professionals that the Warnings and Precautions section of the labels for the 5-alpha reductase inhibitor (5-ARI) class of drugs has been revised to include new safety information about the increased risk of being diagnosed with a more serious form of prostate cancer (high-grade prostate cancer).

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by NavyChief I did have a PSA in May and it was 13.05. Biopsy came back as follows I had a 12 core done. All six cores on the right side were 3+4 90% and two on the left were 3+4 at 15% I saw a Dr Kamat down there who is a Surgeon and I went and got a consult from a radiation Dr. After those coversations I more or less decided on going the RP route. His notes since I hate typing so much Genitourinary exam: Digital rectal exam, he has a 3 x 3 x 3 cm prostate gland. Both lobes are firm and consistent with a clinical T2C exam. Outside hospital PSA 10/18/12 was 14.6. Outside hospital creatinine on 09/18/12 was 0.8. Outside hospital pathology report, left lateral apex 3+ 4, 15%; left lateral mid 3+ 4, 15%; right lateral apex 3+ 4, 95%; right lateral mid 3+ 4, 75%, right lateral base 3+ 4, 95%; right medial apex 3+ 4, 80%; right medial mid 3+4, 80%; right medial base 3+4, 90%. I must say that MD Anderson is definitely quick. I had a Bone Scan the same day as my appointment and then an MRI the next day. BONE SCAN RESULTS IMPRESSION: No active osseous metastases. MRI RESULTS Comparison: Bone scintigraphy, 11/14/2012. There is suggestion of minimal extraprostatic extension bilaterally, image 21 through 23, right greater than left, including in the region of neurovascular bundle. There is no evidence of seminal vesicle involvement, however. The urinary bladder is unremarkable. There are nonspecific mildly prominent bilateral iliac lymph nodes identified, image 22 through 25. These are most likely reactive lymph nodes, considering their size and appearance. There is indeterminate T1 hypointense, slightly heterogeneous lesion identified in the right iliac bone in the region of the sacroiliac joint, image 13, series 2. This is not seen on any other sequence. This lesion is not covered within the field of view of other sequences. No other suspicious bony lesion is evident. This lesion in the right iliac bone is not showing any uptake on bone scintigraphy from 11/14/2012. IMPRESSION: 1. Multifocal prostatic disease with minimal extraprostatic extension in the region of neurovascular bundles, right greater than left. 2. No evidence of seminal vesicle involvement. 3. Indeterminate abnormality within the right iliac bone without corresponding increased uptake in the bone scintigraphy. Plain radiographs can be obtained of this region to further evaluate. Old imaging comparison if available of this region would be helpful. Rick NavyChief, Sorry you are joining our rank but welcome! I included part of your post as reference for my comments: Wow, it is unfortunate that you have prostate cancer at such a young age, but it is very fortunate that someone tested your PSA and you catch it now instead of when symptoms start to appear and the cancer spreads to other locations. As it is, your cancer seemed quite extensive within the prostate. The bone scan came out clean which is good news. The MRI showed a couple of concerns (see bold underlined) one indicating cancer just started to grow outside of the capsule but fortunately no seminal vesicle involvement. The other suspicious finding by the MRI of the right iliac bone is not supported by bone scan so may not be significant. I think you catch your prostate cancer early enough that getting rid of it is very possible. I also believe both surgery and radiation are effective treatments but with cancer very close to the apexes and probable extraprostatic extension, perhaps radiation (brachy+IMRT+hormone) is a better option. Please consult your doctor and get a second opinion from a radiation oncologist. Good luck brother.

Posts.Title: Do Easy Erections Ever Return After Prostate Removal?

Posts.Content: CKrem, The best persons to answer your post are JohnT and Fairwind. I hope they can sign in and give you their perspectives. Since I chose surgery, I do not have any experience to share. However, I went back to the notes I took when I was researching options two years ago: 1. PSA bounce after radiation treatment is common, perhaps 40% experiences that. 2. PSA can take as long as two years to settle down after radiation, and often, after initial treatment, the value sometimes "bounce" up after going down. This usually occurs within two years. 3. Failure is defined by radiation oncologists as PSA = nadir + 2. 4. If the PSA begins to rise after treatment and never settles into a nadir and if doubling time is short, treatment probably failed. Your case seems worrisome to me. I would consult a radiation oncologist and/or an oncologist asap for peace of mind. Good luck.
Posts.Title: PSA Bounce after combination IGRT/Brachytherapy

Posts.Title: Oncologist appointment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gyndavid Just want to thank all of you for responding. I will keep you updated, but at present I do have appts to see a radiation oncologist and Dr Patel. I really appreciate all the input given here. The outcome will be about equal and it depends on which treatment you feel comfortable with. What is more important is to choose the best surgeon or radiation oncologist once you decide on the treatment. For surgery, in the hand of an outstanding surgeon like Dr. Patel, the side effects can be minimized. For radiation treatment (for example brachy), in the hand of an outstanding radiation oncologist like Dr. Grimm, the side effects can also be minimized. If you looked at their published outcome on side effects, both were excellent. Of course, every case is different and your situation often dictates the outcome.

Posts.Content: njs, I also like to welcome you to the other side. Thanks for writing down your experiences especially your thought process of deciding what treatment to pick, your assessments of RALP & RRP and your reviews of surgeons. It will be very helpful for those that follows. I followed similar thought processes as you but came to a different conclusion and decided on robotic instead of open. Posts.Title: 40 yrs old, 2 weeks post-op (my story)

Posts.Content: markinphoenix, I have no ED problem except it is dry. Full function returned about 1 month after surgery. Surgeon said his experience indicated taking 5 mg Cialis helped and he prescribed 90 days supply. I actually only took them for a week. Finally, yes, luck played a role too. Some patients in my cancer support group reported it took some time but things improved over time. I also think a lot depends on individual situations, cancer stage, skill of the surgeon and luck. In my case the cancer was organ confined but was actually extensive, worst than the biopsy report. My surgery took longer than normal but both bundles were saved. Timothy, I don't think keeping sexual function after robotic surgery is that rare. Many of the patients in my support group recovered. joedublin, I do not know about cryosurgery. In fact I was always curious as how the doctor preserved the nerve bundles during cryosurgery. I was able to find information on how they could saved the urethra by worming it but no one mentioned how to warm the nerves or did anything to protect them during cryosurgery.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Wayno2 Referred to rad oncologist who wanted to start me on ADT for 4 months followed by IMRT. Wife...an RN...was vehemently opposed to ADT. Your wife is an RN, not a doctor. You should have followed your rad onc's advice and do ADT prior to IMRT. It is the standard practice nowadays unless you have other health issues. Studies after studies indicated the outcome and survival are much better when combining IMRT with ADT. It is still not too late to start ADT. However, I am just a layperson so please discuss this with your rad onc. Peace.

Posts.Title: 12 months and counting...

Posts.Content: 35coupe, A few comments: 1. If you had atypia, (asap - atypical small acinar proliferation) you have a better than even chance of having prostate cancer. I had that diagnosis on my third biopsy and according to my urologist, a 60% chance. 2. On the other hand, at 69, with a PSA of 5.9, AS could turn out to be a good option for you. 3. Even with a positive diagnosis, you will live a long time since there are so many options available to treat. 4. We can share our experiences and show you how we each arrived at our decisions but what you choose to do is a matter between you and your physician and we should not push you in any direction. Regards,

Posts.Title: Why choose active surveillance

Posts.Content: JustBrandon, Sorry you felt bad about your Dad's outcome. But, look at the bright side: The surgeon did his part about getting rid of the cancer with undetectable PSA. You did not mention but I assumed there is no significant incontinence, if so these are great outcomes.. As for surgery risks, not all doctors explained all of the risks prior to surgery but in the pre-ops, they should have discussed some of the more common complications to your dad. Catheter leakage, DVT that could lead to pulmonary embolism are two common complications. Especially DVT which when leads to pulmonary embolism is dangerous and that is why in the hospital, they put compression sleeves on his legs and attached them to a machine to exercise his legs to minimize DVT. After discharge, the advice is to walk everyday not just to help healing but more important to prevent DVT at home. Did your dad exercise after getting home? Other rarer complications not normally mentioned are lymphocele if lymph nodes were taken out and possible hernia.... I had lymphocele developed after surgery and led to abdominal abscess three years after surgery that landed me in the hospital ICU. Consult a lawyer if you still feel strongly about suing his surgeon but first and foremost, focus on healing. Lawyer can come later. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: considering sueing surgeon

Posts.Content: To add to what Fairwind said, for some people, the initial Lupron shot could cause a PSA flare-up (spike) and often oncologists add Bicalutamide (Casodex) to keep PSA down until the flare-up goes away or keeping the Casodex for the duration. It is referred to as double blockage. Some oncologists also add Avodart to enhance the effectiveness even further. It is called triple blockage. If the effectiveness wears off, there are a bunch of new medications at your disposal. For someone like you who has survived prostate cancer a long time, the new hormone treatments should be effective if the current ones lose their effectiveness. One of my former coworkers has been on hormone for 15 years and still going strong. Good luck

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Wayno2 Help! Wife, a devout Christian (AND an RN by the way) wants AS because "God Has already healed me!". So, what the hell are "microscopic cancer clusters"? Two comments: 1. God help those that help themselves. 2. your cancer is the multifocal type meaning they are diffuse and tend to spread compare to a single solid tumor. So, in my non professional opinion if I were you I would seek treatment now instead of thinking you are cure. Also I think your wife is in denial like us when first diagnosed. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by trinity3 Since none of the procedures come with a penis warranty, maybe you could let me know your thoughts on what best option is for ED and incontinence issues. If you have ED now, you will have ED after surgery. If you do not have ED, the best chance to avoid it, either surgery or radiation is to find the best practitioners in the business, surgeons or radiation oncologists, which ever your choice. The ED side effect due to surgery is immediate and many improved/recovered over time. Radiation on the other hand has delayed ED effect for some, sometime in the future after the treatment. There were claims that the chances of ED was less for radiation treatment but I have not seen any side by side comparisons. As for incontinence, nowadays it is actually rare. Most (~90-95%?) will recover after a period of time. Also, I have some concern about running to some of the famous cancer centers for fear that someone other than the doctor I choose will be performing the procedure. I certainly welcome any comments!! If you ask the surgeon to not let someone other than him/her operates on you he/she will comply, if not you move to the next candidate. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Second Biopsy More Concerning

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate As far as multiple cancer sites, some of the comments that I have read from HIFU enthusiasts is that secondary lesions are usually G6, and don't pose a danger if left alone or treated later. Actually secondary are usually the more aggressive type in general, just the nature of cancer progression.
Posts.Title: HIFU Treatment Receives FDA Approval

Posts.Content: I don't know if I make any sense but my shying away from HIFU and cryosurgery was not from medical ground but from fundamental physics. Cryo kills by freezing and HIFU kills by heating. I don't understand how they can limit the heating and cooling from spilling over to adjacent healthy cells or nerves or muscles through heat conduction and I am especially worry about the urethra, sphincter muscles, the bladder neck and nerves. If you are too cautious you may leave cancer cells behind if you are too aggressive you will kill off a lot of other parts. I like to know how a surgeon can "wall off" just treating the prostate with an external ultrasound device (trans-rectal), how he/she can precisely control exactly where the ultrasound beam goes and not affecting at least in some fashion the adjacent tissues unless he/she only spot treat and leaves a lot of prostate tissues around. There are a lot of smart people around and they may eventually provide answers to the issues I mentioned but so far I have not seen any good paper published on that (as opposed to radiation treatment where there were tons of papers published).

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Sounds like doctors can give prostrate sizes with either way. When asking my surgeon at Mayo how large the tumor was compared to the prostate. He replied by saying my prostate was about 98 grams and the tumor was about 2 grams. So, I think both ways are used, perhaps depending on the particular aspect being discussed at the time. Highlander, I think after surgery, they have the specimen so they can weigh and determine the weight. Before surgery, with ultrasound, they only have the dimensions (X cm by Y cm by Z cm) so cc is more likely. But, as I said, I don't know, they can convert cc into gm easily.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tim1029 Can anyone help me. I just was diagnosed at age 44 with very early stage 1 Gleason score 6 prostate cancer. My Doctor told me the standard for someone my age is to have a radical prostectomy to give me the best shot of a long life. My concern is how will my sex life be after the surgery. I hear many conflicting storys ranging from you will be able to have erections a couple weeks after surgery to, forget it you'll never be able to have sex again. Please is there anyone out there that could possibly give me some straight answers to what to exspect with the surgery. Also maybe a little advice on possible other options. Welcome. As mentioned in prior posts, you do have a lot of options beside surgery. However, if you decide on surgery, like some of us on this site, then I cannot emphasize enough about finding a competent surgeon to do the operation. Published results of the "best in class" are quite a bit better than the overall population of surgeons. You have one shot to do it right and there is no do-over. When you interview surgeons, do ask how many operations have they done, the rate of positive margins, the rate of incontinence and the rate of ED. They should be willing to answer those questions. If not, you should find someone else. If you read Dr. Walsh's book, in it he shared his statistical outcome on positive margins, incontinences and ED. The surgeon you select should have comparable results. Good luck.

Posts.Title: 2 years after surgery. single and the effects of surgery related impotence

Posts.Content: dk6 & Fairwind gave you the 1 min version. Let me give you the 10 min version. It has been one and a half years ago so it is from distant memory: First of all, the surgeon, his nurse and the hospital should run you through pre-op checks, by him, her and the hospital. Also, run some tests to make sure you can be operated on. One of them, usually your doctor's office should give you instructions on what to do, pre and post op, what to do in case of complications post op, etc. The instructions should include how to deal with the catheter, clean the areas, emptying the bag, disinfect the bag... The morning of the surgery, I checked into the hospital at 5am, by 6:30am they prepared me, wheeled me into the staging area, the anesthesiologist greeted me, put the IV in my arm and explained the process. My surgeon came in next all dressed and I said Hi. I did not even remember what he said, the next thing I knew, I was in my room, I saw the wall clock in the room said 1:30pm and saw my wife looking and smiling at me. I did not feel any pain but started noticing the catheter bag and the compression sleeves they put on my legs pumping (to prevent blood clogs). The nurse got me up that evening to walk around. I was supposed to be discharged the next afternoon but because I did not pass gas (indication of bowel movement, which is important after surgery to indicate everything in your system is getting back to normal), they kept me till the morning of the third day when I passed gas. During discharge, the nurse went through the catheter care and handling again. So, this is a good time for you to ask as many questions regarding the catheter as you can. Best to have someone with you and take note or you might forget. There were no pain. I did not take any pain medication except some Tylenol the first day at home to ease the sore throat that Fairwind mentioned, that was caused by the breathing tube. The catheter was not painful, just not comfortable, especially when I accidentally tugged on it. the tip where it came out got irritated after a couple of days because I walked too much. Called the doctor and he told me the best treatment was to washed the area regularly with clean warm water and applied Neosporin occasionally. Mobility was not any problem, I used the big bag for indoor and leg bag for outdoor. As for clothing, Fairwind was spot on. You won't be able to run but any walking at a normal pace should not post any problem. Sleeping was a little uncomfortable the first night because I was afraid to press on the tubing and did not "turn", just stayed on my back all night. Slept through the rest of the nights and did not even notice the tube. There were some blood clots and some bleeding but they told me those were normal. So, don't be too alarm if the urine collection looks pink. Do drink plenty of fluid. Best part as dk6 said, for the first time in years I did not have to get up multiple times to urinate at night. You need to watch your bowel movement and make sure to take stool softener. For the first few weeks, I took Colace and drank prune juice and had no problem with bowel. It is very bad for your incision sites if you strain too much. Straining could also cause irritation to your bladder and might cause the catheter to leak. When you laugh or cough, best thing is to press a pillow on your tummy so as not to stress the incisions. Be careful, the incisions could come apart if you stress them too hard. That is also why for a few weeks you should not lift anything heavy. I was amazed with the whole experience with regard to the lack of pain and discomfort and how quickly I recovered. My friend went through open and had to stay in the hospital for 4 days and he was in quite a bid of pain after he went home. It is not a walk in the park for sure but overall I had a good experience and was happy I selected the treatment and selected my surgeon. Best of luck to you and please share your experience after you are on the other side. Cheers.

If I remember correctly, he also had some side effects but don't know if he had leg cramps. Perhaps he can comment or you can send him a private message to get his perspective on Zytiga. Posts.Title: need info on taking Zytiga

Posts.Content: I did a search for you and the instructions of when, how and what are extremely important when you take Zytiga. As for side effects, do you have hypertension, hypotension and edema? Leg cramps/pain is apparently one of the side effects if you have the above conditions either caused by Zytiga or pre-existing. According to their website: ZYTIGA® may cause serious side effects including: High blood pressure (hypertension), low blood potassium levels (hypokalemia), and fluid retention (edema). Tell your healthcare provider if you get any of the following symptoms: Dizziness Fast heartbeats Feel faint or lightheaded Headache Confusion Muscle weakness Pain in your legs Swelling in your legs or feet Talk to your oncologist, especially if you have hypertension, etc. Maybe by controlling your blood pressure, etc. the side effects can be minimized. Good luck.

Posts.Title: daVinci soon

Posts.Content: You have a positive DRE, i.e., the urologist felt a nodule, so, ignoring this issue is not wise. As for the statement that "Research has not yet proven that the potential benefits of testing outweigh the harms of testing and treatment" it is a carefully crafted statement. Notice it did not state testing did not save life. Numerous studies, especially one from Europe indicated testing and treatment saved lives, just that over treatments often caused unwanted side effects and that all these testing and treatment were very expensive and perhaps our healthcare systems cannot afford it. I think the main issue is not testing but after tested positive, what do you do? Many cases can be treated with AS (Active Surveillance) to avoid cost and bad side effects.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 My comment referred only to my surprise at the 2 week period you mentioned for a PSA test following radiation. And I don't understand why anyone would have a PSA test done in the middle of your SR treatment. I did not have HT. Posters like Fairwind are clearly more knowledgeable in the area of SR plus HT and I must defer to him. Others should also be chiming in shortly. Best of luck. Jim Here is one study indicating HT helped reduced recurrence for folks that had RP and RT. http://www.redjournal.org/article/S0...075-4/abstract In this study, they found that each additional month of ADT reduced the chance of recurrence. With 6 months, the chance was reduced by a factor of 1.8. With 24 months, the chance was reduced by a factor of 9.8. Seemed to indicate a HT of at least 24 months is warranted. Regards,

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Derkie54 I had 40 and hormone injections as well at the same time, this may be the reason for the big drop ! You answered your own question. My understanding is that for radiation treatment without hormone, PSA drop tends to be more gradual. The treatment protocol of radiation + hormone showed better outcome and is now almost a standard protocol for radiation treatment, especially for someone with your PSA and staging of T3a. You should not worry too much as the quick drop indicated your treatment is working well. Good luck.

Posts.Title: When Do You Stop Worrying !

Posts.Content: Good luck on your prostate biopsy and neck(?) CT. Painful glands could be infection? Yes, biopsy if positive is definitive. Negative result unfortunately does not mean no cancer, just they do not detect it this time. Resolution of CT scan is of the order of 1 cm, anything smaller is hard to detect. Also interpretation depends on the skills of the radiologist. That is why many time a second opinion/read is done.
Posts.Title: Two reasons for concerns; 1) Elevated PSA and 2) Enlarged, painful glands on my neck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PDV Thanks Michael. Remember the Pats scored 35 points after the suspect ball was taken out of the game. Hopefully this focal positive margin is meaningless BS like Deflategate. Free Brady! Lower my PSA! You should ask your surgeon for a copy of the pathology report, not the summary from the surgeon but the one written by the pathologist. Read it carefully to see if the pathologist indicated anything unusual other than the positive focal margin. In a lot of cases if there are no unusual finding other than the one positive margin which is small, you may not have anything to worry about and regular monitoring of PSA maybe all you need. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Positive focal margin

Posts.Content: If you have urinary blockage or urethra stricture due to the cancer, your physician might do a local surgery like TURP to remove a part of the prostate for symptoms relieve. It is however, not curative and does not remove the whole prostate. Sounded like your hormonal treatment is effective so you should continue the treatment. If Lupron and Casodex become ineffective, there are a lot of other drugs available (I counted 46 different hormonal, chemo and inmmunotherapy drugs approved by the FDA, though many are duplicate generic/brand) so you have a lot of options left. Good luck.
