Posts.Title: Prostate removal question.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rooster0330 He is 69 but in excellent health, eats right, works out every morning, he was told about a year ago that he has the body/health of a 49 year old!!! Late stage is considered what on the gleason scale or is it the PSA? I suggest he seeks a second read from another radiologist and perhaps consult an oncologist also. Hot spots sometimes can be caused by other events like arthritis and injuries and a good radiologist always wants to know about his past medical histories. PSA of 7.9 is not too high and G7 is considered intermediate risk prostate cancer, so, even if the cancer already spread, there are many treatments that can keep the cancer at bay for many many years and very likely he will not die from prostate cancer. Good luck and best wishes to your father.

Posts.Title: New here....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman DP, i have to say i find it odd, that a physician, who has followed many Prostate Cancer patients, would come to an internet forum for advice from a group of laymen With that said, there is always possibility of a lab error, as you probably know. I had 3 consecutive undetectable PSAs after surgery with very favorable pathology and similar results on the MSKCC Nomogram as your dads. And then my fourth PSA test came back at 3.88!!!!! I had it retested at another lab, it came back undetectable, and the first lab then confirmed that after retesting the same blood they too got an undetectable. So yes, its possible that its a lab error, get a retest. Pratoman, He may be a physician but with his Dad's situation, he is just like us, seeking support and some help and we may be all laypersons but with our collective experiences perhaps we could offer some comfort to him and his family. That said, I don't think his case is lab error: His post-op PSAs were: April 2015 PSA = 0.003 August 2015 PSA = 0.005 Oct 2015 PSA = 0.007 Jan 2016 PSA = 0.16 (done in middle east at a different lab from his usual labs) The PSA was detectable from the get go and there is a monotonic increase so the only possible error is the magnitude and not the increase. Bottom line is the surgery failed. In addition since all margins, nodes are negative. I worry the cancer may have gone systemic but lets hope it is still local so SRT can kill them all. The question really is how aggressive he wants to take the next step and a consultation with an oncologist with expertise in prostate cancer is in order. To the op, you should know that it is not a death sentence for your Dad. If the Gleason score is not too aggressive, the cancer can be managed and life span of decades is very likely. Take care.

Posts.Title: My 1st Post Op PSA

Posts.Content: dk6 & Fairwind gave you the 1 min version. Let me give you the 10 min version. It has been one and a half years ago so it is from distant memory: First of all, the surgeon, his nurse and the hospital should run you through pre-op checks, by him, her and the hospital. Also, run some tests to make sure you can be operated on. One of them, usually your doctor's office should give you instructions on what to do, pre and post op, what to do in case of complications post op, etc. The instructions should include how to deal with the catheter, clean the areas, emptying the bag, disinfect the bag... The morning of the surgery, I checked into the hospital at 5am, by 6:30am they prepared me, wheeled me into the staging area, the anesthesiologist greeted me, put the IV in my arm and explained the process. My surgeon came in next all dressed and I said Hi. I did not even remember what he said, the next thing I knew, I was in my room, I saw the wall clock in the room said 1:30pm and saw my wife looking and smiling at me. I did not feel any pain but started noticing the catheter bag and the compression sleeves they put on my legs pumping (to prevent blood clogs). The nurse got me up that evening to walk around. I was supposed to be discharged the next afternoon but because I did not pass gas (indication of bowel movement, which is important after surgery to indicate everything in your system is getting back to normal), they kept me till the morning of the third day when I passed gas. During discharge, the nurse went through the catheter care and handling again. So, this is a good time for you to ask as many questions regarding the catheter as you can. Best to have someone with you and take note or you might forget. There were no pain. I did not take any pain medication except some Tylenol the first day at home to ease the sore throat that Fairwind mentioned, that was caused by the breathing tube. The catheter was not painful, just not comfortable, especially when I accidentally tugged on it. the tip where it came out got irritated after a couple of days because I walked too much. Called the doctor and he told me the best treatment was to washed the area regularly with clean warm water and applied Neosporin occasionally. Mobility was not any problem, I used the big bag for indoor and leg bag for outdoor. As for clothing, Fairwind was spot on. You won't be able to run but any walking at a normal pace should not post any problem. Sleeping was a little uncomfortable the first night because I was afraid to press on the tubing and did not "turn", just stayed on my back all night. Slept through the rest of the nights and did not even notice the tube. There were some blood clots and some bleeding but they told me those were normal. So, don't be too alarm if the urine collection looks pink. Do drink plenty of fluid. Best part as dk6 said, for the first time in years I did not have to get up multiple times to urinate at night. You need to watch your bowel movement and make sure to take stool softener. For the first few weeks, I took Colace and drank prune juice and had no problem with bowel. It is very bad for your incision sites if you strain too much. Straining could also cause irritation to your bladder and might cause the catheter to leak. When you laugh or cough, best thing is to press a pillow on your tummy so as not to stress the incisions. Be careful, the incisions could come apart if you stress them too hard. That is also why for a few weeks you should not lift anything heavy. I was amazed with the whole experience with regard to the lack of pain and discomfort and how quickly I recovered. My friend went through open and had to stay in the hospital for 4 days and he was in quite a bid of pain after he went home. It is not a walk in the park for sure but overall I had a good experience and was happy I selected the treatment and selected my surgeon. Best of luck to you and please share your experience after you are on the other side. Cheers.

He had his prostate out last November, by March it was 4.3 and then in May it was 4.7, just last month it was the same at 4.7. The fact that PSA stabilizes is very good news. I personally knew of someone whose PSA increased to 1 after surgery and radiation but stayed at 1 for years and symptom free. Good luck to your father and hope things stay the same for a long time.

Posts.Title: T-Minus 36 Hours until da Vinci...

Posts.Content: I think even for aggressive prostate cancer it is quite slow growing as compare with other types of cancers. So for someone with a family history, early detection is the key since early detection and treatment are in most cases curative. Early PSA testing for his sons, perhaps even as early as 35 to establish a baseline is smart. Because of family history, I started monitoring my PSA quite early. Unlike breast cancer and ovarian cancer (Angelina Jolie) there is currently no policy/recommendation for preventative prostate surgery even if genetic testing indicated they carried the BRCA mutations because prostate cancer surgery still carries a lot of risks for bad side effects. Just my layperson's opinion.

Posts.Title: BRAC2 Testing For Family Mmenbers?

Posts.Content: Proton is most likely no better than other radiation protocols except more expensive. When I was researching treatment options, I could not find too many peer reviewed (more objective and unbiased) papers on long term outcome of proton but found lots on IMRT, brachy, etc. that indicated they were equivalent to surgery in terms of getting rid of the cancer. I have no dog in this fight, so, hopefully I am objective: If he wants radiation, the best out there according to studies seemed to be brachy + IMRT + adjuvant hormone. If he lives near Loma Linda, he should get second opinions from the City of Hope and UCLA, two of the best prostate treatment centers in the US. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Dad Newly Diagnosed--Proton Therapy?

Posts.Content: You have a positive DRE, i.e., the urologist felt a nodule, so, ignoring this issue is not wise. As for the statement that "Research has not yet proven that the potential benefits of testing outweigh the harms of testing and treatment" it is a carefully crafted statement. Notice it did not state testing did not save life. Numerous studies, especially one from Europe indicated testing and treatment saved lives, just that over treatments often caused unwanted side effects and that all these testing and treatment were very expensive and perhaps our healthcare systems cannot afford it. I think the main issue is not testing but after tested positive, what do you do? Many cases can be treated with AS (Active Surveillance) to avoid cost and bad side effects.

Posts.Title: Value of Testing and Treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by AsksALOTofQuestions I wonder if the cost benefit is dramatically shifting, especially for someone (almost everyone) in a position to budget $25k for the latest technology in treatment to minimize side effects and invasiveness of treatment. So what if the kids have a reduced inheritance or there is lien against the house at probate. That's what money is really for right...a rainy day! Asks, Your budget is way off. Without insurance, a typical surgery costs >$75K (I was going to pay out of pocket at one time), IMRT >$100K, proton >$150K, a course of new hormone, Provenge... costs >$100K per year.... I think after you add them all up for someone going through surgery, SRT, hormone, Provenge, chemo, etc. you are off by at least a factor of 10. My back of the envelop calculation showed that if we go back to the 1975 situation, no PSA testing, wait until symptoms show up and cancer is terminal (1/3 of cases then), it is a lot cheaper to insurance and Medicare.

Posts.Title: Food preservative Nisin and cancer

Posts.Content: Welcome. After prostatectomy if his PSA was 3, that means a), the cancer had already spread beyond the prostate before surgery or b), cancer had not spread but the surgery left some prostate tissues (benign or cancerous) behind around the prostate. If it is b), salvage radiation to the prostate bed and around the pelvic area should kill off the cancer. CAT and Bone scans are clear is good news, that means no major metastasis or spread but there still could be micro-metastasis that is not detectable. His doctor should also track his PSA velocity (how fast the PSA rises and sometimes call PSA doubling time) to get a sense of how rapidly things change. If his PSA changed from 3 six months ago to 4.7 now, the doubling time is about a year, which is moderate, but needs to be dealt with (if the doubling time is 2 to 3 years perhaps doing nothing could be a strategy). Typically, in this situation oncologists will recommend hormone therapy and salvage radiation. In many cases that should cure the cancer. In my layperson's opinion, your father is healthy, radiation to the pelvis area should not be too harmful, many here had this treatment with very little side effects and were effective in curing their remaining cancer. Hormone therapy does have side effects but not too bad for most. What else can you do? First of all, read Dr. Walsh's book on Guide to Survive Prostate Cancer to be an informed patient and patient advocate. Understand his pathology, especially his Post Op Pathology Report to get an idea if some cancer cells were left behind (positive margins, etc.) and to see the type of cancer he has (Gleason scores indicate if the cancer is aggressive or not). Second, provide him with moral and emotional support to improve his quality of life. Some of us were depressed and needed emotional support. Third, get a second opinion and Fourth, get him to improve his diet and perhaps take supplements like pomegranate extracts... Your father should enjoy many more years of living, so do not be too stressed.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by TheDaughter His Gleason score before his surgery was 7, they are saying its at a 9 now.... but I'm hesitant to believe that as they cant tell us why. At the time of surgery they checked the surrounding area, nodes included and everything came back clear. I don't think radiation is a good idea since he's older, I think it would cause more problems than good. Are there any medications that might help? We're not necessarily looking for a cure, just more healthy years of life. Thank you Chuck! If everything was clear after surgery, his PSA of 3 after surgery indicated the cancer already spread beyond the prostate at the time of surgery. Get a second opinion regarding treatment options. In this case salvage radiation may not be effective. Just my layperson's opinion. Good luck.
Posts.Title: New here, need advice.

Posts.Content: If you choose surgery, you may want to ask your surgeon to remove as many of the lymph nodes as possible. This has two benefits: 1. If the nodes are clean, you know you have a good chance that the cancer stays within the prostate. 2. If not, you still have a chance that the cancer may only escape to the nodes and by removing them, there is a chance you can be cancer free. But as Fairwind said, there could be complications with the lymph nodes removal. Some of us ended up with abdominal infection due to the lymphatic fluids accumulated in the abdominal cavity.

Posts.Title: Mets to lymph nodes

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ronjem I don't wanna have radiation because it can damage other parts of the body as well so im going to have the whole thing removed. I'm not going to give up because i've come to far in life. I am a era-vet & a recovering addict who just celebrated 8yrs clean, so giving up is not an opition for me. Please if there is any information that you can give me please feel free to do so!!!! For organ confined cancer and low to intermediate risk cancer (which seemed to be what you have from the limited info you provided), surgery and radiation are equally effective and long term results and side effects are about equal: six of one and half a dozen of the other. In general, doctors advice surgery for younger and physically fit patients and radiation for older patients. Most of the time it is a personal preference more than outcome and side effects. If you have already decided, one suggestion is to start getting yourself in shape between now and surgery time. It will help reduce complication and allows faster healing. Good luck and we wait for you on the other side.

Posts.Title: Finally made it to GPS Calypso Beacons and Radiation Therapy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gailannr He fully intends to take another look at whether he will continue with the Lupron or take a break from the HT and possibly take it again after a break. It is a very hard decision for him. A combined HT/RT/HT had a far superior outcome than no HT, so much so that all oncologist and radiation oncologist recommend this. The only debate is the HT duration after RT. I am sure his doctors will give him the proper guidance. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Finally made it to GPS Calypso Beacons and Radiation Therapy

Posts.Content: MKEvman, Welcome. Your case demonstrates why in many cases PSA tests save lives. If your doctor follows the new guideline and forgoes PSA testing, your cancer will probably not be curable after symptoms appear. You are very fortunate your doctor tracked your PSA and both he and the urologist went for a biopsy. Another good news is no lymphatic or perineural invasion which means cancer has not found a path to escape yet. A cure/full remission for you! Take your time to research and decide on a treatment that you are comfortable with. The most important choice is to choose the right physician (surgeon if you choose surgery or radiation oncologist if you choose radiation). You have one shot to do it right and outcome is very physician dependent. - especially side effects of the treatment. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: New Member Here!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind You are accepting it as Gospel that your cancer is being accurately described and diagnosed by the biopsy results..Frequently, after surgery, the more complete biopsy reveals the cancer is more extensive and more dangerous than the original biopsy discovered..Talk this over with your doctors.... I agree with Fairwind. Your age probably means you will eventually have to seek aggressive treatment. Often time, the final pathology stage will be more advanced than the clinical stage from biopsy (look at my signature). There are a lot of unknown-unknown, however, the final decision is yours and not your doctor's. Talk it over again with your doctors and family members then decide.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed - need advice

Posts.Content: Don't know if you are still reading this thread, I am sorry your husband is joining our club but welcome. Do not panic, he will be around for a long long time since his diagnosis indicate early stage. He is lucky his is detected early. My opinion is since he is very young (40) and assuming he is physically fit and the cancer is organ confined, surgery is the best option for him. The key is to assess if the cancer is organ confined. For someone with a PSA of 4.5, 5 of 12 cores positive and G6 the chance of organ confined is very high. If I were you guys, I would go ahead and ask for the tests JohnT recommended to find out. Studies of radiation vs surgery indicated up to 20 years, radiation and surgery are equally effective. But your husband should want to be around for 30 or 40 more years and comparison is not available. In my opinion, the real unknown is the so call "Secondary Primary Cancer": The effect of radiation on adjacent organs 30 to 40 years later is not known. Even though modern radiation techniques are very precise, some leakage is unavoidable and no one knows for sure if they are OK after 30 to 40 years. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Help newbie need advice

Posts.Content: A PSA increase of 50% in six months is a concern. If you look at the anatomy of where the prostate is relative to the rectum and where the needle biopsy can sample, you will see that there are places where it is difficult for the needle to access to get samples so a normal biopsy could miss the cancer. You either get a saturation biopsy or use some other method like color Doppler Ultrasound to see if you can get a more accurate picture. One poster here (JohnT) had similar problem with multiple negative biopsies until he had a CD Ultrasound. Second, if you look at Fairwind's signature, you will notice he took Proscar and his PSA was reduced by half. Later, when his PSA started to increase even though he was on Proscar, his urologist was worried. That is because if there were no cancer, Proscar should keep his PSA at about half indefinitely. When it increased, it could indicate cancer. In fact there were a number of posts on this site some time ago discussing this topic and there were a number of medical articles on this subject. I am a lay person and have no formal training in medicine so I could be all wrong and you should seek professional help.

Posts.Title: psa went to 14 from 8.9 in 6 months

Posts.Content: Akai is correct, looks like Blue Shield of California won't cover proton therapy for prostate cancer and Cigna may follow. I have been unable to find any meaningful long term outcome studies (large population, >10 years) for proton therapy. In addition, in one population studies published in 2012 using Medicare and SEER data (out of 12,976 patients for IMRT and 1,368 patients for proton) comparing proton, IMRT and conformal radiation therapy and the outcome for side effects were interesting: proton therapy had worst gastrointestinal complication than the other two: 17.8 incidences per 1,000 vs 12.8 per 1,000 for IMRT. In another large population study also using Medicare and SEER database published in 2011 looking at long term (5 years) gastrointestinal complications also found proton had worst outcome compare to the other radiation protocol (20.1 incidences per 1,000 person year vs 5.3 incidences per 1,000 person year for brachy and 8.9 incidences per 1,000 person year for IMRT). The good news is there were no differences in other side effects. Perhaps with the high costs and without head to head comparison to show superiority insurance company are beginning to have second thoughts about covering proton therapy.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wish full Also, is high grade and high risk the same? Originally Posted by wish full What I'm really concerned about is the prostate covering the Apex and being high grade. I see this as a possible apex margin due to the amount and being high grade. Sorry we have to welcome you to our club. Mikla gave you good advice and you should take him up on his suggestions. To answer your specific questions: Yes, high Gleason scores mean higher risks. However, risks also depend on staging, i.e., how extensive the cancer is and whether it has spread to other organs. Since you have one score of 3+4, it is moderately aggressive. 3+4 means most of your cancer is grade 3, the least aggressive type, but there are some grade 4 which is more aggressive. Looking at your biopsy pathology report, your cancer is at exactly where the radiologist said it was - left mid and left base (near the bladder, not apex). So, you had a very good radiologist read your MRI. The other good news are the biopsy did not detect any spread and more important, the MRI report showed no evidence of spread. All in all, looks like an organ confined case and if you take action to seek treatment, you should be fine. Good luck.

Posts.Content: San635, Your physician's and your reasoning of treating aggressive prostate cancer make sense to me. Looking at some of the recent clinical trials, quite a few of them are for combination therapies. This is consistent with the trends of other cancer treatments and HIV treatments. I know because my wife was diagnosed with advanced breast cancer and her surgeon/oncologist went all out with a very aggressive treatment protocol involving surgery, adjuvant radiation, two separate and different combination courses of chemo medications for over six months, and finally tamoxifen for five years. She is still in remission after 10 years. Best of luck to your husband.

Posts.Title: Husband with Gleason 9 at age 48

Posts.Content: Since you had such good results with continence right after surgery, I suspect you did not need to do a lot of Kegel exercises to regain continence. Since you only have the external sphincter muscles to control your urethra often time they need to be trained and over time they could be weaken or relaxed. I suggest you start to do Kegel again to see if controls can be tighten up. All else fails, there are implants that can fix incontinence. As for ED, there are a lot of remedies including injection and implant if that is important to you. Life is precious and I would not trade 10 years for ED and some leakage. I am not trying to minimize your bad situations, just some suggestions in case you want to take actions and be proactive to improve your conditions. Peace and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Looking for information

Posts.Content: George is technically correct. From what I read, once metastasized, it is no longer "curable" but I won't call it palliative yet since most cases can be controlled like a chronic disease by keeping cancer at bay for a long time through a series of treatments. I hope my following comments don't upset you: I think there is no correct answer to the question of odds as everyone is different. However, based on statistics, taking chemo and ADT early conferred significant survival advantage in terms of relative survival compared to ADT alone and then chemo: Better than 40% according to studies. The other significant point is the more serious the cases the better the relative results. In one study: http://www.cancer.gov/news-events/pr...ses/2013/E3805 the median survival (50% lived longer) was about 5 years for those took the combo treatment. And for patients with great extent of met, the median survival was over 4 years for those took the combo. So, I think he has a better than 50/50 chance of being around five years from now. And with new treatments coming on line rapidly, I think in five years the survival statistics will change for the better. Peace and best to you.

AgeInfo.Phrase: he has a better than 50 50 chance of being around

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by LL Fauntleroy As for staging can someone help, my Uro told me T1C, RO said it's T2A, the Onc Uro said T2C PSA 5.6/ 8 cores with less than 50% for any core, both sides equally affected, clean DRE If one uses the 1992 UICC Clinical Staging System, technically, you are a T1c: Not palpable (clean DRE), cancer found by needle biopsy because of elevated PSA. However, biopsy result could classify you as T2c: Involved both lobs. If one uses the 1997 UICC Staging System, there is no T2c, so, you could be a T2a or T2b depending on how extensive your cancer. Your RO could be using the new staging system and used his judgment to classify you a T2a.

Posts.Title: Two negative biopsies, but....

Posts.Content: One of the things I do not understand about medicine is who does what. Radiologists trained 5 to 6 years to learn how to read x ray, CT, MRI and ultrasound and they read and perform CT guided, MRI guided and ultrasound guided biopsy on most areas of the body (breast for example) except the prostate. Urologists trained 5 to 6 years on doing surgery and spend very little time on reading ultrasound yet they perform ultrasound guided prostate biopsy? I had three negative biopsies performed by urologists. Finally, the fourth biopsy was performed by a radiologist at a hospital. He read the ultrasound in real time and directed the tech to get samples from where he had concerns. He found the cancer.

Posts.Title: Friend Died From Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ChiliDog His MRI result is that he has "1.5 cm mass in the peripheral zone of the right mid gland and apex with likely extracapsular extension, which abuts the right neurovascular bundle." Next step is a biopsy done by the young guys with fancy equipment. That will happen later in December. He will then will go before a committee for treatment recommendations. The good news is there were no mentioned of other areas of involvements (e.g., lymph nodes, seminal vesicles...) so it is very likely organ confined and he has a high probability of a cure. Also, MRI cannot be a definitive diagnosis as the mass could be inflammations or other issues. The biopsy will be definitive if positive. The one area of concern is the mass is very close to the nerves on the right so very likely the surgeon, if surgery is the treatment chosen, will have to cut out that nerve bundle resulting in higher probability of ED. For major cancer centers, the current practice is to form a "Cancer Board" to review the diagnosis and recommend treatment. This is to reduce "treatment bias" of the physicians (the old saying: Surgeons like to cut). In this case if Ed is an important issue to you, perhaps radiation is a better approach. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ChiliDog Newporter, I'd say that ED is important! But I'd rather have the husband alive, and well, the rest is secondary. My impulse is to get that prostate outta here, but it's not my body. Actually all the recent studies indicated modern radiation techniques and surgery produced almost the same cancer outcome but radiation seemed to give better outcome on ED in the short term. The main differences between surgery and radiation are the side effects of surgery are immediate and most get better over time whereas radiation side effects are few at the beginning but over time some may get worst. There are also side effects of radiation that surgery does not have like bowel and bladder irritations....and side effects that surgery has but not radiation like lymphedema....

Posts.Content: My non professional guess is similar to what Highlander suspected: Could be delayed side effects of salvage radiation. It is a well known but seldom mentioned consequence of radiation treatment: Initial side effects are minimal but for some people they show up long after treatment is over, up to five years later. This is contrary to surgery where side effects, if any, are immediate but for many people they diminish as time passes. You may have to adjust and retrain your system, just like right after surgery. Highlander gave you very good advice and perhaps you should try them. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Good Luck Highlander

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Marve PDV: Already next day out hospital? Here they hold hospital 10 days! So they told. Or maybe you surgery is different than here? I dont know how they make this? Cut stomach or somehow different? I dont know. HighlanderCFH: Is it possible that my father G is really different than 3+3=6? Beacause the biopsy result was that one core has some perineural invasion. And after that sentence was G 3+3=6. Maybe really its more than 3+3=6? Or how there can be perineural invasion? And actually this word was a little bit different...it wasnt invasion, but "the infiltration". But its so good I find this place. I already can eat and I dont worry so much anymore, because I know that everything goes well Marve, You father had what we call open surgery (the urologist/surgeon cut open the abdomen by hand to take out the prostate without any laparoscopic or robot assist), if so, the hospital stay is longer. In the US, those that choose the open approach stays in the hospital about 3-5 days. Many in the US now choose robot assist surgery where they cut several small 1 cm holes and insert robotic surgical instruments inside the abdomen to take out the prostate. Since the incisions are small, the recovery is quick, we tended to stay between 1 to 2 days in the hospital. Your father's cancer is likely early stage so the chance of cure is very high. The perineural invasion (or infiltration, same meaning) is common (many of us including me had it too), it just means the they found the cancer in the nerve channels within the prostate. Good luck to his recovery and let's hope for a complete cure.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Marve PDV: Already next day out hospital? Here they hold hospital 10 days! So they told. Or maybe you surgery is different than here? I dont know how they make this? Cut stomach or somehow different? I dont know. HighlanderCFH: Is it possible that my father G is really different than 3+3=6? Beacause the biopsy result was that one core has some perineural invasion. And after that sentence was G 3+3=6. Maybe really its more than 3+3=6? Or how there can be perineural invasion? And actually this word was a little bit different...it wasnt invasion, but "the infiltration". But its so good I find this place. I already can eat and I dont worry so much anymore, because I know that everything goes well Marve, You father had what we call open surgery (the urologist/surgeon cut open the abdomen by hand to take out the prostate without any laparoscopic or robot assist), if so, the hospital stay is longer. In the US, those that choose the open approach stays in the hospital about 3-5 days. Many in the US now choose robot assist surgery where they cut several small 1 cm holes and insert robotic surgical instruments inside the abdomen to take out the prostate. Since the incisions are small, the recovery is quick, we tended to stay between 1 to 2 days in the hospital. Your father's cancer is likely early stage so the chance of cure is very high. The perineural invasion (or infiltration, same meaning) is common (many of us including me had it too), it just means the they found the cancer in the nerve channels within the prostate. Good luck to his recovery and let's hope for a complete cure.

Posts.Title: First time here

Posts.Content: The good news is your guy has no incontinence. Incontinence is hard to live with but there are many ways to treat ED, first of all, he should consult an ED doctor to get all the latest on rehab and to guide him. By the way, in Dr. Walsh's book he said it might take up to two years for ED to fully recover so your guy needs more time. I am one of the fortunate ones without ED and I am not a healthcare professional so really I should not be giving advices. But, I did some research prior to surgery just in case I had to deal with it: Usually our surgeon starts us on low dose Cialis right after surgery for a few months, he/she also can prescribe full strength Viagra, etc. He/she may also tell us to try the pump and finally to try injections like Trimix. My doctor told me injection should work every time with the right dose which your guy has to experiment with (make sure he gets advices and guidance from his ED doctor) and once the correct dose is used, he should be better than his old self. Good luck to both of you.

Posts.Title: Longterm Girlfriend seeks advice

Posts.Content: Good luck and hope you have a good outcome.
Posts.Title: Have The Biopsy !

Posts.Content: Samie, Sorry you have to be here but welcome. I have a few thoughts: It is a good idea to get a second opinion from another urologist. Perhaps the new urologist will ask for an MRI to see if indeed the cancer is extensive. 1 core out of 8 positive does not explain the 39 PSA #. Maybe his cancer is extensive and aggressive or maybe not. It is possible that his high PSA # could be due to a combination of cancer and infection. Did his urologist prescribe a course of antibiotics to see if that brings down the PSA. Since cancer is already diagnosed, it is done to see how extensive is the cancer, perhaps, just perhaps it is not as extensive as the PSA # indicated. In that case the treatment protocol may be different. In any case, if he is more comfortable with the non surgery approaches (some forms of radiations), the cure rate is about equal to surgery so he should proceed without worry. Another point we all like to make is this is not a death sentence by any means. Even if the cancer is aggressive, there are lots of options for him to keep him around for a long time, so, do not interrupt your plan for a wonderful retirement.

Posts.Title: How high can PSA go ?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Replicant How about this: "We present a 64-year-old Caucasian man with no specific urologic or pain symptoms and with an initial PSA serum value of 21,380 ng/ml. Initial laboratory studies showed chronic anemia and elevated alkaline phosphatase, most likely from bone marrow infiltration due to metastatic disease...Treatment was initiated with bilateral subcapsular orchiectomy and bicalutamide therapy in an effort to create total androgen blockade. After 3 months of follow-up, the serum concentration of PSA was 29 ng/ml. CONCLUSION: This case presents an asymptomatic prostate cancer patient with bone and liver metastasis, enlarged retroperitoneal lymph nodes and the highest PSA level published to date." http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20215802 Replicant, Thank for the info. Now I know one can have a PSA of 21,000 and no symptoms.

Posts.Title: Two Year Anniversary

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Derkie54 I had 40 and hormone injections as well at the same time, this may be the reason for the big drop ! You answered your own question. My understanding is that for radiation treatment without hormone, PSA drop tends to be more gradual. The treatment protocol of radiation + hormone showed better outcome and is now almost a standard protocol for radiation treatment, especially for someone with your PSA and staging of T3a. You should not worry too much as the quick drop indicated your treatment is working well. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FeatherBoy I may be wrong but I thought the gold standard on the conventional test was <0.01 to be considered undetectable? Some surgeons, like mine, refused to use an ultrasensitive test and only ordered .1 accuracy tests. Others, depending on sensitivities of the instruments, range from .001 to .002 to .005.... As long as there is a < sign you are OK no matter the number. Good luck recentlydiagnosed56.

Posts.Title: First psa after prostectomy

Posts.Content: The half life of PSA remaining in your blood is between 2 to 3 days, so, in 90 days post op, your PSA should be undetectable. You should look for the < sign in front of the PSA #, if it is there that means undetectable. Good luck.
Posts.Title: I'm going for my 90-day post-da Vinci PSA. How low should my score be?

Posts.Content: Otego and the others are right. Retest before commit to a biopsy. The normal procedure in the US is to take a course of antibiotic and then retest. Depends on what the new # is and depends on the DRE (digital rectal examine) finding, then do/don't do the biopsy.

Robert, I sent you a Private Message and hope to keep in contact with you. I asked Dr Sanda what he would do with all of his knowledge about Prostate cancer. He said if I were you and with all the information that you have given me I would go with the brachytherapy. I asked Dr. Sands if there was a problem could I go back and have the Prostate taken out and he said, no problem. He said with my MRI and a biopsy of 40 cores there should be no surprises. Anybody else out there have any advise on this? I still have not called my decision in. Here is an article on how the former Chairman of Intel, Dr. Andy Grove arrived at his decision to choose brachy: http://www.phoenix5.org/articles/Fortune96Grove.html And the techniques of performing brachy have improved a lot since he did his. But like everyone said, find the best practitioner to perform brachy and you won't go wrong. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Brachytherrapy any advice

Posts.Content: I am sorry no one responded to your post. Let me welcome you to our corner of the world and the club no one wants to join. First of all, buy or borrow from the library the book written by Dr. Patrick Walsh on Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer. This is a complicated disease with a lot of treatment options that are sometimes very confusing. Knowledge is power, without knowledge, it is difficult to decide what to do or discuss with doctors on treatment options. Second, I am very surprised his doctor would not order a bone scan and a CT scan. For someone going through adjuvant or salvage radiation, that is almost unheard of. Where do you folks live? Third, looks like your partner's cancer could have escaped the prostate and could be systemic and that was why radiation after surgery. He needs to consult an oncologist who specializes in treating prostate cancer for a second/third opinion and to give him an assessment of whether to start hormone at the same time. Studies indicated combining hormone and salvage/adjuvant radiation improved survival. Finally, under the care of good and competent doctors, even if the cancer has spread, he can keep the cancer at bay for a long time with medications. Good luck to you and your partner and do not give up hope.
Posts.Title: Looking for advice on Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: 7 years is not too bad since you had been monitoring your situation closely after 2011 and I believe you did catch it in time. As a comparison, from my first high PSA/negative biopsy and final positive biopsy + treatment was also 7 years. The difference was I was monitoring my PSA every year and had two more negative biopsies in between before I caught mine. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: How long is too long?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Friendly A couple years ago I had several bad days with Vertigo. I mentioned to the doctor that the Vertigo never seemed to go away and recently he did a MRI of my inner ears and found nothing. Did or does anyone ever experience an unsteadiness with Prostate Cancer as a symptom? A month ago they found my blood count is double digits. I had a Bone Scan and Kat Scan after a needle biopsy. They found 70 percent of the needle biopsy had cancer. My unsteadiness seems to be getting worse, could the cancer be attacking something that has made me this way? THANK YOU.[/SIZE][/B][/SIZE] Friendly, Welcome to this site. You should thank your wife for insisting you take a blood PSA test and let's hope you catch yours in time for a "cure" or as some other posters would prefer to say "full remission". Let me quote from Wikipedia: Vertigo is caused by problems with the inner ear or vestibular system. A number of conditions that involve the central nervous system may lead to vertigo including: lesions caused by infarctions or hemorrhage, tumors present in the cerebellopontine angle. So unless your prostate cancer metastasizes to your brain, your vertigo is most likely caused by something else. By the way vertigo is quite common and many of my otherwise healthy friends have this problem. You need to find out: 1. Your doctor should tell you what is your PSA number. He was irresponsible if he just told you it was double digit. 2. Your doctor needed to give you the full biopsy report and explained/summarized the results for you and your wife. If I were you, I next time you see your doctor, you should have your wife with you to take note. 3. The most important information from the biopsy report are: The type of prostate cancer, perhaps adencarcinoma or something else, # of core positive and % of positive, Gleason scores of each positive core, any other information like perineural invasions, prostate size, etc. would also be helpful. The treatment options and assessment of how serious your situation is depends on the biopsy outcome as described above. Fortunately, even with serious cases there are a lot of options and treatments to keep you around for a long long time. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SDrunner my Urologist telling me when I had this first episode with prostatitis that I had "calcium" deposits in my prostate according to the CT scan. Did the radiologist who read your CT (the radiologist, not your urologist, read the CT and wrote the report) indicated you have any sport injuries of your lower spine or any DDD (degenerated disc disease) which could also explain the lower back pain. Posts.Title: Lower Back Pain and Stiffness

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by BeeMan Any advice about active surveillance vs. beginning a treatment plan for VERY EARLY stage prostate cancer? Age 65 when diagnosed (now 66). Gleason 6 (3 & 3) Last PSA: 6.44 last done on 9/10/2012 (every 3 months) PCA3 Neg (14.5) Biopsy: 1 (7%) core positive out of 12 Considering IMRT if treatment needed. BeeMan I agree with lancepeace, it is a very personal decision only you can make. However, your cancer appeared to be very early stage, so AS is a good option to consider for someone who is 66 years old. One piece of information missing from your posts is your PSA doubling time. You have been monitoring your PSA for sometime, if your PSA increase is slow, AS is an excellent choice, if it is fast, treatment is probably needed soon. For example, if the doubling time is 3-4 years, in 15-20 years, your PSA will be about 170. On the other hand, if PSA doubles every year, within 5 years your PSA will reach 170 meaning sooner or later you have to treat, in that case, the earlier you treat it the better the outcome. From your prostate volume, normal PSA should be around 3, so, it is possible your cancer is more extensive than indicated (read my signature, I had G6, 1 core positive 5%, after surgery, pathology indicated extensive cancer and some Grade 4 cancer inside). Read Dr. Walsh's book on treatment options, he discussed all the pros and cons. However, be aware he is biased toward treatment. He did say for folks older than 65 and slow growing cancer, AS is a good option. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by BeeMan PSA Tests: 09/10/2012 6.44 06/11/2012 5.70 02/17/2012 6.71 06/27/2011 6.18 01/21/2011 4.62 04/26/2010 3.88 04/20/2010 4.80 06/01/2009 3.20 09/30/2008 2.40 06/13/2008 2.40 05/01/2007 2.90 04/03/2006 2.50 05/03/2004 2.20 04/01/2003 2.10 04/11/2002 2.80, % Free PSA: 17.8 04/02/2002 5.30 Regular PSA BeeMan, If I used all the PSA # starting from 4/11/2002, your PSA doubling time was calculated to be 13 years! However, that is probably not relavent as the early years' PSA were very stable so they should not be used. Starting 9/30/2008 @ a PSA of 2.4, PSA started to creep up, so I re-do the calculation starting from that PSA #, and the answer is: PSA doubling of ~3 years. AS can be a good option if you would like to consider AS. Hope that helps.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Boris Zolotaryov Was my case(condition) exceptional? I've never been aware of that, Dr Samadi told me that my cancer was local, no metastasis. At the appointment before the surgery, Dr Samadi told me he will perform a surgery himself. I have very strong belief that one of Dr.Samadi's residents practiced on me. You cannot know certainly when you are unconscious under anesthesia. Boris, It is unethical for a surgeon who said he would perform the surgery and had a resident done it. Are you sure that is the case? I am truly sorry to hear of your incontinence and it is a bad case of incontinence. I have never encountered anyone after robotic surgery having as bad a situation as yours and I have attended support groups, have many friends and relatives who had robotic surgeries. Most recovered nicely. You had your surgery in 2011 and after almost 4 years with no improvement it probably won't go away. My suggestion is to look into installing an artificial sphincter and to stop the incontinence so you can lead a normal life. This forum also have a few posts discussing that and/or installing a sling. You can also visit other forums to seek advices on the same subject. Life is miserable if this is not fixed. If I were you, I would focus on moving forward and seek a better solution for a better future. Good luck and best to you.
Posts.Title: Incontinence after Dr.Samadi surgery

Posts.Content: Well, Pratoman, see my signature and my response to the other thread. My second biopsy had PIN, third biopsy had atypia and fourth biopsy had cancer. Post op pathology had extensive caner. High Grade PIN often turns into cancer. I suggest you redo biopsy in six months. Good luck.

Posts.Title: HI Grade PIN

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bobkeenan 1. Does this sound like early stage? 2. Will the Doc likely want to run more tests? which ones? 3. what would be good questions for the first visit? 4. Any good books or other reading material that I should be reading? Fairwind and ddayglo gave you most of the answers to your questions. Let me just add my 2 cents: 1. Yes, most likely early stage. However, since you have one core G3+4 and 60%, active surveillance is not an option and treatment is in your future. However, to be sure, send your biopsy samples out for a second read by another Lab, like Bostwick to confirm the finding. 2. As Fairwind said, most likely a bone scan and a CT scan as CYA for the doctor. 3. First order of business, ask your urologist to go through the pathology report with you and explain the finding, second, ask him to send the samples out for a second opinion, third ask him what options you have regarding treatments. He is a surgeon and most likely like to operate on you, so ask him how many operations he performed and if you can talk to his patients, finally ask for a referral to see a radiation oncologist for radiation options. 4. Order and read Dr. Walsh's book. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Just got my first bad biopsy results. Thoughts? Suggestions?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Friendly A couple years ago I had several bad days with Vertigo. I mentioned to the doctor that the Vertigo never seemed to go away and recently he did a MRI of my inner ears and found nothing. Did or does anyone ever experience an unsteadiness with Prostate Cancer as a symptom? A month ago they found my blood count is double digits. I had a Bone Scan and Kat Scan after a needle biopsy. They found 70 percent of the needle biopsy had cancer. My unsteadiness seems to be getting worse, could the cancer be attacking something that has made me this way? THANK YOU.[/SIZE][/B][/SIZE] Friendly, Welcome to this site. You should thank your wife for insisting you take a blood PSA test and let's hope you catch yours in time for a "cure" or as some other posters would prefer to say "full remission". Let me quote from Wikipedia: Vertigo is caused by problems with the inner ear or vestibular system. A number of conditions that involve the central nervous system may lead to vertigo including: lesions caused by infarctions or hemorrhage, tumors present in the cerebellopontine angle. So unless your prostate cancer metastasizes to your brain, your vertigo is most likely caused by something else. By the way vertigo is quite common and many of my otherwise healthy friends have this problem. You need to find out: 1. Your doctor should tell you what is your PSA number. He was irresponsible if he just told you it was double digit. 2. Your doctor needed to give you the full biopsy report and explained/summarized the results for you and your wife. If I were you, I next time you see your doctor, you should have your wife with you to take note. 3. The most important information from the biopsy report are: The type of prostate cancer, perhaps adencarcinoma or something else, # of core positive and % of positive, Gleason scores of each positive core, any other information like perineural invasions, prostate size, etc. would also be helpful. The treatment options and assessment of how serious your situation is depends on the biopsy outcome as described above. Fortunately, even with serious cases there are a lot of options and treatments to keep you around for a long long time. Good luck.

Posts.Title: I was wondering if anyone else experienced this as a symptom of Prostate Cancer.

Posts.Content: A positive biopsy is a definitive diagnosis. A negative biopsy means either you do not have or they did not find it this time. The advice from biopsy veterans like Fairwind and I (4 times) are you just have to watch it from now on if your PSA keep increasing. What I learned from my 4 times is that preparation is very important to minimize infection. Often, we did not take the antibiotics precisely as prescribed or did not thoroughly clean out our bowel before the procedure. Now you know. By the way, we are very happy to reject your membership to our club. Take care.

Posts.Title: QUESTION ABOUT BIOPSY _Got 0 OF !2 NEG

Posts.Content: If the infection that attacked the discs also went into your prostate, the PSA would be high. Enlarged prostate usually does not cause a PSA of over 50. With a PSA of over 50, it is prudent to do a DRE and biopsy to rule out cancer, especially since you already had a course of IV antibiotics. In terms of questions to ask your urologist, you might ask him if the infection that attacked your discs could cause the high PSA, and could an enlarged prostate caused a PSA of over 50. Also, what sort of special preparations and precautions you should take prior to biopsy since you did have a blood infection. Good luck and hope we can deny your club membership application.
Posts.Title: Discitis Then Raised PSA's

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Gimmy Hi all, had bone scan today and the cancer has spread to whole spine,arms,legs just about everywhere. I'm in huge pain. I was afraid to ask and my regular doctor is off until jan 7. How long do guys last in my shape? Will the pain get worse? Thank you. Gimmy Hi Gimmy, Hang in there as there are still many options, though palliative, that can reduce your bone pain and keep you going a long time. If you look at the adjacent post by squoiaranger, you will find that he has been fighting metastasized prostate cancer for many years with many treatment protocols and is still hanging in there. Perhaps, you can either write him a PM, or post on his thread so he can share some of his experiences with you. Good luck and God bless you.
Posts.Title: Am I dying?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Derkie54 .......It seems a bit of a minefield with people having multiple negative biopsy's and still having PC....... My PSA's are 61, 53, 40 & 47 are we definately talking cancer here or could it just as easily be something else ? If you look at the anatomy, you can see that there are places within the prostate that is difficult for a trans-rectum needle biopsy to access. So, if your cancer is not within the "peripheral zone" it is easy to miss in a biopsy. Even if it is within the zone, if the cancer is small, it is still easy to miss. I had quite extensive cancer yet the biopsy indicated only 1 core 5% positive. Your PSA is very high, so even with a negative biopsy, you should still be vigilant.

Posts.Title: Discitis Then Raised PSA's

Posts.Content: Welcome. Based on your signature and introductions, you are a very good candidate for AS. However, if you choose that route, make sure to have a second read of your biopsy slides by another pathologist, e.g. send them to Johns Hopkins to make sure the G3+3 stays 3+3. One issue with AS is while on it, most likely your doctor won't prescribe TRT and your "energy level" will continue to remain low during this time. With treatment, after your PSA becomes undetectable, your doctor might restart TRT to improve your "energy level". If you choose treatment, with your stats, all the treatment options including surgery are good and what you choose is mostly your preference and your doctor's recommendation. Good luck.

Posts.Title: New, G 3+3, Decisions?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by goatts Got a copy of my biopsy results today. Will meet with doctor on 3/5/15. I guess MRI and bone scan will be next. Any feedback from you guys who have been thru this would be appreciated. 6 cores (a thru f) show clear (all left side) g) 3+4=7 98% h) 3+4=7 90% i) 4+3=7 90% j) 3+4=7 95% k) 3+4=7 85% l) 4+3=7 95% So the right side is almost solid tumor. Perineural invasion on 2 cores, adenocarcinoma is present. My PSA is 38. I expected much worse. Based on the above, do you think it's spread beyond the prostate. Thanks Tom Tom, Sorry about your diagnosis. I took the liberty to input your biopsy results into the MSK prostate cancer nomogram and it is kind of a good news bad news situation: According to the nomogram, if you choose surgery here are the probabilities outcome: Good news: Prostate cancer specific survival - 10 yrs ~99%, 15 yrs ~97% Not so good news: 5 yrs progression free probability ~14% Meaning high probability cancer has escape the capsule but because it is G7, you can control them with medications and you will most likely not die from prostate cancer. But remember, these are just their guesses and yours may very well be organ confined. So as the others have advised find the best surgeon, radiation oncologist, oncologist and draw up a plan of attack and beat the hack out of the cancer. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Fairwind, Thank you for the link. Looks like it was a randomized double blind trial for evaluating supplements' effectiveness. Their results were astonishingly good - dramatic differences in PSA doubling time between placebo arm and supplements arm! The only negatives were small sample sizes and short duration (6 months) otherwise a solid piece of research work. The UCLA folks who first published their positive pomegranate results tried to organized a similar trial and last I tracked a couple of years ago, they were recruiting members for the trial and then went silent and I have not seen any write up since then. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: C11 Scan

Posts.Content: i agree with JohnT & lancepeace. You need a second look by a medical oncologist specializing in prostate cancer. Your PSA is too high, also your Gleason (4+3) is quite aggressive. You need to make very sure that your cancer is still localized otherwise surgery will fail. For some high risk cases, radiation could be a better choice. Good luck.

Posts.Title: husband 48 just diagnosed - info needed please

Posts.Content: I don't know if this article had been mentioned here prior but it is worth mentioning again. It was published in the 2013 ASCO (American Society of Clinical Oncology) Conference: http://www.onclive.com/publications/...rostate-Cancer The researchers were from the University of Southern California and it was a phase II study, not randomized. However, for someone who has detectable PSA after treatment, this might be worth a try either in concurrence with treatment or watchful wait. I am normally skeptical about diets' effectiveness after recurrence but this could be a no harm and worth a try situation.
Posts.Title: Herbal Supplement Could Outperform Observation in Recurrent Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Agree with lancepeace about considering taking chemo at the same time as hormone therapy. The recently published "landmark" clinical trial indicated a combined chemo/hormone treatment prolonged life significantly. Ask your oncologist if this combo treatment is right for you: http://www.onclive.com/web-exclusive...Cancer-Therapy Best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: How bad is this?

Posts.Content: To be on the safe side perhaps he should consult with his surgeon about the sore throat. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Dad's surgery is on Tuesday and he has a sore throat

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dirkv I'm the 'dad', and would like to know if there are cases where intermittent Lupron has proven useful. If the psa rise is partly due to Cassodex, I might consider staying off Lupron for six months. But would like to know if this drug recovers it's effectiveness after an interruption. Any experience out there ? Someone I know uses intermittent therapy: On Lupron for a period until PSA went below .1, stopped Lupron for a period and went back to Lupron after PSA started going up. This went on for over a decade. The nadir (low) was higher each successive cycle but was still lower than not taking Lupron. Don't know if this works in your case, best to consult your oncologist.

Posts.Title: Am I dying?

Posts.Content: No one responded so let me try. I am very impressed that you took the time to research the subject matter for your hubby. He is a lucky guy. I had to do all the research myself. Let me make a couple of comments: 1. The article looked to me like a review article geared towards medical education (for medical students or residents for example) and not for laypersons trying to make sense of the disease when first diagnosed. For someone without a lot of knowledge when first diagnosed, the best read in my opinion is what Fairwind posted in the Sticky: Dr. Patrick Walsh's "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer". The book is much better organized and easier to understand for a layperson. 2. Since you are very knowledgeable and technical and if you are looking for detail information, I suggest you go to the National Cancer Institute website and read up on the write up for health care professional: http://www.cancer.gov/cancertopics/types/prostate and click on health professional. I studied this write up carefully before I chose my treatment. Based on your hubby's signature, his cancer is moderately aggressive (a number of G7s) and with a PSA of over 100, it might be systemic or in danger of turning systemic. With your knowledge of statistics you can also get a sense of probability by going to the MSK website using his stats to assess probabilities. Knowledge is power and I hope by studying carefully, you and your husband can find the best path for a cure. In my opinion, he should not wait and should seek aggressive treatments to maximize his chance of a cure. Of course I am a layperson and this is not a medical opinion. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: A terrific overview

Posts.Content: At this stage I suspect it makes no difference but eating a healthy diet may give us the sense of doing something positive and proactive. As for supplements, you may want to give him pomegranate juice or a supplement consists of green tea, pomegranate, turmeric and broccoli which in a clinical trial (in UK?) seemed to slow the progression of prostate cancer but the improvement/slowing down was not dramatic.
Posts.Title: Diet changes / diet recommendations for advanced prostate cancer

Posts.Content: In addition to the machine, the practitioners are also critical. In the hands of an inexperience group, mistakes can often happen and with radiation there is no do over and the damages will not be apparent until it is too late. So, if I were you I would go with a center where there are lot of patients and the radiation oncologists and radiation techs are well trained. You see, how they map the site, where to aim, dosage to where/which... all need to be determined by the radiation oncologist and each and every oncologist can interpret differently. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Rising PSA (again) post RP - questions

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RTS My Urologist feels that I should not risk it, that at some point I will need treatment, and that I should not miss the "cure window". One of the reasons I sometimes appeared passionate and opinionated is because I know someone who missed the "cure window" after practicing AS for a year. Back in 2012, PSA ~5, biopsy showed two G6 <5%. Fast forward to 2013, PSA still ~5, but now 5 cores positive with 1 G7. Had surgery, one lymph node positive (<<1mm meaning beginning metastasized), bladder neck positive.... In your case, since you are so young, sooner or later you will need to take it out, might as well do it before cancer escapes. Yes, you don't know if it will and you may buy many years of QOL by doing AS and as other posters said another six months of delay decision won't matter, but you really don't know for sure. Good luck and sorry if I upset you.

Posts.Content: Instead of trying to remember or write down what your urologist tells you, ask for a copy of your biopsy pathology report and study it carefully to understand what you have. This way you can have an intelligent conversation with the urologist and the second opinion doctor. If you do not understand some of the terms and are willing to post it here, members here are happy to explain them to you. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Sorry to be the newest member of the club

Posts.Content: Sounded like your surgeon did a great job. The initial 2-3 hrs to go urinate is very normal and the time between will lengthen until you won't have to get up at night anymore. Like Highlander said ejaculating urine is also normal for the initial phase of recovery. You can minimize it by emptying your bladder just prior to sexual intimacy. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Leaky catheter - help!

Posts.Content: RTS, Using the last three PSA reading, your PSA doubling time is ~10 months. IF I use the last two values, doubling is about 7.5 months. So it is accelerating meaning there is cause for concern especially since recent MRI indicated cancer in both sides of your prostate now. However, before you decide to remove your prostate, you should get a second opinion and read up on the consequences, risks and side effects of prostatectomy, how to select a surgeon and investigate other treatment options like seeds or radiation. And if you plan on having kids later, bank your sperms. Good luck and best wishes

Back in 2012, PSA ~5, biopsy showed two G6 <5%. Fast forward to 2013, PSA still ~5, but now 5 cores positive with 1 G7. Had surgery, one lymph node positive (<<1mm meaning beginning metastasized), bladder neck positive.... In your case, since you are so young, sooner or later you will need to take it out, might as well do it before cancer escapes. Yes, you don't know if it will and you may buy many years of QOL by doing AS and as other posters said another six months of delay decision won't matter, but you really don't know for sure. Good luck and sorry if I upset you.

Posts.Title: No easy answers for 51 year old

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by trinity3 Since none of the procedures come with a penis warranty, maybe you could let me know your thoughts on what best option is for ED and incontinence issues. If you have ED now, you will have ED after surgery. If you do not have ED, the best chance to avoid it, either surgery or radiation is to find the best practitioners in the business, surgeons or radiation oncologists, which ever your choice. The ED side effect due to surgery is immediate and many improved/recovered over time. Radiation on the other hand has delayed ED effect for some, sometime in the future after the treatment. There were claims that the chances of ED was less for radiation treatment but I have not seen any side by side comparisons. As for incontinence, nowadays it is actually rare. Most (~90-95%?) will recover after a period of time. Also, I have some concern about running to some of the famous cancer centers for fear that someone other than the doctor I choose will be performing the procedure. I certainly welcome any comments!! If you ask the surgeon to not let someone other than him/her operates on you he/she will comply, if not you move to the next candidate. Good luck.

If there is a less than sign (<) in front of the .003, it is as good as it gets. Even without, it is so low it could be machine error. Wait another 6 months to see what happen next. So, don't sweat it and be happy. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: RTS, Using the last three PSA reading, your PSA doubling time is ~10 months. IF I use the last two values, doubling is about 7.5 months. So it is accelerating meaning there is cause for concern especially since recent MRI indicated cancer in both sides of your prostate now. However, before you decide to remove your prostate, you should get a second opinion and read up on the consequences, risks and side effects of prostatectomy, how to select a surgeon and investigate other treatment options like seeds or radiation. And if you plan on having kids later, bank your sperms. Good luck and best wishes

Posts.Title: No easy answers for 51 year old

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RILEYO RP August 2012 3+4 gleason positive margin at apex( grade 3 at margin ) ! Here is the infromation 10/15/2012 <0.05 standard assay , 01/15/2013 <0.05 standard assay , 04/30/2013 0.028 ultrasensitve assay , 07/01/2013 0.030 ultra , 09/05/2013 0.030 ultra , 11/12/2013 .040 ultra , 12/26/2013 .033 ultra , 02/10/2014 0.038 ultra , 04/10/2014 .044 ultra , 06/10/2014 .042 ultra , 08/11/2014 .047 ultra and the latest was 10/07/2014 .055 same lab except for the first 2 standard assays ! At what point should salvage radiation be considered ? Here are the computations for doubling time: 1. 18.91 months using 10 points starting 4/30/2013 2. 18.48 months using 9 points starting 7/1/2013 3. 17.87 months using 8 points starting 9/5/2013 4. 19.83 months using 7 points starting 11/12/2013 5. 14.84 months using 6 points starting 12/26/2013 6. 17.06 months using 5 points starting 2/10/2014 7. 17.67 months using 3 points starting 4/10/2014 8. 10.08 months using 3 points starting 6/10/2014 9. 8.26 months using 2 points starting 8/11/2014 There is definitely a trend of PSA increasing so chances are you have a recurrence. You can see that the doubling time bounced around some (probably due to machine sensitivity) but were consistent, until the last three tests when it accelerated. Of course two to three points are not as accurate but the acceleration in doubling time is unmistakable. When to pull the trigger on SRT is a question only you and your physician can answer as there are no consensus among physicians, but there is a guideline that your physician follows. By the way, did your pathology report indicated positive margins, or any other abnormal findings? Do your research, interview radiation oncologist, oncologist and prepare for action once the PSA number reaches a threshold. Consult an oncologist to see if a combination of hormone and radiation is right for you. We can give you our opinions but they are non professional opinions. Personally, I would go aggressive and start early the rationale being even if prostate cancer is slow growing, I want to minimize the chances of cancer turning systemic. Good luck.
Posts.Title: What is my psa doubling time ? Please help !

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RILEYO Just talked to the nurse she said my doubling time is right at 18 months guys which is fairly slow ! Now is it ok to continue to monitor my psa like I have been every 2-3 months or should i radiate now at .055 ? Feedback please ! The nurse used all of the numbers to arrive at the 18 month doubling time. You need to watch things carefully because if we use the more recent numbers, the doubling time seemed to be shorter. However, the plan of watching things every 2-3 months and wait until a higher threshold to act is reasonable. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: 2nd Opinion on Biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by vaom8 Unfortunately I cannot find the data today, but I did have a spike in the PSA test from 3 to 9 and the biopsy found the 3-4 Gleason level (I am not sure is that is a correct statement). The decision is made I will have the surgery and I will like to Know about how to prepare for it and recover. No Da Vinci , regular .Hopefully nerve saving surgery. Please Advice. As mentioned by HighlanderCFH and others, the outcomes between open and da vinci are not that different as long as you have an experienced surgeon operating on you. As for preparation, your surgeon's office should have a list of things for you to do prior to and after surgery and a list of stuff you should have prior, during and after. Before you know it, it will be over and we are ready to welcome you to join us on the other side. One thing usually not mentioned is your physical condition. The recovery, complications and even side effects depend very much on how fit are you prior to surgery. So, my advice is use the period between now and surgery to get yourself in shape, meaning, exercise, eat right, reduce weight.... I used the two months from diagnosed to surgery for vigorous exercise/boot camp. Of course if you have not exercised and want to start, you better consult your doctor before you start. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mickcee Hi everyone, I have had regular nosebleeds that bleed very heavily ( ENT specialist found nothing wrong) and initially ( a year ago) my bleeding times were fine. I wonder if this may be associated with my prostate cancer. mickcee, If your blood vessels inside your nose are exposed or too closed to the surface, bleeding can happen due to dryness or irritations. Have you asked your ENT if you have that condition and if so, to cauterize the blood vessels inside your nose? This problem often runs in the family and cauterization may help. Otherwise, apply Vaseline using a Qtip to the affected area once or twice a day may also help. Nose bleed is probably not related to your prostate cancer. Again, just a layperson's and not a medical profession's opinion. The other folks gave you good advices on your prostate cancer issues so I won't repeat. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Content: This maybe what you were referring to: In May of 2003, US FDA approved Radium-223 Dichloride to treat bone met. It reduced bone met and prolonged survival. The trade name is Xofigo. I am not familiar with Europe's approval situation.
Posts.Title: prostate cancer with metastasis to bones - most effective drug

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tomeksz Thank you for a warm welcome. It is about my girlfriend's father, 70. I will ask her to give me more details. I see Radium-223 drug was developed by the Norwegians and Bayer, so it is probably not this one. However, I should know about the drug I originally referred and will get back to tell you. Without knowing the name of the drug, we are just guessing. However, since 2010, there were six new drugs/treatments approved by the FDA for treating prostate cancer. 2010: Sepuleucel-T (Provenge an immuno-therapy) - prolong survival 2010: Cabazitaxel (Jevtana - Chemo) - prolong survival 2010: Denosumab (Xgeva for skeletal related event) 2011: Abiraterone (Zytiga for mCRPC, failed chemo) - prolong survival 2012: Enzalutamide (Xtandi - mCRPC, failed chemo) - prolong survival 2012: Abiraterone (Zytiga - mCRPC expanded to pre chemo) - prolong survival 2013: Radium-223 Dichroide (Xofigo - bone met) - prolong survival I am not aware of any new treatment after Radium-223 but there are a lot of options available to him. Good luck.

Posts.Title: prostate cancer with metastasis to bones - most effective drug

Posts.Content: A couple of comments: 1. Fairwind made an excellent point, in a standard radiation treatment, PSA does not go to undetectable immediately so your .02 PSA is most likely caused by the hormone. However, if hormone is what caused the PSA to be undetectable, then from what I read and from many of the posts here, PSA should stay low for some time and not rising immediately after it stops. Maybe you stopped too soon? 2. Most of the literatures I read about adjuvant hormone in radiation treatment started with hormone prior to radiation and usually continued for 6, 12 to 18 months after radiation. To stop right after radiation seemed unusual? 3. If you did not have adjuvant hormone therapy, PSA usually drops slowly and won't reach nadir for sometime, perhaps 12 to 24 months. So, my recommendation is to seek another opinion or perhaps get back to hormone. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: viperfred, Thank you for sharing your experience here. We need more sharing of experiences, good or bad so new members can benefit from our journeys. I am very happy for you that your treatment is very successful and I agree today's radiation treatment is "not your father's radiation treatment". RW744, Reading your biopsy and diagnostic reports again, I see your cancer seemed to be pushing the edge (capsule), I would consult your doctor to see if that could be a risk factor for Cyberknife. A very precise beam is both good and bad. If the cancer is pushing the edge, there may be potential misses or damaging adjacent tissues (if the doctor is too aggressive with the beam coverage). Again, just a layperson's opinion which may or may not be correct.
Posts.Title: CyberKnife or robotic radical prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by AsksALOTofQuestions I wonder if the cost benefit is dramatically shifting, especially for someone (almost everyone) in a position to budget $25k for the latest technology in treatment to minimize side effects and invasiveness of treatment. So what if the kids have a reduced inheritance or there is lien against the house at probate. That's what money is really for right...a rainy day! Asks, Your budget is way off. Without insurance, a typical surgery costs >$75K (I was going to pay out of pocket at one time), IMRT >$100K, proton >$150K, a course of new hormone, Provenge... costs >$100K per year.... I think after you add them all up for someone going through surgery, SRT, hormone, Provenge, chemo, etc. you are off by at least a factor of 10. My back of the envelop calculation showed that if we go back to the 1975 situation, no PSA testing, wait until symptoms show up and cancer is terminal (1/3 of cases then), it is a lot cheaper to insurance and Medicare.

Posts.Title: Value of Testing and Treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman DP, i have to say i find it odd, that a physician, who has followed many Prostate Cancer patients, would come to an internet forum for advice from a group of laymen With that said, there is always possibility of a lab error, as you probably know. I had 3 consecutive undetectable PSAs after surgery with very favorable pathology and similar results on the MSKCC Nomogram as your dads. And then my fourth PSA test came back at 3.88!!!!! I had it retested at another lab, it came back undetectable, and the first lab then confirmed that after retesting the same blood they too got an undetectable. So yes, its possible that its a lab error, get a retest. Pratoman, He may be a physician but with his Dad's situation, he is just like us, seeking support and some help and we may be all laypersons but with our collective experiences perhaps we could offer some comfort to him and his family. That said, I don't think his case is lab error: His post-op PSAs were: April 2015 PSA = 0.003 August 2015 PSA = 0.005 Oct 2015 PSA = 0.007 Jan 2016 PSA = 0.16 (done in middle east at a different lab from his usual labs) The PSA was detectable from the get go and there is a monotonic increase so the only possible error is the magnitude and not the increase. Bottom line is the surgery failed. In addition since all margins, nodes are negative. I worry the cancer may have gone systemic but lets hope it is still local so SRT can kill them all. The question really is how aggressive he wants to take the next step and a consultation with an oncologist with expertise in prostate cancer is in order. To the op, you should know that it is not a death sentence for your Dad. If the Gleason score is not too aggressive, the cancer can be managed and life span of decades is very likely. Take care.

Posts.Title: Urgent, panicked

Posts.Content: Yes, in June 9th 2011, the FDA issued a label change for finasteride (Proscar) and dutasteride to warn of a potential safety concern: There is a potential increased risk of being diagnosed with a more serious form of prostate cancer (high-grade prostate cancer).... However, most physicians dismissed the evidences that the FDA cited as not conclusive and thought the FDA over reacted. As for treatment options, it is really up to you as both surgery and radiation are equally effective. The only advice we can give is whatever you decide, go find the best practitioner to do it for you. That has more bearing than which treatment type you choose. Good luck.
