Posts.Title: confused

Posts.Content: At this stage I suspect it makes no difference but eating a healthy diet may give us the sense of doing something positive and proactive. As for supplements, you may want to give him pomegranate juice or a supplement consists of green tea, pomegranate, turmeric and broccoli which in a clinical trial (in UK?) seemed to slow the progression of prostate cancer but the improvement/slowing down was not dramatic.
Posts.Title: Diet changes / diet recommendations for advanced prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tim1029 Can anyone help me. I just was diagnosed at age 44 with very early stage 1 Gleason score 6 prostate cancer. My Doctor told me the standard for someone my age is to have a radical prostectomy to give me the best shot of a long life. My concern is how will my sex life be after the surgery. I hear many conflicting storys ranging from you will be able to have erections a couple weeks after surgery to, forget it you'll never be able to have sex again. Please is there anyone out there that could possibly give me some straight answers to what to exspect with the surgery. Also maybe a little advice on possible other options. Welcome. As mentioned in prior posts, you do have a lot of options beside surgery. However, if you decide on surgery, like some of us on this site, then I cannot emphasize enough about finding a competent surgeon to do the operation. Published results of the "best in class" are quite a bit better than the overall population of surgeons. You have one shot to do it right and there is no do-over. When you interview surgeons, do ask how many operations have they done, the rate of positive margins, the rate of incontinence and the rate of ED. They should be willing to answer those questions. If not, you should find someone else. If you read Dr. Walsh's book, in it he shared his statistical outcome on positive margins, incontinences and ED. The surgeon you select should have comparable results. Good luck.

Posts.Title: 44yrs old with prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Sounds like doctors can give prostrate sizes with either way. When asking my surgeon at Mayo how large the tumor was compared to the prostate. He replied by saying my prostate was about 98 grams and the tumor was about 2 grams. So, I think both ways are used, perhaps depending on the particular aspect being discussed at the time. Highlander, I think after surgery, they have the specimen so they can weigh and determine the weight. Before surgery, with ultrasound, they only have the dimensions (X cm by Y cm by Z cm) so cc is more likely. But, as I said, I don't know, they can convert cc into gm easily.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Done - whew!!

Posts.Content: Welcome mom2two. As Fairwind said, G8 is aggressive so treatment is needed to get rid of the cancer. However, there are a number of positives in his favor: 1. Looks like the cancer is only confined in the area of the positive DRE and has no sign of spread (no ECE,no PNI, no seminal vesicles involvement, no lymph/vascular invasion...), i.e., cancer is organ confined. 2. The histologic type is acinar, which is the most common type and treatments are normally effective. Statistics for his case is in his favor if he seeks treatment. It is highly likely that he can achieve a cure using either radiation or surgery. Best wishes and good luck.
Posts.Title: I need some support...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wish full Also, is high grade and high risk the same? Originally Posted by wish full What I'm really concerned about is the prostate covering the Apex and being high grade. I see this as a possible apex margin due to the amount and being high grade. Sorry we have to welcome you to our club. Mikla gave you good advice and you should take him up on his suggestions. To answer your specific questions: Yes, high Gleason scores mean higher risks. However, risks also depend on staging, i.e., how extensive the cancer is and whether it has spread to other organs. Since you have one score of 3+4, it is moderately aggressive. 3+4 means most of your cancer is grade 3, the least aggressive type, but there are some grade 4 which is more aggressive. Looking at your biopsy pathology report, your cancer is at exactly where the radiologist said it was - left mid and left base (near the bladder, not apex). So, you had a very good radiologist read your MRI. The other good news are the biopsy did not detect any spread and more important, the MRI report showed no evidence of spread. All in all, looks like an organ confined case and if you take action to seek treatment, you should be fine. Good luck.

Posts.Title: I need some support...

Posts.Content: Fairwind gave you an excellent unbiased review. I might add that in addition to selecting a skill surgeon, outcome depends on a number of other factors and is very personalized. If the cancer is too close to the nerves, nerve sparing could be difficult and potency could be a challenge. If it is too close to the bladder neck, apex or urethra, it might affect continence, etc. So, in the end, it also depends on your situation. Based on a number of posts I read here and elsewhere in the past six months, it seemed for surgery, in general most eventually were able to achieve continence. ED seemed more of a challenge. In the end many required medications or aids to function but were able to function. Folks that had done radiation mostly reported only minor short term side effects. However, there were not too many long term outcome reported. I don't know, maybe because there were none to report? Discuss all options with your doctor. In the end, it is your choice. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Great Balls of Fire

Posts.Content: Half life for PSA in the body is between 2 to 3 days. With your PSA#, at one month after surgery, PSA should be <.1 Since it is .1 and not <.1, it could indicate that the positive margins did leave some cells behind and that is why your surgeon is advocating adjuvant radiation. The good news is that in people with positive margins, if there is biochemical recurrence, salvage radiation's success rate is much higher than people with negative margins. In a way your surgeon was between a rock and a hard place when he operated on you: Some of your cancer cells were at the apex, if he cut too wide, you would certainly have bad incontinence and if he cut too colse he left some cells behind. I believe in your case salvage or adjuvant radiation should give you a good chance of a "cure". You and your radiation oncologist should determine the best course of action in your particular case. Good luck.
Posts.Title: A little confused

Posts.Content: Welcome. Most likely, your husband has BCR (biochemical recurrence), meaning his cancer came back. The good news is his PSA was undetectable for three years and his doubling time is not too aggressive so a lot can be done to control his recurrence and he will most likely not die from it. He may want to consult a radiation oncologist, as often time, with slow growing cancer like what he has, the cancer may still be localized in and around the prostate bed and radiation may kill them all. Also, he should see an oncologist specializing in treating prostate cancer who can help design a treatment protocol for him. Best wishes and good luck.
Posts.Title: Post Prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by kinghorne I have just turned 65 (Sept) - otherwise in excellent health, active etc PSA's - 2008 - 1,94; 2010 - 2,97; 2012 July - 4,36 DREs all negative till 07/2012 - small nodule on prostate Biopsy Oct 2012 ;- 12 cores, 3 positive (no details) PSA 4,36, Stage T2a, Gleason 7 (3 + 4) My preferred option (of course !) is to Wait & Monitor ... I do not know for sure but must assume that the cancerous cores were from the nodule ? I did not verify or ask the urologue at the time (in shock I guess). Many thankls in advance for your advice. +++ kinghorne, Sorry you are here but welcome to the club no one wants to join. Good news: Looks like you have been monitoring your PSA and catch your cancer early enough that a "cure" is definitely possible. Also, the cancer is a Gleason(3+4), so not too aggressive. Another good news is you are i/d as a T2a, meaning the cancer is in less than half of one side. There is also no indication of spread based on PSA #, biopsy and DRE. Wait & Monitor (AS) is probably not the right path for you because you are a G7 and not a G6 and your PSA has gone up quite fast in the past two years. As to the types of treatment, my opinion is both surgery and radiation are appropriate and it is more a personal choice than effectiveness in your case. One more thing, even though DRE detected a nodule, more often, prostate cancers are multifocal and very likely in more places than one nodule. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Discussion with my Surgeon about biopsy...

Posts.Content: Let me be the first to welcome you. We can understand why you are afraid as it is a normal reaction and we all know that feeling. However, chances are even if you ended up having cancer, you will still be around for a long time like all of us here as prostate cancer is one of the most treatable cancers for men and there are many options available to treat. A PSA of 113 is very high and not likely due to an enlarge prostate. However, it is still possible that infection/inflammation of the prostate can cause such high PSA. Usually urologist will prescribe antibiotics to rule out infection before sending you to have a biopsy done. Biopsy is the one definitive diagnosis for cancer if it is positive. Negative scan/x-ray and negative DRE are both positive signs for you and hopefully you have infection instead of cancer. Best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: Hallo

Posts.Content: MKEvman, Welcome. Your case demonstrates why in many cases PSA tests save lives. If your doctor follows the new guideline and forgoes PSA testing, your cancer will probably not be curable after symptoms appear. You are very fortunate your doctor tracked your PSA and both he and the urologist went for a biopsy. Another good news is no lymphatic or perineural invasion which means cancer has not found a path to escape yet. A cure/full remission for you! Take your time to research and decide on a treatment that you are comfortable with. The most important choice is to choose the right physician (surgeon if you choose surgery or radiation oncologist if you choose radiation). You have one shot to do it right and outcome is very physician dependent. - especially side effects of the treatment. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: New Member Here!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ChiliDog His MRI result is that he has "1.5 cm mass in the peripheral zone of the right mid gland and apex with likely extracapsular extension, which abuts the right neurovascular bundle." Next step is a biopsy done by the young guys with fancy equipment. That will happen later in December. He will then will go before a committee for treatment recommendations. The good news is there were no mentioned of other areas of involvements (e.g., lymph nodes, seminal vesicles...) so it is very likely organ confined and he has a high probability of a cure. Also, MRI cannot be a definitive diagnosis as the mass could be inflammations or other issues. The biopsy will be definitive if positive. The one area of concern is the mass is very close to the nerves on the right so very likely the surgeon, if surgery is the treatment chosen, will have to cut out that nerve bundle resulting in higher probability of ED. For major cancer centers, the current practice is to form a "Cancer Board" to review the diagnosis and recommend treatment. This is to reduce "treatment bias" of the physicians (the old saying: Surgeons like to cut). In this case if Ed is an important issue to you, perhaps radiation is a better approach. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: New Member Here!

Posts.Content: Life returned to normal and prostate cancer became a distant memory until I learned yesterday that a former business associate and friend of mine died from prostate cancer a couple of days ago. Our cancers were discovered at about the same time in 2010. My friend never tested his PSA until 2010, for the very first time and unfortunately his PSA at the time was already over 100. So, by the time his was detected, it already spread to adjacent organs. Curative procedures were no longer possible for him. He went through most of the medications including MDV3100. Each time the medication worked for a short time and then stopped working. With bone met, his last two years of life was very painful and uncomfortable. He told me if he could rewind, he would have tested his PSA when he turned 50 and would gladly trade complications from surgery/radiation for his painful/uncomfortable existence. The USPSTF is doing men a disservice by recommending no PSA testing. Logic and statistics from the National Cancer Institute's SEER database simply do not support the USPSTF's position. They arrived at their position by examining specially designed trials instead of looking at real world data. Those in research know that trials can be misleading and flawed. I reviewed the SEER database which went back to the 1960/70. It clearly indicated a dramatic reduction of prostate cancer death rate and dramatic increase in survival rate after PSA testing was implemented. May my friend rest in peace.

AgeInfo.Phrase: his PSA when he turned 50 and would gladly trade complications

Posts.Title: Friend Died From Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ChiliDog Newporter, I'd say that ED is important! But I'd rather have the husband alive, and well, the rest is secondary. My impulse is to get that prostate outta here, but it's not my body. Actually all the recent studies indicated modern radiation techniques and surgery produced almost the same cancer outcome but radiation seemed to give better outcome on ED in the short term. The main differences between surgery and radiation are the side effects of surgery are immediate and most get better over time whereas radiation side effects are few at the beginning but over time some may get worst. There are also side effects of radiation that surgery does not have like bowel and bladder irritations....and side effects that surgery has but not radiation like lymphedema....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tomnan24 1st Opinion. PSA 5.6, biopsy May 2013 gleason 6, 8 of 12 positive. He said it probably wouldn't kill me for 10-15 years. Had CT scan in February 2013. Doctor said from this that Cancer was contained in prostate so I would be a candidate for hormone therapy to delay surgery/seeds til next year when I will have insurance. Got a second opinion to be safe from a respected doctor. He said I am not a candidate for hormone therapy and in addition said I will need another CT scan for staging in order to have surgery/seeds. Can anyone make sense of these differing comments? 2nd doctor was not that easy to discuss things with. I'll probably talk to the first doctor again, but may get a 3rd opinion. Any thoughts? I'm bummed out. One option is to do hormone therapy for a year and then do radiation therapy. This combination actually will provide superior outcome compare to radiation alone. A number of studies in medical journals reported some better outcome with a combination hormone/radiation compare to radiation only. Also, there are some inexpensive generic hormone medications available so that those without insurance will not break their piggy bank. The only issue I see is most hormone prior to radiation only go for 6 months so some expert advices are needed to go hormone for one year. The suggestion of consulting with a radiation oncologist and an oncologist is an excellent one. Good luck.

Posts.Title: More confused than ever.

Posts.Content: Kazzie61, I agree with the other posters. The biopsy results are not bad. He has a very good urologist who called for an MRI and was able to detect the potential SV involvement. The biopsy was then able to confirm that suspicion. That is tremendously helpful to the surgeon and/or radiation oncologist when they start treatment. As to whether it is a G7(3+4) or G7(4+3), often that depends on the pathologist's judgement. The first # represents the majority of cancers in that core and the second # the next most prevalent. Often whether it is 3+4 or 4+3 in a core is a judgement. Also, if overall the were more G3 than G4, the overall diagnosis is G7(3+4). Looking at the percentage of cancer in each core, it looks like they ranged from 30 to 100% indicating cancers are quite prevalent and not incidental thus calling for immediate treatment. After surgery there is often another # call tertiary Gx which is the third most prevalent cancers in the specimen (see my signature). Seminal Vesicle involvement and PNI are additional risk factors but can still be classified as localized cancer with a high cure rate. I had PNI in my final pathology report and I was worried. I then researched and read medical studies that indicated PNI did not increase recurrence rate and my surgeon said so himself. His physicians wanted to be aggressive, which is very good as they wanted a cure. Good luck and we look forward to him takes the plunge and joins us on the other side.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Valar My husband had a 8 hr. surgery because the cancer had multiple positive margins in the the bladder neck and right an left anterior quadrants, right seminal vesicle was present.Lymph-vascular areas suspicious for aniolymphatic invasion were identified.Pathologic staging.pT4NOMO stage 4.So he has had a shot of Lupron and will start radiation 1-2 months.Dr doesn't want to wait long being it spead so fast from the scans in 5 weeks.His urologist say incurable, but oncologist thinks 50/50 any thoughts?I pray that it will be cured,but after reading his stats not sure....... Welcome. If I were you husband and is healthy, I would start adjuvant treatments asap to maximize my chance of a cure. Of course this is the opinion of a non professional. His oncologist should have a better handle than his surgeon/urologist whose job is essentially done. He might also ask his oncologist about adding chemo to the regimen early. Best wishes

Posts.Content: As a non healthcare person but with technical training, I researched HIFU and cryosurgery and thought HIFU was similar to cryosurgery, effective for focal cancer that was localized but it might be difficult to treat multifocal cancers that were all over the prostate and the control for side effects could be difficult because the precision of ultrasound was difficult to maintain so there might be more collateral damages to adjacent tissues and nerves during HIFU and cryosurgery (ED for example). However, medical science progresses rapidly, so like radiation, it maybe ready for prime time now as opposed to 5 years ago.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by micklyn73 Any help or advice would be helpful. Cancer localised in prostrate luckily, not sure of what treatment to have. Fors and against your treatments. Thank you Mick Smith Sorry you have to join the club but welcome. Sounds like you caught yours early and so you have lots of options and you will be around a long long time. Without more information about your condition, like your age, PSA #, biopsy report and symptoms, I don't think any of us can make meaningful comments other than giving you general encouragements. That said, you will find a lot of supportive folks here as we are all fellow sufferers giving one another supports and share our experiences. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Diagnosed prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Wayno2 Help! Wife, a devout Christian (AND an RN by the way) wants AS because "God Has already healed me!". So, what the hell are "microscopic cancer clusters"? Two comments: 1. God help those that help themselves. 2. your cancer is the multifocal type meaning they are diffuse and tend to spread compare to a single solid tumor. So, in my non professional opinion if I were you I would seek treatment now instead of thinking you are cure. Also I think your wife is in denial like us when first diagnosed. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Arthro92, Perhaps, in addition to AIP you may have an enlarged prostate that causes the frequent night time urination? I agree with EdBar, continue to monitor your situation closely just in case.
Posts.Title: Asymptomatic Inflammatory Prostatitis

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Omar1968 2. I also take Propecia for the treatment of male pattern hair loss. The uro that performed my biopsy told me that my "true" PSA reading was actually around 9.6. 3. Prostate cancer runs in my family on my father's side. My grandfather and several of his siblings had PC. My father has BPH, and keeps an active check on his prostate. In fact, one of his biopsies came back with HGPIN. With your family history and positive diagnosis at such a young age, if I were you, I won't do AS. Just my non professional opinion. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Looking for information

Posts.Content: Since you had such good results with continence right after surgery, I suspect you did not need to do a lot of Kegel exercises to regain continence. Since you only have the external sphincter muscles to control your urethra often time they need to be trained and over time they could be weaken or relaxed. I suggest you start to do Kegel again to see if controls can be tighten up. All else fails, there are implants that can fix incontinence. As for ED, there are a lot of remedies including injection and implant if that is important to you. Life is precious and I would not trade 10 years for ED and some leakage. I am not trying to minimize your bad situations, just some suggestions in case you want to take actions and be proactive to improve your conditions. Peace and best wishes.
Posts.Title: Suggestions

Posts.Content: Agree with lancepeace and Putt, ask the doctor to re-test and if still high get a course of antibiotic to eliminate infection as a possibility. His symptoms could very well be a case of acute infection of the prostate. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Fast PSA rises

Posts.Content: Welcome. For his age and stats he should do fine. It is a toss up between surgery and radiation (brachy). If he has no symptoms, with a normal size prostate, and is afraid of surgery, radiation could be a very good choice with the same cure rate. It is very personal and only he can decide. For those of us with an enlarged prostate and loads of urinary symptoms (slow stream, frequent urination, nocturia...) prior to treatment, surgery will cure all those symptoms and allows us to urinate like an 18 year old again. Good luck to your Dad.

Posts.Title: My Dad diagnosed with Prostate Cancer-so many questions-any advice, info, help?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kazzie61 Thank you just for reading my long post let alone taking the time to answer! The full pathology report came today, if I put the report here (I don't know the implications of much of it) again I would appreciate feedback/advice however hard hitting it is. A radical prostatectomy specimen weighing 42g Fibrofatty tissue measuring 20x10x10 A1. adenocarcinoma Gleason 4+3,3.5cm2 right and left side,specimen confined tumour extends beyond the gland for 2mm at right lateral but is clear of the circumference inked surgical limit. Apical inked limit shows tumour for 1mm. A2. adenocarcinoma Gleason 4+3 (with focal Gleason 5) 3.1cm2 right and left side,tumour extends beyond the gland and is seen at an extraprotastic inked surgical limit for 1mmat right posterior. A3. adenocarcinoma Gleason 4+3,2.5cm2 right and left side,tumour extends beyond the gland for 1mm at right lateral but is clear of the circumferential inked surgical limit. A4. adenocarcinoma Gleason 3+4,2.5cm,right and left side,specimen confined,tumour extends beyond the gland for 4mm at right posterior but is clear of the circumferential inked surgical limit. A5. adenocarcinoma Gleason 4+3, 1.9cm2,right and left side,specimen confined,tumour extends beyond the gland for 10mm at right posterior but is clear of the inked surical limit. Tumour infiltrates extensivelyinto right SV and focally into left SV muscle coats( stage pT3b). Basal inked limit and vasal limits are free of tumour. B. Sections show pre-prostatic fat is free of tumour. No lymph nodes are seen. There are good news and concerns in this pathology report. The good news is even though there were two positive margins, they were small and even if the post op PSA is not undetectable, radiation should provide him with a cure. The bad news is what was not reported: The surgeon did not take out any lymph nodes! You are smart to ask for the report. I think the reason the surgeon kind of refused to provide one is because it showed he was somewhat irresponsible. With seminal vesicles involvement and EPE, surgeons should take out at least a few lymph nodes and examined them to make sure they were negative. It is really very easy to do in both open and robotic surgeries. Instead none was taken out (No lymph nodes are seen). Maybe it was a misprint if so I apologize but this is an important point to ask him. If the lymph nodes were taken out and were negative, he has an excellent chance of a cure with adjuvant radiation or salvage radiation. Even if some lymph nodes were positive, taking them out sometimes cure the cancer if they were localized within those nodes. In adjuvant or salvage radiation therapy, the RO should consider irradiating those nodes. Hopefully, there is still a chance of a cure for him. Your husband is lucky to have you looking after him and protecting his health.

Posts.Title: Advice please on patholgy report- post op prostatectomy

Posts.Content: dk6 & Fairwind gave you the 1 min version. Let me give you the 10 min version. It has been one and a half years ago so it is from distant memory: First of all, the surgeon, his nurse and the hospital should run you through pre-op checks, by him, her and the hospital. Also, run some tests to make sure you can be operated on. One of them, usually your doctor's office should give you instructions on what to do, pre and post op, what to do in case of complications post op, etc. The instructions should include how to deal with the catheter, clean the areas, emptying the bag, disinfect the bag... The morning of the surgery, I checked into the hospital at 5am, by 6:30am they prepared me, wheeled me into the staging area, the anesthesiologist greeted me, put the IV in my arm and explained the process. My surgeon came in next all dressed and I said Hi. I did not even remember what he said, the next thing I knew, I was in my room, I saw the wall clock in the room said 1:30pm and saw my wife looking and smiling at me. I did not feel any pain but started noticing the catheter bag and the compression sleeves they put on my legs pumping (to prevent blood clogs). The nurse got me up that evening to walk around. I was supposed to be discharged the next afternoon but because I did not pass gas (indication of bowel movement, which is important after surgery to indicate everything in your system is getting back to normal), they kept me till the morning of the third day when I passed gas. During discharge, the nurse went through the catheter care and handling again. So, this is a good time for you to ask as many questions regarding the catheter as you can. Best to have someone with you and take note or you might forget. There were no pain. I did not take any pain medication except some Tylenol the first day at home to ease the sore throat that Fairwind mentioned, that was caused by the breathing tube. The catheter was not painful, just not comfortable, especially when I accidentally tugged on it. the tip where it came out got irritated after a couple of days because I walked too much. Called the doctor and he told me the best treatment was to washed the area regularly with clean warm water and applied Neosporin occasionally. Mobility was not any problem, I used the big bag for indoor and leg bag for outdoor. As for clothing, Fairwind was spot on. You won't be able to run but any walking at a normal pace should not post any problem. Sleeping was a little uncomfortable the first night because I was afraid to press on the tubing and did not "turn", just stayed on my back all night. Slept through the rest of the nights and did not even notice the tube. There were some blood clots and some bleeding but they told me those were normal. So, don't be too alarm if the urine collection looks pink. Do drink plenty of fluid. Best part as dk6 said, for the first time in years I did not have to get up multiple times to urinate at night. You need to watch your bowel movement and make sure to take stool softener. For the first few weeks, I took Colace and drank prune juice and had no problem with bowel. It is very bad for your incision sites if you strain too much. Straining could also cause irritation to your bladder and might cause the catheter to leak. When you laugh or cough, best thing is to press a pillow on your tummy so as not to stress the incisions. Be careful, the incisions could come apart if you stress them too hard. That is also why for a few weeks you should not lift anything heavy. I was amazed with the whole experience with regard to the lack of pain and discomfort and how quickly I recovered. My friend went through open and had to stay in the hospital for 4 days and he was in quite a bid of pain after he went home. It is not a walk in the park for sure but overall I had a good experience and was happy I selected the treatment and selected my surgeon. Best of luck to you and please share your experience after you are on the other side. Cheers.

Posts.Title: Da Vinci robotic prostatectomy recovery--the first weeks after surgery--advice wanted

Posts.Content: You have a positive DRE, i.e., the urologist felt a nodule, so, ignoring this issue is not wise. As for the statement that "Research has not yet proven that the potential benefits of testing outweigh the harms of testing and treatment" it is a carefully crafted statement. Notice it did not state testing did not save life. Numerous studies, especially one from Europe indicated testing and treatment saved lives, just that over treatments often caused unwanted side effects and that all these testing and treatment were very expensive and perhaps our healthcare systems cannot afford it. I think the main issue is not testing but after tested positive, what do you do? Many cases can be treated with AS (Active Surveillance) to avoid cost and bad side effects.

Posts.Title: Value of Testing and Treatment

Posts.Content: MKEvman, Welcome. Your case demonstrates why in many cases PSA tests save lives. If your doctor follows the new guideline and forgoes PSA testing, your cancer will probably not be curable after symptoms appear. You are very fortunate your doctor tracked your PSA and both he and the urologist went for a biopsy. Another good news is no lymphatic or perineural invasion which means cancer has not found a path to escape yet. A cure/full remission for you! Take your time to research and decide on a treatment that you are comfortable with. The most important choice is to choose the right physician (surgeon if you choose surgery or radiation oncologist if you choose radiation). You have one shot to do it right and outcome is very physician dependent. - especially side effects of the treatment. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: New Member Here!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by julie bell Firstly he was perscribed bicalutanide which did not lower the psa sufficiently so he went on to get the hormone injections (Monthly). This successfully reduced his PSA and about a year and a half ago he had a course of radiotherapy. Since then his PSA has remained at an undetectable level and he continued to have the injections along withTamoxifen and Bicalutanide. Now after 1.5yrs the consultant has stopped the injections and the 2 medications mentioned above. I would like to know, in your experience - is this usual practice? Julie (Anxious daughter!!) x Agree with Fairwind, I believe it is a standard treatment protocol: Radiation Therapy sandwich between 36 months of hormone treatment. It looks like the treatment is working since his PSA is undetectable. Stop now and hopefully the PSA will remain undetectable. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Father is coming off medication - is this normal?

Posts.Content: From UPI, an interesting study by UC San Francisco: Men with non-metastatic prostate cancer who replaced some carbohydrates and animal fat with vegetable fat had lower risk of dying, U.S. researchers say. Erin L. Richman of the University of California, San Francisco, and colleagues examined fat intake in men after a diagnosis of prostate cancer in relation to lethal prostate cancer and all-cause mortality. The study included 4,577 men diagnosed with non-metastatic prostate cancer from 1986-2010 who were enrolled in the Health Professionals Follow-up Study. The study, published in the journal Internal Medicine, found after a midpoint follow up of 8.4 years, there were 315 lethal prostate cancer events and 1,064 deaths. Replacing 10 percent of calories from carbohydrates with vegetable fat was associated with a 29 percent lower risk of lethal prostate cancer and a 26 percent lower risk of death from all-cause mortality. "In this prospective analysis, vegetable fat intake after diagnosis was associated with a lower risk of lethal prostate cancer and all-cause mortality," the study authors wrote in summing up their work. Read more: http://www.upi.com/Health_News/2013/...#ixzz2VrRutt2S
Posts.Title: UCSF Study: Diets Do Reduce Prostate Cancer Death

Posts.Content: edmcc, Welcome. You are only one month post surgery so things have not settled down yet. Give yourself a few more months and incontinence should be gone. Usually recovery from ED takes longer. There were studies that indicated taking 5mg Cialis and pump helped with ED rehab so you should follow your doctor's instructions. Even though there were indications that cancer cells might have escaped the capsule, lets hope your surgeon had taken them all out by taking adjacent tissues out (that was how the pathologist noted microscopic cancer cells in surrounding tissues) . So strictly speaking you might not have positive margins and should have undetectable PSA when the next test comes around. Good luck.
Posts.Title: New to site one month post surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ChiliDog Newporter, I'd say that ED is important! But I'd rather have the husband alive, and well, the rest is secondary. My impulse is to get that prostate outta here, but it's not my body. Actually all the recent studies indicated modern radiation techniques and surgery produced almost the same cancer outcome but radiation seemed to give better outcome on ED in the short term. The main differences between surgery and radiation are the side effects of surgery are immediate and most get better over time whereas radiation side effects are few at the beginning but over time some may get worst. There are also side effects of radiation that surgery does not have like bowel and bladder irritations....and side effects that surgery has but not radiation like lymphedema....
Posts.Title: Joining the club.

Posts.Content: Congratulations. I am very happy for you and your hubby because an undetectable nadir is a good predictor of good long term outcome. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: That sweet 0.1

Posts.Content: My two years anniversary date with Da Vinci is coming up on August 23rd and I am happy to report I have undetectable PSA since surgery and no incontinence or ED. A while back I decided I was going to stay away from posting or reading prostate cancer forums and "move on". Life was good. However, about a month ago, I posted that a friend and former business associate passed away due to prostate cancer two years after he was diagnosed. Right after that, a classmate of my brother in law also passed away after several years of fighting the disease. In quick succession, a relative was diagnosed with stage T2 and a friend who had surgery and SRT in early 2000s found out his PSA was rising rapidly and doubling about every 6 months after being dormant for 8 years. The two that are alive checked their PSA every year prior to diagnosed. The two that died did not and had advanced disease when diagnosed. Since coming back and getting involved again, I am impressed with the number of new medications being tested recently. There will be more weapons available to fight prostate cancer in the near future. So, to those that are new, do not panic, relax and try to gain as much understanding of the disease and treatment options as you can. There are many options available but choose carefully for you have one chance to get it right.

Posts.Title: Two Year Anniversary

Posts.Content: Pratoman and Highlander gave you good advices. With a PSA over 10, insurance should pay. Also ask for a transrectal MRI (with the coil inserts inside the rectum), they have higher resolutions. Good luck.
Posts.Title: PSA number on a steep rise

Posts.Content: Your urologist should be able to tell you the volume of your prostate and from there gives you a guesstimate of how high your normal PSA should be. Your 6-7 PSA could very well be normal if you have a large prostate, e.g. Highlander had a prostate of ~100cc which would give off a normal PSA of 6-7. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Results Coming Back Next Week: What questions to ask given the possible situations

Posts.Content: Here is a look at your PSA history: Based on Memory with some help PSA 3.53 Jun 12 Age 53 (in 2012) PSA 5.5 Aug 12 PSA 6.83 Sep 12 PSA 7.5 Oct 12 Biopsy Oct 12 16 Cores taken all negative PSA 8.5 Jan 13 MRI Apr 13 Negative for signs of Cancer PSA 7.5 Jun 13, PSA 6.4 sept 14, PSA 6.54 Oct 14 I calculated your PSA doubling time to be about 9 years! And if I removed the first reading of 3.53 in Jun 12, your PSA has not change over almost three years! Meaning your PSA is actually very stable, unlike when cancer is present where mostly PSA increases monotonically. I suspect you either have a chronic inflammation of the prostate or an enlarged prostate? Perhaps if you get another negative biopsy, you may want to ask your urologist about it. In addition it might make sense to send your biopsy slides to JH or Mayo for a second read. Most negative biopsies that leads to eventually a positive one have some abnormal cells present like HGPIN, or atypical cells (look at Ray61's signature and mine). Also, did you have any symptoms of BPH or infections and did your urologist prescribed a long course of antibiotics to see if the PSA would come down? Best wishes and hope we can reject your application for membership. Cheers.

Posts.Title: Results Coming Back Next Week: What questions to ask given the possible situations

Posts.Content: Samie, Sorry you have to be here but welcome. I have a few thoughts: It is a good idea to get a second opinion from another urologist. Perhaps the new urologist will ask for an MRI to see if indeed the cancer is extensive. 1 core out of 8 positive does not explain the 39 PSA #. Maybe his cancer is extensive and aggressive or maybe not. It is possible that his high PSA # could be due to a combination of cancer and infection. Did his urologist prescribe a course of antibiotics to see if that brings down the PSA. Since cancer is already diagnosed, it is done to see how extensive is the cancer, perhaps, just perhaps it is not as extensive as the PSA # indicated. In that case the treatment protocol may be different. In any case, if he is more comfortable with the non surgery approaches (some forms of radiations), the cure rate is about equal to surgery so he should proceed without worry. Another point we all like to make is this is not a death sentence by any means. Even if the cancer is aggressive, there are lots of options for him to keep him around for a long time, so, do not interrupt your plan for a wonderful retirement.
Posts.Title: 61 yo husband newly diagnosed with high risk prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wish full Also, is high grade and high risk the same? Originally Posted by wish full What I'm really concerned about is the prostate covering the Apex and being high grade. I see this as a possible apex margin due to the amount and being high grade. Sorry we have to welcome you to our club. Mikla gave you good advice and you should take him up on his suggestions. To answer your specific questions: Yes, high Gleason scores mean higher risks. However, risks also depend on staging, i.e., how extensive the cancer is and whether it has spread to other organs. Since you have one score of 3+4, it is moderately aggressive. 3+4 means most of your cancer is grade 3, the least aggressive type, but there are some grade 4 which is more aggressive. Looking at your biopsy pathology report, your cancer is at exactly where the radiologist said it was - left mid and left base (near the bladder, not apex). So, you had a very good radiologist read your MRI. The other good news are the biopsy did not detect any spread and more important, the MRI report showed no evidence of spread. All in all, looks like an organ confined case and if you take action to seek treatment, you should be fine. Good luck.

Posts.Title: MDV3100 side effects

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FredS Post surgery report 11/30/12: Sections show extensive mixed pattern adenocarcinoma (Gleasons 4+4) present in all four quadrants of the prostate. The tumor is comprised primarily of acinar-type glands that exhibit a gleasons 4+3 pattern. Some areas of ductal adenocarcinoma (Gleasons's 4+4) are also identified. Adenocarcinoma is seen focally at the apex margin and focally on the right capsular margin. Tumor is fairly extensively present at the bladder neck margins. Seminal vesicles are negative. Lymphovascular invasion and perineural invasion is not identified. Any thoughts would be greatly appreciated. Marie & Fred, Sorry you have to be here but welcome. Let me try to interpret the pathology report from what I know: 1. The pathologist identified two types of prostate cancer cells: acinar adenocarcinoma and ductal adenocarcinoma. The first type is the most common, most of us have it. The second type is less common and it is in the ductal area of the prostate gland (he said "some areas", didn't say extensive which is good). Ductals are more aggressive. 2. There are three positive margins identified, at the apex and on the right capsule edge and near the bladder neck. The good news is those are adenocarcinoma, the less aggressive type. So, if there is escape due to the positive margins, it is the less aggressive type. 3. The other good news is no seminal vesicles and lymph node involvement and no perineural invasion. I interpret the no lymph node invasion identified as your surgeon did take the lymph nodes out. The no perineural invasion is good as cancers usually follow the nerves to escape the prostate capsule. Because of the ductal adenocarcinoma, if I were you, I would do adjuvant radiation and hormone therapy early, even if the post op PSA is undetectable, to nip the positive margins before they expand somewhere else. I would not wait and will consult a radiation oncologist and fine the best oncologist I can find who specializes in treating prostate cancer to discuss adjuvant hormonal treatment. I was at a cancer support meeting and listened to a prominent oncologist discussed treatment options. She said "Hormonal treatment is often an art, sometimes the oncologist can try different combinations, start and stop and can keep a patient's cancer under control for many many years, but you need to start early." Best of luck to you two.

Posts.Title: Legs pain after 2 1/2 weeks surgery

Posts.Content: The good news is your guy has no incontinence. Incontinence is hard to live with but there are many ways to treat ED, first of all, he should consult an ED doctor to get all the latest on rehab and to guide him. By the way, in Dr. Walsh's book he said it might take up to two years for ED to fully recover so your guy needs more time. I am one of the fortunate ones without ED and I am not a healthcare professional so really I should not be giving advices. But, I did some research prior to surgery just in case I had to deal with it: Usually our surgeon starts us on low dose Cialis right after surgery for a few months, he/she also can prescribe full strength Viagra, etc. He/she may also tell us to try the pump and finally to try injections like Trimix. My doctor told me injection should work every time with the right dose which your guy has to experiment with (make sure he gets advices and guidance from his ED doctor) and once the correct dose is used, he should be better than his old self. Good luck to both of you.

Posts.Title: Longterm Girlfriend seeks advice

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Marve PDV: Already next day out hospital? Here they hold hospital 10 days! So they told. Or maybe you surgery is different than here? I dont know how they make this? Cut stomach or somehow different? I dont know. HighlanderCFH: Is it possible that my father G is really different than 3+3=6? Beacause the biopsy result was that one core has some perineural invasion. And after that sentence was G 3+3=6. Maybe really its more than 3+3=6? Or how there can be perineural invasion? And actually this word was a little bit different...it wasnt invasion, but "the infiltration". But its so good I find this place. I already can eat and I dont worry so much anymore, because I know that everything goes well Marve, You father had what we call open surgery (the urologist/surgeon cut open the abdomen by hand to take out the prostate without any laparoscopic or robot assist), if so, the hospital stay is longer. In the US, those that choose the open approach stays in the hospital about 3-5 days. Many in the US now choose robot assist surgery where they cut several small 1 cm holes and insert robotic surgical instruments inside the abdomen to take out the prostate. Since the incisions are small, the recovery is quick, we tended to stay between 1 to 2 days in the hospital. Your father's cancer is likely early stage so the chance of cure is very high. The perineural invasion (or infiltration, same meaning) is common (many of us including me had it too), it just means the they found the cancer in the nerve channels within the prostate. Good luck to his recovery and let's hope for a complete cure.

Posts.Title: First time here

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Friendly A couple years ago I had several bad days with Vertigo. I mentioned to the doctor that the Vertigo never seemed to go away and recently he did a MRI of my inner ears and found nothing. Did or does anyone ever experience an unsteadiness with Prostate Cancer as a symptom? A month ago they found my blood count is double digits. I had a Bone Scan and Kat Scan after a needle biopsy. They found 70 percent of the needle biopsy had cancer. My unsteadiness seems to be getting worse, could the cancer be attacking something that has made me this way? THANK YOU.[/SIZE][/B][/SIZE] Friendly, Welcome to this site. You should thank your wife for insisting you take a blood PSA test and let's hope you catch yours in time for a "cure" or as some other posters would prefer to say "full remission". Let me quote from Wikipedia: Vertigo is caused by problems with the inner ear or vestibular system. A number of conditions that involve the central nervous system may lead to vertigo including: lesions caused by infarctions or hemorrhage, tumors present in the cerebellopontine angle. So unless your prostate cancer metastasizes to your brain, your vertigo is most likely caused by something else. By the way vertigo is quite common and many of my otherwise healthy friends have this problem. You need to find out: 1. Your doctor should tell you what is your PSA number. He was irresponsible if he just told you it was double digit. 2. Your doctor needed to give you the full biopsy report and explained/summarized the results for you and your wife. If I were you, I next time you see your doctor, you should have your wife with you to take note. 3. The most important information from the biopsy report are: The type of prostate cancer, perhaps adencarcinoma or something else, # of core positive and % of positive, Gleason scores of each positive core, any other information like perineural invasions, prostate size, etc. would also be helpful. The treatment options and assessment of how serious your situation is depends on the biopsy outcome as described above. Fortunately, even with serious cases there are a lot of options and treatments to keep you around for a long long time. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Legs pain after 2 1/2 weeks surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by FredS I've been wondering if I should have more tests since the pathology exam after surgery indicates ductal adenocarcinaoma. I'm reading online articles that appear to say that ductal cancer is worse than other cancers. Thanks for any help. Fred First of all, congratulations for an undetectable first post op PSA reading. Hopefully, your surgeon was able to remove all of the prostate cancers from your body. Second, I don't think you should worry too much at this stage. From the medical journal articles I read, the overall survivals of ductal prostate cancer were no different from the "garden variety". The pathology community does as a matter of policy, assign a Gleason grade 4 to ductal cancer and as a g4 it is no different in aggressiveness than the garden variety adenocarcinoma grade 4. Third, if it spreads, whatever treatments that work for adenocarcinoma also work for ductal. I do want to mention that since it is quite rare, there are conflicting articles, some said ductal are more aggressive, others actually said they found longer survival. However, a number of articles did say that if they metastasized, they sometimes went to organs like lung and liver instead of bones. So, monitor your situation carefully and hope for the best. Good luck and welcome to the zero club and hope you stay there a long time. Please note that I am just a layperson and my opinions are not from any formal healthcare trainings.

Posts.Title: First time here

Posts.Content: Samie, Sorry you have to be here but welcome. I have a few thoughts: It is a good idea to get a second opinion from another urologist. Perhaps the new urologist will ask for an MRI to see if indeed the cancer is extensive. 1 core out of 8 positive does not explain the 39 PSA #. Maybe his cancer is extensive and aggressive or maybe not. It is possible that his high PSA # could be due to a combination of cancer and infection. Did his urologist prescribe a course of antibiotics to see if that brings down the PSA. Since cancer is already diagnosed, it is done to see how extensive is the cancer, perhaps, just perhaps it is not as extensive as the PSA # indicated. In that case the treatment protocol may be different. In any case, if he is more comfortable with the non surgery approaches (some forms of radiations), the cure rate is about equal to surgery so he should proceed without worry. Another point we all like to make is this is not a death sentence by any means. Even if the cancer is aggressive, there are lots of options for him to keep him around for a long time, so, do not interrupt your plan for a wonderful retirement.

If you are like most of the posters, you will recover well, life goes back to normal and this will fade into the back of your memory like a bad dream. Most likely we will never hear from you again after a few months. Regards,

Posts.Content: Otego and the others are right. Retest before commit to a biopsy. The normal procedure in the US is to take a course of antibiotic and then retest. Depends on what the new # is and depends on the DRE (digital rectal examine) finding, then do/don't do the biopsy.
Posts.Title: Hi Advice please

Posts.Content: Please don't worry unnecessarily, let's hope the biopsy is negative and the high PSA was due to infection. Good luck.
Posts.Title: me again

Posts.Content: It is a good pathology report. Lymph nodes are clear, seminal vesicles are clear and cancer does not seem too extensive. The upgrade to G7 is quite typical and PNI is also typical (most of us had PNI). The only thing I did not see is there was no mentioned of surgical margins: Usually the pathologist would ink the prostate to see if there were cancer cells on the surface of the specimen. If so, likely some cancer cells were left behind and he would call it "positive margin". It is puzzling the surgeon wanted to do radiation right away. The clue maybe in the pathology report regarding margins, so, go reread the report to see if it says so. In any case even if radiation is necessary he should wait until it is all healed and side effects subside. As for how long to wait for a PSA, it ranges from 5-6 weeks to 3 months after surgery. If all the cancers are out of him, 5-6 week is sufficient to show undetectable PSA reading. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Why radiation after surgery???

Posts.Content: Chief, Looks like you are recovering well, especially in the ED department! As I said before, for most, the JP drain stayed for only a couple of days and they usually took it out before we left the hospital. But no two of us are the same and it is better they err on the safe side and keep it in a little longer. As for bowel movement, did your doctor tell you to take a stool softener and prune juice to make sure you have "smooth" bowel movements so as not to strain your bladder and catheter? If not you should take them and make sure your stools are soft. As for the catheter, it is actually very simple to take it out, just drain the fluid and it will slide out easily. The other side (inside the bladder) of the catheter has a fluid fill (water) balloon that sits inside the bladder neck and prevent it from slipping out. Once you let out the fluid, it should slide out easily. However, it is advisable to let the nurse/doctor do it in their office so as to make sure there is no stricture or other complications. Usually they want you to empty your bladder (check stricture) and also check for incontinence before letting you go. And, for most of us the catheter stayed in for about a week as it usually took only a few days for the stitches connecting the urethra and bladder to heal. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Day 5 after Surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by dshinnick Not quite sure why the G number would be relevant, if it was all organ-confined, and the whole thing came out, and margins were clear. If it was, say, G9, but it all came out, why would it matter? Is it just the concern that maybe a little bit escaped that we don't know about? A couple of comments: grade 4 is relevant because the higher the grade the higher the chance of microscopic escape (micro-metastasis), even with a clean pathology report. As far as pathology report, looks like it is all clean. The part about lymphatic vessel (not lymph nodes, just the ducts that carry the lymphatic fluids) is good, said they were free of cancer. He identified some fatty tissues that looked like a lymph node and it was also clean. Frankly I don't think your surgeon took out any lymph nodes and that was why the statement: cannot be assessed. Usually in a surgery, the surgeon will take out/clean some surrounding fatty tissues and the pathologist will read them. Did you have a JP drain? Usually with lymph nodes dissection, the surgeon had to install the JP drain to drain off excessive fluids. If not he most likely did not remove any nodes. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: So im ready for the surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by BeeMan PSA Tests: 09/10/2012 6.44 06/11/2012 5.70 02/17/2012 6.71 06/27/2011 6.18 01/21/2011 4.62 04/26/2010 3.88 04/20/2010 4.80 06/01/2009 3.20 09/30/2008 2.40 06/13/2008 2.40 05/01/2007 2.90 04/03/2006 2.50 05/03/2004 2.20 04/01/2003 2.10 04/11/2002 2.80, % Free PSA: 17.8 04/02/2002 5.30 Regular PSA BeeMan, If I used all the PSA # starting from 4/11/2002, your PSA doubling time was calculated to be 13 years! However, that is probably not relavent as the early years' PSA were very stable so they should not be used. Starting 9/30/2008 @ a PSA of 2.4, PSA started to creep up, so I re-do the calculation starting from that PSA #, and the answer is: PSA doubling of ~3 years. AS can be a good option if you would like to consider AS. Hope that helps.
Posts.Title: Active Surveillance vs. begin treatment?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by BeeMan Any advice about active surveillance vs. beginning a treatment plan for VERY EARLY stage prostate cancer? Age 65 when diagnosed (now 66). Gleason 6 (3 & 3) Last PSA: 6.44 last done on 9/10/2012 (every 3 months) PCA3 Neg (14.5) Biopsy: 1 (7%) core positive out of 12 Considering IMRT if treatment needed. BeeMan I agree with lancepeace, it is a very personal decision only you can make. However, your cancer appeared to be very early stage, so AS is a good option to consider for someone who is 66 years old. One piece of information missing from your posts is your PSA doubling time. You have been monitoring your PSA for sometime, if your PSA increase is slow, AS is an excellent choice, if it is fast, treatment is probably needed soon. For example, if the doubling time is 3-4 years, in 15-20 years, your PSA will be about 170. On the other hand, if PSA doubles every year, within 5 years your PSA will reach 170 meaning sooner or later you have to treat, in that case, the earlier you treat it the better the outcome. From your prostate volume, normal PSA should be around 3, so, it is possible your cancer is more extensive than indicated (read my signature, I had G6, 1 core positive 5%, after surgery, pathology indicated extensive cancer and some Grade 4 cancer inside). Read Dr. Walsh's book on treatment options, he discussed all the pros and cons. However, be aware he is biased toward treatment. He did say for folks older than 65 and slow growing cancer, AS is a good option. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance vs. begin treatment?

Posts.Content: What you read is most likely the summary biopsy pathology report and not the detail report the pathologist wrote. You could ask your doctor for the full report. In any case, if you have ASAP, very likely there is cancer there. I read some studies that said the majority of ASAP cases ended up positive. I had ASAP in my third biopsy in 2009 and urologist wanted a repeat in three months. I opted to wait a year figuring that if there was cancer the chance of catching it would be higher if I waited and let it grow a little more (engineer's logic). Sure enough, cancer was found a year later: One core positive. Post op pathology indicated cancer very extensive but multifocal. The good news is most likely even if there is cancer you are catching it at a very early stage and a cure is very possible. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Title: Simple Biopsy Report

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by scratch The PSA screening is applied to all men over a certain age, and a good screening test should be sensitive so as to not miss many cancers and have enough specificity so minimize the amount of invasive testing. PSA does not do that very well but so far it is the best we have. Totally agree. There are some newer imaging techniques that may provide better diagnostics but only time will tell if they will be adopted. I think the good doctor Ablin said it correctly, PSA is a measure of risk. A low PSA (say 1) only means the risk of cancer maybe low and a high PSA (say 1000) only means the risk of cancer maybe higher. A good urologist will go through the process of elimination to arrive at an answer. If positive, then comes a process of assessing the risks of aggressiveness then and only then comes the decision of treatment and most of the time it is the individual (in the US anyway) who must decide. In the US, the number of prostate cancer death kept going down; in 1975 there were 31 death per 100,000 and in 2010 it went down to 21.8 death per 100,000 ~ 30% drop. If the death rate remained the same, there would have been 10,000 more men died of prostate cancer in 2010. Is it worth it? I frankly don't know if spending $3B to save 10,000 lives is a good deal.

Posts.Title: Interesting article/interview on the history of the PSA test

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rooster0330 I know everyone is different but is there an average time that bladder control is usually regained after a prostate removed with traditional surgery not robotic (I understands robotic is shorter?)? The answer is it depends, depends on the individual, on his age, etc., it depends very much on the skill of the surgeon. The results quoted by Dr. Walsh (open surgery) of his own patients: "79% are wearing no pads at 3 months, 88% at 6 months and 98% at 12 months". I don't think all surgeons can achieve those results but in my prostate cancer support group, very few has continence problem after one year. I was told robotic does not improve continence rate or continence recovery time.
Posts.Title: Average time to gain bladder control

Posts.Content: Quite a life story and sorry about the latest development. It is impressive that you have been battling prostate cancer for 13 years and are still going strong. In spite of the spread, you should still have ways to control your cancer with some of the newer drugs and hope you won't need the "chronic illness kit" for a while yet. Like your positive fighting spirit! Good luck.
Posts.Title: It's all you can do

Posts.Content: With surgery, any post op psa that is non zero is a concern. Radiation is different. Often one would not achieve a zero psa but gets a very low number like your 0.1 psa. So, in your case, I would not worry as .2 is still a low number by the definition of an effective radiation treatment. For peace of mind, you may want to consult your radiation oncologist and get his opinion. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Simple Biopsy Report

Posts.Content: Yes, from first principle concept to a drug is a long long road. I have to constantly remind myself that the first principle of modern medicine is: DO NO HARM. On a side note, Provenge and the upcoming PROSTVAC are both based on similar principles. Good luck to you.
Posts.Title: Another breakthrough?

Posts.Content: Sorry your PSA starts to go up after hormone holiday. I think in your case the absolute PSA value is more significant than the relative rise. Most likely your oncologist will have to put you back on hormone. You have one thing going for you and that is you PSA nadir was undetectable. I read that it was the most significant factor for long term survival and for progression to hormone refractory cancer. There were a number of studies confirmed that this number was the best predictor of long term outcome. Best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: Rising PSA after hormone therapy "holiday"

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JustSlappy While there is much attention, understandably, to sexual function after surgery (and radiation), I don't read or hear much about dry orgasms. Satisfying? Frustrating? Very different? thanks As Fairwind said, for some, it is not dry because ejaculate has urine. However, in many cases there were some fluids accompanying the orgasms that came from the Cowper's gland which was not removed. Since the Vas Deferens was cut, there are no sperms coming out and that is why you won't be able to have kids after prostatectomy. Orgasms? As good and not messy.
Posts.Title: Dry Orgasms

Posts.Content: cy7, Welcome. I am very sorry you have to endure all the treatments and I hope you continue to seek conventional treatment in addition to taking diet supplements. The recently approved new medications in addition to alternative therapy may keep your cancer at bay. I am impressed you are not letting your cancer prevent you from living a full and productive life. You are an inspiration to us. Best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: viperfred, Thank you for sharing your experience here. We need more sharing of experiences, good or bad so new members can benefit from our journeys. I am very happy for you that your treatment is very successful and I agree today's radiation treatment is "not your father's radiation treatment". RW744, Reading your biopsy and diagnostic reports again, I see your cancer seemed to be pushing the edge (capsule), I would consult your doctor to see if that could be a risk factor for Cyberknife. A very precise beam is both good and bad. If the cancer is pushing the edge, there may be potential misses or damaging adjacent tissues (if the doctor is too aggressive with the beam coverage). Again, just a layperson's opinion which may or may not be correct.
Posts.Title: CyberKnife or robotic radical prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Instead of trying to remember or write down what your urologist tells you, ask for a copy of your biopsy pathology report and study it carefully to understand what you have. This way you can have an intelligent conversation with the urologist and the second opinion doctor. If you do not understand some of the terms and are willing to post it here, members here are happy to explain them to you. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Sorry to be the newest member of the club

Posts.Content: edmcc, Welcome. You are only one month post surgery so things have not settled down yet. Give yourself a few more months and incontinence should be gone. Usually recovery from ED takes longer. There were studies that indicated taking 5mg Cialis and pump helped with ED rehab so you should follow your doctor's instructions. Even though there were indications that cancer cells might have escaped the capsule, lets hope your surgeon had taken them all out by taking adjacent tissues out (that was how the pathologist noted microscopic cancer cells in surrounding tissues) . So strictly speaking you might not have positive margins and should have undetectable PSA when the next test comes around. Good luck.
Posts.Title: New to site one month post surgery

Posts.Content: Fortunately the one good news trumped everything: undetectable PSA! Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Back to work..back in the hospital

Posts.Content: I had surgery so do not have experience with Cyberknife. I believe it was FDA approved around 2001, about the same time robotic prostatectomy got popular so there are really not enough very long term study on either. Based on what I read, it should be as good as any other forms of modern radiation treatment. To shorten treatment time and because it is a very precise beam, the radiation is quite intense. As a result if a mistake is made (misalignment for example), the side effect can be severe. So, make sure your Cyberknife team is very experience. Good luck and happy new year.

Posts.Title: CyberKnife or robotic radical prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RTS My Urologist feels that I should not risk it, that at some point I will need treatment, and that I should not miss the "cure window". One of the reasons I sometimes appeared passionate and opinionated is because I know someone who missed the "cure window" after practicing AS for a year. Back in 2012, PSA ~5, biopsy showed two G6 <5%. Fast forward to 2013, PSA still ~5, but now 5 cores positive with 1 G7. Had surgery, one lymph node positive (<<1mm meaning beginning metastasized), bladder neck positive.... In your case, since you are so young, sooner or later you will need to take it out, might as well do it before cancer escapes. Yes, you don't know if it will and you may buy many years of QOL by doing AS and as other posters said another six months of delay decision won't matter, but you really don't know for sure. Good luck and sorry if I upset you.

Posts.Content: RTS, Using the last three PSA reading, your PSA doubling time is ~10 months. IF I use the last two values, doubling is about 7.5 months. So it is accelerating meaning there is cause for concern especially since recent MRI indicated cancer in both sides of your prostate now. However, before you decide to remove your prostate, you should get a second opinion and read up on the consequences, risks and side effects of prostatectomy, how to select a surgeon and investigate other treatment options like seeds or radiation. And if you plan on having kids later, bank your sperms. Good luck and best wishes

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance vs. begin treatment?

Posts.Content: Welcome. Based on your signature and introductions, you are a very good candidate for AS. However, if you choose that route, make sure to have a second read of your biopsy slides by another pathologist, e.g. send them to Johns Hopkins to make sure the G3+3 stays 3+3. One issue with AS is while on it, most likely your doctor won't prescribe TRT and your "energy level" will continue to remain low during this time. With treatment, after your PSA becomes undetectable, your doctor might restart TRT to improve your "energy level". If you choose treatment, with your stats, all the treatment options including surgery are good and what you choose is mostly your preference and your doctor's recommendation. Good luck.

Posts.Title: No easy answers for 51 year old

Posts.Content: In addition to the machine, the practitioners are also critical. In the hands of an inexperience group, mistakes can often happen and with radiation there is no do over and the damages will not be apparent until it is too late. So, if I were you I would go with a center where there are lot of patients and the radiation oncologists and radiation techs are well trained. You see, how they map the site, where to aim, dosage to where/which... all need to be determined by the radiation oncologist and each and every oncologist can interpret differently. Good luck.

Posts.Title: No easy answers for 51 year old

Posts.Content: Putt and Lance, I went on line to search for the REDEEM trial and found it on Pubmed: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22277570 The trial was to see if Deutasteride (Avodart) could help folks on AS get better outcome by taking Deutasteride. It is a double blind test with the endpoint of cancer progression. The outcome was that if you were on AS and took Deutasteride, you had a 38% chance of progression at 3 years and those that took placebo had a 48% chance of progression at 3 years. There were no mention of the aggressiveness of cancers detected at progression. A second clinical trial from Canada found only 18% progressed to treatment for the Deutasteride group vs 38% for the placebo group but again, they were silent on the aggressiveness of the cancer at time of progression: http://www.onclive.com/publications/...e-Surveillance I am happy that Deutasteride helped reduced the incidences of cancer progression for folks on AS but am disappointed both trials remained silent and did not report the aggressiveness of the cancer at progression. So, to me the issue of aggressive cancer incidences from the PCPT and REDUCE trials remains a question mark. Readers should draw their own conclusions on this issue.

Posts.Title: The REDEEM Clinical Trial

Posts.Content: The definition of T3a in prostate cancer means the pathology report found extracapsular extension, or cancer went outside of the capsule. This is not as serious as state IIIc in breast cancer. First order of business for you and your husband is to obtain a copy of his pathology report and get a better understanding of the outcome. But from what you stated from the surgeon's comment, it is actually very good: Only 15% of the gland is cancerous so it is quite an early stage. She said there were clear margins (I assumed she meant negative margins, meaning she cut outside of the capsule so she got all of the cancers out). As for perineural invasion, I had that too and did quite a bit of research to see if that should be a concern. I found a number of studies indicating it not to be a predictor of recurrence. All in all, a good outcome, so please focus on healing and just watch his psa periodically. By the way, my wife is also a breast cancer survivor. She was stage III with lymph nodes involvement. She is cancer free for 12 years now. Good luck and best wishes to both of you.

Posts.Title: Wife of Newly Diagnosed--what do I need to know about this info?

Posts.Content: A recently completed study showed some worrisome trends in prostate cancer: New cases of advanced prostate cancer in the United States have skyrocketed 72 percent in the past decade, a troubling new study shows. The biggest increase was among men aged 55 to 69, with a 92 percent jump seen over 10 years. This rise is worrisome because these men are the ones who may benefit most from screening and early treatment, the researchers said. You can read the summary here: http://health.usnews.com/health-care...soars-us-study The study compared results of 2013/14 to 2004. USPSTF recommended no PSA test in 2012 saying it did not save life and caused unnecessary treatment.

Posts.Content: A positive biopsy is a definitive diagnosis. A negative biopsy means either you do not have or they did not find it this time. The advice from biopsy veterans like Fairwind and I (4 times) are you just have to watch it from now on if your PSA keep increasing. What I learned from my 4 times is that preparation is very important to minimize infection. Often, we did not take the antibiotics precisely as prescribed or did not thoroughly clean out our bowel before the procedure. Now you know. By the way, we are very happy to reject your membership to our club. Take care.

Posts.Title: QUESTION ABOUT BIOPSY _Got 0 OF !2 NEG

Posts.Content: Dr. Albin made several comments in the interview. Let me summarize some of his comments that are of interest to me: 1. He was against mass PSA testing. He did admit that though PSA did not detect cancer it was a "measure of risk" of prostate cancer. 2. PSA was first approved by the FDA for detecting prostate cancer recurrence after treatment in 1986 but was rapidly used off label for prostate cancer detection. 3. FDA officially approved its use for mass detections in 1994 and the rest is history. He was pessimistic and very discouraged that his invention was "wrongly" used and that PSA should not be use for detection as he cited that of men between 60-69, 65% had prostate cancer but most were not aggressive. To me the statement that PSA is a "measure of risk" is a true representation of the value of the test. It must be and are always followed up with more definitive tests like biopsy, etc. No one in my recollection solely used PSA as a detection tool to treat prostate cancer. The other significant fact is that the majority of men over 60 probably has some prostate cancer in his body and the key is to determine who are likely to have the aggressive types and need to be treated. Otherwise over treatment is inevitable. This led to the USPSTF's position that no men should take PSA test unless there was evidence that it was needed. So, we are really on our own to determine whether we should be treated once we have tested positive for cancer, and it is especially true for the G6 types which many stated should not be treated and AS is appropriate not withstanding that many G6 turned out to be G7 and higher after final pathology report. I like to present some interesting statistics from the National Cancer Institute's SEEER data: 1. Let's compare prostate cancer 5 year relative survival: In 1975 it was 69.2% by 2001-2007 it was 99.4% that means in 1975 if you were diagnosed, the chance of dying within 5 years of detection was very high and in 2001-2007 it was very low. 2. In the 2001-2007 time frame, if you were detected when the cancer was localized, the 5 year survival was virtually 100% but if it was metastasized, even with modern treatment protocol, the 5 year survival was only 28.7%. As a matter of comparison, today, the overall 5 year relative survival of colorectal cancer was 64.7%, i.e., metastasized prostate cancer is much worst than colorectal cancer. 3. If I extrapolate the 2001-2007 data back to 1975, it means in 1975, before PSA, 40% of those detected in 1975 had metastasized cancer by the time cancer was detected. In 2001-2007 that number was 4%! 4. Comparing 1975 and today, the number detected per 100,000 remained about the same which means we are not really getting more detections, just that we are detecting them early giving many patients the opportunity to fully recover instead of too late and cancer metastasized. 5. What was more telling was also today, the worst survival age group was actually those under 45 years of age: 96.4% vs 99.5% for those over 65. I think that is because they represented the group least likely to be given PSA tests. Most doctors won't request PSA tests unless you are over 50. My opinion is that if we get rid of PSA testing without a better replacement, we are doing a great disservice to prostate cancer patients.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by va_catlover Can you explain to me briefly what the perinueral involvement means? Also, my husband's PSA was 11.1. Perineural Invasion means the cancer appeared to spread to the space surrounding the nerves. If they were found around nerves outside the capsule it is not good. If found only within the prostate, some believed it was easier for cancer cells to follow those nerves out of the capsule and invaded other sites. However, a number of studies indicated no correlation between PNI and recurrence.
Posts.Title: Wife of Newly Diagnosed--what do I need to know about this info?

Posts.Content: Gideon, Sorry to hear about your biopsy results but welcome to the brotherhood. I second what njs said as you have an aggressive case and selecting the right physician and right treatment plan are important to maximize your chance of success. Sloan is one of the top cancer centers in the east coast and you won't go wrong going there. However, there are brilliant individual practitioners around you who might be as good and you might feel more comfortable with them. So research and interview a few more before you decide. Perhaps you should also use njs' criteria and questions while you interview the physicians. Finally as Fran said, get Dr. Walsh's book, read and study it to gain as much knowledge as you can about your disease. It might be depressing to read but can help you formulate your plan of attack. Best of luck.

Posts.Content: Different lab has different sensitivity based on the machine they use. What you want to look for is the < sign. Usually a < sign before the number indicates the value is below the detectability of the machine and is effectively undetectable or zero. Many doctors do not believe in ultrasensitive test because it causes test anxiety and so only asks for PSA tests with sensitivity of 0.1. All my post op #s were <.1 which I considered zero.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by JustSlappy While there is much attention, understandably, to sexual function after surgery (and radiation), I don't read or hear much about dry orgasms. Satisfying? Frustrating? Very different? thanks As Fairwind said, for some, it is not dry because ejaculate has urine. However, in many cases there were some fluids accompanying the orgasms that came from the Cowper's gland which was not removed. Since the Vas Deferens was cut, there are no sperms coming out and that is why you won't be able to have kids after prostatectomy. Orgasms? As good and not messy.
