Posts.Content: Originally Posted by BeeMan Any advice about active surveillance vs. beginning a treatment plan for VERY EARLY stage prostate cancer? Age 65 when diagnosed (now 66). Gleason 6 (3 & 3) Last PSA: 6.44 last done on 9/10/2012 (every 3 months) PCA3 Neg (14.5) Biopsy: 1 (7%) core positive out of 12 Considering IMRT if treatment needed. BeeMan I agree with lancepeace, it is a very personal decision only you can make. However, your cancer appeared to be very early stage, so AS is a good option to consider for someone who is 66 years old. One piece of information missing from your posts is your PSA doubling time. You have been monitoring your PSA for sometime, if your PSA increase is slow, AS is an excellent choice, if it is fast, treatment is probably needed soon. For example, if the doubling time is 3-4 years, in 15-20 years, your PSA will be about 170. On the other hand, if PSA doubles every year, within 5 years your PSA will reach 170 meaning sooner or later you have to treat, in that case, the earlier you treat it the better the outcome. From your prostate volume, normal PSA should be around 3, so, it is possible your cancer is more extensive than indicated (read my signature, I had G6, 1 core positive 5%, after surgery, pathology indicated extensive cancer and some Grade 4 cancer inside). Read Dr. Walsh's book on treatment options, he discussed all the pros and cons. However, be aware he is biased toward treatment. He did say for folks older than 65 and slow growing cancer, AS is a good option. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by BeeMan PSA Tests: 09/10/2012 6.44 06/11/2012 5.70 02/17/2012 6.71 06/27/2011 6.18 01/21/2011 4.62 04/26/2010 3.88 04/20/2010 4.80 06/01/2009 3.20 09/30/2008 2.40 06/13/2008 2.40 05/01/2007 2.90 04/03/2006 2.50 05/03/2004 2.20 04/01/2003 2.10 04/11/2002 2.80, % Free PSA: 17.8 04/02/2002 5.30 Regular PSA BeeMan, If I used all the PSA # starting from 4/11/2002, your PSA doubling time was calculated to be 13 years! However, that is probably not relavent as the early years' PSA were very stable so they should not be used. Starting 9/30/2008 @ a PSA of 2.4, PSA started to creep up, so I re-do the calculation starting from that PSA #, and the answer is: PSA doubling of ~3 years. AS can be a good option if you would like to consider AS. Hope that helps.

As for supplements, you may want to give him pomegranate juice or a supplement consists of green tea, pomegranate, turmeric and broccoli which in a clinical trial (in UK?) seemed to slow the progression of prostate cancer but the improvement/slowing down was not dramatic.
Posts.Title: Diet changes / diet recommendations for advanced prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by scratch The PSA screening is applied to all men over a certain age, and a good screening test should be sensitive so as to not miss many cancers and have enough specificity so minimize the amount of invasive testing. PSA does not do that very well but so far it is the best we have. Totally agree. There are some newer imaging techniques that may provide better diagnostics but only time will tell if they will be adopted. I think the good doctor Ablin said it correctly, PSA is a measure of risk. A low PSA (say 1) only means the risk of cancer maybe low and a high PSA (say 1000) only means the risk of cancer maybe higher. A good urologist will go through the process of elimination to arrive at an answer. If positive, then comes a process of assessing the risks of aggressiveness then and only then comes the decision of treatment and most of the time it is the individual (in the US anyway) who must decide. In the US, the number of prostate cancer death kept going down; in 1975 there were 31 death per 100,000 and in 2010 it went down to 21.8 death per 100,000 ~ 30% drop. If the death rate remained the same, there would have been 10,000 more men died of prostate cancer in 2010. Is it worth it? I frankly don't know if spending $3B to save 10,000 lives is a good deal.

Posts.Content: I had surgery so do not have experience with Cyberknife. I believe it was FDA approved around 2001, about the same time robotic prostatectomy got popular so there are really not enough very long term study on either. Based on what I read, it should be as good as any other forms of modern radiation treatment. To shorten treatment time and because it is a very precise beam, the radiation is quite intense. As a result if a mistake is made (misalignment for example), the side effect can be severe. So, make sure your Cyberknife team is very experience. Good luck and happy new year.

Posts.Content: A large lymphocele could cause circulation or nerve problems to the lower extremities, e.g., blood circulation problem to the legs (if presses on the iliac vessels) or numbness (if presses on the nerves). But they should not affect your arms. So, could be something else. We are just speculating as laypersons, so, please consult your physician. Good luck.

Posts.Content: My understanding is stains only differentiate between cancer vs non cancer cells. So, positive vs negative margins. Whether it is grade 3, 4 or 5 depends on the cell structures under microscope. A differentiated reasonably well organized cells indicated lower grade. Corrections: I just realized after reading Fairwind's post that I did not answer your question correctly. I was referred to the stains pathologist used after your surgeon took out your prostate and not the biopsy stains. Sorry about the errors. Fairwind is correct as far as biopsy stains.
Posts.Title: When A Pathologist Orders Stains

Posts.Content: Your cellulitis and lymphocele infection are probably related. Could be you were off antibiotics too soon when you were been treated or could be they were not targeted with the correct antibiotics? How long were you put on antibiotics for your lymphocele? What bacteria infection did you have as i/d? Another factor is you could have a weaken immune system after surgery which put you at risk so you may want to ask your doctor to check your immune system. I was on multiple antibiotics and antifungal immediately while in the hospital and narrowed down to one after they positively i/d the bacteria and for a month after I left hospital. And the infectious disease doctor told me to be watchful of subsequent infection for a while longer. I am a layperson so it is just speculations on my part. Hope this is the final chapter of trouble for you and good luck.

Posts.Title: Cellulitis

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by glock19 I'm 9 days post op from RALP. 5 of the 6 openings are healing nicely. They used a lot of glue and strips. However, the top incision (think it's the one used for the CO2) keeps opening and leaking fluid. That was the one opening that didn't show any residual glue or tape. There is still quite a bit of swelling behind that point. I mentioned it at my post op visit and was told everything was healing nicely. It almost looks like a hernia has developed at that point. I say this because I had a hernia repaired w/ mesh about 15 years ago and that's very close to the bottom edge of the mesh. Just wondering if anyone else has experience this kind of leakage and what outcome did you have. Since he took out some lymph nodes, that "hole" that was not taped/glued could be where the JP drain came out of. If that is the case, some drainage at this stage could be quite normal. If you still worry, wait a few more days and if it does not stop, call your physician again to see if something can be done to speed up the healing. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Question on wound care & healing?

Posts.Content: Good luck and hope your new medications work well for you. I have read about trials combining Samarium with other treatments and got improved results, so I am happy to see your physician gave you the combinations. If this combinations work, I wonder if Alpharadin (assume it gets approved next year) in combination with other treatments might work even better? Alpharadin emits alpha particles, which is short range and should work better than Samarium which emits beta particles. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Xtandi, and Samarium 153

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo Interesting replies.. So, someone with a Gleason 6 (or a 3+4) should really check where the positive core(s) are located. If they are on the outer edge of the prostate, or at the Apex, that is something to consider before deciding on "active surveillance"..... And, if positive core is by the bladder neck, that could be a data point to be considered as part of the radiation-vs-surgery decision. (I hope I got this right) Would really be interesting for everyone to ask their urologist/radiologist about this... Remember, this is just one man's opinion and a non medical one, just your typical engineer's "logic". A real life case: No family history, slow rise in PSA to 4.5 last year. dx with 3 cores G6 <5% each core, all in the middle. Urologist said probable indolence and he chose AS. Fast forward a year, G6 -> one G3+4 and now 6 cores positive with two near the bladder. Surgery, found evidence of bladder neck invasion and was forced to cut deep there. Post Op: Bad incontinence, cancer extensive, positive margins at bladder neck and several places. One lymph node positive (1 mm), Gleason is now G4+3. Cancer is now metastasized. We will never know if his cancer was organ confined a year ago but we could speculate that surgery or radiation a year ago probably would produce better outcome. My own case was similar except I did not choose AS. Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: It is outright criminal for the hospitals to charge patients without insurance 10 to 100 times what they charge medicare. Drug companies also charge many times more for the same cancer drugs in the US as compare to Canada or UK for example. Patients without insurance and has to pay out of pocket are often time better off get treatments from other countries like Singapore, Taiwan or Korea where medical facilities are as good but cost 10 times less. When my HMO refused to allow me to select the surgeon I wanted, I was going to pay out of pocket until I found out that the hospital would charge me $100K for a Da Vinci. I fortunately could change my insurance to use the same hospital and same surgeon (who by the way would charge me the same without insurance as he would charge the insurance carriers) with a final bill of $15K. The system is rig against the little guys and our Government, our politicians allow it.
Posts.Title: Why Does It Cost So Much??

Posts.Content: Has to be a mistake. Logic says no way it can go up so much in 3 months with your statistics (G3+4). I would get a retest and go from there. I feel for you knowing your personality but don't worry yet. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: PSA Results - I'm in a Panic

Posts.Content: Welcome. Based on your signature and introductions, you are a very good candidate for AS. However, if you choose that route, make sure to have a second read of your biopsy slides by another pathologist, e.g. send them to Johns Hopkins to make sure the G3+3 stays 3+3. One issue with AS is while on it, most likely your doctor won't prescribe TRT and your "energy level" will continue to remain low during this time. With treatment, after your PSA becomes undetectable, your doctor might restart TRT to improve your "energy level". If you choose treatment, with your stats, all the treatment options including surgery are good and what you choose is mostly your preference and your doctor's recommendation. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Gideon, Sorry to hear about your biopsy results but welcome to the brotherhood. I second what njs said as you have an aggressive case and selecting the right physician and right treatment plan are important to maximize your chance of success. Sloan is one of the top cancer centers in the east coast and you won't go wrong going there. However, there are brilliant individual practitioners around you who might be as good and you might feel more comfortable with them. So research and interview a few more before you decide. Perhaps you should also use njs' criteria and questions while you interview the physicians. Finally as Fran said, get Dr. Walsh's book, read and study it to gain as much knowledge as you can about your disease. It might be depressing to read but can help you formulate your plan of attack. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: New Member of the group

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by n2hawgs Within the past couple days, I found out I have prostate cancer and all my details. Most biopsies are fully involved with high Gleason. Scans were negative but it is an aggressive cancer. I am just looking for others experiences and information. I have read many posts and found them very helpful. Thanks for help! n2hawgs n2hawgs, Sorry you are here but welcome to the club no one wants to join. Normally, we advice folks to take their time to understand what is going on and then carefully choose their treatment path from a large number of options. Here, because of the aggressive nature of your biopsy results, I would advise you to move quickly while that is still a chance of a cure - before the cancer escapes the prostate. Speaking as a layperson, I waited 8 weeks from biopsy to surgery but if I had your biopsy results, I would not have waited and would choose radiation plus hormone as my first line of treatment right away. However, that is just me and not a professional opinion, so please consult your physicians. You are very fortunate to have your cancer detected now instead of later when symptoms appear, so your cancer may still be organ confined. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Diet changes / diet recommendations for advanced prostate cancer

Posts.Content: It is counter intuitive but having a positive margin is actually good news in your case because it means some cancer cells were left behind at the apex and that could explain the recurrence. It means you actually have a better chance that cancer is not systemic and SRT could be very successful in arresting the cancer. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: What is my psa doubling time ? Please help !

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo Interesting replies.. So, someone with a Gleason 6 (or a 3+4) should really check where the positive core(s) are located. If they are on the outer edge of the prostate, or at the Apex, that is something to consider before deciding on "active surveillance"..... And, if positive core is by the bladder neck, that could be a data point to be considered as part of the radiation-vs-surgery decision. (I hope I got this right) Would really be interesting for everyone to ask their urologist/radiologist about this... Remember, this is just one man's opinion and a non medical one, just your typical engineer's "logic". A real life case: No family history, slow rise in PSA to 4.5 last year. dx with 3 cores G6 <5% each core, all in the middle. Urologist said probable indolence and he chose AS. Fast forward a year, G6 -> one G3+4 and now 6 cores positive with two near the bladder. Surgery, found evidence of bladder neck invasion and was forced to cut deep there. Post Op: Bad incontinence, cancer extensive, positive margins at bladder neck and several places. One lymph node positive (1 mm), Gleason is now G4+3. Cancer is now metastasized. We will never know if his cancer was organ confined a year ago but we could speculate that surgery or radiation a year ago probably would produce better outcome. My own case was similar except I did not choose AS. Good luck to you.

Posts.Content: I agree with you that location of the cancer factors into treatment decision. For example, if the cancer is too closed to the bladder neck, it has an impact on incontinence and positive surgical margins there. In that case, perhaps radiation is a better choice. Good luck to your on your Thursday surgery.
Posts.Title: Location of Positive Cores

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by azsunshine The vast majority of people that are doing great are living their lives are not posting on forums and groups. There are some of us that have made helping others a passion and we are also out there posting or even starting support groups for others. So, please try (I know it's hard) to keep a positive outlook. I know you are scared but post treatment life may not be as bad as you read about in forums and on websites. We have found that to be true. Does life take a different road? Yep, and the road can and will be bumpy. But not as bad as I or he expected. Well said azsunshine. Most folks with my stats move on and live their normal life. This forum helped me tremendously when I was struggling to make sense of this disease. I was especially grateful and impressed with all the supportive posters here. So, I decided to stay around to lend my support, to provide hopes to newcomers that many of us can lead a normal life after surgery. Cheers.

Posts.Title: A note about forums for newbies....

Posts.Content: Welcome but I am sorry you are joining our club. A Gleason (3+4) is very different from a Gleason (4+3). The Gleason score is a combination of two Gleason grades, first one identifies the predominant cancer type and the second the next most common type. Gleason grades run from 1 to 5, 5 being the most aggressive. If your physician said the more aggressive end he might mean a G(4+3). You did not say what your PSA was. If you have very high PSA, say >20, hormones, radiation & seeds is probably a better choice as high PSA indicates a higher probability of cancer growing outside the prostate and radiation will catch them if they are still in the prostate bed, otherwise either of them are good options. In these day and age, it is what you are comfortable with more than which one is better. I selected surgery because I was physically fit with no other health issues and was more comfortable with "getting them out" than "zapping them inside". And by the way, either way you choose, the most important thing is to find a physician that has done at least >250 surgery (or seeds) as skills/experiences trump everything. You should read the book by Dr. Patrick Walsh on "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" and then you will be able to make an informed decision. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Help! Which Treatment - 1) Robotic Surgery, or 2) Hormones, Radiation & Seeds?

Posts.Content: A couple of comments: 1. Fairwind made an excellent point, in a standard radiation treatment, PSA does not go to undetectable immediately so your .02 PSA is most likely caused by the hormone. However, if hormone is what caused the PSA to be undetectable, then from what I read and from many of the posts here, PSA should stay low for some time and not rising immediately after it stops. Maybe you stopped too soon? 2. Most of the literatures I read about adjuvant hormone in radiation treatment started with hormone prior to radiation and usually continued for 6, 12 to 18 months after radiation. To stop right after radiation seemed unusual? 3. If you did not have adjuvant hormone therapy, PSA usually drops slowly and won't reach nadir for sometime, perhaps 12 to 24 months. So, my recommendation is to seek another opinion or perhaps get back to hormone. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: bigbrad2008, Appreciate your comments. Actually, I found 7 Phase III randomized controlled trials addressing the role of adjuvant ADT with radiation for high risk patients. All showed survival benefits for ADT. In addition, some addressed durations of ADT ranged from 4 months to three years. Better survivals were recorded for longer duration ADT. Up until recently, the standard for ADT duration seemed to be 36 months but in a more recent Canadian Phase III trial, the outcome indicated the 36 months could be reduced to 18 months without any increase in mortality. If you are not in the high risk category, then perhaps the duration can be shorter. I am not a doctor, just reporting from what I read. Please consult your oncologist for better clarity. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Diet changes / diet recommendations for advanced prostate cancer

Posts.Content: bigbrad2008, Sorry I missed the part that you had external radiation and HDBT together with hormone. But, intuitively, I don't see how having combined external radiation and HDRT would change the conclusion of the length of ADT treatment and from a risk/reward point of view, a few more months' ADT may not be that bad? However, you know your body and did more researches than I so you know better. Another point, the increases in PSA after you stopped ADT could be a normal timeline of radiation treatment as most reports said you won't reach nadir for up to 12-24 months. One other suggestion: No harm (except maybe to your pocket book) changing and adding some supplements to your diets. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: rising psa post tri-modal treatment.

Posts.Content: Jim is a straight shooter and is usually blunt but gave very good advice. Here are some comments from me: Your prostate is large but not huge and the PSA # is consistent with a 68 cc prostate but with suspicious MRI and DRE a biopsy is a reasonable next step. Taking Cardura and Avodart since mid-July, currently with good success. Flow is better than its been in many years. That is great but you may want to discuss with your urologist this FDA warning label on a class of drugs call 5-ARI which Avodart belongs. I know many urologist disagree with the FDA and I really don't know who is right but it is better safe than sorry. http://www.fda.gov/Safety/MedWatch/S.../ucm258529.htm Unfortunately, the machine was a Siemens 1.5T (and not a 3T) but (thankfully) no ERC was used. You should have asked for the ERC. Though unpleasant it increases the resolutions quite a bit and is almost as good as having the 3T without ERC. The radiologist said findings were compatible with BPH and a PI-RAD score of 2 for the transition zone. However, there was a small focal abnormal signal intensity in the left lateral peripheral zone measuring 1.0x0.6cm, compatible with a PI-RAD 3 lesion. The lesion was mapped for a potential fusion biopsy. (The radiologist notes that this suspicious area is only seen on a single image and no discrete lesion is visible on post-contrast images.) Like Jim if it were me I would go ahead and do a biopsy. But it is a non professional opinion. Good luck and best to you.

Posts.Title: Biopsy based on a Pi-Rad3 finding on a 1.5T MRI

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by northrancher I have a few numbers that I hope will be useful in getting input from the group: PSA: 9 Biopsy: positive; two nodules, one on each side Gleason: 7 (3+4) Grade: T2C Number of positive cores: 11 out of 12 Thanks in advance for your help. You should try to get the full biopsy report and read it. There should be more information on the report. For example, the size of his prostate, the detail of the 11 positive cores (e.g., % cancer, Gx+y for each core), whether there are indications of seminal vesicle involvement, whether there are EPE (extraprostatic extension) etc. It maybe counter intuitive but a large number of positive cores in this case is good news as it is consistent with a PSA of 9 and so hopefully cancer is organ confined. If you look at my case, I had a PSA of 10.7 but only 1 core <5% positive. I worried my cancer was systemic but fortunately post op they found lots of cancer all over but within the prostate which explained the PSA of 10.7. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Husband Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: bigbrad2008, Appreciate your comments. Actually, I found 7 Phase III randomized controlled trials addressing the role of adjuvant ADT with radiation for high risk patients. All showed survival benefits for ADT. In addition, some addressed durations of ADT ranged from 4 months to three years. Better survivals were recorded for longer duration ADT. Up until recently, the standard for ADT duration seemed to be 36 months but in a more recent Canadian Phase III trial, the outcome indicated the 36 months could be reduced to 18 months without any increase in mortality. If you are not in the high risk category, then perhaps the duration can be shorter. I am not a doctor, just reporting from what I read. Please consult your oncologist for better clarity. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: very nervous

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walt_Green Testosterone is fuel for METASTIC PCa ONLY!!!!. it has no relation to low-volume, low-risk PCa. what the poster above me sights is old, statistically-flawed conclusion!! Walt, not trying to argue with you but I can find many many articles that demonstrated testosterone is the main source to provide growth for prostate cancer. Dr. Charles Higgins won the 1966 Nobel Prize for demonstrating that depriving prostate cancer cells of hormone (testosterone) will stop the cancer growth. In fact castration (either surgically or chemically) will stop the growth and kill off non CRPC, whether they are G6 or G10. So, unless I am absolutely sure I am free of prostate cancer, I would be very cautious about using TRT.
Posts.Title: Prostate cancer and sex drive

Posts.Content: sundrop15, Sorry to say, the combination of a PSA of 153 and a hard prostate means very likely he has cancer. However, it sometimes could be infection or inflammation so the doctor could give him a course of antibiotics to see if PSA will drop. I remember one of the posters here had a PSA of ~100 which turned out to be infection and not cancer. However, if it persists, a biopsy is usually the next step. Let's hope it is not cancer and he need not join our club. Good luck to him.

Posts.Title: PSA 150 and a smooth, hard prostate

Posts.Content: It is outright criminal for the hospitals to charge patients without insurance 10 to 100 times what they charge medicare. Drug companies also charge many times more for the same cancer drugs in the US as compare to Canada or UK for example. Patients without insurance and has to pay out of pocket are often time better off get treatments from other countries like Singapore, Taiwan or Korea where medical facilities are as good but cost 10 times less. When my HMO refused to allow me to select the surgeon I wanted, I was going to pay out of pocket until I found out that the hospital would charge me $100K for a Da Vinci. I fortunately could change my insurance to use the same hospital and same surgeon (who by the way would charge me the same without insurance as he would charge the insurance carriers) with a final bill of $15K. The system is rig against the little guys and our Government, our politicians allow it.

Posts.Title: Women's Help?

Posts.Content: HiSunshineMI, You had a 6-core biopsy and had 3 out of 6 positive for cancer with 5%, 25% and 35% of the cores contained cancer cells. Your cancer is the "garden variety" adenocarcinoma, G(3+4) which is less aggressive than a G(4+3). With your PSA of 5.3, your cancer is most likely confined within the prostate and you have an excellent chance of cancer free after treatment, whether you choose surgery or radiation. With your #, you do have to seek treatment and cannot practice Active Surveillance. I know what I would do if I were you but you are the one that have to decide for yourself. Welcome to the twilight zone of prostate cancer treatment. Peace be with you and have yourself a good holiday.
Posts.Title: Help! Which Treatment - 1) Robotic Surgery, or 2) Hormones, Radiation & Seeds?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by myrtha Please, could U tell me about treatments and painkilling in that stage? He said the carcinoma went through his bowel and it is painfull! What about killing metasthases?? please help!!! When you said bowel are you referring to the rectum? The prostate is very close to the rectum wall, so it is one of the common metastasis sites. If your partner truly has metastatic prostate cancer and is having pain, he needs to get hormone treatment immediately if he has not already done so. Hormone will shrink the cancer and relieve pain, especially bone pain. For many, the pain went away after hormone treatment. Of course hormone treatment is not a cure as the cancer will eventually come back but for many it takes years or even decades before that happens. If he has not done so, he should consult a prostate cancer oncologist. Best of luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by thinders1951 Chuck - Can't find the post surgery pathology .....I guess I should frame it. As for" For example, what was the final staging, how were the lymph nodes, seminal vesicles, extraprostatic tissue, etc? Was there any perineural invasion, etc?" My memory (and my wife who is a retired nurse) is "no invasion" and the "margin" was 2 mm ..... One other correction: The T2a vs T2c From your first post, it looked like you went through surgery and salvage radiation and still your PSA is not undetectable. What you need now is an expert prostate cancer oncologist to help guide your treatment plan. If you have not already done so, you should ask your urologist and radiation oncologist to recommend someone to you. At this stage, whether it was T2a or T2c whether you had positive margin, PNI etc. do not matter but the G7 does. It indicated your cancer is moderately aggressive instead of super aggressive and controlling it is quite possible. One more thing, from what you wrote, your PSA doubling time of about 1 year after salvage radiation indeed indicated a moderately aggressive cancer so there is hope. As for treatment options, there are many starting with the standard hormone treatment and go from there. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Carol, Let me give you a rather lengthy response as this is a hotly discussed topic here. This topic was discussed in a few threads recently and there were two schools of thoughts. One cited studies that indicated AS for low risk cases did not result in higher mortality. Both Johns Hopkins and UC San Francisco conducted clinical trials on this. The other point of view were from some of us who believed we were individuals and not statistics; and how could we make sure we were not at the 3-sigma (outliers) statistical distribution and how could we be sure since the diagnostics were not 100% definitive or correct. So, we would rather have treatments early. Of course the problem is treatments have their own risks and side effects so often you are trading peace of mind for side effects. I am still in the early treatment camp. Please note that I am a layperson and I do not have direct statistical studies to back me up. General survival statistics (from SEER) that I studied seemed to favor early treatment but they were not clinical trial results so it was not clear what were the underlaying causes. There were a few posters here discussing and practicing AS and seemed to be doing fine. In that regard, your love one's stats indicated AS is a good option irregardless of his age. You and him should study the options carefully, seek out advices from physicians from both camps and make your own decision. Best of luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by northrancher I have a few numbers that I hope will be useful in getting input from the group: PSA: 9 Biopsy: positive; two nodules, one on each side Gleason: 7 (3+4) Grade: T2C Number of positive cores: 11 out of 12 Thanks in advance for your help. You should try to get the full biopsy report and read it. There should be more information on the report. For example, the size of his prostate, the detail of the 11 positive cores (e.g., % cancer, Gx+y for each core), whether there are indications of seminal vesicle involvement, whether there are EPE (extraprostatic extension) etc. It maybe counter intuitive but a large number of positive cores in this case is good news as it is consistent with a PSA of 9 and so hopefully cancer is organ confined. If you look at my case, I had a PSA of 10.7 but only 1 core <5% positive. I worried my cancer was systemic but fortunately post op they found lots of cancer all over but within the prostate which explained the PSA of 10.7. Good luck.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DTrom I had a radical prostectomy in 2012. It was stage 3. It 2013 I had radiation and hormone treatments. 18 months later, psa was 0.0. 6 months later, psa is at 0.05. Being that it's come back before, I think I'm back there again. Any similar experiences? Thank you If the PSA came back from 0.0 while you were still on Eligard, then, likely you have a recurrence. If the PSA came back after you stopped Eligard for some time, there is a chance your PSA of 0.05 could be due to radiation PSA bounce. In any case most likely your oncologist will demand at least another PSA test to confirm the results. Discuss with your oncologist and research treatment options are perhaps your best path going forward for now: Preparing for the worst and hope for the best. Regards,
Posts.Title: Is it back again?

Posts.Content: If your brother's surgery was able to keep him in remission for 2 1/2 years, and his current PSA is only rising slowly, his chance of a "cure" with radiotherapy is quite good. One option for him is to do a combined hormone and radiotherapy to keep his cancer at bay. Studies showed this to be the most effective treatment after a failed surgery. Most folks with his statistics should easily be around for years. He should has time to see his daughter graduate from college and getting married. Tell him to stay positive. Best of luck to you and your brother.
Posts.Title: Family

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Hi, Actually, I believe it is very unlikely that PC would spread to the rectum or the bowel. Here is a link to one article I just found on Google that discusses one particular case: http://www.wjso.com/content/9/1/56 HighlanderCFH, You are correct that normally PC does not spread to the rectum. Your article described one case where it did so it does happen. I think whether it does or not depends on the location and aggressiveness of the cancer . The prostate sits next to the rectum at the back so if the cancer is near the capsule wall next to the rectum, it can spread to the rectum. The poster already stated the partner has metastasized prostate cancer spread to the bones and "bowel" so I assumed it did attack the rectum. In any case, it is important he seeks treatment/hormone or other means ASAP to shrink the cancer and relieve the pain. From the post, he may not be living at a place where oncological help is available if so it is important he goes to a place where a competent oncologist can provide care. Best wishes and peace.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Putt I was bordering on the edge of restarting another round of ADT, when for some unexplained reason my PSA started going back down and my T is normal for some one my age. My doctor said to continue whatever I was doing, something was working. Whatever it is, I'm a happy camper for now. Next check in 3 months. Interesting. Are you taking any supplements? Changed your diet? Took any other medications? When his PSA started to go up years after surgery & SRT, my friend's oncologist told him: "Before I do anything, I want you to take pomegranate extract, soy extract and drink lots of green tea, for some people, they did work for a while to keep PSA down.

Posts.Title: RALP Scheduled

Posts.Content: I am not a doctor, so my comments are not to be taken seriously. That said, after 6 months of normal urination, you all of a sudden had pain during urination, restriction and urgency, first thing a doctor would check is infection, either urinary track, bladder or kidney. A course of antibiotic is most likely the first thing to try. If it persists, and the flow is highly restricted, you might have urethra stricture due to scar tissues. Opening up should help. Bladder spasm sometimes persists, and medication to relax the bladder could be the next step. Perhaps Flomax? Consult a doctor and good luck.

Posts.Title: What I Need to Know About Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Jim is a straight shooter and is usually blunt but gave very good advice. Here are some comments from me: Your prostate is large but not huge and the PSA # is consistent with a 68 cc prostate but with suspicious MRI and DRE a biopsy is a reasonable next step. Taking Cardura and Avodart since mid-July, currently with good success. Flow is better than its been in many years. That is great but you may want to discuss with your urologist this FDA warning label on a class of drugs call 5-ARI which Avodart belongs. I know many urologist disagree with the FDA and I really don't know who is right but it is better safe than sorry. http://www.fda.gov/Safety/MedWatch/S.../ucm258529.htm Unfortunately, the machine was a Siemens 1.5T (and not a 3T) but (thankfully) no ERC was used. You should have asked for the ERC. Though unpleasant it increases the resolutions quite a bit and is almost as good as having the 3T without ERC. The radiologist said findings were compatible with BPH and a PI-RAD score of 2 for the transition zone. However, there was a small focal abnormal signal intensity in the left lateral peripheral zone measuring 1.0x0.6cm, compatible with a PI-RAD 3 lesion. The lesion was mapped for a potential fusion biopsy. (The radiologist notes that this suspicious area is only seen on a single image and no discrete lesion is visible on post-contrast images.) Like Jim if it were me I would go ahead and do a biopsy. But it is a non professional opinion. Good luck and best to you.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mattie1 I am not a coward - how do I explain to them what I know my gut feeling is saying - which is to let go and enjoy what I have left ? cheers to all of you, Mattie/ Sorry you are here and hope you do seek treatment and if you don't like surgery or radiation, you could try hormone and chemo. Early stage Prostate cancer tends to be symptom free and many of us wondered why treat when things looked/felt normal. I have seen a few end stage prostate cancer cases where pain was constant even with painkillers so if I were you I would seek treatment and see if I could "kill" the cancer before it spreads. Best wishes and good luck.
Posts.Title: Looking for advice and emotional support with new Prostate Ca diagnosis.

Posts.Content: For some reason I could not respond to your post over there, so let me answer it here: I want to emphasize this is just a layperson's interpretation and I maybe all wrong. Starting with the most important, One of three lymph nodes was positive This trumps the negative margins. I assumed the one positive node is the first sentinel node. I assumed the surgeon stopped at three since the following two were clean otherwise many more nodes would have been removed. The cancer already spread. This is an invasive ductal carcinoma, NOS with a micropapillary component. Tumor emboli show micropapillary features and involve small and larger lymphovascular spaces in the peritumoral area and well away from the main mass, they are also seen very close to multiple resection margins and transected at the posterior and the revised inferior margins IDC, NOS is the most common form of breast cancer (like adenocarcinoma in prostate cancer), survival rate is very high. However, the micropapillary component is a more aggressive feature so is not as good. Also, the lymphovascular involvement means the cancer is growing inside the lymphatic vessels so the risk of spread outside is high (e.g. to the lymph nodes). They are also very close to the margins meaning microscopic cancer cells could be outside. All in all I think she needs additional treatments like chemo and possibly radiation to the breast and surrounding area, and if her genetic make up is correct, she could take tamoxifen to further reduce her risk of recurrence. Don't panic, folks I know who had similar pathology went through the multiple treatments and are doing very well after many years. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Husband Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: AS is probably the right choice at this stage of you diagnosis. Your PSA is low and only 1 core 5% positive with G(3+3). You have plenty of time to watch and monitor to see if your cancer is indolent and if so no treatment is needed. You also want to get a couple of books , e.g., Dr. Walsh's book, on prostate cancer to gain some additional insights so you will become an informed patient. The other thing you should do is to send the biopsy slides to a prominent lab, e.g. Johns Hopkins, for a second opinion since the G(3+3) is often the judgement of the pathologist who examined your slides. You want to make sure the 3+3 is not a 3+4. Good luck.

Posts.Content: sundrop15, Sorry to say, the combination of a PSA of 153 and a hard prostate means very likely he has cancer. However, it sometimes could be infection or inflammation so the doctor could give him a course of antibiotics to see if PSA will drop. I remember one of the posters here had a PSA of ~100 which turned out to be infection and not cancer. However, if it persists, a biopsy is usually the next step. Let's hope it is not cancer and he need not join our club. Good luck to him.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jkeyt 60 years old T3b N0 MX positive seminal vesicle invasion Positive perineural invasion Gleason 9 post op 40% PSA 0.2 6 weeks post op Worried. Plan for the worst but hope for the best. Don't know what your pre-op PSA was, but if it was less than 10-20, at 6 week PSA should be undetectable. So, yes, you should start looking for plan B but do not pull the trigger until after another PSA confirmation test at 12 weeks. Suggest you make an appointment to see a rad oncologist and an oncologist to see what options you have going forward if plan B is needed. With a G9 and positive seminal vesicle invasion, if cancer is outside, you want to get a jump on the cancer ASAP. Good luck and best wishes.

I suggest you seek the advice of an oncologist who specializes in prostate cancer and since you are in Houston, getting a second opinion from MDA is a logical next step. Best wishes.

Posts.Content: Thank you for the article. Perhaps that is why some prostate cancers are indolent and some are not - those that have the SPDEF gene are indolent, independent of their G scores. Unfortunately, knowing why is just a first small step. From discovery to treatment is a long road, first, other scientists have to be able to duplicate the results, publish the results through peer review papers, then someone will have to find how to correct this condition and then get a treatment methodology establish. Then go on phase I, phase II and finally phase III clinical trial and then apply for FDA approval... Each of the steps takes time even if they fast track the process. So we could be talking about a decade at least. But there is hope and why we need to hang on for as long as possible for new treatments to come our way.

Posts.Title: My wife is concerned because my PSA is slowly rising every 3 months

Posts.Content: Look at it this way: Cancer already spread to one node, so even if the margins of the lumpectomy are clear, likely there are microscopic cancers within the breast (with the other features indicated), so radiation is a must to mop-up those. If one node is involved cancer is likely outside and in the lymphatic fluids so chemo is necessary. We can imagine a scenario that the only cancer is contained within the lumpectomy and only got into one node and nowhere else so no other treatment is needed. But we don't know and the probability seems low to me and to based treatment on that scenario is risky. My opinion is, instead, think of the best treatment options to get a cure based on the worst case scenario. And that is achievable in her case! Best wishes.

Posts.Title: My CBC Results With Respect to Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: I am posting this as my understanding of a confusing subject and not to stir up debate so please don't get mad at me. Many of the new comers had not read some of the prior posts on PSA half life discussions so let me summarize it here; 1. Half life is defined as the time for the PSA in the body (measured as blood PSA) to reduce by half if there is no new replenishment from the prostate. 2. My research notes indicated typical half life is between 2 to 3 days. One example of the studies: Serum half-life time determination of free and total prostate-specific antigen following radical prostatectomy—a critical assessment Edgar Brändle, Oliver Hautmann, Max Bachem, Klaus Kleinschmidt, Hans Werner Gottfried, Adolf Grünert, Richard E Hautmann Department of Urology, University of Ulm, Ulm, Germany; Department of Clinical Chemistry, University of Ulm, Ulm, Germany Urology (Impact Factor: 2.42). 05/1999; DOI:10.1016/S0090-4295-98-00593-7 3. The finding by these guys was a half life of 2.7 days. 4. Using 3 days as half life, for someone with a pre-op PSA of 10, at 6 weeks (42 days) post-op his PSA should be down to 10/2^14, or ~.0006. Using 2 days as half life, the 6 week PSA should be ~.000005. In both cases, PSA is undetectable. 5. Many urologists (mine included) wanted to get a jump in case surgery failed and thus advocated a 6 week test, others thought it did not matter and op for 3 months. 6. A detectable PSA does not mean failed surgery. There were many cases where some benign prostate tissues were left behind and they never caused BCR (I remembered one poster here had that happened to him). Small detectable PSA could also mean a little cancer cells were left behind locally and SRT should take care of that (many here had successful SRT) and jkeyt might be in either category. Best wishes to all.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Consult Question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by gsteve I have have been reading my brains out trying to decide between rp and brachy. I have read many many stories about bad rp , almost no disappointments with brachy. Im i correct in this thinking? I think there are indications that an experienced RO performing brachy has less side effects, especially ED than a normal surgeon's outcome. On the other hand, an experienced surgeon like Dr. Walsh also gave excellent results including ED. What I am trying to say is whatever you choose is not as important as who you choose to do the treatment. Another factor is the side effects of surgery are immediately so most of us would find out very quickly if we had side effects and posted them in forums. Brachy on the other hand had delayed side effects, so immediately after treatment, most of the reports were good. Sometimes 4 to 5 years or ever many years later problems might show up and I am guessing people who have problems 5 to 10 years after treatment do not normally come back and post here. Just like I don't see too many 5-10 year surgery guys posting here either. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Need help interpreting this positive margin ! Please help !

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jenni63 if they suspected cancer to be in the lymph nodes would they have removed them with the prostate Jenni63, Some surgeons always remove lymph in prostatectomy while others always leave them intact. The arguments: For: Like breast cancer, if you take out the positive lymph nodes, you could be cancer free, or even if it spreads, it might slow the cancer spread. Besides, it is no big deal to take them out while you are on the operating table and it will give a definitive answer of whether the cancer is organ confined. Against: Prostate cancer is different, once cancer is in the lymph nodes, it already spread and taking it out is futile. Also, by taking out the lymph nodes, you increase your chance of lymphoceles (lymph fluids collected inside the abdomen) and cause infection, or worst sepsis. The debate goes on. My personal layperson observation: I have seen many patients with positive lymph nodes taken out, had undetectable PSA for years. My choice: I would like them taken out. Good luck to your hubby and brother in law. By the way, with G6 and PSA of 18, it should not be not too aggressive and he should enjoy many years of productive life. The question is what is in his post op pathology report. He sould get a copy and study it or share it here.

I am not a doctor but there seemed to be many occasions, even before his procedure when they could find out more about his situation instead of letting things slide. It started with his doctor getting him regular PSA testings and properly examining his symptoms to eliminate cancer before recommending the procedure. Also, when physicians do any prostate procedures like TURP or laser to relieve urinary symptoms from an enlarged prostate, they usually do a PSA test and that should detect his high PSA and sent him to a biopsy. And if they performed TURP, they always sent the sample to a pathologist and that would most likely show caner. Thank you for sharing your story as this will help those that come after to be more vigilant.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Tillie Hello, Just wondering if anyone has been treated with taxotere and then with jevtana Looking to hearing about results and side effects with the jevtana any advise would be helpful. Have a blessed day No one answer your post so let me give it a try. I assumed your doctor was already or was proposing to put you on Taxotere and Jevtana and that was why you asked? I do not have any experience with Jevtana so I have no personal experience to share. However, in "preparing for the worst and hope for the best" I have been reading up on some of the new treatment options to treat BCR (biochemical recurrence) and metastasized prostate cancer and here is what I found: Taxotere and Jevtana are two chemo drugs under a class of drugs called microtubule inhibitors which cause cell death by inhibiting cell functions especially when they divide (fast growing cancer cells). (My wife's breast cancer chemo soup contained Taxotere as one of the ingredients. It certainly was not a walk in the park for her, in fact she had a rough time.) Jevtana was recently approved by the FDA after a successful Phase III clinical trial. I believe it acts on a different pathway as microtubule inhibitor than Taxotere so patients that failed Taxotere often got positive result from Jevtana. However, the toxicity of this new drug is quite high so those who takes it requires careful monitoring. Side effects are mainly myelosuppression (the reduce ability of the bone marrow to produce blood cells), anemia, diarrhea and cardiac problems. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Jevtana

Posts.Content: regress, Removing lymph nodes while going through robotic surgery is very easy and many surgeons do that as a matter of practice. However, I have not seen any studies that compare outcomes with or without lymph nodes removal. One thing for sure is once they are removed and examined and are positive, then cancer has most likely spread and thus one should plan for plan B immediately. One risk that is seldom mentioned is removing lymph nodes sometimes causes lymphocele, the accumulation of lymphatic fluid in the body cavity. By itself, if asymptomatic, it will not cause any problem but sometimes they get infected, leading to abscess and could be life threatening. I am aware of three posters on this site that had such happened to them after surgery. Fortunately, all recovered fully after additional treatments. Good luck.

Posts.Content: AS is probably the right choice at this stage of you diagnosis. Your PSA is low and only 1 core 5% positive with G(3+3). You have plenty of time to watch and monitor to see if your cancer is indolent and if so no treatment is needed. You also want to get a couple of books , e.g., Dr. Walsh's book, on prostate cancer to gain some additional insights so you will become an informed patient. The other thing you should do is to send the biopsy slides to a prominent lab, e.g. Johns Hopkins, for a second opinion since the G(3+3) is often the judgement of the pathologist who examined your slides. You want to make sure the 3+3 is not a 3+4. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Jevtana

Posts.Content: You asked a very good question. I worried about this too since I had 4 biopsies before they found cancer. I did some search prior to my second biopsy and in general the risks for prostate biopsy seemed small. Here is one article I found at the time: J Urol. 1991 May;145(5):1003-7. Needle biopsy associated tumor tracking of adenocarcinoma of the prostate. Bastacky SS, Walsh PC, Epstein JI. Department of Urology, Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine, Baltimore, Maryland They found about 2% of cases had evidences of positive tracking. I believe newer needles have "trap door" to close the needle opening to prevent/minimize tracking. Another more recent publication in 2008 which I found just before my 4th biopsy, from U Penn is even more positive and here is the quote: Pennsylvania School of Medicine, responds: I looked at the website, medicalnewstoday.com, and the article is based on a press release from a clinic in Sarasota, Florida, where the author talks about “seeding” the needle track with tumor cells. The problem with this is that while seeding is well described in tumors of the lung, biliary tract and some other sites, there are fewer than 100 cases reported of this happening with prostate cancer. Think about it: 225,000 cases/yr x 15 yrs of PSA screening and biopsy when needed, which means about 100 cases is a relatively small number. Most of the described cases of seeding involve neuroendocrine tumors of the prostate, which are <1% of prostate tumors and don't make PSA, so PSA levels are not elevated.
Posts.Title: Sautrated biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by fastball1 going to MD Anderson for plan of action in 3 days, rcd pathology report yesterday.. wife really upset but I have been her rock and will continue to be...gotta stay positive dob-1958 psa 14.8 7 out of 12 cores positive 2 cores 3+4 gleason cores 64%,31%,19%, 7%,14%,13%, 20% No stage given on report any advice would be awesome.... fastball, Most likely, the doctor will order a CT scan and a bone scan. Since your PSA is >10, I would also ask for an MRI. MRI and CT are somewhat redundant but MRI is better in certain circumstances. At this stage you want as much information as you can get. You should also request a second read on your biopsy slides by another lab. A more precise diagnosis can help you and your MD Anderson physician decide on the best treatment options. Good luck.

Posts.Title: newly diagnosed but staying positive

Posts.Content: How old are you? Something does not add up. Your historical PSA had never gone beyond 3.7 which did not support a diagnosis of suddenly 5 core G7/8. Do you have BPH or are you taking Proscar (finasteride or dutasteride) for BPH? From 11/2014 to 9/2015 was only 10 months and for prostate cancer to progress from 3 cores of very little G6 to so many cores of G7 and G8 with no mentioned of any rare forms of prostate cancer is very puzzling. If I were you I would send both biopsy slides to Dr. Epstein for a second read. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Consult Question

Posts.Content: Your husband's prostate cancer is extensive and perhaps in danger of escaping the prostate capsule and goes systemic. If I were him I would take care of it first unless scrape out the bladder and prostatectomy can be done together? Ask his urologist for an opinion. Take care..
Posts.Title: husband just diagnosed

Posts.Content: I guess they do things differently where you are. After my bone scan, I asked for a CD copy of the scan and waited 15 minutes for it. When I got my CD copy, the radiologist gave me his preliminary read right there. But, I agree with everyone, most likely the scan will come out clean. If your Dad has arthritis and old bone injuries, the scan will light up and show all of them so the radiologist/physician might ask him about all of those, etc.

Posts.Title: How long before I can start working out/bike riding etc.

Posts.Content: Sorry you are here but welcome. Your husband has aggressive prostate cancer (G9) that has escaped the prostate to the seminal vesicle (T3b), to 1 lymph node (N1) and to 1 bone metastasis in the pelvic area (M1). Find the best oncologist and radiation oncologist in your area and seek their advices on treatment options. Hopefully, his hormone therapy is just one part of an overall treatment plan. He is young and if he is healthy, I would go aggressive and throw everything including the kitchen sink at the cancer to try get a "cure" or to prevent the cancer from spreading elsewhere. Of course this is just a layperson's opinion and is not medical advice. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Is it prostate cancer?

Posts.Content: AS is probably the right choice at this stage of you diagnosis. Your PSA is low and only 1 core 5% positive with G(3+3). You have plenty of time to watch and monitor to see if your cancer is indolent and if so no treatment is needed. You also want to get a couple of books , e.g., Dr. Walsh's book, on prostate cancer to gain some additional insights so you will become an informed patient. The other thing you should do is to send the biopsy slides to a prominent lab, e.g. Johns Hopkins, for a second opinion since the G(3+3) is often the judgement of the pathologist who examined your slides. You want to make sure the 3+3 is not a 3+4. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed 10 days ago, insights sought

Posts.Content: regress, Removing lymph nodes while going through robotic surgery is very easy and many surgeons do that as a matter of practice. However, I have not seen any studies that compare outcomes with or without lymph nodes removal. One thing for sure is once they are removed and examined and are positive, then cancer has most likely spread and thus one should plan for plan B immediately. One risk that is seldom mentioned is removing lymph nodes sometimes causes lymphocele, the accumulation of lymphatic fluid in the body cavity. By itself, if asymptomatic, it will not cause any problem but sometimes they get infected, leading to abscess and could be life threatening. I am aware of three posters on this site that had such happened to them after surgery. Fortunately, all recovered fully after additional treatments. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Guess I'm in this Elite Group now.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by inazcity Trying to find out if others have experienced this. 4 years ago I had a PSA of 3 and had a biopsy with all 32 samples clean. After a year I had another PSA done and was at 6. No Biopsy done since 1st one was clean. 3rd year PSA of 13 another biopsy again 32 samples and all clean. Just got this years results of a whopping 21. Does anyone have any idea of what could possibly cause this. Prostate has been slightly enlarged since the first time and have done the antibiotic regiment to no avail. Just looking for answers. Any help or ideas will be appreciated Ask for a copy of the biopsy reports and see if there were the followings found: chronic inflammation (not infection), PIN (low or high grade) and/or ASAP. They are not classified as cancer but will all raised PSA readings. Often, antibiotics won't get rid of chronic inflammation. Other tests like PCA3, color doppler, etc. unfortunately are not definitive. If they are all negative, you might want to have the sample re-read by a different pathologist or get someone else to do another biopsy. Often, finding cancer depends on chance and the skills of the person taking the biopsy (or reading the slides) after all even with saturation biopsy you are only sampling a very small portions of the prostate. Took a radiologist instead of my urologist to find my cancer on the fourth try, even though post op pathology showed extensive cancers. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Ever increasing PSA

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mattie1 I am not a coward - how do I explain to them what I know my gut feeling is saying - which is to let go and enjoy what I have left ? cheers to all of you, Mattie/ Sorry you are here and hope you do seek treatment and if you don't like surgery or radiation, you could try hormone and chemo. Early stage Prostate cancer tends to be symptom free and many of us wondered why treat when things looked/felt normal. I have seen a few end stage prostate cancer cases where pain was constant even with painkillers so if I were you I would seek treatment and see if I could "kill" the cancer before it spreads. Best wishes and good luck.
Posts.Title: Looking for advice and emotional support with new Prostate Ca diagnosis.

Posts.Content: The National Cancer Institute has a website: www.cancer.gov They have a section on prostate cancer. There are two different versions: for layperson and for healthcare professional. The professional version has all the latest information on diagnosis, staging, treatment etc. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Reading List.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by KELLY41 It's been 6 years since I was diagnosed with very serious prostate cancer with a PSA of 95 and a gleasen score of 9. I had 38 radiation treatments and have done well till this year. In Jan PSA was 3, March was 3.6,June was 5 and September it is 10.15. My urologist prescribed Finasteride and Bicalutamide as I can not take the shot due to side effects. My oncologist prescribed an MRI of the hips and back. Nothing was found. The oncologist says the cancer has definitely come back but has not been found yet. I go back in 3 weeks.Can anyone give me advise on how to proceed? Kelly41, The other folks have given you excellent comments and suggestions. Let me add mine and I like to start from the beginning: First I have a bunch of questions you may want to answer: When your cancer was diagnosed, with a PSA of 95 and G9, how did you ended up with a radiation treatment? Did your urologist recommended it and did you consult an oncologist? Did your urologist do a bone scan, ct scan and an MRI? With a very high PSA and aggressive G9, there could be indications of spread prior to treatment and you need to know. Also, you can use that as a baseline to compare any new scans and get a better sense of where are the likely locations of the cancer. And, what was the lowest PSA you achieved (PSA nadir) after radiation? Second, modern radiation protocol often involves a course of hormone before, during and after radiation treatment to enhance effectiveness and increase cure rate. Did your urologist/oncologist provide you with that? Perhaps when you said you could not take shot due to side effects that was the hormone shot they gave you? If so, there are still a number of other hormones you could have taken (like what lancepeace mentioned) did your oncologist give you a substitute? Third, if you can ask for some of the new more sensitive scans. Be able to find out where the cancer hides can be helpful to devise a treatment plan. Fourth, I am not a healthcare professional but from what I read, the Finasteride and Bicalutamide (Casodex) combo is kind of unusual. Maybe you should get a second opinion on treatment options. Fifth, you mentioned reduced stream. It could be urethra stricture, a delayed side effect of the radiation treatment. However, you had a cystoscopy and it was normal? My friend had salvage radiation and six years after had the same problem. His was cured by a simple procedure to remove the stricture. You should consult your urologist. Yes, it is possible (but unusual) for the cancer to attack the bladder muscle. And finally, if you can, go find a cancer center (e.g. The U of Mississippi) and consult with the experts there because your case may be different than the "run of the mill" prostate cancer and you want the best oncologists on your team. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Robotic Procedure and Lymph Node Removal

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ezhelp712 Hi JohnT and thanks for the reply, As posted earlier, a meeting with the Radiation Oncology Specialist is scheduled. This is exactly the topic the urologist and surgeon have concerns - cancer is not contained. Therefore, they suggested the seed therapy. Do you know if the seed therapy is ALWAYS accompanied with hormone therapy? Thank You. If I were you, I probably would choose radiation + hormone as the treatment plan and shoot for a cure. Your enlarged prostate maybe too large for seed therapy, and in that case the radiation oncologist could prescribe hormone therapy to shrink the prostate to make seeds more effective. He should also add IMRT to ensure he gets all of your cancer. There were numerous studies indicating hormone enhances the effectiveness of radiation and increase survival. Good luck to you.

Posts.Title: Hello Everyone

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo I'm almost wondering if I should do everything I was told not to do before checking PSA level, like bike riding, giving my semi-limp friend a "helping hand", etc. Almost do everything I can to raise whatever PSA level there may be to find it sooner. Since you no longer have a prostate, it should not matter. The only things that will cause you to have a non zero PSA are: Some benign prostate tissues were left behind or cancer cells were left behind. Also, your doctor should prescribe low dose Cialis to help your little buddy. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Question about follow-up appt after Davinci

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Don B Yes, Fran... That's why I'm trying to find out how extensive that procedure is. My preference for radiation is due to just recently adjusting to living alone after 46 years of marriage, and I have concerns about recovering on my own. But, to your point, if getting a sample to biopsy the node is a big deal, then I may as well just go for the surgery. Thanks for your humble opinion, Don It is not too complicated but still it takes a skilled radiologist to do it. I think it is not routinely done for prostate cancer because when in doubt most physicians op for radiation which by its nature casts a wider net and can aim at both the prostate and the suspected lymph node area to kill the cancer there. The cure rate for surgery and radiation are about equal so there is no disadvantage in going for radiation except perhaps the cost of radiation is higher to the insurance company. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: Is it prostate cancer?

Posts.Content: Being the pessimist among members here, I worry a little if there is no < sign in front of your 6 weeks PSA #. To add to what Michael F said, there are several possibilities: Lab error; you started out with extremely high PSA; some benign tissues were left behind; some cancer cells are still there. Let's hope it is the first three and not the last. In any case a repeat PSA in the near future makes sense to me. Many surgeons order a PSA test 3 months after surgery, mine wanted a PSA test at 6 weeks and his rationale was he wanted to get a jump on the situation if something was not right. So, the question is: Is 6 week enough time for PSA to be undetectable? The scientific answer is yes and here is the computation: Numerous studies confirmed normal PSA half-life is between 2 to 3 days meaning if there is no replenishment, blood PSA will be down by half in 2 to 3 days. At 6 weeks (42 days), if your are on the slow side, your PSA should be down by 14 half-lives and if yours is fast it should be down by 21 half-lives. If your pre-op PSA was 10, it should be at 0.0006 with a 3 days half-life and would be 0.000004 with a 2 days half-life. I hope your case is just like Michael F's. So, it is too early to worry but to be on the safe side, if I were you I would take the pathology report and get a second opinion from an oncologist just in case. Good luck and let's hope the others are correct.

Posts.Content: I guess they do things differently where you are. After my bone scan, I asked for a CD copy of the scan and waited 15 minutes for it. When I got my CD copy, the radiologist gave me his preliminary read right there. But, I agree with everyone, most likely the scan will come out clean. If your Dad has arthritis and old bone injuries, the scan will light up and show all of them so the radiologist/physician might ask him about all of those, etc.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by WifeinWorry Isn't Flomax only for when the prostate was enlarged, so you can pee? Why would you need it after the prostate has been radiated and shrunk? Or can it still become enlarged? hmmm Radiation swells the tissues in and around the prostate. Flomax works by relaxing the muscles of the prostate, urethra and bladder so urines can flow more easily.

Posts.Title: First Post

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Don B Yes, Fran... That's why I'm trying to find out how extensive that procedure is. My preference for radiation is due to just recently adjusting to living alone after 46 years of marriage, and I have concerns about recovering on my own. But, to your point, if getting a sample to biopsy the node is a big deal, then I may as well just go for the surgery. Thanks for your humble opinion, Don It is not too complicated but still it takes a skilled radiologist to do it. I think it is not routinely done for prostate cancer because when in doubt most physicians op for radiation which by its nature casts a wider net and can aim at both the prostate and the suspected lymph node area to kill the cancer there. The cure rate for surgery and radiation are about equal so there is no disadvantage in going for radiation except perhaps the cost of radiation is higher to the insurance company. Good luck and best wishes.
Posts.Title: New here, wondering about "suspicious" lymph node

Posts.Content: First of all, ask for the results of his DRE his DR performed: how big is his prostate and any abnormality (nodules, SV...); ask him what are the usual symptoms of prostate cancer to watch out for; should he go for a biopsy (a PSA of <4 at his age is quite normal). By the way in the US, we have a colonoscopy every 3 to 10 years depending on symptoms and risk profile, so when was the last time he had his colon checked? Extreme rectal pain (sharp or dull? constant or intermittent?) is usually not a symptom of prostate cancer. Like Fairwind said, did his doctor check his bowel, stools and/or do a colonoscopy to check out his colon/rectum? It is unusual for prostate cancer to attack the rectum and to cause extreme rectal pain. If antibiotics helped, it could be infection and he could have multiple problems. You might give your friend info on the usual symptoms of BPH/infection/prostate cancer: A need to urinate frequently, especially at night Difficulty starting urination or holding back urine Weak or interrupted flow of urine Painful or burning urination Difficulty in having an erection Painful ejaculation Blood in urine or semen Frequent pain or stiffness in the lower back, hips, or upper thighs Of course we are not healthcare professionals, so he should listen to his PCP and Urologist instead of us. Good luck to him.
Posts.Title: Prostate info for friend

Posts.Content: Here in the US, the standard procedure is that if the cancer metastasized to other organs, prostatectomy will not be done. Effectively, if the cancer is already outside, taking the prostate out will not stop the cancer, at best, it only "de-bulk" the cancer and slow it down somewhat. Standard surgery will always remove the seminal vesicle and most surgeons, especially those doing robotic (my surgeon told me that it was very easy to take lymph nodes out during da vinci) often will remove some lymph nodes for pathology examination to ensure they are OK.
Posts.Title: Prostatectomy when there is bone involvement?

Posts.Content: Pratoman, Why don't you do what some of us did: Schedule your surgery 2 months after your biopsy which pushes the earliest you can go to January. The reason you need 2 months for the earliest surgery is surgeon won't cut if the prostate is still full of needle holes not yet heal. Use the two months to get your second opinion regarding AS, surgery or radiation. To me the most critical decision point is between AS and treat. Once you get pass that, it is mostly a matter of personal preference and finding the best practitioner in whatever you choose to do. So in that regard, the MSK mid Dec consult is within the time frame. No loss of time, unless you decide to cancel the surgery date and start over with another surgeon. I think radiation scheduling is usually easier than surgery dates so if you choose radiation, you should be able to schedule within the two months. In engineering they advice against "paralysis by analysis" too much analysis and agonizing over everything and not taking action sometimes is worst than get up and go. Best regards,

Posts.Title: Losing my Mind

Posts.Content: Thanks for the link. Some of the outcome don't make sense to me, for example: 1. The prostate cancer specific survival is worst for low risk patients than for intermediate risk patients and the difference I believe is statistically significant based on the number of patients and the difference. 2. Adjuvant ADT had a negative effect on survival, counter to quite a number of other published studies. It is also interesting to compare the results to the 30 years Johns Hopkins prostatectomy outcome study published in 2012: For JH: From 1992-2011 (similar period), out of 3385 patients, 51 died of prostate cancer (1.5%). Patient classification based on the D'Amico Risk Group: Low 2224, Intermediate 1034 and High 121. The median years followed-up: 8.6 (range 1 to 19). For Mount Sinai (Brachy): From 1990-2007, out of 1669 patients, 37 died of prostate cancer (2.2%). Your article did not break out the risk group and population in each risk so comparison is difficult. I must say the results are excellent except for the two points I mentioned and the difference between surgery and Brachy is really very minor. So folks should be comfortable choosing Brachy. Another interesting point from JH is the survival outcome was much worst in the pre-PSA era of 1982-1991. That can be accounted for by the Risk grouping: Only 38% were diagnosed with low risk pre-PSA as compared to 66% in the post-PSA era. Best wishes.
Posts.Title: New data released "15-year survival and related data after first-line brachytherapy"

Posts.Content: Welcome LeslieKay. In another thread you mentioned your Dad's physician wanted to operate and remove the prostate. That is a good sign since it means they still think there is a chance the cancer, even though already escaped are localized and can be removed by surgery. Typically, in aggressive cases (G8 and escaped), they also add adjuvant radiation and hormone. So the short answer is it is treatable and many with his conditions were in remission/cured. Good luck to both your parents on their fights against prostate cancer and lung cancer.

But without a positive test, he isn't eligible for the study...so we're waiting for the next positive test. Perhaps he should try taking probiotics if he is not a candidate for fecal transplants. Maybe the friendly bacteria in probiotics can help fight C-Diff. similar to fecal transplant? Best wishes.
Posts.Title: Ductual prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Without drilling down to compare treatment modalities, the study is not very helpful to us prostate cancer patients. There are numerous studies within the prostate cancer treatment communities on comparing secondary cancer risk from various treatment methods. The findings (I can go back and dig those studies out if someone is interested) I remembered when I was searching for treatment options were: 1. For surgery, colorectal and bladder cancer risks were no different from the general population. 2. For brachy, the colorectal and bladder cancer risks were only slightly higher than the general population. 3. For external beam radiation, they about double the risk of the general population, but if you looked at the absolute number, i.e., case per 100,000, it was still a very small number and comparable to the risk of death/complications due to surgery. But remember, the outcome for radiation was taken over a long time (years if not decades) and the technology in external radiation has improved so much that I am sure the risks are much smaller nowadays. And, I think that was the reason many doctors recommended surgery for very young prostate cancer patients as they still have decades to live and cancer risk due to radiation goes up in time after treatment. So, it is correct that we should watch out for the possibility of secondary cancer, it is not a risk high enough that those needing treatment should stop getting treatment. Specifically, those that were treated with external radiation should not lose any sleep. Others should perhaps just follow the guidelines for the general population. Peace, just want to add my comments and not try to create a fight.

Posts.Title: Losing my Mind

Posts.Content: Ronald007, Sorry about your diagnosis and very sorry about your situation. If you choose surgery, you do not need to do hormone as studies found no benefits of adding hormone prior to surgery and in some cases might affect the "feel and appearance" of the cancer and confused the surgeon. On the other hand, studies indicated adding hormone treatment prior to radiation enhanced the cure rate and survival. Both radiation and surgery are good options in your case. The patient should have the final say, so, you do have to decide and push for the treatment you want. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Losing my Mind

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lovethedeck My husband was diagnosed last May with prostate cancer after his biopsy showed 12 of 12 cores positive for cancer 8 cores were 3+4=7 (30-100%) 3 cores were 4+3=7 (60-100%) 1 core was 4+5=9 (90%) tertiary pattern 5 in 3 cores bone scan showed two small spots on lower back and shoulder also found in lymph nodes beginning PSA was 51.7 He started the Lupron shot for every 4 months...has had two. He had 40 radiation treatments also is getting a calcium infusion every 4 to 8 weeks to strengthen bones current PSA is 0.1 age 74 Doctor said his stage was T2b......but I thought since the cancer is not confined to the prostate...it was stage 4 ???? He feels fine with very few side effects. I know this is bad....but how bad? What should we expect? Unless the two spots are old wounds and not metastasis? And the positive lymph nodes are false positives? You really need to clarify these with his urologist for it could make a lot of differences. Usually with distant metastases they don't advocate radiation treatment. One other thought, with only 2 suspected spots and suspected lymph nodes, you might want to ask about spot radiating the spots. Dr. Myers and some other oncologists thought that could cause a durable remission. Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Title: New..... some confusion

Posts.Content: Your urologist is very thoughtful, gave you Lupton shot right away so that in case you select radiation you will get the optimum outcome. Your cancer is aggressive so do not wait but seek treatment as soon as possible. The good news is there is no indication it has spread so a cure is within your grasp. Good luck.
