Posts.Title: Gleason 4+4, Starting Lupron

Posts.Content: I have been suggesting folks asked their physicians on this subject for over a year now. For those of our brothers with advanced prostate cancer, combined chemo and hormone early provided significant survival advantage. This is the third study and is a randomized trial on this topic and again proven its effectiveness. The key is to start chemo and hormone as early as possible. I strongly suggest those that have BCR, or metastatic cancer discuss this new protocol with your oncologist: http://www.medpagetoday.com/MeetingCoverage/ASCO/51527 http://consumer.healthday.com/cancer....google.com%2F To me it represents one of the major advances in prostate cancer treatment. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Early Chemo May Boost Survival in Advanced Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Arthur Dent Also, I thought someone might chime in about the rash. Some googling reveals that allergic reactions to surgical scrub solutions and adhesives are not uncommon. Art Quite common and that is why in pre-op consultation and admission questionnaires they always ask about allergic reactions to medications, latex, tapes, anesthetic, etc.
Posts.Title: Hello from a newbie and a couple of questions.

Posts.Content: Pratoman, Why don't you do what some of us did: Schedule your surgery 2 months after your biopsy which pushes the earliest you can go to January. The reason you need 2 months for the earliest surgery is surgeon won't cut if the prostate is still full of needle holes not yet heal. Use the two months to get your second opinion regarding AS, surgery or radiation. To me the most critical decision point is between AS and treat. Once you get pass that, it is mostly a matter of personal preference and finding the best practitioner in whatever you choose to do. So in that regard, the MSK mid Dec consult is within the time frame. No loss of time, unless you decide to cancel the surgery date and start over with another surgeon. I think radiation scheduling is usually easier than surgery dates so if you choose radiation, you should be able to schedule within the two months. In engineering they advice against "paralysis by analysis" too much analysis and agonizing over everything and not taking action sometimes is worst than get up and go. Best regards,

Posts.Title: Losing my Mind

Posts.Content: Ronald007, Sorry about your diagnosis and very sorry about your situation. If you choose surgery, you do not need to do hormone as studies found no benefits of adding hormone prior to surgery and in some cases might affect the "feel and appearance" of the cancer and confused the surgeon. On the other hand, studies indicated adding hormone treatment prior to radiation enhanced the cure rate and survival. Both radiation and surgery are good options in your case. The patient should have the final say, so, you do have to decide and push for the treatment you want. Good luck.
Posts.Title: New member looking for advice and support

Posts.Content: I noticed no one responded to your post yet. I did not have brachy so really cannot share my experience. From my research, the incidence of ED after surgery if there is ED is immediate and may improve with time. With brachy, it mostly won't show up until later. Looks like it is happening to you. You should go back to your radiation oncologist, they usually have seen a lot of cases and probably is in a better position to give you advices. Cialis worked some of the time? since you bought from an online pharmacy(?) do you know if all the medications are genuine? Sorry I cannot help you. Good luck

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by iamtjdas My father is 65. Diagonised with T3C , No , Acinar Adenocarcinoma. 4 out of 12 cores +ve. G score 7 (3+4) with Peineural Invasion present(13% involved). Bone Scan NORMAL. PSA 30(August2014). Hormone therapy started with eligard taken on 9.9.2014. Now we are confused about further treatment pocedure Pls help For a cure, your Dad needs another treatment in addition to hormone and either radiation or surgery could offer a chance of cure. Choose carefully and hope he can be "cure/in remission". We are not physicians so he needs to consult his physician for the best option but in my non professional opinion hormone alone is not enough. Good luck.

Posts.Title: adenocarcinoma prostate

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by 35coupe Who gives the hormone treatment. Is it the urologist or the oncology doctor. Both can give the shots but if I were you and needed hormone shots, I would look for the best prostate cancer oncologist in my area and transfer my case to him. I would still consult with my urologist/surgeon but he should be taking a back seat going forward.
Posts.Title: Who gives the horomone shot

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by heypapa I have a few questions to ask : 1) is there any food or drink that he can't eat/consume? oily fried meat etc.../ coffee? 2) what should I ask when we went back to the doctor on 23 dec? what information do I need to know? actually in my heart, i only want to know how many more years can my dad live. thank you from a worried son. heypapa, Sorry you have to visit our club but welcome. Let me answer question #2 first. Since he already had his prostate biopsy and the doctor immediately started Hormone therapy indicating he has cancer, so the first task is to assess how aggressive is his cancer. You do that by asking the doctor to go through his biopsy report with you: how many cores were taken, how many of which were positive with cancer and what % of each core had cancer. Next, what is the Gleason scores (range from 6 to 10, 6 being less aggressive). A psa of 300 with high Gleason score means the cancer is aggressive and requires aggressive treatments. Hopefully his Gleason score will be below 7 meaning cancer could be the slow growing type. Ask the doctor to order not just a bone scan, but also a ct scan to see if there are soft tissues involvements, i.e., lymph node, bladder, seminal vehicles, etc. Some doctor will also order a MRI scan which gives better resolution than ct. If his cancer has escaped the prostate, he needs to consult an oncologist specializes in treating prostate cancer to maximize his chance of long term survival. With some many different drugs available, it takes an expert to get the right sequence and combinations right. Prostate cancer, even the aggressive ones allows us to live a long time so your Dad won't go away soon. How long depends on the results of the diagnostic tests and the right treatments he receives. Many of my friends who were diagnosed with high pas are still around after 10 years. As for question #1, there is no miracle diets that can cure cancer, just make sure that going forward he maintains a healthy diet. Others on this forum will add more pointers. Good luck to your father.
Posts.Signature: PCa Dx 2010 at 65. PSA increased from 2.5 in 2000 to 10.7 in 2010. Four biopsies in 6 years. Posts.Content: Thanks for the article. I learned something new today: I never thought anyone diagnosed with cancer would not be diligently tracking their disease to make sure they stayed low risks. Anyway, 72% is an impressive number for a 13 years follow-up. However, looked like the 27% who "disappeared" were included in the no treatments required group so we really don't know what the real number was. Take care.

Posts.Title: 300+PSA, still have hope?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mimi711 Here is the language from DH's post-op pathology report: Margins: Focally positive left posterior mid and superior pseudocapsular resection margin. All other margins negative for tumor. Yes, two spots had positive margins: One @ left posterior mid and one @ superior pseudo capsular resection (cut). Otherwise, pathology report is excellent. Like HighlanderCHF said, they are likely small but normally the pathology report should say e.g. < x mm focally positive for example. Small positive margins will sometimes not be a problem as Dr. Walsh said in his book that the act of surgery usually kill off the cancer cells at the margin if there are only a small amount at the margins. Good luck.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago Well, your doubling time seems to be about 5 years. Which would put you up to a PSA of 17 by age 65 and 34 by age 70 if it continues climbing. Otego, you made some very good points. Let me add a slightly different spin: If I were to use the last three PSA numbers, which I think is a better representation, the doubling time is about 2.5 years, though still quite slow, seemed to be speeding up. So, as all of you were saying, as PSA doubling time is speeding up and with a G7, AS is probably not a good long term option. DanF, good luck to you.

Posts.Content: You are one of the most knowledgeable posters here. You did your homework and made an excellent choice of treatment/surgeon. As a result, your pathology report and post-op PSA are both excellent. I am sure the side effects are temporary and you will have a full recovery.
Posts.Title: 10 weeks post-op

Posts.Content: I have no dog in this fight, but logic tells me if your PSA is undetectable after prostatectomy and that indeed there are no cancer cells or prostate cells left in your body then TRT should not cause any prostate cancer to come back. The risk is if there are microscopic cancer/prostate cells still lurking around then TRT would fuel the cancer growth. I think today many urologist would be amenable to TRT after several years of undetectable PSA.
Posts.Title: Post Prostatectomy, what is the general consensus on testosterone treatment?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by skizman Prostate left side, biopsy: -Benign prostatic tissue -Benign colonic mucosa and squamous mucosa. Would someone please explain about the colonic and squamous mucosa? Thankyou! Ski Very interesting and I am just guessing: Could be the biopsy samples on the left side when taken, took out some colon cells, i.e., contained some epithelial colon/rectum cells? They are benign anyway so nothing to worry about. Suggest you ask your urologist to confirm.

Posts.Title: Prostate Patholosist report>>>>

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 I agree with Chuck. A biopsy is indeed warranted. It's only a diagnostic test, not open-heart surgery and while we can choose to identify instances that rarely occur (deadly infection, please!!), only a biopsy will give an accurate picture. One question does come to mind: Why bother going to a doctor -- any doctor -- if you already decided what you were or were not going to do based on your 2,000 pages of reading on the subject? And it sounds like since you have all of the answers, why bother coming to a website where thousands of patients are willing to share their actual experiences? I will not comment on a 63-year-old male who ejaculates daily. But not for me to say. It sounds like you have a good "grip" on the subject. +1 However, if his urologist had also done a DRE and it was normal, he is asymptomatic with the size of the prostate consistent with the number, his position is not unreasonable. The risk of course is he could end up with an aggressive cancer and he may have given up the chance of early detection and a possible cure. Personally, I have not seen a single case of biopsy gone wrong among all my friends and relatives but have witnessed friends and relatives suffered pains and died from prostate cancer so my view is biased. Like everything in life, we all take risks so to each his own, especially since he is doing it with his eyes wide open. I do wish the best of luck to the poster and hope we can reject his application to join our club.

Posts.Title: Do I really need treatment?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Inquiring Mind Sorry for the confusion I've caused! My current situation is salvage radiation, with high risk of recurrence. Based on that study, the radiation oncologist recommended two years HT in addition to the radiation - I assume to increase the chances of the radiation being successful. This thread is hypothetical - should my slavage radiation fail and curitive options are exhausted, how early should chemo start? I hope your treatment will be successful so you do not have to face this dilemma. Since it is hypothetical, let me give you a hypothetical answer based on logic: I assumed there are a lot of similarities between different types of cancer, especially between breast cancer and prostate cancer. I am not arguing about non aggressive prostate cancer where AS seemed to be fine. I am talking about prostate cancer that are aggressive, so similar to typical breast cancers. Here are a few recent researches on delaying treatment and delaying chemo for breast cancer: http://www.mdanderson.org/newsroom/n...-negative.html http://archsurg.jamanetwork.com/arti...icleid=1681805 http://journal.frontiersin.org/artic...014.00087/full It essentially said delaying treatment and chemo reduced survival. I often stayed up at night think about "what if's". My conclusion, for me anyway was to throw everything at it as early as possible and with as many modalities as my body could take because a., multiple modalities reduced the chance of mutation and b., earlier gets the cancer before drug resistance or distant met. As for QOL, being cancer free >> on hormone for the rest of my life, even if I have to endure up six months of chemo and two years of hormone. I don't know if the logic makes any sense but as you said it is hypothetical. These are legitimate topics to talk over with your oncologists to see what their views are so in case you have to pull the trigger you have a plan. Regards,

Posts.Title: "Early" Chemo - how early?

Posts.Content: In 2014 April PSA was .04 pre radiation and during hormone therapy. Received hormone drugs for 6 months. I will have another PSA test next month. Currently I sit at 2.0 PSA. Michael F did right by asking for your history. Are you sure your current PSA is 2.0? If so, I am sorry to say this, your current PSA of 2.0 after salvage radiation and hormone therapy indicated the cancer is still there, though in amount small enough that scans could not pick them out. The good news is the cancer can likely be managed and controlled so they won't do much damage for a while. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: Recent Tests

Posts.Content: That is great news that means his is responding well to treatment. Good luck and best wishes.
Posts.Title: Good news after Casodex?

Posts.Content: No one reply so let me try. Seeds is an excellent way to go for a localized cancer. However, some radiation oncologists would not recommend it if your prostate is enlarged. Most modern studies comparing radiation treatment to surgery found the outcome to be similar. Since seeds placement in the prostate is critical to ensure all the cancers are radiated, the skill and experience of the radiation oncologist who places the seeds is the most important factor to consider. As for what if cancer comes back? It is true, surgery after seeds is difficult but not impossible. More likely you can still do salvage radiation after seeds failed, just like surgery. But, don't take my word for it since I am a layperson, please consult your physicians. Good luck.

Posts.Content: You should read PDV's signature. As I mentioned in my other post, don't treat it lightly if fever and pain persist. Go seek help, it is better to err on caution.
Posts.Title: Fever and pain?!?!

Posts.Content: If the consultant already knew you had prostate cancer, then he should do a biopsy to determine what type and how aggressive so a treat/no-treat decision can be made more intelligently. After all at 79 you could live another 20+ years! That said, once they determined your cancer to be non aggressive, you should choose "Active Surveillance" and will probably die of something else. The key is you and your doctor need to know that your cancer is non aggressive. Good luck.

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> After all at 79 you could live another 20

Posts.Title: No Biopsy

Posts.Content: A lot of studies indicated the outcome and side effects are about the same for folks choosing between radiation (seeds, IMRT.....) and surgery. It is more based on your situation (any heart problem, prior abdominal surgery, prior radiation treatments...), personal choice/preference than anything else. If I could not choose surgery because of a heart problem I would be comfortable going the radiation route. Good luck.
Posts.Title: The Best Treatments to go with?

Posts.Content: Many of the posters here experienced metastatic prostate cancer at diagnosis and their physicians immediately put them on ADT. This year's ASCO conference reported a clinical trial that showed combining chemo with ADT significantly improved overall survival. Those of you who has metastatic prostate cancer might want to discuss this with your oncologists. Here is the website: http://www.healio.com/hematology-onc...rostate-cancer Here is the comments from Dr. Hudis from MSK: This is an old-dog new-tricks question. This is now a generic drug that is available more broadly than ever before with reduced costs. In prostate cancer, I’m not aware of a historical study that ever offered this magnitude of improvement in survival. Quite frankly, across all of solid tumors, this is almost an unprecedented improvement in median survival. This is the kind of thing that can be transformative for people. The issue of toxicity is a big one, which leads us to the next chapter of our attempt to move to less toxic, even more effective therapies. Clifford A. Hudis, MD, FACP Chief, Breast Cancer Medicine Service Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center Immediate past ASCO president

He will though give it a try. But of course I am concerned on ED with few or no nerves spared. Wilde, If this is the situation, radiation might be a better fit for you since cure rate is about equal and ED outcome might be better. Good luck and best to you.

Posts.Title: Advice or comments on my treatment choice

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mom2two Can you please explain how the bone scan is done? We were told he'd get an injection then have to wait three hours before having the scan. Also given that the CT scan was negative, wouldn't that also show bone metastisi? thanks for all you help! Let me give it a try: CT scan can mostly detect abnormalities in soft tissues/organs and are not too sensitive in detecting bone metastasis. A bone scan uses a radioactive tracer that acts similar to calcium and will be taken up by bones where things are active, like cancer sites, injury sites, arthritis, etc. The tracer has very short radioactive life and will be excreted by the body afterwards. It takes about 3 hours after injecting the radio-tracer for them to be picked up at the cancer sites, so the 3 hour wait. A camera that can detect those radioactive tracer is use to detect active areas. Good luck to your husband.
Posts.Title: Dad had first appointment with surgeon

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tomseeley I'm totally new here. No clue at all what to expect or what to do. My PCP told me my PSA has risen suddenly, from 4-something to 7-something in 3 months. So he has referred me to the urology firm in town that he typically refers people to. I have no idea at all if they're competent or not. But today I checked their web page and found out the "doc" I'm going to see for my initial consultation later this week is not an M.D., he's a D.O. I've Googled that term also, but I still have no clue at all if I'm being sent to a real doctor I can trust or to some guy with webbed feet. All I know for sure is that 60 years ago, a D.O. almost killed my grandmother because he didn't know what the **** he was doing and what was wrong with her. When my dad found out (after he came down from hitting the roof) he pulled his mom out of the hospital where she was and got her an M.D., and in a very short time she was fine and back home. So my one data point with a D.O. is not a good one. Should I be concerned? If I am, and the urology firm does have other doctors who are in fact M.D., what should I do? One of the best, if not the best brachy radiation oncologists, Dr. Grimm is a DO. They received the same training and many attended the same residencies as MD, so I do not believe there are any differences between an MD and a DO. I would not hesitate to be treated by a US trained DO and if I choose brachy therapy, I would probably travel to Seattle to be treated by Dr. Grimm. As for your psa, a jump from 4 to 7 in three months probably is not cancer but infection. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Who should I trust?

Posts.Content: Infection at the surgical site should not affect your PSA reading. If I were you, I would wait a few more weeks and repeat the PSA test before deciding on any actions. As I said before, it is sometimes possible for the surgeon to left some benign prostate tissues around, if so, the PSA will not increase from the small reading going forward. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Recovery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by D&K Our Docs jumped into action upon receipt of the PSA: immediate bone scan & (MRI?) were scheduled, moved from Urology who did hormone shot; to Oncology. Next met with Oncology to get the scan results && off and running with chemo. It all went VERY fast! Because we were already in lymph nodes & bone we are 'automatically' stage 4. Now fighting!! D&K, Looks like his oncologist is on top of things. With that combination of chemo and hormone, he can expect to have his cancer under control for a long time. Sometimes, to make him feel that he is proactive, you may want to investigate changing his diet to be more anti-cancer friendly, like more fruits and veggies, a Mediterranean diet... Good luck and best wishes.

Posts.Content: I just post a new thread and saw yours so let me give you some encouragement. Relax, someone with a PSA of 3 rarely has advanced (metastasized) prostate cancer. Even if you have prostate cancer it is very treatable. Go ahead and have the biopsy, it is not a big deal and not painful. And a week's delay won't change things. I had four biopsies before they found cancer. Good luck and hope you won't join our club.

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA - nervous

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Jim215 newporter: I read the study (wow - that was a long one) and I'm not a science guy but it would seem that the findings leave a couple of questions unanswered. For example, does it mean that the Food Supplements Group benefit from a lessened spread of cancer or does the ingestion of certain juice and/or food products simply mask the spread of cancer by artificially reducing the PSA numbers. Jim Jim, You are good! That has always been a major point of debate for proponents and opponents of this class of supplements. Frankly no one knows and a lot of physicians are saying if it does no harm, do it if you feel you are doing something positive. The older UCLA and Johns Hopkins studies were only with pomegranate juice/extract and were for patients with BCR after prostatectomy. There they found lengthening of PSA doubling time perhaps indicating cancer growth slowing. Even there, there were controversies with the same questions. Unfortunately the studies did not last long enough to show improvements in cancer specific survival. I read last year they were starting a phase III to find out but I have no info on the results. So bottom line is we are on our own to decide. Best wishes.

Posts.Title: "Alarming" Chemo Discovery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by donelson Can you have RP then radiation? Should you? I assume I can do HDT with either or both... Yes but if the probability of radiation after RP is high, like your case, why not just go for radiation, which is equal in cure rate? In addition, a number of studies indicated adjuvant HDT helps radiation patients but not surgery patients. Walsh's book had a page discussing that aspect too. Also, with an aggressive cancer, do not delay any further, pick your treatment and go, ASAP. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Content: Why don't you check out this clinical trial results published in March 2014: http://www.nature.com/pcan/journal/v...can20146a.html All patients were on AS. After 6 months, Control Group had PSA increase of 78.5% and for the Food Supplements Group PSA only increased by 14.7%. The food supplements were pomegranate, green tea, broccoli and turmeric. It was a double blind and randomized trial. Cheers.

I will not comment on a 63-year-old male who ejaculates daily. But not for me to say. It sounds like you have a good "grip" on the subject. +1 However, if his urologist had also done a DRE and it was normal, he is asymptomatic with the size of the prostate consistent with the number, his position is not unreasonable. The risk of course is he could end up with an aggressive cancer and he may have given up the chance of early detection and a possible cure. Personally, I have not seen a single case of biopsy gone wrong among all my friends and relatives but have witnessed friends and relatives suffered pains and died from prostate cancer so my view is biased. Like everything in life, we all take risks so to each his own, especially since he is doing it with his eyes wide open. I do wish the best of luck to the poster and hope we can reject his application to join our club.

AgeInfo.Phrase: will not comment on a 63 year old male who ejaculates

Posts.Title: New study. Prevalence of Prostate Cancer on Autopsy in undiagnosed men 60+

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SamInToronto Six core biopsy in June was Gleason 3+4 in 3 of 6 samples. Second biopsy in September grade was 3+3 (and they also reviewed previous biopsy and downgraded it to 3+3). After reading everything everybody else here has read, I felt that brachy was the best option and I am scheduled for the procedure in mid-November. But I just got results of the second biopsy and I now think that AS might be a good option. So, like many others have done before me, I welcome your collective insight, guidance and suggestions. Thanks! I beg to disagree. The first biopsy's G3+4 is still in your prostate and is not going away. The second biopsy's G3+3 only means they sampled different areas of your prostate and not where the first G3+4 was located. If you want to do AS, I suggest you ask your urologist to send the first set of slides to a reputable pathologist like at Johns Hopkins or Bostwick Lab and get a second read. If it is downgraded to a G3+3, I would be more comfortable to go AS, otherwise, IMHO you still need treatment, after all you are young. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Gleason downgraded - AS now a good option?

Posts.Content: I just post a new thread and saw yours so let me give you some encouragement. Relax, someone with a PSA of 3 rarely has advanced (metastasized) prostate cancer. Even if you have prostate cancer it is very treatable. Go ahead and have the biopsy, it is not a big deal and not painful. And a week's delay won't change things. I had four biopsies before they found cancer. Good luck and hope you won't join our club.

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA - nervous

Posts.Content: STL, Looks like your PSA stabilizes at .1 and if that continues, you have a very long PSA doubling time (> 1 yr) and so a very slow BCR. It is too early to take medical action. The near term course of action could be just watching your PSA closely and maybe it will stay at .1 a lot longer. There is another possibility: Very slow rise in PSA post op could be due to benign prostate cells instead of cancer cells that were left behind. Good luck.
Posts.Title: PSA Velocity after RP - What is normal?

Posts.Content: No one reply so let me try. Seeds is an excellent way to go for a localized cancer. However, some radiation oncologists would not recommend it if your prostate is enlarged. Most modern studies comparing radiation treatment to surgery found the outcome to be similar. Since seeds placement in the prostate is critical to ensure all the cancers are radiated, the skill and experience of the radiation oncologist who places the seeds is the most important factor to consider. As for what if cancer comes back? It is true, surgery after seeds is difficult but not impossible. More likely you can still do salvage radiation after seeds failed, just like surgery. But, don't take my word for it since I am a layperson, please consult your physicians. Good luck.
Posts.Title: torn between two treatments

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago Well, I hope I can see the actual study instead of only the abstract. The abstract said " When adjusted for age and prostate weight, ASI men still had a greater probability of having GS 7 or greater PCa " But the world prostate cancer statistics you refer to only include diagnosed cases and/or death rates from PCa, potentially leaving out a large number of the men in this study who, but for death from other causes, might never be diagnosed or have died from prostate cancer. I don't know the details, but screening for PCa in Japan is far lower. Thus naturally you'll have much lower incidence of PCa being reported. It may be that Russian and Japanese rates of screening are roughly comparable. Rates of new diagnosed cases per 100,000 (back in 2002) were similar in both Russia and Japan. http://www.gapminder.org/world/#$majorMode=chart$is;shi=t;ly=2003;lb=f;il=t;fs=11 ;al=30;stl=t;st=t;nsl=t;se=t$wst;tts=C$ts;sp=6;ti= 2002$zpv;v=0$inc_x;mmid=XCOORDS;iid=phAwcNAVuyj1ji MAkmq1iMg;by=ind$inc_y;mmid=YCOORDS;iid=phAwcNAVuy j3qX39HWaQjEg;by=ind$inc_s;uniValue=8.21;iid=phAwc NAVuyj2vXUZJKI0XHA;by=ind$inc_c;uniValue=255;gid=C ATID0;by=grp$map_x;scale=log;dataMin=377;dataMax=7 5860$map_y;scale=lin;dataMin=-2.3805;dataMax=135$map_s;sma=49;smi=2.65$cd;bd=0$i nds=i110_t002002,,,,;i184_t002002,,,, And in this chart, you can also compare. http://cebp.aacrjournals.org/content...3/F3.large.jpg Interesting. Lots of factors involved. I'd like to see the entire study with the details. It may be that genetics or especially the lifestyle of Japanese men forestalls their PCa from advancing to the point of obvious symptoms (diagnosis) or death. Gleason 6's and 7's may not advance so rapidly in those who have lived and eaten differently for their entire life. Of question is whether Western men, changing their diets after age 50, or after diagnosis will make a significant change in progression. I've completely altered my diet for over 7 years now but have no great faith it will do much more than perhaps delay my genetics. Thus far, no positive biopsy, but PSA still poking along at 3.5 to 3.8 (with some worrying leaps up here and there). That is why I watch and wonder about these types of reports. How come Japanese men can have considerable rates of PCa ongoing, yet have a mortality rate half of ours. You made some excellent points, so I went to the UN WHO world prostate cancer statistics database to see the incidence and mortality rate for Russia and Japan: For the year 2008: Japan, incidence rate 22.7/100,000; mortality 5/100,000 Russia, incidence rate 26.1/100,000; mortality 10.8/100,000 So, incidence rate is about the same but death in Japan is only half of Russia. Since Japanese men live the longest, we cannot explain away that they died of something else. The article's biopsy results showing Japanese men had more aggressive prostate cancer but they didn't die from it is still a mystery to me.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lancepeace Yes, I saw this also on the Cancer News forum. The new nanotechnolgoy therapies and also the new antibody drug conjugate therapies target these chemo poisons preferentially in the cancer cells and might avoid corrupting the tissue micro-environment. Hopefully they are discovering solutions to these problems. Yes, a number of recent studies have positive results using nanoparticle as vector to deliver chemo more effectively and directly to cancer cells and avoid the "chemo damage" to good cells that Sequoiaranger was talking about. One such nano carrier is BIND-014 which is entering clinical trial. Sequoiaranger, you started Taxotere in April. Is everything OK? Perhaps you should ask your doctor about BIND-014 or something similar just in case Taxotere stops working for you? Just a thought and best of luck to you. Your courage and perseverance are great inspirations to me.

Posts.Title: I refused the biopsy. Urologist not happy and arrogant...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by rivtrail My Psa was 6 and rising (up from 3 a couple years ago, then 5+, then 6+ a few weeks later). Doc seemed optimistic after my biopsy and didn't mention any major concerns (I'm 56). Also, my CRP was high (2.9) on my most recent blood test. My concerns are these: 1) the freak show that is my semen (pure blood, after about five days). Been afraid to see it since then and am uncertain how to normalize. Should I be regularly ejaculating to empty things out or refrain? Everything else (urine, bowel) has checked out with no blood. 2) if no cancer was found, then what the heck else could be going on to make those numbers so bad? 3) what sort of special supplements, protocol should I be following? Thanks, in advance. rivtrail, Welcome to the twilight zone of prostate cancer. First of all, did your physician gave you a DRE? If so, did he detect anything abnormal? Second, blood in the semen is very common after a biopsy and will go away after a few weeks. It is harmless mostly unless you have consistent pain, etc. Third, if the biopsy is positive, you will be applying for membership here. However, if it is negative, it could mean you are cancer free, or that the biopsy missed the cancer this time. Remember, the needle biopsy only sampled a small fraction of your prostate. Prostate cances are usually multifocal and happen in multiple small spots instead of a big node. As for the third question, if you referred to what to take after the biopsy, most likely your physician prescribed an antibiotic that you should take. Other than that, take it easy for a few days and you should be fine. Good luck and seasons greetings to you and your family.

Posts.Title: negative biopsy

Posts.Content: Why don't you check out this clinical trial results published in March 2014: http://www.nature.com/pcan/journal/v...can20146a.html All patients were on AS. After 6 months, Control Group had PSA increase of 78.5% and for the Food Supplements Group PSA only increased by 14.7%. The food supplements were pomegranate, green tea, broccoli and turmeric. It was a double blind and randomized trial. Cheers.

Posts.Title: On the PSA, free PSA, (now PCA3) treadmill

Age.Phrase: by Jim215 Because at age 67  the clock is ticking  Otago

DoctorRecommended.Sample: So BCR is not a given. 2. Most surgeons recommend not start radiation right away when positive margins are < a few mm as they may not cause BCR. 3. I watched a number of Da Vinci prostatectomy videos and noticed differences in surgical techniques of different surgeons....What you need now is an expert prostate cancer oncologist to help guide your treatment plan. If you have not already done so, you should ask your urologist and radiation oncologist to recommend someone to you....If his PSA changed from 3 six months ago to 4.7 now, the doubling time is about a year, which is moderate, but needs to be dealt with (if the doubling time is 2 to 3 years perhaps doing nothing could be a strategy). Typically, in this situation oncologists will recommend hormone therapy and salvage radiation....That said, your clinical pathology indicated cancer is intermediate risk but quite extensive so perhaps radiation(IMRT and/or brachy)+hormone could be your best bet as suggested by JohnT. But, please consult with your doctor as we are not health care providers, just fellow sufferers like you....PSA half life in your body is between 2 to 3 days which means with an initial PSA of 10, within 30 days, it should be down to .01 or less. I suggest you consult an oncologist and a radiation oncologist to plan you next attack and hopefully the cancer is still local, in the prostate bed and can be eradicated....Finally, I think radiotherapy (and/or surgery) on the other hand can be curative for local, locally advanced or even some that spread to local adjacent organs. It is unusual for physicians not to prescribe radiation therapy if the patient requests it....With aggressive cases, one should prepare for the worst but hope for the best. Hopefully everything will work out for him but ask his urologist about his views on adjuvant vs salvage radiation and if he recommend going ahead with adjuvant, would he also recommend adding hormone therapy prior/during/after adjuvant radiation....If you have not already done so, you should ask your urologist and radiation oncologist to recommend someone to you. At this stage, whether it was T2a or T2c whether you had positive margin, PNI etc. do not matter but the G7 does....Testosterone is fuel for prostate cancer so it is not advisable to take T unless you are sure the cancer is completely eliminated. With surgery, if you have undetectable PSA for a few years, some doctors would prescribe T. For brachy, sometimes PSA does not reduce to undetectable due to benign cells remaining in there....You really need to clarify these with his urologist for it could make a lot of differences. Usually with distant metastases they don't advocate radiation treatment....But remember, these are just their guesses and yours may very well be organ confined. So as the others have advised find the best surgeon, radiation oncologist, oncologist and draw up a plan of attack and beat the hack out of the cancer....Even with metastatic cancer, there may be hope for a "cure" if the spread is limited to only a few spots (<5 for example). Some oncologists like Dr. Myers advocate spot treating the metastatic spots with radiation in addition to hormone therapy....With surgery, if you have undetectable PSA for a few years, some doctors would prescribe T. For brachy, sometimes PSA does not reduce to undetectable due to benign cells remaining in there. When that happens taking T is not smart....And, I think that was the reason many doctors recommended surgery for very young prostate cancer patients as they still have decades to live and cancer risk due to radiation goes up in time after treatment. So, it is correct that we should watch out for the possibility of secondary cancer, it is not a risk high enough that those needing treatment should stop getting treatment....This is exactly the topic the urologist and surgeon have concerns - cancer is not contained. Therefore, they suggested the seed therapy....Based on that study, the radiation oncologist recommended two years HT in addition to the radiation - I assume to increase the chances of the radiation being successful. This thread is hypothetical - should my slavage radiation fail and curitive options are exhausted, how early should chemo start?...Hi, not trying to play doctor, just curious and want to learn why his oncologist doesn't recommend radiation for the prostate area and spot radiation to kill off the metastasized cancers since my recollection was he only had a few spots? However I am very happy that everything is working out great for the two of you....I suggest you consult an oncologist and a radiation oncologist to plan you next attack and hopefully the cancer is still local, in the prostate bed and can be eradicated. No lymph node involvement is a good sign....But remember, the outcome for radiation was taken over a long time (years if not decades) and the technology in external radiation has improved so much that I am sure the risks are much smaller nowadays. And, I think that was the reason many doctors recommended surgery for very young prostate cancer patients as they still have decades to live and cancer risk due to radiation goes up in time after treatment....It is a very hard decision for him. A combined HT/RT/HT had a far superior outcome than no HT, so much so that all oncologist and radiation oncologist recommend this....If I were you, I probably would choose radiation + hormone as the treatment plan and shoot for a cure. Your enlarged prostate maybe too large for seed therapy, and in that case the radiation oncologist could prescribe hormone therapy to shrink the prostate to make seeds more effective....Let me add mine and I like to start from the beginning: First I have a bunch of questions you may want to answer: When your cancer was diagnosed, with a PSA of 95 and G9, how did you ended up with a radiation treatment? Did your urologist recommended it and did you consult an oncologist?...However, I believe some doctors do prescribe Viagra prior, during and post radiation treatment. Jose, some others maybe able to help you if you do what Highlander suggested, post your statistics and history so others can give you some advice....So as the others have advised find the best surgeon, radiation oncologist, oncologist and draw up a plan of attack and beat the hack out of the cancer. Good luck....Typically, in this situation oncologists will recommend hormone therapy and salvage radiation. In many cases that should cure the cancer....Hopefully everything will work out for him but ask his urologist about his views on adjuvant vs salvage radiation and if he recommend going ahead with adjuvant, would he also recommend adding hormone therapy prior/during/after adjuvant radiation. There were studies that indicated for very high risk cases, adjuvant radiation plus hormone offers better odds of getting rid of the cancer....My current situation is salvage radiation, with high risk of recurrence. Based on that study, the radiation oncologist recommended two years HT in addition to the radiation - I assume to increase the chances of the radiation being successful....Chuck Chuck, I had never heard of urologist prescribed Viagra prior to surgery. However, I believe some doctors do prescribe Viagra prior, during and post radiation treatment....Some oncologists like Dr. Myers advocate spot treating the metastatic spots with radiation in addition to hormone therapy. They reported some complete remissions from that treatment protocol....2. Most surgeons recommend not start radiation right away when positive margins are < a few mm as they may not cause BCR. 3. I watched a number of Da Vinci prostatectomy videos and noticed differences in surgical techniques of different surgeons. Most surgeons used a combination of Thermal Dissection and Athermal Dissection....Your enlarged prostate maybe too large for seed therapy, and in that case the radiation oncologist could prescribe hormone therapy to shrink the prostate to make seeds more effective. He should also add IMRT to ensure he gets all of your cancer....Sail on! Hi, not trying to play doctor, just curious and want to learn why his oncologist doesn't recommend radiation for the prostate area and spot radiation to kill off the metastasized cancers since my recollection was he only had a few spots?...However, some radiation oncologists would not recommend it if your prostate is enlarged. Most modern studies comparing radiation treatment to surgery found the outcome to be similar....It is unusual for physicians not to prescribe radiation therapy if the patient requests it. Usually it is because of age, physical limitations, health issues or they think radiotherapy would not help....Seeds is an excellent way to go for a localized cancer. However, some radiation oncologists would not recommend it if your prostate is enlarged....A combined HT/RT/HT had a far superior outcome than no HT, so much so that all oncologist and radiation oncologist recommend this.
